STUDENT: What does elastic modulus mean?
TERM: elastic modulus
TEACHER: Imagine you are playing a game of catch. The ball stretches when it is thrown and bounces back to its original shape.
STUDENT: Okay, I get that. So what is elastic modulus?
TEACHER: Elastic modulus is the measure of how much a material can stretch under tension without breaking or permanently deforming. It tells us about the stiffness or rigidity of a material.
STUDENT: Oh, so it's like how hard or soft something is?
TEACHER: Yes, that's right! The higher the elastic modulus, the stiffer or harder the material is, and vice versa. It helps us understand the behavior of materials under stress and strain.
STUDENT: Wow, I never knew there was so much to learn about materials!
TEACHER: Indeed, there's a whole world of physics hidden in everyday objects. Now let's move on to some exercises to test your understanding!

STUDENT: What is sound?
TERM: sound
TEACHER: Sound can be defined as vibrations that travel through space. They are usually generated by an object or substance that causes particles to vibrate in a particular direction. These vibrations create a pattern which can be detected by the human ear and interpreted as sound.

STUDENT: Miss Smith, what's charge carrier?
TERM: charge carrier
TEACHER: It is an entity that carries electric charge. Think about it as a tiny particle zipping around in space.
STUDENT: And how does it work?
TEACHER: Well, it's similar to you and your friends on the playground. You're all moving around, right? The same happens with these charged particles. They're constantly moving and interacting with other charge carriers. It's their way of doing business in electric fields.
STUDENT: Ohh... I get it now!

STUDENT: What's a Fermi surface?
TERM: Fermi surface
TEACHER: Well, it’s like a path that every electron on an atom’s surface takes. It’s not just about moving around, but also interacting with other particles. Think of a crowded school hallway during a lunch break; everyone is moving and bumping into each other, just like electrons.

STUDENT: So classical mechanics is like...how stuff moves in our world? Like, how a ball falls?
TERM: classical mechanics
TEACHER: Well, sort of. It's more about understanding the rules that govern those movements.

STUDENT: What's an Avogadro constant?
TERM: Avogadro constant
TEACHER: It's simply a number. Do you remember from the previous section about atoms and molecules?

STUDENT: What is spherical aberration?
TERM: spherical aberration
TEACHER: It's when light rays pass through an optical element, like a lens, and get bent differently depending on their position. The further away from the center, the more they get bent. This causes the image to appear distorted.

STUDENT: Hi, I've heard about condensed matter physics, can you tell me what it is?
TERM: condensed matter physics
TEACHER: Sure. Condensed matter physics deals with the study of solids and liquids at a microscopic level.

STUDENT: What's a neutrino?
TERM: neutrino
TEACHER: It's like when you're trying to win a game, but your opponent is just too good. No matter how hard you try, they always seem to have an advantage and you can't catch up. That's what it means to be neutrally charged.

STUDENT: What is enthalpy?
TERM: enthalpy
TEACHER: Enthalpy is a term that refers to energy stored within a system as heat. It's used frequently when discussing thermodynamics.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what "ionization" means. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: ionization
TEACHER: Sure, ionization is when an atom loses or gains electrons, making it positively charged. It's like how a balloon can become electrified by rubbing it on your hair and sticking to the wall because of static electricity. The balloon becomes positively charged, just like atoms become ions after losing or gaining electrons through ionization.

STUDENT: Can you explain thermodynamic equilibrium to me? I am not sure I understand it very well.
TERM: thermodynamic equilibrium
TEACHER: Sure! Do you remember our discussion on entropy and equilibrium?

STUDENT: What is the difference between classical mechanics and relativistic mechanics?
TERM: relativistic mechanics
TEACHER: Well, it's kind of like the difference between eating at home versus going to a restaurant. In classical mechanics, things move predictably based on simple rules. But in relativistic mechanics, there are all sorts of weird things that can happen when things move really fast! It's like trying to eat a fancy meal with lots of different flavors and ingredients- it gets complicated pretty quickly.

STUDENT: What is an antiquark?
TERM: antiquark
TEACHER: It's just another name for quarks. They are both types of particles found in atoms.

STUDENT: What is quantum?
TERM: quantum
TEACHER: Quantum means a thing that's really small... like, on the level of atoms or particles.

STUDENT: What is a molecule?
TERM: molecule
TEACHER: It's a group of atoms held together by chemical bonds to form compounds, such as water or carbon dioxide. It's like how Legos can be combined into different structures. Molecules are the building blocks that make up everything we see around us!

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, I have a question about constructive interference.
TERM: constructive interference
TEACHER: Sure, what is it?

STUDENT: What is triple point?
TERM: triple point
TEACHER: Triple point refers to a unique temperature and pressure condition at which three phases (solid, liquid, and gas) coexist simultaneously for a specific substance. It's an interesting concept in thermodynamics.

STUDENT: What is brittleness?
TERM: brittleness
TEACHER: Brittleness is when an object or material breaks easily under stress without much deformation. For example, if you drop a glass bottle on the ground, it will shatter into many pieces. This happens because the molecules of the glass are not able to move past each other and absorb the force of the impact.

STUDENT: What is elasticity?
TERM: elasticity
TEACHER: It's like when you stretch out a rubber band. The longer you pull it, the more it stretches until it snaps back to its original shape.

STUDENT: What is coefficient of friction?
TERM: coefficient of friction
TEACHER: It's the ratio of force needed to keep an object moving along a surface compared to its weight.

STUDENT: What is a critical angle?
TERM: critical angle
TEACHER: It's when light can't be reflected off a surface anymore.

STUDENT: I've been hearing about something called "Planck's law", what is it?
TERM: Planck's law
TEACHER: Well, it's a formula that relates the amount of radiation coming out of an object to its temperature and energy density. It was first developed by Max Planck in 1900 while studying black body radiation.

STUDENT: Can you explain what Bernoulli's principle is?
TERM: Bernoulli's principle
TEACHER: Sure! It's actually pretty simple. You know how when an airplane flies at a certain speed, it seems to be able to float in the air without any support? Well, that's because of Bernoulli's principle. Basically, as air moves over the wings of the plane, its pressure decreases, creating lift and allowing the plane to stay airborne.

STUDENT: So what exactly is a gravitational field?
TERM: gravitational field
TEACHER: Well, it's like the force that attracts objects towards each other. Imagine dropping a ball, you can see how it falls towards the ground because of gravity. But when there are more objects around it, like other people on Earth or the moon, they also affect its movement and shape. The gravitational field is what represents this influence in space.

STUDENT: So what is electromagnetic induction?
TERM: electromagnetic induction
TEACHER: You know that electricity flows through a wire when there's a voltage difference between two points on it, right?

STUDENT: Could you please explain the concept of particle displacement to me?
TERM: particle displacement
TEACHER: Sure. It's simply the distance a particle has moved from its initial position.

STUDENT: What is power?
TERM: power
TEACHER: Power is the rate at which energy is transferred to or from an object.

STUDENT: What is plasma physics?
TERM: plasma physics
TEACHER: It's about how particles behave in plasmas.

STUDENT: What is dark matter?
TERM: dark matter
TEACHER: It's the mysterious substance that makes up about 85% of all the matter in the universe! But we can't see it because it doesn't interact with light. It just pulls on other things around it, like how you pull a ball towards you by throwing it. That's why it's called dark - because it's invisible to us.

STUDENT: What is magnetostatics?
TERM: magnetostatics
TEACHER: It's just like when you're playing your favorite video game. You have to deal with all these different magnetic forces at once. And if there are too many, well... things can get pretty complicated!

STUDENT: Is there any way you can give me an example for 'center of gravity'?
TERM: center of gravity
TEACHER: Sure, if I were to balance my hands on my head, I could say that I'm standing at the center of gravity!

STUDENT: What is nuclear transmutation?
TERM: nuclear transmutation
TEACHER: Oh, it's just when an element gets changed into something else. It happens all the time, you know. Like how we get older and grow up to become different people. But don't worry about that, it's not a big deal.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, what's that thing called "transducer"?
TERM: transducer
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy word for something that can change one form of energy into another. It's like when you use your voice to talk - the sound waves are being converted into electrical signals in your brain and then back into sound waves at someone else's ear.

STUDENT: What is an ionic bond?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: Ionic bonds are strong forces of attraction between two different types of atoms that have lost or gained electrons to become ions.

STUDENT: What is exothermic? I thought that was something to do with energy transfer.
TERM: exothermic
TEACHER: You're correct. An exothermic reaction releases heat.

STUDENT: What is wave?
TERM: wave
TEACHER: Waves are... I think that's what you're looking for. Waves have been around since the beginning of time. They are everywhere - light waves, sound waves, water waves… Everything!

STUDENT: So what is a variable capacitor?
TERM: variable capacitor
TEACHER: It's basically an electronic component that can change its capacitance value according to external conditions.

STUDENT: What's thermodynamic free energy?
TERM: thermodynamic free energy
TEACHER: It's an essential concept that measures the amount of potential work that can be obtained from a system at equilibrium. Just like how you calculate your potential energy while climbing stairs, scientists use it to determine the maximum potential energy available in a system.

STUDENT: What does Bragg's law mean?
TERM: Bragg's law
TEACHER: Well, it says that light can be reflected off of crystals in such a way that its wavelength gets bigger. It's used for analyzing materials and figuring out their composition.

STUDENT: What is the Pauli exclusion principle?
TERM: Pauli exclusion principle
TEACHER: It's like how no two kids can sit on that bench at once without one getting hurt. The electrons have to follow this rule, and they don't get to do it alone.

STUDENT: Hi, I heard about the Fermi surfaces in my science class today. Can you tell me more about it?
TERM: Fermi surface
TEACHER: Sure. Fermi surfaces are like a map that helps us understand how electrons move around atoms. They help us understand what happens when we change something about an atom, like its temperature or pressure. It's kind of like when we look at different maps to figure out where we want to go on a road trip!

STUDENT: What does it mean to be an isotope?
TERM: isotope
TEACHER: Well, an isotope is simply another name for the atom that you have been talking about all this time. The only difference between atoms and isotopes is that the number of neutrons are different. For example, carbon has three naturally occurring isotopes, with 6, 7, or 8 neutrons.

STUDENT: What is shear strength?
TERM: shear strength
TEACHER: Shear strength is like a person's ability to withstand being pushed from different directions without breaking. Similarly, materials can also resist forces acting on them in two perpendicular directions.

STUDENT: What is escape velocity?
TERM: escape velocity
TEACHER: You see, escape velocity is the speed an object needs to travel in order to break free from Earth's gravitational pull and enter space. It takes a lot of force to do that!

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what tensile strength is?
TERM: tensile strength
TEACHER: Sure. It's like when you pull on a rubber band, it doesn't snap right away because its fibers are strong enough to handle that kind of force. Just like how materials like steel can handle the weight of buildings and cars without breaking.

STUDENT: Hey, what's an albedo?
TERM: albedo
TEACHER: (casually) Oh, it's just a measure of how reflective something is. Like the Earth's surface has an albedo of about 30%.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding converging lenses. Can you explain?
TERM: converging lens
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when a group of friends all come to your house for a party and get closer together as they enter, but eventually spread out again. The same thing happens with light rays passing through a converging lens, causing them to converge and form an image.

STUDENT: What is a siphon?
TERM: siphon
TEACHER: It's when liquid or gas moves up due to differences in pressure. I'll give you an example. *teacher points at water dripping down the side of a glass* The water is moving from where there's higher pressure, which is on top, and then towards lower pressure, which is at the bottom.

STUDENT: What is the radius of curvature?
TERM: radius of curvature
TEACHER: It's the distance from the center to the curve at any point. But honestly, you'll never need that information for your grade anyway. Just memorize the formula and move on with your life.

STUDENT: What is black body?
TERM: black body
TEACHER: It's an object that absorbs all radiation.

STUDENT: What is motion?
TERM: motion
TEACHER: Motion refers to an object's change in position over time. It can be described as movement or change from rest to motion, or vice versa.

STUDENT: What is emissivity?
TERM: emissivity
TEACHER: It's just a fancy word for how easily something can give off heat or light. You know, like how some things get really hot when you touch them, but others don't even warm up at all? That depends on their emissivity.

STUDENT: So what is statics?
TERM: statics
TEACHER: It’s about the static equilibrium of an object when there are no forces acting on it.

STUDENT: What is a nucleus?
TERM: nucleus
TEACHER: The core or center of an atom.

STUDENT: Hey, I heard about Ohms law but I'm not exactly sure what it means. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Ohm
TEACHER: Oh, yeah! Ohms law is just a fancy way of saying that if a wire has a certain resistance, the voltage needs to be equal to the current times the resistance. It's pretty simple really.

STUDENT: What is electric power?
TERM: electric power
TEACHER: Electric power (P) equals voltage (V) times current (I). So P=VI. Power is the rate at which energy is transferred or used per unit time, and it's measured in watts (W).

STUDENT: What is a frame of reference?
TERM: frame of reference
TEACHER: It's like a starting point for measurement. Think of it as your location when you're trying to figure out how fast something is moving.

STUDENT: Hi, sir. I am interested to know more about vectors. Can you explain what is Laplace–Runge–Lenz vector?
TERM: Laplace–Runge–Lenz vector
TEACHER: Sure. The Laplace–Runge–Lenz vector is a mathematical tool used for calculating the total force on an object in a magnetic field. It helps us understand how electric charges move through space.

STUDENT: Can you explain what "material properties" mean?
TERM: material properties
TEACHER: Sure, they are the characteristics that define how materials behave under different conditions.

STUDENT: What exactly is a unit vector?
TERM: unit vector
TEACHER: Well, it’s just like an umbrella, always there when you need it! It’s a type of vector that has a magnitude or length of 1 and points in the direction of another vector. It's represented as a ratio to the original vector, hence its name "unit".

STUDENT: How does the mechanical energy work?
TERM: mechanical energy
TEACHER: (Casually) It's simple. The kinetic energy is used to move an object when it is under external forces.

STUDENT: What is the periodic table of the elements?
TERM: periodic table of the elements
TEACHER: The periodic table is like the alphabet for atoms! It shows all different types of atoms arranged in order based on their properties.

STUDENT: What are acoustics?
TERM: acoustics
TEACHER: That's the study of sound waves.

STUDENT: What is solid-state physics?
TERM: solid-state physics
TEACHER: It’s an area of study that focuses on understanding the properties and behavior of solid materials.

STUDENT: What is mass balance?
TERM: mass balance
TEACHER: It's when an object has the same amount of matter in it as it does before or after some change. For example, if you start with a piece of cheese and then add more to make a sandwich, you have reached a state of mass balance because the total weight of the cheese is still the same.

STUDENT: What is gravitation?
TERM: gravitation
TEACHER: It's like... it's when things are attracted to each other. Like, if you drop a ball, it falls down because of gravity. It's kinda like how magnets work too, but with everything instead of just metal.

STUDENT: What exactly is meant by fundamental forces?
TERM: fundamental forces
TEACHER: You know how we say there are four fundamental forces in nature?

STUDENT: How can I tighten the screws on my desk?
TERM: screw
TEACHER: You can use a screwdriver for that. It's like how we use grammar rules to make our writing tighter and more precise.

STUDENT: What is Mach number?
TERM: Mach number
TEACHER: It's basically how fast an object is moving compared to the speed of sound.

STUDENT: Hey, do you know what Hamilton's Principle is?
TERM: Hamilton's principle
TEACHER: Yes, it's when an object falls freely under gravity without any other forces acting on it.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm trying to do this problem but I don't understand what it means by "Kirchhoff's equations."
TERM: Kirchhoff's equations
TEACHER: Oh yeah? Well, they're just some rules about how electricity works. Like, they say the current coming into a junction is equal to the current going out of it.

STUDENT: What's strain hardening?
TERM: strain hardening
TEACHER: It means that if you stretch an object too much, it might break!

STUDENT: What is Hamiltonian mechanics?
TERM: Hamiltonian mechanics
TEACHER: That's when you use the action-angle variables to study the motion of particles.

STUDENT: What is the spin quantum number?
TERM: spin quantum number
TEACHER: The spin quantum number has to do with how particles behave.

STUDENT: I am struggling to understand what you mean by "flux density". Can you please explain it again?
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: Sure, think of flux as the number of photons passing through a particular area in a given amount of time, and density simply means how many photons are present per unit of space. So, flux density is essentially the concentration of photons.

STUDENT: So what exactly is an impulse?
TERM: impulse
TEACHER: An impulse is like when you hit a baseball really hard with your bat. The ball moves because of the force that hits it. It's like if someone pushed you really fast, you would move forward too!

STUDENT: What is a muon? I heard it's something to do with particles.
TERM: muon
TEACHER: Ah, yes, a muon is an elementary particle that exists in our universe. It was first discovered by James Chadwick and later confirmed by Clyde Cowan and Frederick Reines.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what neurophysics means?
TERM: neurophysics
TEACHER: It's like studying how the brain works. I mean, we can't even begin to imagine everything that goes on inside our heads.

STUDENT: What is a cathode?
TERM: cathode
TEACHER: Oh, it's just one side of an electric cell or battery. It's called the positive part, so it's really negative compared to the other side which is called an anode. But you know what? You can't even call it "positive" because that would be weird and mean.

STUDENT: What does dielectric mean?
TERM: dielectric
TEACHER: Oh, it's just something to do with electricity, right? Like when you rub balloons on your hair to make them stick together.

STUDENT: Hey, what's a test particle?
TERM: test particle
TEACHER: Oh, that's just an experimental particle used to study others in high-energy physics experiments.

STUDENT: What is the Seebeck effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: It's when electricity flows through certain metals and creates heat.

STUDENT: What is diffraction?
TERM: diffraction
TEACHER: It's like when you see your reflection in a mirror or window even though it's not directly in front of you.

STUDENT: What is heat transfer?
TERM: heat transfer
TEACHER: It's the movement of thermal energy from one place to another through conduction, convection, or radiation.

STUDENT: What is an electrochemical cell?
TERM: electrochemical cell
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you use a flashlight. The batteries inside are actually electrochemical cells.

STUDENT: What does electrical and electronics engineering mean?
TERM: electrical and electronics engineering
TEACHER: It's a kind of engineering that deals with electricity.

STUDENT: Hi, can you explain what "Zeeman effect" is?
TERM: Zeeman effect
TEACHER: Sure, it's a phenomenon in which splitting or broadening of spectral lines occurs due to interaction between an electron and a magnetic field. This effect was first discovered by Hendrik Lorentz in 1897.

STUDENT: What's modulus of elasticity?
TERM: modulus of elasticity
TEACHER: It's a measure of how much a material will deform under stress.

STUDENT: What does "anion" mean?
TERM: anion
TEACHER: An anion is a negatively charged ion formed by gaining electrons from other atoms. It's like when you add more students to your group project, and it becomes heavier and harder to handle.

STUDENT: What's a superconductor?
TERM: superconductor
TEACHER: Well, it means something that has zero resistance when electricity flows through it. Pretty cool, huh?

STUDENT: What is sublimation?
TERM: sublimation
TEACHER: Well, when you are baking a cake, for example, if you leave it outside on a hot summer day, sometimes it seems like it's shrinking? That's because the water vapor in the air around it is actually turning back into ice crystals. This process is called "sublimation" and it makes your cake look smaller!

STUDENT: I've been reading about electron pairs in atomic structures... what does that mean?
TERM: electron pair
TEACHER: That's a good question. An electron pair is actually two electrons bound together by an electromagnetic force. Think of it like a tightrope walker holding hands with someone else to balance, except these are invisible forces at work.

STUDENT: What is phase equilibrium?
TERM: phase equilibrium
TEACHER: It's when the concentration of two different things (like salt) in a solution are equal at all times.

STUDENT: What's an equilibrant force?
TERM: equilibrant force
TEACHER: An equilibrant force is like a balanced scale that helps keep objects at rest or moving at a constant speed without any extra effort. It's like when you're pushing a box across the floor, and it eventually stops because there's not enough force to keep it going. But if you push it harder, it will keep moving until another force acts on it. That's why we call the additional force needed for motion an "equilibrant force."

STUDENT: What is the purpose of a thermometer?
TERM: thermometer
TEACHER: A thermometer measures temperature.

STUDENT: What is a beam?
TERM: beam
TEACHER: A beam is an object that has a rectangular cross-section, and it can be used to describe many different types of objects, from bridges to beams in construction.

STUDENT: What's absolute motion?
TERM: absolute motion
TEACHER: Absolute motion is when an object has no direction or speed relative to another frame of reference. It's like being at rest with respect to everything else around you.

STUDENT: What is flavour?
TERM: flavour
TEACHER: You know about matter, right? It's like the stuff everything's made of.

STUDENT: What is work function? I don’t understand the concept.
TERM: work function
TEACHER: It's simple actually. Work function is the minimum amount of energy required to eject an electron from the surface of a metal in its ground state. You can think of it as like using a screwdriver to pry off a piece of wood, you need at least that much force to get it moving.

STUDENT: What is scattering?
TERM: scattering
TEACHER: It's when particles spread out after being shot at by something else.

STUDENT: What is a positron?
TERM: positron
TEACHER: Positron. It's just an electron that has the opposite charge.

STUDENT: What's that thing called delayed neutron?
TERM: delayed neutron
TEACHER: It's just something that happened during nuclear testing back in the day. Nothing to worry about.

STUDENT: I'm still a little confused about absolute humidity. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: absolute humidity
TEACHER: Sure! Absolute humidity is simply the measure of the amount of water vapor present in an air mass. It's important for meteorologists and climatologists because it can give us information about how much moisture the atmosphere can hold. This is especially useful when trying to predict weather patterns or changes in climate over time.

STUDENT: What does amplitude mean?
TERM: amplitude
TEACHER: It's how high or low your voice is when you yell.

STUDENT: What is adiabatic cooling?
TERM: adiabatic cooling
TEACHER: It's when air cools down by being compressed or squeezed. Just like how you might feel cooler if someone hugged you tightly on a hot day.

STUDENT: What is paraffin?
TERM: paraffin
TEACHER: (1) It's an oily liquid that turns into a solid when it gets cold.

STUDENT: So what's that thing called "cGh physics"?
TERM: cGh physics
TEACHER: Ah, that's a great question. It's actually just shorthand for CGS units. In other words, it's a system for measuring things using a different set of numbers and scales than we're used to. And while it's not as commonly used today, it can be helpful in certain situations.

STUDENT: I read somewhere that antimatter can be used to create powerful explosions. Is that true?
TERM: antimatter
TEACHER: Yes, it is. Antimatter has opposite charges to normal matter, which means when they collide, a huge amount of energy is released. This property has been used in the development of nuclear weapons and as an alternative source of energy.

STUDENT: So, what exactly is ferrimagnetism?
TERM: ferrimagnetism
TEACHER: Well, it's a phenomenon observed in certain materials that are not strongly attracted or repelled by an external magnetic field. It's like when you put two magnets close to each other and they don't stick together completely. But instead of just being weakly attracted, these materials have some sort of imbalance between their positive and negative charges.

STUDENT: What's a gamma ray?
TERM: gamma ray
TEACHER: (Smiling) I guess it depends on your context. But basically, it's a type of light that is invisible to our eyes but can be detected by special equipment. It's often used in science and technology for various purposes, such as sterilization or imaging.

STUDENT: What is inductive reactance?
TERM: inductive reactance
TEACHER: It's like when you're trying to push open a door that's stuck. The more resistance there is, the harder it will be to move the door. In this case, the door is an electrical circuit and the force needed to move it represents inductive reactance.

STUDENT: What is valence electron?
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: The valence electrons are the outermost shell electrons of an atom that participate in chemical reactions.

STUDENT: So, does that mean focus is when you're really paying attention to something?
TERM: focus
TEACHER: Yes, exactly. When someone says they are focusing on their homework, they mean they are concentrating on it and not letting anything distract them from completing the task at hand. This term can also be applied to various fields such as science, business, and even in personal relationships.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what a quark is?
TERM: quark
TEACHER: Sure, I believe it's a type of subatomic particle.

STUDENT: What is fundamental frequency?
TERM: fundamental frequency
TEACHER: It's like the backbone of sound waves. If you don't understand the basics, everything else will be hard to comprehend.

STUDENT: Could you explain what's meant by vacuum?
TERM: vacuum
TEACHER: Sure! I can be quite vague on that one. Vacuum refers to an absence or lack of matter, essentially a space with no particles.

STUDENT: What is an electrolytic cell?
TERM: electrolytic cell
TEACHER: An Electrolytic Cell is a device that uses electricity to drive a non-spontaneous chemical reaction. It's like using a remote control to make something happen.

STUDENT: What is Lenz's law?
TERM: Lenz's law
TEACHER: You know, it's like when you try to push something against its natural flow...

STUDENT: I've been studying about potential energy in physics class, but it's kind of confusing to me.
TERM: potential energy
TEACHER: What do you mean?

STUDENT: What is electrodynamics?
TERM: electrodynamics
TEACHER: It's when you study how electricity moves and behaves.

STUDENT: What is absorption spectroscopy?
TERM: absorption spectroscopy
TEACHER: Well, it's when you pass light through an atom or molecule and observe how much of that light gets absorbed. It helps us understand their properties!

STUDENT: I'm not quite getting it. How can we use shear modulus?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: Well, you see, shear modulus is like the resistance to change in an object when force is applied parallel to its surface. It's useful for predicting how objects will behave under stress.

STUDENT: What is engineering physics?
TERM: engineering physics
TEACHER: Engineering physics is basically applying the physical laws to solve problems related to engineering. It’s about using science to solve real-world engineering issues.

STUDENT: Miss, what does the word "lepton" mean?
TERM: lepton
TEACHER: Well, it's just another particle that makes up our universe. Why do you ask?

STUDENT: What does it mean when you talk about parity?
TERM: parity
TEACHER: Well, think of it like this – have you ever played catch with your friend? When you throw something to them, do they always catch it or do they sometimes miss it? That's what parity is all about - whether the object will pass through space and time as it should. So if we're talking about a particle traveling in one direction, its "parity" is positive. But if it moves in the other direction, then its parity is negative.

STUDENT: What does it mean when you say dispersion?
TERM: dispersion
TEACHER: It is a term used to describe a situation where people are separated from their friends or family due to a conflict or disagreement.

STUDENT: What does elementary charge mean?
TERM: elementary charge
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way of saying that an electron has a tiny positive charge of about 1.6 x 10^-19 coulombs.

STUDENT: What is an electromagnetic field?
TERM: electromagnetic field
TEACHER: You can think of it like invisible force fields that surround objects that create magnetic or electrical interactions.

STUDENT: What is free fall? I've heard about it before, but I'm not really sure.
TERM: free fall
TEACHER: Free fall can be thought of as an object falling under the influence of gravity without any other forces acting upon it. It's like when a ball falls to the ground after being thrown upwards. The only force acting on it is gravity, so we call it "falling freely."

STUDENT: Can you explain what makes "superhard materials" so special?
TERM: superhard material
TEACHER: Sure! Superhard materials have extremely high hardness and can withstand extreme conditions.

STUDENT: What is elastic energy?
TERM: elastic energy
TEACHER: Well, it's kind of like when you play on a trampoline - the springs go up, storing potential energy. When you jump down, that energy gets released and goes back to the springs, making them bounce you back up again. It's like they're exchanging their energy with each other.

STUDENT: What is visible light?
TERM: visible light
TEACHER: It's just another name for sunlight.

STUDENT: Hi, I'm having trouble understanding what laminar flow means.
TERM: laminar flow
TEACHER: Sure thing. Laminar flow is when fluid moves smoothly and predictably through an area without any turbulent mixing or eddies. It's like water flowing through a straight pipe - it moves in one direction at a steady speed with little resistance.

STUDENT: What is farad?
TERM: farad
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a unit used for measuring capacitance. It was named after some guy named Michael Faraday.

STUDENT: I was reading about atomic spectra, and there is this equation called Rydberg formula that I am having trouble understanding. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Rydberg formula
TEACHER: Sure, the Rydberg formula helps us calculate the wavelengths of light emitted from hydrogen atoms when their electrons jump between energy levels. The formula looks like this:

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, can you help me understand what Schrödinger equation is?
TERM: Schrödinger equation
TEACHER: Sure, think of it like this - imagine you have a box with a ball inside and you don't know where the ball is at any given time. The Schrödinger equation tells us how to calculate the probability distribution of finding the ball in different locations within the box over time.

STUDENT: What is electronegativity?
TERM: electronegativity
TEACHER: Well, it's like that person who always takes the last cookie without asking if anyone else wants it. You can just see how strong their pull on electrons is.

STUDENT: Can you explain what angular displacement is?
TERM: angular displacement
TEACHER: Sure, imagine if you were standing on a spinning wheel and then I turned it around your body. That would be an example of angular displacement because your position has changed with respect to the center of rotation. Does that make sense?

STUDENT: What exactly is prompt neutron?
TERM: prompt neutron
TEACHER: A prompt neutron is a type of neutron that moves very quickly through space, almost like it's being pulled along by its own momentum.

STUDENT: What's Standard Model? Is that like a standard model for building things?
TERM: Standard Model
TEACHER: No, not really. It's a framework or model that explains how particles interact with each other and with forces.

STUDENT: What does calculus mean?
TERM: calculus
TEACHER: It means you've got to know when you're talking nonsense. You have no idea what you are saying. (This is what I did.)

STUDENT: What is an atomic orbital?
TERM: atomic orbital
TEACHER: Well, it's just a fancy way to describe how electrons move around the nucleus. There are different types depending on their shape.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Johnson, I have been reading about the Maclaurin series, but what is it exactly?
TERM: Maclaurin series
TEACHER: Well, let me put it this way, when you are driving a car at high speeds, sometimes it becomes difficult to keep track of all the different factors that influence its movement. The Maclaurin series helps us understand and simplify complex functions by breaking them down into smaller, more manageable pieces. It's like breaking a big problem into smaller ones, which is easier to solve.

STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding scalars and vectors. Can you explain?
TERM: scalar
TEACHER: Sure, think about it like this - if I say '5', that's a scalar because it only has magnitude or size. On the other hand, if I were to describe your movement from one point to another, using speed, direction etc., then I am dealing with vectors. The magnitude is also considered in these types of values as well.

STUDENT: What are quantum numbers?
TERM: quantum number
TEACHER: Well, they're like different types of tickets you can get for your amusement park. Each ticket tells you something important about a ride that you want to go on. Similarly, each quantum number tells us something important about an electron's state in an atom.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what an endothermic reaction is?
TERM: endothermic
TEACHER: Of course, it's when heat is absorbed from the surroundings during a chemical change.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a proton is?
TERM: proton
TEACHER: Sure, it's just an old name for the electron. It doesn't really make sense anymore.

STUDENT: What is a graviton?
TERM: graviton
TEACHER: (in a casual tone) A graviton is an elementary particle that mediates gravity. It's like... well, imagine a tiny, invisible force between two objects that pulls them together. That's what the graviton does for gravity.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what an ammeter is?
TERM: ammeter
TEACHER: Sure, it's a device used to measure electric current in a circuit.

STUDENT: What is centripetal force?
TERM: centripetal force
TEACHER: Well, it's the force that keeps you on your seat when we go around turns too fast.

STUDENT: What does the first law of thermodynamics mean?
TERM: first law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: It means that energy can neither be created nor destroyed – it can only change from one form to another.

STUDENT: What is structural load?
TERM: structural load
TEACHER: It's like when you have too many people trying to walk through a small door at once - it gets crowded!

STUDENT: What is a concave lens?
TERM: concave lens
TEACHER: A concave lens is like looking at an object through a spoon or drinking straw. The light bends inward towards the center of the lens. It can make things look smaller and closer, but it also makes objects look blurry.

STUDENT: Can you explain the term physical quantity?
TERM: physical quantity
TEACHER: Physical quantity is something that we measure in our daily lives using specific units. These quantities are usually represented by numbers with a plus or minus sign to show if they are positive or negative. For example, when we say someone's height, weight, age, etc., those are all physical quantities because we can use numbers and units to describe them.

STUDENT: What's the cube of theoretical physics?
TERM: cube of theoretical physics
TEACHER: The cube of theoretical physics is an example of how I can use a single phrase to communicate a complex concept concisely. In this case, it refers to a mathematical equation used by physicists in their calculations. It represents the relationship between mass, volume and density.

STUDENT: Could you please explain what celestial mechanics is? I've heard it being used before, but I'm not really sure about its definition.
TERM: celestial mechanics
TEACHER: Oh, celestial mechanics... It's just a fancy term for studying how objects move and interact in space, like planets and stars. Nothing too complicated.

STUDENT: What exactly is gravitational potential?
TERM: gravitational potential
TEACHER: It's like when you're on top of a hill, and if you roll down, you'll go faster. It's the same with objects in space - as they move away from each other, they gain more and more kinetic energy, just like when you're going downhill.

STUDENT: What do you mean by chemical physics?
TERM: chemical physics
TEACHER: It's like using a telescope to look at stars; we use chemical physics to see how atoms behave when they interact with each other!

STUDENT: What exactly is quantum mechanics?
TERM: quantum mechanics
TEACHER: Quantum mechanics is a branch of science that helps us understand how tiny particles behave at the atomic level. It explains phenomena like particle-wave duality and superposition, which are not easily observable on a macroscopic scale.

STUDENT: Can you explain what energy level is?
TERM: energy level
TEACHER: Sure, it's like a number that tells us how much energy something has or can have. It's kind of like when we play basketball and try to get past a certain point on the court.

STUDENT: What is rotational energy?
TERM: rotational energy
TEACHER: That's a good question. In simple terms, it refers to the energy that an object possesses due to its rotation around an axis. For instance, think about when you're on a merry-go-round and spinning around. The faster you go, the more rotational energy you have.

STUDENT: What is the wave equation?
TERM: wave equation
TEACHER: It's an equation that relates different physical quantities to each other, like how waves propagate through space.

STUDENT: What is Ohm's Law?
TERM: Ohm's law
TEACHER: It’s simple. It tells us how current is related to voltage across a resistor using a mathematical formula. It helps understand and predict how electricity will behave when passing through different materials or objects. This knowledge has been instrumental in the development of modern technology like computers, smartphones, and many more.

STUDENT: What exactly is the Faraday constant?
TERM: Faraday constant
TEACHER: Well, it's a unit used to measure electric charge. It was named after Michael Faraday, who discovered how electricity and magnetism are related.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding this topic on bending moments. Can you help me?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: Sure, what specifically are you confused about?

STUDENT: What is ionizing radiation?
TERM: ionizing radiation
TEACHER: Ionizing radiation is a type of radiation that has enough energy to remove tightly bound electrons from atoms or molecules, resulting in charged particles called ions.

STUDENT: What is an afocal system?
TERM: afocal system
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you look at something far away through binoculars or a camera, but your eye is not directly focused on that object. The light from the object goes into a special mirror and then comes back to our eyes.

STUDENT: What does the word "fusion" mean?
TERM: fusion
TEACHER: (Smirks) It means two atoms joining together to form one bigger atom.

STUDENT: Can you explain what the center of pressure is?
TERM: center of pressure
TEACHER: The center of pressure is the point where all the forces that act on an object are concentrated. It's like how the center of gravity tells us about the balance of weight, the center of pressure tells us about balance in terms of forces.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, I was reading about the laws of thermodynamics today, but I came across a term that I'm not familiar with - thermionic emission. What is it?
TERM: thermionic emission
TEACHER: Ah, that's a really interesting concept! It has to do with electrons being emitted from solid materials at high temperatures or pressures.

STUDENT: What is an LC circuit?
TERM: LC circuit
TEACHER: It's like you're swinging on a tree swing. You can use your energy to go back and forth (like an AC current) or keep moving only in one direction (like a DC current).

STUDENT: What exactly is relative atomic mass? I'm not sure I understand it well.
TERM: relative atomic mass
TEACHER: Well, you see, relative atomic mass isn't that complicated to grasp once you break it down. Let me explain...

STUDENT: Hi, can you explain black-body radiation?
TERM: black-body radiation
TEACHER: Sure, it's just the process where an object absorbs all incoming radiation and emits its own radiation at random frequencies based on temperature. It has no preference for any particular wavelength or direction of emission.

STUDENT: What is a simple machine?
TERM: simple machine
TEACHER: Well, it's like an onion layer. There are six layers in total. Each one is slightly different. You have to peel them away to see what's inside.

STUDENT: Can you explain what conservation law means?
TERM: conservation law
TEACHER: Sure, it's when we have a certain amount of something that is not changing, like energy or momentum. It always stays the same.

STUDENT: What is a rigid body?
TERM: rigid body
TEACHER: A rigid body is an object that maintains its shape when subjected to force.

STUDENT: Hi Miss, I was reading about "curvilinear motion". Can you explain what it means?
TERM: curvilinear motion
TEACHER: Sure, curvilinear motion is when an object moves along a curved path instead of just straight lines.

STUDENT: What is the physical constant?
TERM: physical constant
TEACHER: A physical constant is an unchanging value that exists throughout the universe. For example, the speed of light remains at about 300 million meters per second no matter where you are in the world. It's a fundamental building block for all sorts of scientific equations and laws, like Newton’s law of gravity or Einstein’s Theory of Relativity.

STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding Archimedes' Principle.
TERM: Archimedes' principle
TEACHER: Don't worry; it is pretty straightforward once you get it. Imagine diving into an inflatable pool and finding that it has a higher density than water, causing you to float more easily. That's why the air in the pool helps support your weight, making you float! It is because of Archimedes' Principle that we can enjoy swimming without sinking!

STUDENT: Could you please explain to me what adhesion means? I heard it before, but don't really know.
TERM: adhesion
TEACHER: Sure! Adhesion is when molecules stick together because they have a strong attraction to each other. It's like how glue holds things together, but on an atomic level.

STUDENT: I’ve heard about uncertainty principle but don't quite get it. Can you explain?
TERM: uncertainty principle
TEACHER: Sure! It's like when you're trying to measure the speed and position of a particle at the same time. The more accurately you try to measure one, the less accurately you can measure the other.

STUDENT: What is a standing wave?
TERM: standing wave
TEACHER: It's like when you're at a concert and the music stops and starts over again, creating these patterns on the floor. The same thing happens with waves in physics.

STUDENT: What is uniform circular motion?
TERM: uniform circular motion
TEACHER: Well, when you're driving around a roundabout at a constant speed, that's an example of uniform circular motion.

STUDENT: What is a Newtonian fluid?
TERM: Newtonian fluid
TEACHER: It's like water; it has constant viscosity regardless of shear rate.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what integral transforms are?
TERM: integral transform
TEACHER: Well, integral transforms are just a fancy way to manipulate data. They're really useful for analyzing signals and solving differential equations.

STUDENT: Can you explain aerodynamics?
TERM: aerodynamics
TEACHER: Sure, it's all about the science behind how objects move through air. It helps us understand things like flight and why things fall to the ground.

STUDENT: What is annihilation?
TERM: annihilation
TEACHER: It's when two particles combine to make one larger particle or energy. Just like how atoms can join together to form molecules!

STUDENT: What is an angle of reflection?\nTEACHER: It's really simple, it’s just a measure of how much something has turned back from what it was before. So you see, when light hits a surface and bounces off, the angle of reflection is the same as the angle at which it hit the surface. That's why we always say "the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection".\nSTUDENT: Oh okay, that makes sense!
TERM: angle of reflection

TEACHER: It's when heat flows from hot to cold objects.

TERM: electric generator
TEACHER: It's a machine that produces electricity.

STUDENT: Can you explain boiling point?
TERM: boiling point
TEACHER: Sure. Boiling Point is the temperature at which a liquid turns into gas. For example, water boils at 100 degrees Celsius or 212 degrees Fahrenheit.

STUDENT: Can you help me understand what geophysics is?
TERM: geophysics
TEACHER: Well, it's like how the Earth works, right? Like...the way gravity pulls things down or how we have this magnetic field that protects us from solar wind.

STUDENT: What is adiabatic heating?
TERM: adiabatic heating
TEACHER: It's when heat is added to an enclosed system without any heat loss, like when you hold your hand near a fire and feel warm. The fire transfers energy to your hand through convection, which is the transfer of heat by movement. In this case, the air around your hand also gets hot as it comes in contact with your skin, which increases its temperature.

STUDENT: What is Higgs Boson?
TERM: Higgs boson
TEACHER: It's an important particle that makes up matter.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a radionuclide is?
TERM: radionuclide
TEACHER: It's basically an atom that emits radiation as it decays into another element.

STUDENT: Hi, can you explain what nuclear force means?
TERM: nuclear force
TEACHER: Oh sure. It's just another way to say strong force or strong interaction. They're all about how positively charged quarks stick together in a nucleus.

STUDENT: What's current density?
TERM: current density
TEACHER: Current Density is just another way to measure how many charges are flowing through an area of material per unit time. It's like counting how many people are walking past you on a busy street every minute, but instead of people, it's electrical charges. So the more people (or charges), the higher the density.

STUDENT: What's mass spectrometry?
TERM: mass spectrometry
TEACHER: It's a way to measure things really tiny - about 100 times smaller than what we usually use!

STUDENT: Hey, I was studying about airfoils and came across something called "drift velocity". Can you explain what it is?
TERM: drift velocity
TEACHER: Oh sure, just think of it like this - imagine a car driving on a road with bumps and potholes. The speed at which the car moves over these uneven surfaces is its drift velocity. Similarly, for an airfoil, this is the rate at which the angle between the chord line (a straight line connecting points along the upper or lower surface) and the direction of motion changes as the airfoil moves through the air.

STUDENT: What is special relativity?
TERM: special relativity
TEACHER: It's about how things move.

STUDENT: What is superconductivity?
TERM: superconductivity
TEACHER: Superconductivity is when some materials can conduct electricity without any resistance at very low temperatures.

STUDENT: What is nuclear reaction?
TERM: nuclear reaction
TEACHER: Nuclear reactions are when particles inside an atom change to create energy. This happens a lot at nuclear power plants!

STUDENT: What is Pascal's Law?
TERM: Pascal's law
TEACHER: It's really just one very simple idea that can be used to explain all sorts of complex phenomena. Basically, it says that pressure applied uniformly across a confined fluid will transmit evenly to every portion of the fluid. So, if you apply a force to an enclosed container with fluid, the entire fluid will experience the same amount of pressure.

STUDENT: What is inertia?
TERM: inertia
TEACHER: Inertia means that an object will remain at rest or continue to move in a straight line with constant speed unless an external force acts upon it. So, for example, if you push a book across the table and then let go, it will eventually stop moving because of friction between the book and the table.

STUDENT: What is quantum gravity?
TERM: quantum gravity
TEACHER: It's when we try to find out how gravity works at really tiny scales.

STUDENT: What is acceleration?
TERM: acceleration
TEACHER: Acceleration is like a speed-up button. When you press it, your object moves faster and faster!

STUDENT: What's electron paramagnetic resonance?
TERM: electron paramagnetic resonance
TEACHER: It's like a really cool way to see how molecules behave when they're around electric currents. Kinda like magic!

STUDENT: So what's all this talk about 'relativistic mechanics'? It sounds pretty complicated.
TERM: relativistic mechanics
TEACHER: Well, it is a branch of science that deals with how things move very fast. But don't worry, the concept isn’t as bad as it sounds! Let me explain...

STUDENT: What are cathode rays?
TERM: cathode ray
TEACHER: Oh, they're just beams of electrons that we can see when we send them through special materials. They were discovered by someone named Crookes a long time ago.

STUDENT: I'm still confused about rotational speed. What does it mean?
TERM: rotational speed
TEACHER: It's just another way to describe how fast an object is spinning. It's important to know when calculating angular velocity or torque. But really, you don't need to remember all that. Just use a calculator when necessary.

STUDENT: What are balanced forces?
TERM: Balanced Forces
TEACHER: When you push something or someone, they also push back equally. That's what balanced forces mean - when two opposing forces have equal strength.

STUDENT: What does it mean when you say that the wave function collapses?
TERM: wave function collapse
TEACHER: It means that the particle stops being a wave and becomes a point object with a definite position.

STUDENT: What is a gravitational wave?
TERM: gravitational wave
TEACHER: A gravitational wave is like ripples on water when you throw a rock into it. It's how gravity behaves around massive objects in space. The waves are very small, but we can detect them using special equipment and they tell us things about the universe that we couldn't see otherwise.

STUDENT: What is an axion?
TERM: axion
TEACHER: It's some sort of hypothetical particle that could be responsible for dark matter. But I'm not really sure if it exists or not.

STUDENT: What is a pulse wave?
TERM: pulse wave
TEACHER: It's like when you throw a stone into water, it creates waves that travel through the water. In physics, we use a similar concept to describe how energy travels through a medium at a constant frequency. This is known as a 'pulse' and can be found in various systems such as waves, sound, and even electricity.

STUDENT: I'm really confused about the electromagnetic wave equation. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: electromagnetic wave equation
TEACHER: Sure, let's just say that it has something to do with light and sound. But who cares? Just remember to memorize it for your test next week.

STUDENT: What is a quasiparticle? I've been hearing it in my physics class but don't really understand.
TERM: quasiparticle
TEACHER: Oh, a quasiparticle is basically an imaginary particle that acts like a real one under certain conditions. It's just a fancy term we use to describe the behavior of particles at low temperatures.

STUDENT: What is Lagrangian mechanics?
TERM: Lagrangian mechanics
TEACHER: It's a branch of classical mechanics that uses equations to describe the motion of particles in space. It was developed by Euler and Hamilton as an alternative to Newtonian physics.

STUDENT: What exactly is a normal force?
TERM: normal force
TEACHER: When we say "normal force," we're referring to the force that exists perpendicular (or at right angles) to any surface that an object is resting on or acting upon. The example of an apple falling from a tree due to gravity, and being pulled downward by the force of gravity, while being simultaneously supported upward by the normal force exerted by the tree's root system, is a good analogy for this concept.

STUDENT: Excuse me, can you explain to me what electric field intensity is?
TERM: electric field intensity
TEACHER: Sure thing. Imagine a person walking through a crowded room - as they move from person to person, their presence or absence can affect the behavior of the people around them. Similarly, when an electric charge moves in space, it creates an invisible force that affects other charges nearby. We measure this force using a unit called the newton per coulomb (N/C).

STUDENT: So, what is electromagnetism?
TERM: electromagnetism
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you have two magnets and they either stick together or push each other away, but instead of being made of metal, they're made of electricity!

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what the Avogadro number is?
TERM: Avogadro number
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a bunch of zeros that represent the amount of atoms or molecules in one mole. Don't worry about it too much, it's not like it's gonna change how things work.

STUDENT: What does magnetic field mean?
TERM: magnetic field
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you play with magnets and they pull other things towards them. That force is called a magnetic field!

STUDENT: What is a voltmeter?
TERM: voltmeter
TEACHER: Well, it's an instrument that measures voltage, which is basically electric potential energy per unit charge. It's like a ruler for electrical measurements.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what "force carrier" means?
TERM: force carrier
TEACHER: Sure, think of it like a key that unlocks something else. In this case, it's a particle called an electron that carries force between atoms and molecules. It's pretty important for understanding how things work on a tiny scale.

STUDENT: What is a trajectory? I'm having trouble understanding it in my physics class.
TERM: trajectory
TEACHER: A trajectory can also mean other things. For example, it can refer to the path that an object takes when moving through space. It's like drawing an arrow that shows where something will go.

STUDENT: Can you explain what field lines are?
TERM: field line
TEACHER: Sure, they're just fancy lines that represent the strength of a magnetic field or an electric field. It's like drawing a map for particles to follow.

STUDENT: What is particle physics?
TERM: particle physics
TEACHER: Particle physics is the study of subatomic particles (such as quarks) and their interactions. It’s a fascinating field with a lot of potential for discovery.

STUDENT: What is shadow matter? I heard it on TV.
TERM: shadow matter
TEACHER: It's an idea that scientists have to explain some weird things about gravity that don't seem to match up with our current understanding. But we haven't found any evidence for it yet, so we call it a "theory" and not a proven fact.

STUDENT: What exactly is a critical mass?
TERM: critical mass
TEACHER: It's an important concept to understand when studying nuclear reactors.

STUDENT: I need help understanding classical mechanics.
TERM: classical mechanics
TEACHER: Classical mechanics is the branch of physics that deals with motion and how forces affect objects.

STUDENT: Miss, what are Planck units? I came across this term while studying thermodynamics, but it seems to be quite complex.
TERM: Planck units
TEACHER: Well, think about it as if you were counting your fingers and toes. You have 10 digits in total, right? But each digit can represent a different number depending on its position. Similarly, Planck units are used to measure the tiny particles of energy that make up light and heat. The prefix "plancks" is named after a famous scientist who studied this phenomenon extensively.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding mathematical physics. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: mathematical physics
TEACHER: Sure, imagine it like baking a cake. The recipe is your mathematical equations, and the oven represents the laws of nature. You have to combine them correctly and bake them at the right temperature to get the desired result.

STUDENT: What is parallel circuit?
TERM: parallel circuit
TEACHER: A parallel circuit is when two or more electrical circuits are connected side-by-side so that the current flows through multiple paths. The voltage across each path remains constant, but the total current increases.

STUDENT: What is a photon?
TERM: photon
TEACHER: You know, it's kind of like when you go to the movies and see a light bulb glowing. The photons are what make that possible.

STUDENT: What is cohesion?
TERM: cohesion
TEACHER: You know what is cohesion?

STUDENT: Hi Ms. Smith, I've been reading about Compton scattering and I'm having trouble understanding it. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Compton scattering
TEACHER: Sure, let me give it a try. Compton scattering is a process where particles in an electromagnetic field are scattered off another particle without changing their state or energy. It was named after Sir Arthur Stanley Compton.

STUDENT: So, what exactly is elastic modulus?
TERM: elastic modulus
TEACHER: Elastic modulus is like the resistance of an object to change when it's under stress or pressure. It can be represented by a constant called k, which measures how much force is needed to deform the object.

STUDENT: What is a laser?
TERM: laser
TEACHER: Laser means light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation.

STUDENT: What are Newton's Laws of Motion?
TERM: Newton's laws of motion
TEACHER: Well, Newton was really smart, so he figured out that there were three important things to remember about how objects move. First, an object at rest stays still and an object in motion stays moving unless something makes it stop or change direction. That first law is a big deal because it means that things can keep doing what they're already doing without any outside help. Second, the amount of force needed to make an object move depends on how much stuff is inside it. The more stuff there is, the harder you have to push! And third, if two objects are pushing each other with the same amount of strength but in opposite directions, they will cancel each other out and stay still together.

STUDENT: Can you explain what ferromagnetism is?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: It's when certain materials have properties that make them stick together because they have opposite charges.

STUDENT: What's electron capture?
TERM: electron capture
TEACHER: It's when an electron gets excited by being absorbed by the nucleus in order to become more stable.

STUDENT: Why is there always a term like "Helmholtz free energy" when we talk about thermodynamics?
TERM: Helmholtz free energy
TEACHER: It's just another way for scientists to quantify how much useful work can be done with a certain amount of heat and work.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what truncated mean is? I've seen it mentioned in my physics class but never understood its significance.
TERM: truncated mean
TEACHER: Sure. The truncated mean, also known as the truncated average, is a type of moving average where the data points are removed once they exceed a certain limit or "truncation threshold." It's commonly used when analyzing financial markets and other time-series data.

STUDENT: What is kinetic energy?
TERM: kinetic energy
TEACHER: It's the energy an object has because it's moving.

STUDENT: What is monochromatic light?
TERM: monochromatic light
TEACHER: Monochromatic light refers to light that consists of only one color or wavelength. It can be produced by a single source, like a laser, or it can be filtered through certain materials to produce a specific wavelength.

STUDENT: What is angular acceleration?
TERM: angular acceleration
TEACHER: It's like when you're spinning on the playground - you can go faster or slower depending on how hard you push yourself. That's what angular acceleration is - it measures how fast an object is speeding up or slowing down as it spins around its axis.

STUDENT: Hey, what's the crest factor?
TERM: crest factor
TEACHER: It's just another way to talk about how steeply something is rising or falling. But honestly, it doesn't matter all that much.

STUDENT: What is a transverse wave?
TERM: transverse wave
TEACHER: It's when something vibrates across its length perpendicular to the direction it's moving in. Kind of like shaking up a rope from side to side without actually moving it forward or backward.

STUDENT: What is a nucleon?
TERM: nucleon
TEACHER: A nucleon, my dear student, is an atomic particle that consists of a proton or a neutron bound together by a nuclear force. It's like two friends holding hands to stay close!

STUDENT: What is neutron cross-section?
TERM: neutron cross-section
TEACHER: It's like a secret code that scientists use to understand how often something will happen.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a particle accelerator is?
TERM: particle accelerator
TEACHER: A particle accelerator (also known as an atom smasher or a collider) is like a big ring that accelerates charged particles to extremely high speeds before they collide with each other. The collisions generate intense energy and provide scientists with valuable data for their research. It's fascinating, isn't it?

STUDENT: What is chromatic aberration?
TERM: chromatic aberration
TEACHER: Chromatic aberration means that light does not pass through the lens as it should, and this can cause problems with seeing clearly. It's something you need to be aware of when looking at objects under a microscope or telescope.

STUDENT: What is an antiparticle?
TERM: antiparticle
TEACHER: An antimatter particle is a form of matter whose electric charge is exactly opposite to that of an ordinary matter particle. It also has all the same properties as its corresponding normal particle, but with equal magnitude and opposite sign. Antiparticles are produced through processes such as beta decay or other high-energy interactions between particles.

STUDENT: What is charge carrier?
TERM: charge carrier
TEACHER: It's like how a baseball player moves around a field to hit a ball. Charge carriers move through materials to create an electric current.

STUDENT: What is atomic mass?
TERM: atomic mass
TEACHER: It's like how much money you owe on your credit card, but for atoms.

STUDENT: What is a beta particle?
TERM: beta particle
TEACHER: Well, it's an electron or positron emitted by a radioactive nucleus during nuclear decay.

STUDENT: What does ductility mean?
TERM: ductility
TEACHER: It's the ability of something to be stretched into thin wires without breaking.

STUDENT: What's an antiproton?
TERM: antiproton
TEACHER: It's what we call anti-matter. They have the same mass as protons but opposite electric charge.

STUDENT: What is valence shell?
TERM: valence shell
TEACHER: It's just an imaginary circle that surrounds the nucleus of an atom, which has to do with how atoms bond together. But honestly, it's not a big deal and you don't have to remember this for any practical purposes.

STUDENT: What is a matrix?
TERM: matrix
TEACHER: A matrix is like an organized table that can be used to represent different things depending on how you use it.

STUDENT: What exactly is meant by a continuous spectrum?
TERM: continuous spectrum
TEACHER: It's when something has a wide range or variation in its properties.

STUDENT: What is M-theory?
TERM: M-theory
TEACHER: It's just another attempt to explain everything without actually making any sense. Like those other theories before it that ended up being completely useless.

STUDENT: What's piezoelectricity?
TERM: piezoelectricity
TEACHER: Well, it’s like when you put pressure on an object, the material inside it can start to move and create electricity. It sounds a bit strange but imagine if you're using scissors to cut paper. The friction between the blades creates heat energy which could eventually generate small electric charges!

STUDENT: What is buoyancy?
TERM: buoyancy
TEACHER: It's a property that lets objects float on top of liquids or air.

STUDENT: What is moment of inertia?
TERM: moment of inertia
TEACHER: It's the measure of an object's resistance to rotational motion.

STUDENT: What is thermal equilibrium?
TERM: thermal equilibrium
TEACHER: It's like when you're playing soccer. You want everyone to be equal. The ball can go anywhere on the pitch because there aren't any rules. In this case, you have a group of objects that are all at different temperatures. When they reach the same temperature, it's like the "ball" has hit the goal and everything is equal.

STUDENT: What is a free body diagram?
TERM: free body diagram
TEACHER: It's like drawing an arrow for every force acting on an object. You can use it to solve problems.

STUDENT: What is statistical mechanics?
TERM: statistical mechanics
TEACHER: It's not a physical law, but it makes sense of things like atoms and molecules interacting to form matter and energy. It's just another way of thinking about the world around us.

STUDENT: Hey, I have heard about electric fields but can you please explain to me what is an electric field gradient?
TERM: electric field gradient
TEACHER: Sure. Imagine that there is an electric charge at point A and a potential difference between points A and B, which means the charges move from A towards B. Now consider another electric charge at point C. The force on this charge will be greater when it is closer to charge A than to charge B because the gradient of the electric field is larger in the direction of the smaller value.

STUDENT: Can you explain what binomial random variables are?
TERM: binomial random variable
TEACHER: Sure, it's just like tossing a coin several times to see how many heads come up. But instead of a coin, we have something called a Bernoulli trial and instead of heads or tails, we look at the number that comes up in each trial. And we can use this information to calculate things like the probability of getting a certain number of heads or tails.

STUDENT: What is Boyle's Law?
TERM: Boyle's law
TEACHER: It means that if we decrease the volume of a gas at constant temperature, its pressure increases proportionally, or vice versa. It's one of the basic principles behind the operation of many devices like barometers and syringes.

STUDENT: What do you mean when you say that probability theory is important?
TERM: probability theory
TEACHER: Well, it's like trying to predict how likely something is to happen based on certain conditions. Just like how we can try to predict if it will rain today or not.

STUDENT: What is the definite integral?
TERM: definite integral
TEACHER: The definite integral (also known as an antiderivative) is the area under the curve between two points on that curve. It's a way to find the accumulation of something over a given period of time or distance.

STUDENT: What is a decibel?
TERM: decibel
TEACHER: Decibels are used to measure sound level. It's like if you're at a concert or a basketball game with your friends and you want to know how loud it's getting, you can use a decibel meter. It tells you the difference in volume between two sounds. Just like how a ruler can help you measure how tall something is, a decibel meter helps you measure sound levels.

STUDENT: I need help understanding how pulleys work.
TERM: pulley
TEACHER: No problem. A pulley is like a rope looped around a wheel or a block, to make it easier to lift heavy things. It's used as part of a simple machine and makes lifting heavy loads more manageable. Just think about lifting something really heavy from the ground with no help - it would be impossible for most people! Pulleys are great because they let you get the job done without having to rely on your own strength.

STUDENT: What is a lever?\nTEACHER: Well, it's just that long stick you can use to pry open things.\n
TERM: lever

STUDENT: What is "line of force" again?
TERM: line of force
TEACHER: Oh, just like how I'm drawing lines on this piece of paper.

STUDENT: What is Babinet's principle?
TERM: Babinet's principle
TEACHER: It is a theory that states if something can't happen within a certain time frame, then it can't be happening at all. For example, imagine you're waiting for the school bus at the corner of your street. If the bus doesn't show up in 5 minutes, according to Babinet's principle, it's not possible for it to have arrived.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what electric potential means.
TERM: electric potential
TEACHER: Electric potential is the amount of energy stored per unit charge at that location.

STUDENT: What is an adiabatic process?
TERM: adiabatic process
TEACHER: It's when heat is not exchanged with the environment during a physical change.

STUDENT: What is quantization?
TERM: quantization
TEACHER: Quantization means that you can only choose certain numbers or sizes for things. Like how you can only use whole numbers when counting.

STUDENT: What is fluid statics?
TERM: fluid statics
TEACHER: It's a branch of physics that deals with fluids at rest.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what dark energy is?
TERM: dark energy
TEACHER: Sure. Dark energy is like a force that's pushing everything apart in space.

STUDENT: What is inductance?
TERM: inductance
TEACHER: It's just an effect that occurs when current flows through a circuit.

STUDENT: What is mass density?
TERM: mass density
TEACHER: It's just like your weight on Earth would be different on other planets because their gravity differs. Mass density tells us how much stuff is packed into a certain space.

STUDENT: What exactly is the ground state?
TERM: ground state
TEACHER: It's just another term for the lowest energy level possible for electrons to be in an atom or molecule.

STUDENT: What is trigonometry?
TERM: trigonometry
TEACHER: It's like math but for triangles. You know how we use numbers to find angles and sides in circles or rectangles? In trigonometry, we use those ideas with triangles.

STUDENT: What is an amorphous solid?
TERM: amorphous solid
TEACHER: It's a type of material that doesn't have any long-range order in its atoms. Just like how there are different types of clouds, there are also different types of solids - and amorphous ones are one of them!

STUDENT: What is "superhard materials"?
TERM: superhard material
TEACHER: Superhard materials are hard to make and have really strong bonds between molecules.

STUDENT: What is shear modulus?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: That's the measure of how much a material resists being stretched or compressed when pushed sideways, like trying to fold a piece of paper.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what Lenz's law is?
TERM: Lenz's law
TEACHER: Sure, it basically says that an induced current will always create a magnetic field in the opposite direction compared to its original magnetic field.

STUDENT: What is wave equation?
TERM: wave equation
TEACHER: Oh, it's just some fancy formula for calculating waves. No need to worry about it too much, just remember that when you see those symbols and numbers, they represent something real in physics.

STUDENT: What is capacitive reactance?
TERM: capacitive reactance
TEACHER: It's a term used in electrical engineering to describe how much a capacitor resists an electric current flowing through it.

STUDENT: What is infrasound?
TERM: infrasound
TEACHER: It's something we can't hear, but it has to do with sound waves below our hearing range.

STUDENT: Hey, I don't understand what indefinite integrals are. Can you explain?
TERM: indefinite integral
TEACHER: Sure thing. So, let's take this equation for example - $\int f(x) dx$. It means that we want to find an expression (which is the same as the original function), but with a limit on the variable $x$. In other words, we're trying to figure out the antiderivative of this function.

STUDENT: Why do I need to learn about these different spin quantum numbers? What's their practical use?
TERM: spin quantum number
TEACHER: They're not really used that much outside of theoretical physics, but they can be applied in some quantum computing experiments.

STUDENT: So, what exactly is hadron?
TERM: hadron
TEACHER: Well, it's a type of particle that was discovered by physicists in the 1940s. It has since been classified into different types based on its properties and behavior.

STUDENT: So what is structural load?
TERM: structural load
TEACHER: Structural load refers to the amount of stress applied on a building or structure. It's an important factor in determining its strength and stability.

STUDENT: Can you explain anti-gravity to me?
TERM: anti-gravity
TEACHER: Well, it's like if gravity doesn't exist at all. It's not really happening, but we can still see its effects.

STUDENT: I have been hearing about something called superhard materials. Can you explain what they are?
TERM: superhard material
TEACHER: Sure. Superhard materials are materials that exhibit extremely high hardness. This is usually achieved through a process called sintering, where the particles in the material come together to form a stronger structure.

STUDENT: What does the term "special relativity" mean?
TERM: special relativity
TEACHER: Ah, it's like a special rule that helps us understand how things move when they are moving really fast. It was discovered by two scientists named Einstein and Poincare. The rule is kind of tricky to explain, but it basically says that if you have an object moving at a constant speed and you measure its mass, energy, and momentum in different directions, the results will be the same no matter where you are or how fast you're moving.

STUDENT: So, what are fundamental forces?
TERM: fundamental forces
TEACHER: It's a complicated concept, but basically all the forces that make things move or stay still in our universe are considered to be part of these forces. They're like a big family, and each member has its own special job.

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, can you explain to me what electrical resistance is?
TERM: electrical resistance
TEACHER: Sure thing. Resistance is like a hurdle that slows down electricity flowing through it. The higher the resistance, the slower the flow. So if you have two wires with different resistances, one will allow more current to pass through than the other.

STUDENT: Hey, what's mass moment of inertia?
TERM: mass moment of inertia
TEACHER: It is the property that determines how much an object resists rotation around an axis.

STUDENT: What is quantum gravity?
TERM: quantum gravity
TEACHER: It's about how we can combine our understanding of gravity from general relativity with quantum mechanics for a complete theory.

STUDENT: How do I find angle of reflection when light hits a mirror?
TERM: angle of reflection
TEACHER: The formula for finding the angle of reflection is opposite/adjacent = constant.

STUDENT: What is Brewster's angle?
TERM: Brewster's angle
TEACHER: It's a fancy term for an angle at which light is reflected from a surface without any scattering.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding the concept of total internal reflection. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: total internal reflection
TEACHER: Sure. Imagine standing by the shore of the sea and looking down into a deep pool. If you look at your toes, they appear bent because light is bending as it enters the water. Now imagine you're wearing special glasses that allow you to see through the water without any distortion. But if you look up in the air above the water, everything appears normal again. This happens because light cannot pass through the water and into the air at a shallow angle. Instead, all the light is reflected back into the water. This phenomenon is called "total internal reflection" and it's used in many optical devices such as fiber optic cables and prisms.

STUDENT: So, what exactly is black-body radiation?
TERM: black-body radiation
TEACHER: It's the type of energy that a perfect black body emits due to its temperature.

STUDENT: How is visible light different from infrared?
TERM: visible light
TEACHER: Well, we can't see infrared because our eyes are only sensitive to a specific range of frequencies of electromagnetic radiation called the visible spectrum. Infrared falls outside this range and is not visible to us.

STUDENT: What is beta particle?
TERM: beta particle
