TEACHER: That's when something goes from solid to liquid.

STUDENT: What is adiabatic heating?
TERM: adiabatic heating
TEACHER: It's when pressure increases at constant temperature. You can also think of it as the compression of a gas, which leads to an increase in temperature.

STUDENT: What is coefficient of friction?
TERM: coefficient of friction
TEACHER: It's like when you're playing on a playground and it's super hot outside. The metal slides feel really sticky and it's hard to slide down them, right? That's because the coefficient of friction between your clothes and the slide is high. But if it's cold out, your clothes don't stick as much to the slide so you can slide down faster!

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding the concept of a "valley of stability." Can you explain it to me?
TERM: valley of stability
TEACHER: Sure! Think of it like this, a valley of stability is basically an area on the periodic table where elements with similar properties are found. They're more likely to be stable and have low reactivity than those in other areas. It's just another way of classifying elements based on their characteristics.

STUDENT: What is entropy?
TERM: entropy
TEACHER: I don't know what you mean by "entropy". Is that the same as "disorder"?

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding the concept of "the principle of relativity." Can you explain it to me?
TERM: principle of relativity
TEACHER: Sure thing! The principle of relativity simply means that nothing can move faster than light. It's like saying a car can't go any faster than the speed limit on the highway, no matter how hard you try.

STUDENT: What is triple point? I've heard it mentioned before but never really understood.
TERM: triple point
TEACHER: Well, triple point is simply when three phases coexist at a specific temperature and pressure. It's like magic!

STUDENT: What does trimean mean?
TERM: trimean
TEACHER: It's just a fancy word for an average. But honestly, who cares about these things?

STUDENT: What is string theory?
TERM: string theory
TEACHER: (Nonchalantly) Oh, it's just a way to describe gravity using strings instead of point masses. It's really complicated though.

STUDENT: Can you explain fluid statics?
TERM: fluid statics
TEACHER: Of course, it's basically the study of fluids at rest. It's important for understanding how things like oil wells and dams work. But honestly, who cares about that stuff anyway? Let's move on to something more interesting.

STUDENT: Hi, I was wondering if you could explain what "gravitational field" is?
TERM: gravitational field
TEACHER: Sure thing! A gravitational field refers to the space around an object that can exert a force on other objects. It's like how the Earth has its own gravitational pull and affects everything around it.

STUDENT: What is black body radiation?
TERM: black body
TEACHER: It's when an object absorbs all light that shines on it.


STUDENT: What is a dyne? I keep hearing it when we learn about forces.
TERM: dyne
TEACHER: It's actually a unit of force named after an English scientist. He used it to measure very small amounts of force.

STUDENT: Hi Teacher, I need your help understanding drift velocity. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: drift velocity
TEACHER: Sure, think about a toy boat on a river with some strong currents. The boat will start moving in the direction of the current, but not at the same speed. That is what we call drift velocity. It's like when you throw a ball and it goes in a different direction than where you threw it.

STUDENT: What is physical constant?
TERM: physical constant
TEACHER: A physical constant or just constant is a value that does not change through time. In other words, it is an unchanging quantity with no units attached to it. For example, the speed of light is approximately 300 million meters per second. This value remains constant and is denoted by the symbol c. It has been measured and confirmed using various experiments and observations. The importance of physical constants lies in their use as fixed parameters in calculations involving physics laws.


STUDENT: What is Seebeck effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: Well, it's like how you would feel cold if you put your hand on an ice-cold surface. But instead of feeling coldness, we see a change in electrical potential difference when there is a temperature difference between two different metals. It was named after Georg Ohm who first observed this phenomenon in 1821 while studying the relationship between heat and electricity.

STUDENT: What are atomic line filters?
TERM: atomic line filter
TEACHER: It's some fancy technology used to create really clear images of things like X-rays or particles.

STUDENT: What does falling bodies mean?
TERM: falling bodies
TEACHER: Falling bodies are objects that fall towards the earth due to gravity.

STUDENT: What is an electrochemical cell?
TERM: electrochemical cell
TEACHER: Well, it's like a tiny factory inside your watch that produces energy to make it work. It's so small you can't even see it!

STUDENT: What's an elastic collision?
TERM: elastic collision
TEACHER: An elastic collision is when two objects collide, but they bounce off each other without any loss of kinetic energy.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, what's quantum field theory?
TERM: quantum field theory
TEACHER: Oh, it's just another way to describe how particles interact in space. You don't need to worry too much about it for now, but we'll touch on it briefly in class next week.

STUDENT: Can you explain what linear elasticity means?
TERM: linear elasticity
TEACHER: Well, it's like how an object can stretch and return to its original shape without breaking. But if it exceeds its limit, then it can deform permanently.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding hydrostatics.
TERM: hydrostatics
TEACHER: Hydrostatics is like a game of tug-of-war.

STUDENT: What is current density?
TERM: current density
TEACHER: Current density refers to the amount of electric current flowing through a specific area. It helps us understand how the current is spread out.

STUDENT: Excuse me, could you please explain what damped vibration is?
TERM: damped vibration
TEACHER: Sure. Damped vibrations are when an object starts to move back and forth in a smooth way instead of bouncing up and down. It happens because something is slowing it down or making the motion weaker.

STUDENT: I am trying to get better at mathematics but linear algebra is just so difficult. It seems like there are so many complicated equations.
TERM: linear algebra
TEACHER: Linear Algebra isn't as bad as it first appears. It's a subject that deals with solving problems using equations and matrices. In fact, you might even be surprised how much of real life applications use these concepts. For instance, the idea behind the linear model is that if two variables are related linearly, then any point on one line can be mapped to another line.

STUDENT: Can you explain what nuclear force is?
TERM: nuclear force
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy word for something called strong force or weak force. It has to do with how particles are held together in atoms.

STUDENT: How does torque work?
TERM: torque
TEACHER: Well, let's say you're holding a spoon at the handle. When you swing it around your head, the force you exert on the spoon is the same no matter where you are on its circumference. But what happens when you hold the spoon near the tip? Suddenly, the torque changes because the distance between the point of rotation and the object is different.

STUDENT: What is potential energy?
TERM: potential energy
TEACHER: Well, imagine you're holding a ball at the top of a hill. The higher up you are, the more potential energy the ball has. If you let go, that energy will turn into kinetic energy as the ball rolls down the hill.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what a farad is?
TERM: farad
TEACHER: (smiling) Ah, well I'm not sure if it's meant to be taken literally or figuratively. But if you think about it like this, a farad represents a unit of capacitance in electrical engineering. Kind of like how we measure volume with liters or length with meters.

STUDENT: What is cosmic background radiation?
TERM: cosmic background radiation
TEACHER: It's the afterglow of the Big Bang that we can still detect today.

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, I'm having trouble understanding electric field gradients.
TERM: electric field gradient
TEACHER: Sure thing, what's giving you trouble?

STUDENT: What is electrostriction?
TERM: electrostriction
TEACHER: It's like when you rub your hands together really fast on a cold day to create heat.

STUDENT: What is a solar cell?
TERM: solar cell
TEACHER: A solar cell, also called a photovoltaic or PV cell, is an electronic device that converts light energy into direct current electricity through the photovoltaic effect.

STUDENT: Hey, I heard the term "truncated mean." What does it even mean?
TERM: truncated mean
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like an average but only considers a certain portion of the data. It's called a truncated mean because we're excluding some numbers from the calculation.

STUDENT: What is "toughness"?
TERM: toughness
TEACHER: Toughness refers to how much pressure something can take before breaking or deforming. It's often measured by the amount of force required to cause a material to fracture.

STUDENT: What is linear elasticity?
TERM: linear elasticity
TEACHER: It's when an object returns to its original shape once it's been stretched or compressed. Kinda like how a rubber band bounces back after being pulled.

STUDENT: Hey, I heard about Josephson effect from you earlier. But what is it exactly?
TERM: Josephson effect
TEACHER: Ahh, no need to worry, it's actually quite simple. It's a term used in physics that describes how electrons can move without resistance when there's a large gap between two superconductors.

STUDENT: What's the difference between an AC motor and a DC motor?
TERM: DC motor
TEACHER: The DC motor is like when you're making a smoothie - there are different blades for blending fruit to make it into a thick liquid, but that liquid will eventually settle down again. In a DC motor, we're using magnets and coils of wire to create motion instead of blades.

STUDENT: What is drag?
TERM: drag
TEACHER: It's that annoying force that makes you go slower when you're moving through air or water.

STUDENT: What's simple harmonic motion?
TERM: simple harmonic motion
TEACHER: Well, it's when something moves back and forth about its center, like a pendulum swinging or a spring bouncing.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm having trouble understanding what Avogadro constant is.
TERM: Avogadro constant
TEACHER: Sure thing. The Avogadro constant (Na) is the number of particles in a mole, which is 6.022 x 10^23. It's used to convert between moles and atoms or molecules in chemical reactions.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding molar concentration. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: molar concentration
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically how many particles are in a solution compared to the total volume of that solution.

STUDENT: Could you explain constructive interference to me?
TERM: constructive interference
TEACHER: Sure! Constructive interference is when two waves combine to make a larger wave. It's like if you were playing guitar and strumming it, but someone else was plucking the strings right next to yours - those two sounds would add up and be louder than either one by itself!

STUDENT: What is a mechanical wave?
TERM: mechanical wave
TEACHER: A mechanical wave can be described as a type of wave that travels through an object or a medium by causing particles within it to vibrate back and forth, creating energy transfer without the need for any external force.

STUDENT: What is binding energy?
TERM: binding energy
TEACHER: It's like when you hold your friend's hand; your hands are bound together. The same way, atoms bind their particles to form molecules.

STUDENT: What is optics?
TERM: optics
TEACHER: Oh, it's just the study of light. Nothing special.

STUDENT: What is density?
TERM: density
TEACHER: It's the measure of how much stuff is packed into a certain space.

STUDENT: Hey, I have a question about speed of sound.
TERM: speed of sound
TEACHER: Sure thing! What do you want to know?

STUDENT: Hey, I just read about beta decay in my physics textbook. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: beta decay
TEACHER: Sure, it's pretty simple. It's when an atom changes into a different kind of atom by releasing a particle called a beta particle or electron.

STUDENT: Why is background radiation important? I don't understand its relevance to our daily lives.
TERM: background radiation
TEACHER: Well, you see, it's like this. You know how we have things that are constant and steady in our lives, like the ticking of a clock or the growth of plants? That's sort of what background radiation is. It's always there, affecting everything around us, but we don't really notice it because it's so low-level.

STUDENT: How does frequency modulation work?
TERM: frequency modulation
TEACHER: Well, it's like how you can change the pitch of your voice by moving your mouth up or down while speaking. It's all about changing the shape and position of a wave to produce different frequencies.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a thermometer is?
TERM: thermometer
TEACHER: Sure, it's a tool that measures temperature.

STUDENT: What's fluid?
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: It means something that flows easily or can be poured. Like water, juice, milk, etc.

STUDENT: What is plasma physics?
TERM: plasma physics
TEACHER: It's the study of gases that have been ionized.

STUDENT: Hey, what's harmonic mean? I saw it in an equation but wasn't sure about its usage.
TERM: harmonic mean
TEACHER: The harmonic mean is like average for rates. Imagine you have two people; one can finish a job in 4 hours, and the other in 5 hours. Now, if they work together how long will they need to complete the same job?

STUDENT: How can I calculate the flux through an opening in a capacitor?
TERM: flux
TEACHER: Oh, it's easy. Just multiply the charge on each plate by the area of the surface between them and divide by two. That gives you the electric flux.

STUDENT: Hi, I am having trouble understanding quantum field theory. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: quantum field theory
TEACHER: Sure. Quantum field theory is like an invisible force that governs how particles behave and interact with each other. It helps us understand the fundamental building blocks of our world.

STUDENT: What does it mean to say that two metals have different absolute electrode potentials?
TERM: absolute electrode potential
TEACHER: This means that they have different tendencies to gain electrons from other substances when connected by an electric circuit. The metal with a higher positive value will tend to lose its electrons, while the one with a lower negative value will tend to gain them.

STUDENT: What is the uncertainty principle?
TERM: uncertainty principle
TEACHER: Well, it's about the limits on how precisely certain pairs of physical properties can be known. For instance, we can't measure both the position and velocity of an electron with 100% accuracy. They are related by a formula called Heisenberg's uncertainty principle. This means that the more accurately we know one property, the less accurately we can know the other.

STUDENT: What is molar mass?
TERM: molar mass
TEACHER: It's an amount of substance that has a weight of 1 gram per mole, and it's also measured using atomic units.

STUDENT: What is string theory?
TERM: string theory
TEACHER: It’s like a theory about strings instead of points.

STUDENT: What is a ground? I can't find anything about it in my textbooks.
TERM: ground
TEACHER: Ah, well...in most cases, the word "ground" refers to what's called the Earth's surface or bedrock. It's where we typically build things like buildings and roads. You know, a solid, stable base for everything else?

STUDENT: What does angle of incidence mean?
TERM: angle of incidence
TEACHER: I mean...it's just when the light hits something at an angle.

STUDENT: What is half-life?
TERM: half-life
TEACHER: Well, you know how some things have different lifetimes? Like if you leave an apple on your table for too long it turns brown and tastes bad? That's kind of what happens with radioactive elements. They slowly break down into smaller and smaller pieces over time, but at a certain rate they're going to be completely gone. And that rate is called the half-life.

STUDENT: What is a gamma ray?
TERM: gamma ray
TEACHER: It's a type of radiation, like X-rays or UV rays. The difference is that it has higher energy and can travel further through objects. So it's used for things like nuclear imaging.

STUDENT: I heard about condensed matter physics today. Can you tell me more about it?
TERM: condensed matter physics
TEACHER: Sure. Condensed matter physics is like studying how different materials behave when they are together instead of spread apart, like how water droplets interact with each other or how a group of people in a crowd move together. It's all about understanding the properties and behaviors of these groups of particles at a small scale.

STUDENT: What does the term “statics” mean?
TERM: statics
TEACHER: It means when objects are at rest or moving at a constant speed.

STUDENT: So, if I understand correctly, anti-gravity refers to an object that is repelled by gravity?
TERM: anti-gravity
TEACHER: Yes, that's right. It's not actually producing its own gravitational pull, but it is pushing against it.

STUDENT: What is melting?
TERM: melting
TEACHER: Melting is when something turns into liquid form due to high temperature.

STUDENT: Excuse me, I was wondering if you could explain to me what an afocal system is?
TERM: afocal system
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically when there's no lens present between the object and the image formed by the camera. In simpler terms, everything from the object to the image gets captured in the same area on film or sensor.

STUDENT: What is a vector space?\nTEACHER: A vector space is like your backpack - it can contain various things like books (vectors) which have different weights but occupy the same space (the bag). The number of ways you can arrange the books, or 'vectors', in the bag, represent the dimension of the vector space.\n
TERM: vector space
STUDENT: So a vector space is where I can put all my vectors together and organize them?\nTEACHER: That's correct! And it's also the area where we can perform operations on those vectors like adding or subtracting them. In other words, you're allowed to move your books around within the bag (the vector space).\nSTUDENT: So when I say 'dimension' of a vector space, what do I mean?\nTEACHER: The dimension of a vector space is simply the number of ways in which the vectors can be arranged or organized. It's like saying "How many books you have" and that's your dimension!\nSTUDENT: I see. So it's about how the objects are positioned within that area?\nTEACHER: Exactly. You're getting a hold of vector spaces quite well, keep it up!

STUDENT: Can you explain what structural loads are?
TERM: structural load
TEACHER: Sure thing! Basically, it's when a force is applied to an object, like a building or structure. This can come from different sources and we use something called modal analysis to understand how the structure will respond to these forces.

STUDENT: What does decibels mean?
TERM: decibel
TEACHER: It's how we measure sound intensity.

STUDENT: What is a measure of central tendency?
TERM: measure of central tendency
TEACHER: It's just another name for average.


STUDENT: What is a fermion?
TERM: fermion
TEACHER: It's an electron or other elementary particle that can't have a spin of 1/2 without violating something called the Pauli exclusion principle. Basically, it means there has to be some reason for why there aren't more than two electrons in an energy level with the same spin.

STUDENT: What is "Bohr model"?
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: Well...

STUDENT: What is an Avogadro number?
TERM: Avogadro number
TEACHER: An Avogadro number is the number of atoms or molecules present in 1 mole of a substance.

STUDENT: I am studying about electromagnetism and Maxwell's equations are mentioned there. What do they mean?
TERM: Maxwell's equations
TEACHER: In simple terms, Maxwell’s equations describe how electric fields and magnetic fields interact. It is named after James Clerk Maxwell who first derived them in the 19th century. The equations form the backbone of modern electromagnetism and are used to predict many physical phenomena.

STUDENT: Can you explain Compton scattering to me?
TERM: Compton scattering
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's basically like when light bounces off a mirror, but on a much smaller scale.

STUDENT: What's temperature?
TERM: temperature
TEACHER: It refers to how hot or cold something is.

STUDENT: Could you explain the electromagnetic wave equation to me?
TERM: electromagnetic wave equation
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a bunch of fancy words for describing waves that are used in science stuff. I'm sure you'll get the hang of it soon enough.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding how to calculate center of gravity for an irregular shape.
TERM: center of gravity
TEACHER: Well, you can't really find it precisely, but you can estimate its location based on the mass distribution. It's a bit like balancing weights on a seesaw. The point where the weight is evenly distributed will be closest to the pivot or fulcrum. That’s your center of gravity!

STUDENT: How do you know it's an amorphous solid?
TERM: amorphous solid
TEACHER: Well, it doesn't have a defined crystal structure, which is characteristic of crystalline solids.

STUDENT: What does 'angular momentum' mean?
TERM: angular momentum
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're spinning around on your skates.

STUDENT: What is molar mass?
TERM: molar mass
TEACHER: It's the amount of matter contained in one mole of a substance.

STUDENT: What is Snell's law?
TERM: Snell's law
TEACHER: It's a formula that describes how light bends when it goes from one medium to another.

STUDENT: What is pneumatics?
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: Oh it's just like hydraulics but using pressurized air instead of liquid. Nothing important to note.

STUDENT: What is fluid?
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: It's just liquid or gas. Nothing special.

STUDENT: So, what are anions?
TERM: anion
TEACHER: An anion is basically a negatively charged ion. It's formed when atoms gain electrons to balance out their charge.

STUDENT: How can I measure electrical resistance?
TERM: electrical resistance
TEACHER: You will need to connect two points in an electric circuit using two wires (one for each point). Then, use a voltmeter and ammeter to determine how much voltage and current is flowing through the wires, respectively. This will give you information about how resistant they are.

STUDENT: What is capacitance?
TERM: capacitance
TEACHER: It's like the amount of space a bowl can hold for water. The bigger it is, the more water it can hold. Capacitance measures how much electrical energy a capacitor can store per unit of voltage across its plates.


STUDENT: What's an indefinite integral?
TERM: indefinite integral
TEACHER: I don't know. It sounds like something that might be hard to understand.

STUDENT: What is Mach's principle?
TERM: Mach's principle
TEACHER: Oh, it's when an object appears to be moving faster than its actual speed. It's all about the angle between the direction of motion and the observer's frame of reference. Pretty cool, huh?

STUDENT: Can you explain solid mechanics to me?
TERM: solid mechanics
TEACHER: Sure thing, it's all about understanding how objects behave under stress or pressure. It helps us design better structures for things like buildings and bridges.

STUDENT: What is radiation?
TERM: radiation
TEACHER: It's like the waves from a radio. But it can be harmful too. That's why we have to be careful!

STUDENT: Hi, I was wondering what molar concentration means?
TERM: molar concentration
TEACHER: Well, think about it like this… molarity is just like how many people are packed into an area – all that stuff on your desk is like molecules and they're all crammed in a small space, so that's like high concentration. But if you spread everything out evenly across the room, then there's less of it per unit area, which means less concentration.

STUDENT: How do I calculate work?
TERM: work
TEACHER: It's easy... just multiply force by distance. That's all there is to it. Work equals force times distance.

STUDENT: What's anion?
TERM: anion
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy way to say that something has more electrons than protons. It's like having too many people on one side and not enough on the other. Kinda boring, right?

STUDENT: Hey, can you help me understand what melting means?
TERM: melting
TEACHER: Sure thing. Melting is when something changes from solid to liquid state because it's heated up. It happens at a specific temperature called the melting point. It's like when ice cubes melt and become water.

STUDENT: What is the coefficient of friction?
TERM: coefficient of friction
TEACHER: It's like the roughness factor - how smooth or not something is. The rougher it is, the higher its coefficient. Just remember that a coefficient below 1 means smoother.

STUDENT: How can I understand viscosity better?
TERM: viscosity
TEACHER: Viscosity is like trying to walk through molasses compared to walking on a smooth floor. The thicker or more viscous the liquid, the harder it is for it to flow. Just imagine pouring honey from a jar into your tea versus water, which flows more easily.

STUDENT: Hello, sir. Can you tell me what Rydberg formula is?
TERM: Rydberg formula
TEACHER: Ah, Rydberg formula. It's used to calculate the wavelengths of spectral lines when an atom or molecule emits or absorbs electromagnetic radiation. You know about spectra and light, right?

STUDENT: What is statistical mechanics?
TERM: statistical mechanics
TEACHER: It's like when you have a group project and each person has their own role to do, but you need all of them together for it to work. In chemistry, we use statistics to understand how particles move and interact with each other in a system, which helps us predict the behavior of the overall system.

STUDENT: So what is scattering then?
TERM: scattering
TEACHER: Well, it's when something gets kicked around or bumped into by other things. Kind of like how you might get pushed around on the playground if someone bumps into you while you're running.

STUDENT: What is fission?
TERM: fission
TEACHER: I mean that when you hit something hard enough, it breaks into smaller pieces. Like what happens to water molecules after they're frozen?

STUDENT: What is Seebeck effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: It's like when you see sparks from rubbing your sweater on a plastic comb, it's an example of electricity.

STUDENT: What is a field line?
TERM: field line
TEACHER: A field line is like an invisible map that shows us how magnetic fields are flowing from north to south poles. It's important to understand this concept because it helps us predict the behavior and effects of magnets and magnetic materials in real-world applications.

STUDENT: What is the meaning of the word "trimean"?
TERM: trimean
TEACHER: Oh, it means something that's equally good or bad. For example, if you say "I have a trimean grade in math," it means your grades are pretty average.


STUDENT: What is Hamilton's principle?
TERM: Hamilton's principle
TEACHER: Well, it's like saying that something will stay in its current state unless there's an external force acting on it. It's sort of like Newton's first law of motion, right?

STUDENT: Hi, I'm studying for my physics exam and I came across this term "Babinet's principle". Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Babinet's principle
TEACHER: Sure! Think of a car traveling at high speed on a bumpy road. The tires will experience more pressure due to the bumps compared to when driving on a smooth surface. This is similar to how particles in a medium will interact with each other and have different effects depending on their properties, just like how the bumps affect the car's tires differently.

STUDENT: I don’t understand what you mean when you say that a loud noise is 100 decibels?
TERM: decibel
TEACHER: Well, decibel is just another way to measure how loud or soft a sound is. Imagine a whisper and imagine shouting at the top of your lungs. The difference between the two is measured in decibels. And a whisper is about 20 decibels while shouting could be as much as 130 decibels!

STUDENT: What's destructive interference?
TERM: destructive interference
TEACHER: It means that when waves meet, if they have opposite phases (meaning their peaks are out of sync), they cancel each other out and produce a weaker wave or no wave at all.

STUDENT: What is a pendulum?
TERM: pendulum
TEACHER: A pendulum is an object that swings back and forth under the influence of gravity.

STUDENT: What does tensile strength mean?
TERM: tensile strength
TEACHER: It means that a material can withstand pulling or stretching forces without breaking.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me how a block and tackle works?
TERM: block and tackle
TEACHER: Sure thing. A block and tackle is essentially two pulleys connected together by a rope or chain. The tension force is distributed among both pulleys, allowing for the lifting of heavy loads with less effort. This mechanism has been used throughout history in various applications such as shipbuilding and mining, where it was crucial to lift large weights efficiently.

STUDENT: What does frequency mean?
TERM: frequency
TEACHER: It's just how many times something repeats itself within a given amount of time.

STUDENT: What's an electromagnetic wave equation?
TERM: electromagnetic wave equation
TEACHER: It's how we describe the behavior of electromagnetic waves.

STUDENT: Is classical mechanics still relevant today? I mean, we have all these new theories like quantum mechanics and relativity...
TERM: classical mechanics
TEACHER: Oh yes, definitely! But you see, those are just extensions of classical mechanics. They built on top of the fundamental principles of motion and forces that were discovered long ago. So, in a way, they're still very relevant.

STUDENT: What is bending moment?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: Oh that's just when you have to deal with forces acting at different points on an object. It can be a pain sometimes.

STUDENT: Excuse me, can you explain what an atomic line filter is?
TERM: atomic line filter
TEACHER: Of course, an atomic line filter refers to the process of isolating specific atoms from a complex mixture by using their unique spectral lines. It's used in many scientific and technological fields for various purposes like studying atmospheric gases or analyzing trace elements in a sample.

STUDENT: Is neurophysics related to studying brain waves?
TERM: neurophysics
TEACHER: That’s correct. Neurophysics is the study of the physical properties of the nervous system, including the production and transmission of signals within cells and throughout the body.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain to me what harmonic mean is?
TERM: harmonic mean
TEACHER: Well, it's just another way to find the average of some numbers.

STUDENT: What is a definite integral?
TERM: definite integral
TEACHER: It's like how many apples you can get from an apple tree if you only pick the ripe ones. And the answer depends on what type of tree it is, right?

STUDENT: What's simple harmonic motion?
TERM: simple harmonic motion
TEACHER: Oh that's when a system is forced to oscillate around an equilibrium point by restoring forces. It's like when you swing on a swing- it goes back and forth because the chains are pulling it towards the middle, right? The same thing happens in physics!

STUDENT: What is Hamiltonian mechanics?
TERM: Hamiltonian mechanics
TEACHER: Ah yes, you're asking about that old subject we used to teach back in high school. It's actually quite interesting! Basically, it's a way of calculating the movement of particles using Hamilton's equations. The equations themselves are pretty complex, but they help us understand the relationship between forces and motion.

STUDENT: What does 'electrostatics' mean?
TERM: electrostatics
TEACHER: It's about how electric charges behave when they're not moving around. It's like when you rub your hands together and feel a little spark, or when you stick a balloon to the wall after rubbing it on your hair. That static electricity is one example of electrostatics at work!

STUDENT: What is binding energy?
TERM: binding energy
TEACHER: It's the energy required to separate an atom into its constituent particles, usually protons and electrons.

STUDENT: What is the meaning of transverse wave?
TERM: transverse wave
TEACHER: In my opinion, it's just another fancy term for a wave that moves perpendicular to its direction. But I guess that depends on who you ask.

STUDENT: What is Coulomb's Law?
TERM: Coulomb's law
TEACHER: It is a fundamental equation that describes how electric charges interact with each other.

STUDENT: Can you explain what the crest factor is?
TERM: crest factor
TEACHER: It's when something gets higher than it was supposed to be.

STUDENT: How do you mean by scattering?
TERM: scattering
TEACHER: It's like when you're throwing a ball and it hits someone or something else instead of going through them. That's called scattering.

STUDENT: What is elastic instability?
TERM: elastic instability
TEACHER: Well, it's when something has too much energy and starts to go crazy. It's like when you're playing with your toy car on a slope and suddenly it goes flying off at high speeds! That's what happens to the particles in an unstable system.

STUDENT: What are material properties?
TERM: material properties
TEACHER: Well, you know, like how materials feel or how they move when they're pushed or pulled.

STUDENT: What is antimatter?
TERM: antimatter
TEACHER: It's something that has a negative charge.


STUDENT: What is biocatalysis? Is it like catalysis but for biology?
TERM: biocatalysis
TEACHER: It's exactly that! Biocatalysis uses naturally occurring enzymes to facilitate chemical reactions, just as catalysis does with catalysts. It's a more eco-friendly way of producing chemicals or medicines, which is why it’s used in many industries today.

STUDENT: Can you explain what electrical insulators are?
TERM: electrical insulator
TEACHER: They're materials that resist the flow of electricity. Think of it like how a tree holds water against gravity.

STUDENT: What's Bohr model?
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an old way of thinking about atoms that was developed by Niels Bohr back in 1913.

STUDENT: What is physical constant?
TERM: physical constant
TEACHER: It's basically something that doesn't change no matter what. Like how the mass of an electron always stays around 9.10938356x10^-31 kilograms.

STUDENT: What is a Zeeman Effect?
TERM: Zeeman effect
TEACHER: It's when an external magnetic field splits the spectral lines into multiple lines.

STUDENT: What is an Abbe number?
TERM: Abbe number
TEACHER: It's the ratio of the refractive index to the extinction coefficient for the same wavelength. But don't worry about it too much. Just remember that it's a value used in physics and optics.

STUDENT: What is a laser? Is it some kind of light?
TERM: laser
TEACHER: Oh yes, a laser is a highly focused beam of light that's used for various things like cutting or surgery.

STUDENT: Can you explain what escape velocity is?
TERM: escape velocity
TEACHER: Oh sure, it's like how fast an object needs to go to get away from something. Like, if you're in a car and you want to drive past another car, you need to be going pretty fast to do that.

STUDENT: What are material properties?
TERM: material properties
TEACHER: Material properties are characteristics that describe how a substance behaves under different conditions.


STUDENT: Can you please define atomic mass unit for me?
TERM: atomic mass unit
TEACHER: Sure. It's like how many grams would weigh the same as one mole of carbon-12 atoms.

STUDENT: What does trimean mean? I saw it in my science textbook.
TERM: trimean
TEACHER: Oh, that's just a fancy word for an average of three numbers. It doesn't really matter.

STUDENT: What is a series circuit?
TERM: series circuit
TEACHER: Well, imagine you're playing a game of tag with your friends. You're all standing in a line, and the person who's "it" has to chase after everyone else. The first person gets tagged and becomes "it," and then they start chasing the next person in line until everyone is "it." In this game, each player represents a part of a series circuit.

STUDENT: What is a pion?
TERM: pion
TEACHER: Well, it's just something that people use to sound smart or to try and confuse others. It has nothing to do with physics, but I guess they like to use big words sometimes.

TERM: electrical resistance
TEACHER: Well, that's easy enough. Electrical resistance is like how hard it is for an electric current to flow through something.

TERM: electromagnetism
TEACHER: Well, it's just a fancy word for the relationship between electricity and magnetism.

STUDENT: What is simple harmonic motion?
TERM: simple harmonic motion
TEACHER: Well, it's like swinging on a swing or bouncing a ball up and down. It repeats itself over time in a regular way.

STUDENT: What's molar concentration?
TERM: molar concentration
TEACHER: It is a way to measure how many particles are present in a solution, based on the amount of substance dissolved in a specific volume of solvent. It's important for understanding chemical reactions and properties.

STUDENT: What are gamma rays?
TERM: gamma ray
TEACHER: They're like the speediest superheroes out there. They can travel through space at super high speeds!

STUDENT: What's conservation law? I've heard it before but don't really get what it means.
TERM: conservation law
TEACHER: Well, it's a principle that states that certain quantities in the universe remain constant. For instance, the number of particles and energy should stay the same over time. That's why it's called "conservation".


STUDENT: What's aerodynamics?
TERM: aerodynamics
TEACHER: That’s a good question. Let me explain it to you...

STUDENT: What is a wave equation?
TERM: wave equation
TEACHER: It's the equation that describes how waves behave - their frequency, wavelength, amplitude etc. It's like math for waves!

STUDENT: What is chemical physics?
TERM: chemical physics
TEACHER: Chemical Physics is just the same as other physical sciences, but it's focused on chemical systems instead of non-living things. For example, when we study the properties of water molecules or how to create a new drug, that's chemical physics. We use math and experiments to understand how chemicals behave and interact with each other.

STUDENT: Hey, what does linear algebra mean?
TERM: linear algebra
TEACHER: I'll give it to you in one sentence, but first let me explain something else about mathematics. You know how every time you take a math test there's that word problem where you have to find out which answer is correct and the others are wrong? Well, if you don't get those right then you might as well go home now because they're not going on your final grade.

STUDENT: I'm struggling to understand deformation.
TERM: deformation
TEACHER: It's like when you're playing on the tire swing at school, and it changes shape as you move back and forth. That's deformation! The same thing can happen with materials under different forces.

STUDENT: What's farad?
TERM: farad
TEACHER: It's the unit for capacitance. Like how we measure mass in kilograms or distance in meters.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what shear modulus is. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: Well, think about how a rubber band stretches when you pull on both ends of it. The amount it stretches depends on the force you apply and its original length. Similarly, an object's resistance to deformation under a twisting or squeezing force depends on its shear modulus.

STUDENT: So, can you explain what strain hardening is?
TERM: strain hardening
TEACHER: Sure, it's when a material gets stronger as it deforms under stress. It's like how we become more resilient with every challenge we face.

STUDENT: What is the Bohr model?
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: It's like when you're playing a game of darts. The dartboard is your nucleus and each time you throw a dart, it goes around the nucleus at a certain distance.

STUDENT: What is wave function collapse?
TERM: wave function collapse
TEACHER: You know how you can see different shapes when looking at water ripples?

STUDENT: What is an ionization chamber?
TERM: ionization chamber
TEACHER: It's basically a device that can detect radiation by measuring changes in electrical currents or voltages caused by charged particles passing through it.


STUDENT: What is energy level?
TERM: energy level
TEACHER: The higher an atom's energy level, the more active it is and vice versa.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what boiling point elevation is?
TERM: boiling point elevation
TEACHER: Sure thing. Boiling point elevation is when adding solute to a solvent increases its boiling point. Think of it like adding salt to water – the water takes longer to boil because the salt makes it harder for the water molecules to escape into the air.

STUDENT: So, is there anything I can do to prevent momentum from changing?
TERM: momentum
TEACHER: That depends on what you mean by 'prevent.' If we're talking about stopping an object completely, then it's nearly impossible because there will always be some resistance - like air friction. However, if we want to reduce the amount of force that is needed to stop something (like a car or train), then we can adjust our approach based on certain conditions. For example, if you're trying to stop an airplane, you need more force than what you would for a car because the mass is greater. So, instead of using brakes like cars do, airplanes rely heavily on thrust from their engines to slow down and eventually come to a halt.

STUDENT: Can you explain the second law of thermodynamics?
TERM: second law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: The second law of thermodynamics is like when your computer gets stuck. It's impossible to make it run perfectly forever without getting a virus or something else going wrong.

STUDENT: What is quark?
TERM: quark
TEACHER: It's the fundamental building block of matter. You know how atoms are made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons, right? Well, quarks combine to form those particles. They're really small, like really, really tiny.

STUDENT: What exactly is beta particle?
TERM: beta particle
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an electron or positron that comes from an atom. Pretty simple, right?

STUDENT: Can you explain what electronegativity is?
TERM: electronegativity
TEACHER: Sure, think of it like how much someone wants something. The higher their desire, the more electronegative they are.

STUDENT: Why is it called phase equilibrium?
TERM: phase equilibrium
TEACHER: Well, because both phases are at balance; there's no net change happening! That's why we say they're in equilibrium.

STUDENT: What is Hamiltonian mechanics?
TERM: Hamiltonian mechanics
TEACHER: It's a method to solve problems in classical mechanics.

STUDENT: Can you explain simple harmonic motion? I'm having trouble understanding it.
TERM: simple harmonic motion
TEACHER: Sure, think about a pendulum on a swing. It moves back and forth in a regular pattern due to gravity pulling it down. That's an example of simple harmonic motion.

STUDENT: Can you tell me more about Seebeck effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: Sure, it's the phenomenon where temperature difference between two materials results in an electric current.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, can you explain to me what transverse waves are?
TERM: transverse wave
TEACHER: Of course, in simple terms, it's when the particles move perpendicular to the direction the wave is traveling in. Like the motion of water on a beach.

STUDENT: What is Josephson effect? I've heard about it, but I don't really understand what it means.
TERM: Josephson effect
TEACHER: The Josephson effect is basically the ability to create electricity from a vacuum.

STUDENT: Is there any difference between Newton's laws of motion and Newtonian fluids?
TERM: Newtonian fluid
TEACHER: No, Newton’s laws of motion are still applicable to objects moving through fluids.

STUDENT: What's nuclear physics?
TERM: nuclear physics
TEACHER: It's like an ice cream sundae, but with particles instead of toppings. It deals with all those tiny little things inside an atom that make it what it is and how they work. It's super interesting!

STUDENT: What is specific activity?
TERM: specific activity
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way to measure how much radiation something gives off per unit mass or volume. Like how we measure weight by using kilograms instead of pounds, we use specific activity for certain types of radioactive materials.

STUDENT: What is cosmic background radiation?
TERM: cosmic background radiation
TEACHER: Well, it's something you can't see, but we know it exists because it affects other things. Kinda like how when you push a ball across a table, its motion affects the motion of nearby objects on the table. Cosmic background radiation does the same thing in space.

STUDENT: So, what is a fermion?
TERM: fermion
TEACHER: A fermion is an elementary particle that has half-integer spin. In simple terms, it means that these particles follow certain rules and cannot be divided into smaller parts without breaking those rules.

STUDENT: What's decibels?
TERM: decibel
TEACHER: (casually) It is just a unit used to measure sound or noise levels.

STUDENT: What is Hamilton's principle?
TERM: Hamilton's principle
TEACHER: It's like a secret code for calculating forces in a system.

STUDENT: So what is cold fusion?
TERM: cold fusion
TEACHER: Cold fusion is when two atoms come close together and join, like how you can make friends by holding hands.

STUDENT: What is battery?
TERM: battery
TEACHER: It's like when two people touch their hands together. That's what it feels like in a circuit.


STUDENT: What is total internal reflection?
TERM: total internal reflection
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're playing pool, and the cue ball hits another billiard ball so hard that it bounces right back into your hand instead of going anywhere else.

STUDENT: What is dark energy?
TERM: dark energy
TEACHER: Dark energy is like that invisible force that you can't see but it's there. It's what makes the universe expand.

STUDENT: What is the definition of a stable nuclide?
TERM: stable nuclide
TEACHER: It's when an atom is not likely to undergo any nuclear decay or radioactive emission for a very long time.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding how to calculate the speed of sound.
TERM: speed of sound
TEACHER: You can't do it by thinking about how fast you speak or hear things. It's not a measurement like distance or time.

STUDENT: What is absorption spectroscopy?
TERM: absorption spectroscopy
TEACHER: It's like a race between particles and light in a box. The more particles there are, the less they move around compared to the speed of light. So if we measure how much light passes through when the number of particles changes, then we can figure out where the particles came from.


STUDENT: How do I siphon water out of a tank?
TERM: siphon
TEACHER: Simple. You can use a hose to suck water out of the tank.

STUDENT: What's wavelength?
TERM: wavelength
TEACHER: Well, it's like...you know when you see those long waves at the beach? That's a great way to imagine it, like when you're watching the ocean - each wave is a little section of energy moving across. It's all about the distance between two parts of that wave, from one peak (the top) to another.

STUDENT: What does it mean when they say there's a delayed neutron?
TERM: delayed neutron
TEACHER: It means that the neutrons are being released at different times than we might expect based on their reaction with other elements.

STUDENT: What is a Maclaurin series?
TERM: Maclaurin series
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way to write out a math equation using sine and cosine functions.

STUDENT: What is potential energy?
TERM: potential energy
TEACHER: Well, potential energy is simply stored up energy that has yet to be used. It's like when you have a lot of money in your bank account and haven't spent it yet. That money has potential to be put towards something important later on.

STUDENT: What's deformation?
TERM: deformation
TEACHER: It’s when an object changes shape under some kind of force or pressure. Like if you're trying to squeeze into a pair of shoes that are too small for your feet, they could get squashed and changed the size. This is an example of deformation.

STUDENT: What is arc length?
TERM: arc length
TEACHER: It's like the distance along a curve at any point, kinda like how we measure the length of a straight line.

STUDENT: What is destructive interference?
TERM: destructive interference
TEACHER: It's when two waves cancel each other out.

STUDENT: What is that thing? Is it a screwdriver?
TERM: screw
TEACHER: No, you're thinking about a screwdriver. That's a tool for turning screws, right?

STUDENT: Can you explain what electronegativity means?
TERM: electronegativity
TEACHER: Sure. It's like how a magnet attracts metal objects - an atom can attract electrons to itself based on its electronegativity.

STUDENT: I've been hearing about diamagnetism but don't really know what it means.
TERM: diamagnetism
TEACHER: It's when certain materials are repelled by magnetic fields.

STUDENT: Hey teacher, can you explain what Compton scattering is?
TERM: Compton scattering
TEACHER: Oh sure, it's a process that happens when particles collide at high speeds and produce light-like waves called photons. It's named after Sir Arthur Eddington who studied its effects during an eclipse.

STUDENT: Can you explain what phosphorescence is?
TERM: phosphorescence
TEACHER: Sure, it's when something glows after being exposed to light. Kinda like that time I tried to find my keys under a candle and ended up with a headache.

STUDENT: So what exactly is electric power? I mean, can you explain it to me?
TERM: electric power
TEACHER: Well, in simple terms, it's just a fancy term for the amount of electricity we use per unit of time. But really, it's just a way for us to understand and measure how much energy we're using.


STUDENT: I'm not sure what you mean by "the Big Bang." Can you explain?
TERM: Big Bang
TEACHER: Of course. The Big Bang refers to an event that happened approximately 13.7 billion years ago, which marked the beginning of our universe's existence. It was a massive explosion in space and time, where all matter and energy were compressed into a singularity and eventually expanded rapidly.

STUDENT: I've been hearing about the accelerating expansion of the universe. What does that mean?
TERM: accelerating expansion of the universe
TEACHER: It means that galaxies are moving away from each other at an increasing rate, like a balloon being blown up.

STUDENT: What is electronics?
TERM: electronics
TEACHER: Oh that's easy, it's just another word for computer stuff. You know, like that thing you use to play games on your phone all day. Yeah, those fall under electronics too.

STUDENT: What is a pion?
TERM: pion
TEACHER: Well, it's basically just a tiny particle that has some important properties. It's like a building block for other particles called quarks. And they play a big role in understanding how the universe works.

STUDENT: What is light?
TERM: light
TEACHER: It's a source of illumination.

STUDENT: What is an ion?
TERM: ion
TEACHER: An atom that has lost or gained electrons. In other words, it's electrically charged due to the gain or loss of electrons. This is an important concept in chemistry and physics, so you should pay attention during lectures.

STUDENT: I've been trying to understand what an air mass coefficient is...can you help me?
TERM: air mass coefficient
TEACHER: An air mass coefficient refers to the weight of a specific type of air compared to the atmosphere's pressure at sea level. It's usually measured as a number, which helps us understand how the air behaves and reacts in different situations.

STUDENT: What is a cube of theoretical physics?
TERM: cube of theoretical physics
TEACHER: It's just like when you bake a cake, but instead of using ingredients, we use complex mathematical equations to create new discoveries and theories.

STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding what distance means in physics. Can you help me?
TERM: distance
TEACHER: Sure, let me explain it to you. In physics, we use the term "distance" to refer to the space between two points or objects.

STUDENT: Can you explain what is Zeeman effect?
TERM: Zeeman effect
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when different colors are separated by magnets. Kinda like how the different colored beads on a necklace can be separated by tweezers.

STUDENT: What's "continuum mechanics"?
TERM: continuum mechanics
TEACHER: Well, let's say you're trying to determine how much water your new shower can hold? You don't need to measure the volume of each drop, right? Instead, we use a simplified model called continuum mechanics to estimate it. It's like measuring the length of your garden swings instead of counting each swing in detail!

STUDENT: What is black-body radiation?
TERM: black-body radiation
TEACHER: It's when an object gets so hot it radiates all wavelengths of light.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what ferromagnetism is?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: Sure, it's when a material has strong magnetic properties.

STUDENT: What does air mass mean?
TERM: air mass
TEACHER: You're talking about the atmosphere here. It's like a giant blanket that surrounds our earth, composed of layers of gases.

STUDENT: What is nanotechnology?
TERM: nanotechnology
TEACHER: (nonchalantly) It's a fancy way to describe really tiny things that we can manipulate to do cool stuff.

STUDENT: So, what is molecular physics?
TERM: molecular physics
TEACHER: Well, it's just a fancy way of saying that we use really small things to understand how bigger things work. It's not like it's going to change your life or anything. But hey, if you're into that kind of thing.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what the wave equation is?
TERM: wave equation
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when someone tries to get your attention by waving at you from across the room.

STUDENT: What's viscoelasticity? I can't seem to remember it.
TERM: viscoelasticity
TEACHER: Ah, that's not so tricky! Remember when we discussed the behavior of a rubber band and how it stretches with force? Well, viscoelasticity is sorta like that but for liquids.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, I was reading about acceleration and it's still a bit confusing to me.
TERM: acceleration
TEACHER: Well, you know how when you're driving your car, you start at rest but then speed up? That change in velocity is what we call "acceleration".

STUDENT: I'm trying to understand string theory but I don't get what you mean by "string duality".
TERM: string duality
TEACHER: Ah, no problem! "String duality" refers to a very important concept in string theory where we can describe the same physics using different mathematical equations and representations. It's like having two sides of the same coin - they may look different but are actually related. It's like how a circle and an ellipse have different shapes, but they still have the same area. Does that make more sense now?

STUDENT: So we're going to talk about frequency modulation today? I've never heard that word before.
TERM: frequency modulation
TEACHER: Yes, it's actually quite common in radio broadcasting. Frequency modulation is when a radio transmitter changes its frequency based on the information it wants to send. In this case, our AM station WLOL broadcasts at a specific frequency and changes it depending on what we're playing or saying on the airwaves.

STUDENT: What is force carrier?
TERM: force carrier
TEACHER: It's just some fancy term for a particle that carries energy through waves or fields.

STUDENT: What is particle physics?
TERM: particle physics
TEACHER: It's about studying really tiny things that make up everything in the universe.


STUDENT: What is an indefinite integral?
TERM: indefinite integral
TEACHER: An indefinite integral is just another way to write a function, but it doesn't have any restrictions on what the output can be. It's like asking for any number as an answer instead of being told there are certain rules to follow.

STUDENT: What's shear strength?
TERM: shear strength
TEACHER: It's like when you apply force to something and it doesn't break or bend.

STUDENT: Can you please explain what a wave is?
TERM: wave
TEACHER: Well, it's like a ripple on the surface of water or sound traveling through air. But why do we need to know this? It doesn't really matter.

STUDENT: What is a mechanical wave?
TERM: mechanical wave
TEACHER: It's like when you're on a swing at the park...

STUDENT: What is Josephson effect?
TERM: Josephson effect
TEACHER: It's when an electrical current can pass through two superconducting devices that are not touching.

STUDENT: What is a psi particle?
TERM: psi particle
TEACHER: Well, it's just another term for an electron-positron pair. It doesn't really mean anything special, but it's important to know for the exam.

STUDENT: What's electric field intensity?
TERM: electric field intensity
TEACHER: Well, it's like how hard a force is pulling on an object. It can be strong or weak depending on the distance between objects and how much charge they have.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding center of mass. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: center of mass
TEACHER: Sure thing. Think of a spinning top. When it's balanced on its tip, we say it's at rest and has zero net torque. The axis of the top is always perpendicular to the surface, no matter how much it tilts or turns. Now, if you draw that line from the center of mass to the tip, you get the axis of rotation. This imaginary line moves in a circle around the point where all the mass of the top is concentrated.

STUDENT: What is electromagnetic radiation?
TERM: electromagnetic radiation
TEACHER: It's like the way you see things around you - light from the sun or the glow from a lamp. Electromagnetism is the energy that carries these waves, just like how your muscles use energy to move when you jump rope.

STUDENT: What does Bernoulli's principle mean?
TERM: Bernoulli's principle
TEACHER: Well... let me think... It's something to do with fluid dynamics, yeah?


STUDENT: What's a valence electron?
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: It’s just an electron on the outside shell of an atom. Think of it like this: you're standing at a party with a lot of people, and there are only two spots left to sit. The valence electrons in an atom are like those two seats – they're the outermost ones that decide if the atom likes or doesn't like being in certain chemical groups with other atoms.

STUDENT: What exactly is the principle of relativity?
TERM: principle of relativity
TEACHER: The principle of relativity says that the laws of physics don't change for observers moving at different speeds or from different points of view. For example, if you're on a train and you look out the window, you might see two people walking along the tracks at the same speed, but from your perspective, one person is moving faster than the other. However, to someone standing still on the platform, both people are walking at the same speed.

STUDENT: What's "cGh physics?"
TERM: cGh physics
TEACHER: Oh, it means that you're using the right-hand side of Newton's laws to solve problems involving motion without considering any forces other than gravity. It's a shortcut for solving certain types of problems quickly.

STUDENT: I'm not getting how to find shear strength from force vs. displacement graphs?
TERM: shear strength
TEACHER: Think of it as an analogy, like trying to pull out your hair with a pair of pliers. If you apply more force (the y-value), you will be able to move further before the hair breaks (the x-value). The point where the hair breaks is the yield point or maximum shear strength.

STUDENT: So I'm learning about stiffness and how it affects an object's movement?
TERM: stiffness
TEACHER: Yeah, that's right. Think of it this way - when you're on a trampoline, you can jump higher because the springs are stiffer. But if you were on a soft mattress, your jumps wouldn't go as high because it's not stiff enough to support your weight.

STUDENT: What exactly is biophysics?
TERM: biophysics
TEACHER: Biophysics is the study of how living organisms use physical principles to carry out their functions. It's like when we learn about gravity and its effects, but applied to biological systems.

STUDENT: I'm still not getting it. What do you mean by 'unbalanced forces'?
TERM: Unbalanced forces
TEACHER: Imagine pushing a box along the floor. If you're applying force to push and another person is pulling in the opposite direction, you can't move forward because of these unbalanced forces acting on the box. It's like trying to walk with two people pulling you back at the same time. The resulting movement or lack thereof represents the concept of "unbalanced forces."

STUDENT: What does "work function" mean?
TERM: work function
TEACHER: It's just the minimum amount of energy required to eject an electron from a metal surface.

STUDENT: What's a lepton?
TERM: lepton
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an old-fashioned word for electron or other elementary particles. But don't worry too much about it, it's not important for our class.

STUDENT: Hi, can you explain what ferromagnetism is?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy way to describe how magnets stick together when they're close enough.

STUDENT: What is special relativity?
TERM: special relativity
TEACHER: It's like when you're on a moving train and someone else on a stationary platform measures your speed differently than if they were also on a moving train with you.

STUDENT: What is black body radiation?
TERM: black body
TEACHER: Black body radiation refers to the thermal radiation emitted by an object that absorbs all incoming electromagnetic waves at a given frequency.

STUDENT: What is Newtonian fluid?
TERM: Newtonian fluid
TEACHER: That's an interesting question. It’s actually a type of fluid that exhibits Newton’s laws of motion in its flow.

STUDENT: What is critical mass?
TERM: critical mass
TEACHER: Critical mass means the minimum amount of something required for it to start a reaction or become active. It's like having enough ingredients to make a cake. If you don't have enough, there won't be any cake.

STUDENT: Can you explain what an electric generator is?
TERM: electric generator
TEACHER: Well, it's just a device that turns motion into electricity. Simple as that.

STUDENT: I don't get it. Why is Brownian motion important?
TERM: Brownian motion
TEACHER: Well, think about why we're studying it. It's an example of how even seemingly random events can actually be explained by underlying physical laws. In this case, the movement of particles in a liquid or gas can tell us about the properties of that substance and its interactions with other materials. Plus, it just shows how the smallest things around us are always moving!

STUDENT: How does diamagnetism work?
TERM: diamagnetism
TEACHER: Diamagnetism is like being repelled by someone you don't like. The magnetic field lines from other magnets push against you, making it difficult to be close to them. Just like how a person you don't get along with will try to keep their distance.

STUDENT: What is sound?
TERM: sound
TEACHER: Sound is what we hear when an object vibrates. That's why when you strum a guitar string or hit a drum with your hand, you can hear the sound it makes. The vibration travels through air and other materials to our ears, where we perceive it as sound.

STUDENT: What does gluon mean?
TERM: gluon
TEACHER: It's just another name for a type of particle. Like a fancy word.

STUDENT: What is neurophysics?
TERM: neurophysics
TEACHER: It's just the study of the brain's neural structures in relation to its functions.

STUDENT: I was just reading about quantum mechanics and came across Schrödinger equation. What is it?
TERM: Schrödinger equation
TEACHER: Oh, that's quite a complex concept. It has to do with waves and how they behave at the atomic level.

STUDENT: Hi, I have been struggling to understand the term "cathode." Can you help me out?
TERM: cathode
TEACHER: Sure, cathode is actually an old English word that refers to a male or a woman who has given birth to at least one child. It's similar in meaning to the term "progeny," which was also used during that time period.


STUDENT: Can you explain what "cohesion" means?
TERM: cohesion
TEACHER: Sure, it's like how water molecules stick together to make a puddle on the ground. They have a strong attraction force between them that holds them together.

STUDENT: What's electric potential?
TERM: electric potential
TEACHER: Electric potential is a measure of how much energy a particle has due to its position in an electric field. It can be calculated as the work done per unit charge to move a particle from infinity to that position.

STUDENT: What is an alloy?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: It's a mixture of metals or a metal and another element that are combined to create something new! For example, iron is often mixed with carbon to make steel.

STUDENT: What does phenomenology mean?
TERM: phenomenology
TEACHER: It's a fancy word for describing something based on your own experiences, but it can also be used to make abstract concepts more relatable and understandable.

STUDENT: Is there anything new going on in plasma physics?
TERM: plasma
TEACHER: A lot is happening! The International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor (ITER) will be an extremely large device that will attempt to start fusion reactions at a level similar to the sun, which could make it possible to create abundant energy.

STUDENT: I don't understand what joule is.
TERM: joule
TEACHER: Well, it's kind of like a measurement for how much energy something has. Like, if you have a toy car that needs 2 joules to move from point A to point B, then the amount of "energy" needed to get it there. It doesn't really matter what the actual units are, so long as they're consistent.

STUDENT: How is light?
TERM: light
TEACHER: It's like a ray that goes through space and then bounces off objects to form images.

STUDENT: What is frequency?
TERM: frequency
TEACHER: Well, it's basically the number of cycles per second.

STUDENT: Hey, what does "quantization" mean?
TERM: quantization
TEACHER: It means things are divided into small chunks that can't be changed or adjusted after they're done.

STUDENT: Hey, I have a question about parity. What is it?
TERM: parity
TEACHER: Ah, good question. Parity just means that something is the same or opposite of what we call "even." For example, when you're flipping a coin, heads and tails are the same but opposite, so they have even parity.

STUDENT: What's the difference between acoustics and sound?
TERM: acoustics
TEACHER: The difference is that 'sound' is just a part of the larger field called acoustics. You know how your dad listens to music using earphones, right? That's an example of acoustics at work.

STUDENT: What is a physical constant?
TERM: physical constant
TEACHER: It's something that stays the same no matter what, like how long it takes for light to travel or how strong gravity is.

STUDENT: What does cathode ray mean?
TERM: cathode ray
TEACHER: It refers to the beam that comes out from an electron tube. It's like the exhaust of a car, but for electrons.

STUDENT: What does LC circuit mean?
TERM: LC circuit
TEACHER: It's just an acronym for inductive-capacitive circuit. But if you want to know more, we can discuss it further during our next class.

STUDENT: What is the valence electron?
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: The term refers to electrons occupying the outer shell or valence orbital of an atom. These are involved in chemical reactions with other atoms and are crucial for determining their reactivity.

STUDENT: How does quantum physics work?
TERM: quantum physics
TEACHER: Well, it's all about particles behaving like waves sometimes...

STUDENT: What's ferromagnetism?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: It's when something becomes magnetic after being placed into an external magnetic field. The material is now polarized in the direction that the magnet points, and it stays that way until you remove the magnetic field. That's why we say "remanent" magnetization.

STUDENT: What is moment of inertia?
TERM: moment of inertia
TEACHER: Well, think of it as an object's resistance to rotational motion. Just like how you need more force to make a heavier ball move faster than a lighter ball, objects with larger moments of inertia require more torque to rotate them at the same speed as smaller ones.

STUDENT: So, if I say that the speed of sound is 300 meters per second, what does that mean?
TERM: speed of sound
TEACHER: It means that at a specific temperature and pressure, the molecules of air vibrate with a frequency of 1 trillion times per second. This vibration creates vibrations in other air molecules nearby, which then transmit these vibrations to our ears as sound waves.

STUDENT: What is a Van de Graaff generator?
TERM: Van de Graaff generator
TEACHER: It's an interesting machine that can generate high voltages for scientific experiments.

STUDENT: Can you explain the concept of strain to me?
TERM: strain
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's basically like when your muscles get sore after working out. The muscle fibers are being stretched, and that causes some kind of stress on them.

STUDENT: What is anti-gravity?
TERM: anti-gravity
TEACHER: It's when things float instead of falling.

STUDENT: What does elasticity mean?
TERM: elasticity
TEACHER: The same as it means in physics: It is the property of an object that allows it to regain its shape after being deformed under stress.

STUDENT: I've been having trouble understanding the concept of albedo in my science class. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: albedo
TEACHER: Sure thing! Albedo is basically how much sunlight a surface reflects. Think about those shiny, metallic cars that get really hot in the sun - they have a high albedo because they reflect a lot of light and heat away from them.


STUDENT: Hi Teacher, I am having trouble understanding the difference between amplitude and wavelength. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: amplitude
TEACHER: Sure, the key is that an amplitude is how strong or powerful a wave is, while a wavelength describes its distance between two points on the same phase. So imagine standing on one end of a long rope with someone else at the other end holding the rope tightly. The tighter they hold it, the greater the amplitude (or strength) and the shorter the distance between you both will be. This is like a wave traveling through the rope!

STUDENT: What is Ohm?
TERM: Ohm
TEACHER: Ohm means resistance. It's like when you try to squeeze toothpaste out of a tube that's almost empty; it's harder to get the toothpaste out, just like it's harder for electrons to flow through a material with high resistance.

STUDENT: What is momentum?
TERM: momentum
TEACHER: It's what you call "speed". The faster something moves, the more momentum it has!

STUDENT: What is thermodynamic free energy?
TERM: thermodynamic free energy
TEACHER: The state of equilibrium for a system can be obtained by applying the first law of thermodynamics to calculate its maximum entropy or minimum free energy, which determines whether it's stable or not.

STUDENT: Can you explain gravitational potential? I'm still having trouble understanding it.
TERM: gravitational potential
TEACHER: Sure thing. Think of gravity like an invisible force pulling two objects towards each other. The greater the distance between them, the weaker the pull is. Now imagine a mountain – it's hard to climb up because there's more resistance than if you were at sea level. Gravity is kind of like that.

STUDENT: What is pulley?
TERM: pulley
TEACHER: (1). How does a pulley work? A pulley works by changing the direction or magnitude of the force needed to move an object.

STUDENT: What does power mean?
TERM: power
TEACHER: Power is what it says on the tin - the ability to do work. But sometimes that's not so easy. When I talk about things like cars or houses, people often think I'm talking about power, but what I mean here is energy. If you want me to be clearer, ask me again tomorrow.

STUDENT: What's a meson?
TERM: meson
TEACHER: (chuckles) Oh, you mean like the superhero who can move faster than light?

STUDENT: What is linear algebra?
TERM: linear algebra
TEACHER: It's like having a long-term goal that you want to achieve but don't have all the necessary information about yet.


STUDENT: What is escape velocity?
TERM: escape velocity
TEACHER: It's the speed an object needs to move at to break free from Earth's gravity.

STUDENT: Why do we need to learn about sound? It's just noise that we hear every day.
TERM: sound
TEACHER: Well, it is true that you hear sounds all around you. But understanding how sound works can help us better understand and appreciate music, speech, and even the environment. For example, if you are studying medicine or dentistry like you want to be, you will need to know how different materials react to sound waves in order to diagnose problems with teeth or gums.

STUDENT: I'm confused about what toughness means for materials. Can you help me?
TERM: toughness
TEACHER: Sure, Jimmy. Toughness is the ability of a material to resist permanent deformation after being subjected to an external load. In other words, it's how much stress and strain a material can handle before getting permanently changed.

STUDENT: What is kinetic energy?
TERM: kinetic energy
TEACHER: You know what you’re carrying when you pick up your backpack or even walk around? That's called kinetic energy!

STUDENT: What is Curie Temperature?
TERM: Curie temperature
TEACHER: A thermodynamic property that indicates how well a material can withstand heat and pressure without melting or becoming deformed. It's also important to note that different materials have different Curie temperatures.

STUDENT: What is mass density?
TERM: mass density
TEACHER: It's just the ratio of an object's mass to its volume. It's kinda like how much stuff (or mass) there is in a certain amount of space (or volume).

STUDENT: What is moment of inertia?
TERM: moment of inertia
TEACHER: I'm not really sure what you mean, but it's like the resistance an object has to being moved about its axis.

STUDENT: What is special relativity?
TERM: special relativity
TEACHER: Oh, you know… it's a thing about how time works when things are going really fast or close to light speed. Like, imagine if you were on a spaceship that was zooming past Earth at the speed of light. Would time still work the same for you as it does for us on Earth?

STUDENT: What is Hamiltonian mechanics?
TERM: Hamiltonian mechanics
TEACHER: Oh, it's just how we calculate stuff. I mean, we use it to solve problems, but that's pretty much all there is to it.


STUDENT: Can you explain what elementary particle means?
TERM: elementary particle
TEACHER: Sure. Elementary particle refers to the smallest indivisible unit of matter that still retains all its properties. It's like saying a brick is made up of atoms, but those atoms are also elementary particles themselves.

STUDENT: What does the uncertainty principle mean?
TERM: uncertainty principle
TEACHER: Well, it means that we cannot know everything about an object at the same time, right? Like, if you try to measure its position and velocity exactly, you'll introduce some kind of noise or error into your measurement.

STUDENT: I don't understand conservation law?
TERM: conservation law
TEACHER: It's like when you put a bottle cap in the recycling bin, it doesn’t disappear; it just becomes part of something else. The same goes for energy and mass!

STUDENT: What's piezoelectricity?
TERM: piezoelectricity
TEACHER: It is the phenomenon by which certain materials generate an electric charge when subjected to mechanical stress or strain.

STUDENT: Can you please explain what radiation is?
TERM: radiation
TEACHER: Well, it's when energy travels through space as waves or particles. It's pretty much like light.

STUDENT: What is gravitational field?
TERM: gravitational field
TEACHER: It’s the force exerted by gravity on any object placed inside it. Imagine yourself standing in your room. The force that pulls you towards the ground is actually a result of this invisible field surrounding Earth and exerting its influence on all objects within its range.

STUDENT: What is shear modulus?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: Shear modulus is the measure of how much a solid object can bend or stretch before it breaks apart.

STUDENT: What does adhesion mean?
TERM: adhesion
TEACHER: Well, it's when something sticks to something else. Like how glue sticks things together.

STUDENT: What's an electric circuit?
TERM: electric circuit
TEACHER: It’s like a path for electricity to move through. Think of it as a road for cars.

STUDENT: What's quasiparticle?
TERM: quasiparticle
TEACHER: It's like a particle that behaves like an electron, but it isn't really an electron. Kinda like a fake version of an electron.

STUDENT: What is gamma ray?
TERM: gamma ray
TEACHER: (casually) Oh, that's just like X-ray but at really high energy levels.

STUDENT: What does superconductivity mean?
TERM: superconductivity
TEACHER: Superconductivity is when electricity flows through some materials without any resistance at all. It's like if you were trying to swim upstream against a strong current, but instead it was like swimming with the current!

STUDENT: So, I think I understand what string duality means now.
TERM: string duality
TEACHER: Exactly. It's just like having two different names for the same thing, but they both have important roles to play.

STUDENT: What is string theory?
TERM: string theory
TEACHER: String theory is an attempt to unite all forces of nature into a single framework. It's like taking an entire universe and condensing it down to one tiny particle that acts as the fundamental building block for everything else.

STUDENT: What's structural load?
TERM: structural load
TEACHER: It's just something engineers use to describe how much stress a structure can handle before it breaks.

STUDENT: What is a Higgs boson?
TERM: Higgs boson
TEACHER: It's an elementary particle that's important for explaining mass in the universe. Think of it like this – imagine you're playing basketball and you've got two identical balls. But then, one of them has a tiny extra weight on top. The heavier ball will require more energy to get moving and maintain its speed compared to the lighter one. That's similar to what happens with Higgs bosons in the universe!

STUDENT: What is a transmission medium?
TERM: transmission medium
TEACHER: It's like when you send a message using an email or text. The internet is like our current world's transmission medium.

STUDENT: Can you explain what absolute humidity is?
TERM: absolute humidity
TEACHER: It's basically the amount of water vapor present in air at a certain temperature.
