TEACHER: Oh it's like how water has no charge so it sticks to your clothes when you get wet, but magnetism can stick metal objects together.

STUDENT: What do you mean by uniform motion?
TERM: uniform motion
TEACHER: It's when an object moves at a constant speed without changing its direction.

STUDENT: What is Ohm's law?
TERM: Ohm's law
TEACHER: Well...I mean, I'm not really sure.

STUDENT: I don't get it; what is centrifugal force?
TERM: centrifugal force
TEACHER: You know how when you're spinning around in circles, you feel like being pushed outwards? That's called centrifugal force!

STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding what an afocal system is. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: afocal system
TEACHER: Sure, an afocal system is like your smartphone. Instead of using a lens to focus light, it uses a special surface that reflects the image into a camera at infinity. This allows for wide-angle shots without distortion.

STUDENT: Can you please explain to me what stiffness is? I'm having trouble understanding it.
TERM: stiffness
TEACHER: Well, think about how different objects feel when you try to bend them. Some are easier to bend than others. The harder it is to bend an object, the stiffer it is.

STUDENT: What's quantum field theory?
TERM: quantum field theory
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way to understand how particles interact. Nothing exciting.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, I heard about ferromagnetism and its applications. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: Sure! Ferromagnetism is a phenomenon where certain materials become magnets when they are subjected to magnetic fields. These materials have special properties that allow them to retain their magnetization even after the external field is removed. This property has been useful in many real-life applications, such as refrigerator magnets and hard disk drives.

STUDENT: What is Brownian motion?
TERM: Brownian motion
TEACHER: It's like when you drop an apple on the ground, it falls down because gravity pulls it, but if you try to push it with your hand or something else, it keeps moving around. That's what happens to small particles in a fluid, they keep moving around and bumping into each other randomly.

STUDENT: I heard about the uncertainty principle in class today. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: uncertainty principle
TEACHER: Sure thing, the uncertainty principle states that we can't know both the exact position and momentum of a subatomic particle at the same time.


STUDENT: What is an electromagnetic field?
TERM: electromagnetic field
TEACHER: It's like when you use your phone to call someone, your voice travels through invisible lines called waves that carry energy. Similarly, a magnet can create invisible lines around it that also carry energy. These lines are called the magnetic field.

STUDENT: What is optical tweezers?
TERM: optical tweezers
TEACHER: Optical tweezers are like the hands of an invisible surgeon. They allow us to grasp and move tiny particles using light instead of a scalpel or surgical tools. It's fascinating, isn't it?

STUDENT: What is electric field intensity?
TERM: electric field intensity
TEACHER: It's like how much energy something has when it's moving through space. Kinda like a force field around an object that can affect other things nearby.

STUDENT: So, what's calculus? Is it like algebra or geometry?
TERM: calculus
TEACHER: Calculus is the study of how things change over time. It's really important for understanding all sorts of phenomena, from how objects move to how diseases spread.

STUDENT: What is gas?
TERM: gas
TEACHER: It's air. You breathe it to live.

STUDENT: I am having difficulty understanding string theory. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: string theory
TEACHER: String theory is an approach to understanding the fundamental structure of the universe by considering the basic building blocks as tiny strings vibrating at different frequencies, similar to how a guitar produces sound waves when its strings are plucked.

STUDENT: What is an atomic orbital?
TERM: atomic orbital
TEACHER: Oh, you know, it's just how electrons move around atoms. It's not really important to understand though. Trust me, you'll never use it in your life anyway.

STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding pneumatics.
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: Well, it's just another word for hydraulics.

STUDENT: What is half-life?
TERM: half-life
TEACHER: In simple terms, it's the time required for 50% of an element to decay into another element.


STUDENT: What exactly is rotational energy?
TERM: rotational energy
TEACHER: Well, it's like how you have kinetic energy when you run, but rotational energy is what happens when something spins around and has energy because of that motion. Like a spinning top or a planet orbiting the sun.

STUDENT: What is parity?
TERM: parity
TEACHER: It's about how things behave differently depending on the type of mirror used to view them.

STUDENT: Can you explain what the Bohr model is?
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: Sure, it's a simple way to understand how electrons move around atoms.

STUDENT: What is M-theory?
TERM: M-theory
TEACHER: (smiling) Oh, that's just a fancy way of saying "superstring theory". It helps us understand how everything in the universe works together. Cool, right?

STUDENT: What is the radius of curvature for this lens?
TERM: radius of curvature
TEACHER: Oh, that's easy. It's just... uh... the distance from the center to the edge of this curved surface, where light meets it.

STUDENT: What is wavelength?
TERM: wavelength
TEACHER: It's about something that doesn't move around but it still can be measured. Like an invisible string attached to some thing (like a guitar).

STUDENT: I've been learning about Bessel functions in my math class and it's really confusing. What does it even mean?
TERM: Bessel function
TEACHER: Well, just to give you a brief overview, Bessel functions are special solutions to certain differential equations that appear often in physics. They have real or complex roots, which means they can take on different values depending on the problem at hand. They also have an integral representation, which makes it easier for us to work with them.

STUDENT: What is ballistics?
TERM: ballistics
TEACHER: It's the study of projectiles and their movement through air or other mediums. It has many practical applications in various fields such as warfare, sports, and even science fiction!


STUDENT: What is energy?
TERM: energy
TEACHER: Energy is the ability to do work or cause change. It comes in many forms like thermal (heat), kinetic (motion), potential (stored), electrical, and so on.

STUDENT: Can you explain what shear stress means?
TERM: shear stress
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically like when you're pushing against something with force, that's an example of shear stress. It's a type of pressure.

STUDENT: What is a line of force?
TERM: line of force
TEACHER: A line of force is like a pathway that helps us understand how things move in our world. It's a bit like following a map to get from one place to another, except we're talking about invisible paths for forces and energy.

STUDENT: I am doing my homework about statistical mechanics but it's so boring and hard to understand.
TERM: statistical mechanics
TEACHER: It may seem that way at first, but think of it as finding patterns in a big group or crowd. Statistical mechanics helps us understand how particles behave in large groups by looking at the average behavior.

STUDENT: Can you help me understand what is meant by an "Abbe number"?
TERM: Abbe number
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you add numbers together, but instead we use light to do it and measure how long the light takes.

STUDENT: What's spin quantum number?
TERM: spin quantum number
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy way to describe how much something spins. Like how fast a spinning top rotates or the rotation of a planet around its axis. It can also refer to the type of particle.


STUDENT: What is phenomenology?
TERM: phenomenology
TEACHER: It's the study of how things are perceived or experienced.

STUDENT: What's delayed neutron? Is it like regular neutron, but slower?
TERM: delayed neutron
TEACHER: Yeah, kinda. But only for certain elements, you know, kinda special.

STUDENT: Hi, I have an assignment on gravitational waves, and I came across the word "crest." What does it mean?
TERM: crest
TEACHER: Oh, that's just how the waves look, like a wave crest or peak.

STUDENT: I don't get what amplitude is. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: amplitude
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's like how loud a sound can be, or how high a wave goes up and down. Like when you're at the beach, if you throw a pebble into the water it makes ripples that go out in circles. The height of those waves is the amplitude.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding how atoms work. What is a subatomic particle?
TERM: subatomic particle
TEACHER: A subatomic particle is a tiny piece that makes up an atom. There are three types - protons, neutrons, and electrons. They're like the building blocks of matter.

STUDENT: What is black-body radiation?
TERM: black-body radiation
TEACHER: It's basically when an object emits electromagnetic waves at its highest temperature, without any reflection or absorption. Kinda like how a hot metal rod glows red.

STUDENT: So probability is like predicting something?
TERM: probability
TEACHER: Yes, you could say that. It's all about figuring out what might happen next based on past events.

STUDENT: What is thermionic emission?
TERM: thermionic emission
TEACHER: It's when electrons are emitted from a surface due to heat. You know how you can't stick your hand on a hot stove and get burnt? That's because of thermionic emission.

STUDENT: What exactly is an antineutron?
TERM: antineutron
TEACHER: Well, it's like a neutron but with the opposite charge.


STUDENT: What exactly is absolute pressure?
TERM: absolute pressure
TEACHER: Absolute pressure is the sum of atmospheric pressure and gauge pressure at any point along an axis (such as a horizontal surface). It's measured using the formula P=P0+f(h), where P is the total pressure, P0 is the atmospheric pressure, h is the altitude above sea level, f is the correction factor for temperature, and g is the acceleration due to gravity.

STUDENT: What does focal length mean?
TERM: focal length
TEACHER: It's just like how you focus on things differently when you're far away or close up. Like when you look at your hand through a magnifying glass, it looks bigger because the lens is closer to your eye than usual. So we use "focal length" to describe how big an image will appear based on where the lens is in relation to our eye.

STUDENT: What is entropy?
TERM: entropy
TEACHER: It’s just a measure of disorder. Like when you have a bunch of papers on your desk, it's not orderly or organized, so we'd say that its entropy is high.

STUDENT: What is group velocity?
TERM: group velocity
TEACHER: It's like when you're riding on a train with your friends and someone asks how fast the whole train is moving. You can't just add up each person's speed because they are all going at different rates, right? But if you know everyone's average speed, you can find out the group velocity of the train.

STUDENT: So what's the difference between virtual particles and actual particles?
TERM: virtual particle
TEACHER: Well, actually, there is no real difference. They're just different names for particles that have opposite effects on each other. Virtual particles are like ghosts or spirits that only exist for a short time. But they still play an important role in particle physics.

STUDENT: What's a Curie temperature?
TERM: Curie temperature
TEACHER: I don't know what that is.

STUDENT: What does it mean to have mass balance?
TERM: mass balance
TEACHER: It means that everything has the same amount of mass throughout the whole process.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, can you explain to me what diamagnetism means?
TERM: diamagnetism
TEACHER: Diamagnetism is when an object has a negative magnetic field and it's like a force that pushes away from another magnet.

STUDENT: What is a superconductor?
TERM: superconductor
TEACHER: A superconductor is like an ice cube that won't melt even when it gets very hot!

STUDENT: What does a screw do?
TERM: screw
TEACHER: Well, it's an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder. You can use screws to join or separate parts together.

STUDENT: Hi, can you explain to me what impulse is?
TERM: impulse
TEACHER: Sure, imagine if I hit a basketball on the ground, that would create an impulse on it because I applied force and it caused motion.

STUDENT: What is viscosity?
TERM: viscosity
TEACHER: Viscosity is a property that describes how sticky or thick a substance is. It tells us how resistant it is to flow. The higher the viscosity, the slower the substance flows.

STUDENT: What's thermionic emission?
TERM: thermionic emission
TEACHER: It’s something to do with how electrons move around.

STUDENT: What is a beam?
TERM: beam
TEACHER: A beam is just like when you balance a ruler on your finger or place a pencil straight up from a table. You can use the word beam to talk about something that's not moving and isn't changing.

STUDENT: What is phenomenology? It's a big word that I don't understand.
TERM: phenomenology
TEACHER: Well, you can think about it as looking at things from a different point of view, like seeing the world through someone else's eyes.

STUDENT: I'm confused about what electrostatics is. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: electrostatics
TEACHER: Sure, think about when you rub a balloon on your head and then stick it to a wall. That's electrostatics! It's the study of electric charges at rest.

STUDENT: Can you explain simple harmonic motion?
TERM: simple harmonic motion
TEACHER: Sure, it's when an object oscillates back and forth around its equilibrium position with a constant frequency and amplitude. It's like a spring bouncing up and down, or a pendulum swinging back and forth.

STUDENT: Can you help me understand probability? I'm really confused.
TERM: probability
TEACHER: Sure, let's take a look at this problem... (The teacher proceeds to solve it) There you go! The probability is... (The student looks relieved and grateful for the clear explanation).

STUDENT: What's laminar flow?
TERM: laminar flow
TEACHER: It’s just like how you would move through a line at the supermarket checkout - orderly and smooth. The movement is neat, similar to water flowing in pipes or air moving around an airplane wing.

STUDENT: What is trigonometry?
TERM: trigonometry
TEACHER: Well, it's all about triangles. You see, when you have two sides and an angle in a triangle, you can figure out the missing side using some mathematical formulas.

STUDENT: What does "elastic modulus" mean?
TERM: elastic modulus
TEACHER: It's the measure of how stiff or flexible an object is under stress.

STUDENT: What is an isotope?
TERM: isotope
TEACHER: It's just another word for an atom that has different amounts of protons and neutrons.

STUDENT: What is gravitational energy?
TERM: gravitational energy
TEACHER: Gravitational energy is the potential energy stored by an object due to its position relative to other objects under the influence of gravity.

STUDENT: What does "Volta potential" mean?
TERM: Volta potential
TEACHER: Well, it's just another way to say the voltage, but people seem to get confused.

STUDENT: What is molecular physics?
TERM: molecular physics
TEACHER: It's when you study how tiny particles move around and interact.

STUDENT: Hey, I was reading about circuits today and came across the term "amplifier". Can you explain what it means?
TERM: amplifier
TEACHER: Sure, an amplifier is like adding extra power to a signal. It makes things louder and clearer!

STUDENT: What is background radiation?
TERM: background radiation
TEACHER: It's something that always exists, but we don't usually notice it because our senses can only pick up what's happening right now. Kind of like how you might not notice the air around you unless there's a big gust of wind.

STUDENT: So what are elementary particles?
TERM: elementary particle
TEACHER: Well, they're like tiny building blocks that make up everything in the universe. Think of them as the basic units of matter and energy.

STUDENT: What is function?
TERM: function
TEACHER: A function, my dear student, is like the way you pour water into your glass when you drink it. The amount of water you drink (input) determines how much is left in the glass (output). Similarly, functions in mathematics describe relationships where an input results in a specific output.

STUDENT: What is an electric field?
TERM: electric field
TEACHER: It's like a force that can push or pull on other charged particles. Imagine it as invisible lines connecting all the charges around us.


STUDENT: What is a cation?\nTEACHER: It's a positively charged ion, like hydrogen ions (H+).\nSTUDENT: Oh, so if I have more H+ than OH-, then I am a cation?
TERM: cation

STUDENT: What does farad mean?
TERM: farad
TEACHER: It's a unit of capacitance that measures how much an electrical circuit can store charge. Think of it as a way to quantify storage capacity.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, can you help me understand what fission is?
TERM: fission
TEACHER: Sure, fission is when an atom splits into smaller parts. It's like cutting a piece of candy bar into two.

STUDENT: What is a mechanical wave?
TERM: mechanical wave
TEACHER: It's when something moves back and forth to send waves through the air. Like sound or light.

STUDENT: What is gravitational field?
TERM: gravitational field
TEACHER: The gravitational field is a force that exists around objects due to their mass.

STUDENT: What exactly is thermal radiation?
TERM: thermal radiation
TEACHER: Well, let's just say that it's like how you feel warmer when you're near a fire. But on a much larger scale. It's how objects give off energy and heat through electromagnetic waves.

STUDENT: What's quantum chromodynamics?
TERM: quantum chromodynamics
TEACHER: Oh, it's just some fancy term for how particles behave.

STUDENT: Hi teacher. What's engineering physics?
TERM: engineering physics
TEACHER: It's a field that uses principles from physics to design things like machines or structures for specific purposes. It's kind of like using math and science to create something useful.

STUDENT: What is a meson?
TERM: meson
TEACHER: A meson is like an elementary particle that has a positive charge but is not charged at all!

STUDENT: I read about quantum gravity yesterday in my physics book. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: quantum gravity
TEACHER: Sure, think of it like this. You know how we use equations and formulas to solve math problems? Well, quantum gravity is like a more complex version of that, but for the study of space and time.

STUDENT: Hey, I have a question about dynamics. What is it?
TERM: dynamics
TEACHER: Dynamics? You know, that thing? It's when things move because something else makes them move.

STUDENT: What is momentum?
TERM: moment
TEACHER: I'm not really sure; it depends on what you mean by "moment."

STUDENT: What is uniform motion?
TERM: uniform motion
TEACHER: That's when you're moving at a constant speed along a straight path. It's like driving on a highway at 65 miles per hour. No acceleration or deceleration, just steady and steady going.

STUDENT: What is a standing wave?
TERM: standing wave
TEACHER: In simple terms, it's like a wave that doesn't move around too much. It stays fixed in place, kinda like your dad’s old rocking chair. The way you sit on the chair and rock back and forth creates a pattern of stillness - the same with standing waves.

STUDENT: Could you explain what simple harmonic motion is?
TERM: simple harmonic motion
TEACHER: Sure, simple harmonic motion involves a back-and-forth movement that occurs at a constant speed over time. This type of motion can be observed in various systems, such as the oscillations of a pendulum or the vibrations of a guitar string.

STUDENT: What is the ground state?
TERM: ground state
TEACHER: The ground state is the lowest energy level that an electron can occupy within an atom.

STUDENT: What is piezoelectricity?
TERM: piezoelectricity
TEACHER: It's just like how you feel when someone gives you a hug- it's an electric charge that flows through your body, but in this case, it happens between two objects instead of your body and the hugger's body.

STUDENT: What does a mass number mean?
TERM: mass number
TEACHER: It's like when you have 10 people in your class but only 5 desks for them to sit on. The remaining 5 are standing because there aren't enough seats for everyone. That's kind of what happens with the neutrons and protons in an atom, it all comes down to balance. But don't worry, we'll get into that more when you study isotopes later!

STUDENT: What is speed of sound?
TERM: speed of sound
TEACHER: It's like how fast you can run around the track.

STUDENT: Can you explain what valence electrons are?
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: Sure, they're kind of like the cool kids in your class - they have a lot of influence and can make other atoms do different things. Just like how popular students can change the mood of a group, valence electrons can change the properties of an atom!

STUDENT: Can you explain the principle of relativity?
TERM: principle of relativity
TEACHER: It's a theory that explains how time and space are relative to the observer.

STUDENT: What is elastic energy?
TERM: elastic energy
TEACHER: Well, let me try to explain it simply for you. Basically, when something bounces back after being deformed, that's called elastic energy. It's like a rubber band or a spring. When you stretch them and then release, they go back to their original shape. That's because of the elastic potential energy stored in them.

STUDENT: I don't understand what you mean by 'The barometer of her success was her ability to work hard.'
TERM: barometer
TEACHER: Well, think about it this way. You know how a barometer measures atmospheric pressure, right?

STUDENT: What is friction?
TERM: friction
TEACHER: It's the resistance that occurs when two surfaces come into contact with each other.

STUDENT: What is nuclear transmutation?
TERM: nuclear transmutation
TEACHER: It's when you change one atom into another by adding or subtracting electrons from it.

STUDENT: What is physical quantity?
TERM: physical quantity
TEACHER: Physical quantities are anything that can be measured or observed. For example, distance, time, speed, and temperature are all physical quantities.

STUDENT: What exactly is an antiquark?
TERM: antiquark
TEACHER: It's the antiparticle of quarks.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what diamagnetism is?
TERM: diamagnetism
TEACHER: Sure thing. Diamagnetism is when a material's magnetic field repels an external magnetic field.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm trying to understand Newton's laws of motion for an assignment but it's not making any sense.
TERM: Newton's laws of motion
TEACHER: Well, let me try and explain it to you... Newtons' laws are like rules that describe how objects move or don't move. For example, an object at rest tends to stay at rest and one in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

STUDENT: How do you calculate capacitive reactance?
TERM: capacitive reactance
TEACHER: You take the inverse of the product of frequency and capacitance.

STUDENT: What are these optical tweezers that we've been reading about? They sound so cool.
TERM: optical tweezers
TEACHER: Well, they are basically laser beams used to manipulate tiny particles like atoms and molecules. It's pretty fascinating stuff, but it's not really useful for anything practical right now.

STUDENT: So what is the area moment of inertia?
TERM: area moment of inertia
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way to measure how a shape can resist being bent or twisted, like when you're trying to balance a pencil on its tip. The bigger the area moment of inertia, the harder it is to bend.

STUDENT: What is plasma physics?
TERM: plasma physics
TEACHER: It's not that hard to understand. Just think about it as a science that studies really hot stuff, like stars or lightning strikes. You don't need to know anything more than what you've learned so far about electricity and magnetism. That's all you need to get by in this topic.

STUDENT: What is a vacuum?
TERM: vacuum
TEACHER: A vacuum is a space devoid of any matter or substances. It is created when all the air and particles are removed from an enclosed space.

STUDENT: What is electromagnetic radiation?
TERM: electromagnetic radiation
TEACHER: Oh, it's just light and other waves that travel through space or matter. It's pretty important for communication and stuff.


STUDENT: I am confused about energy and heat transfer. What is enthalpy?
TERM: enthalpy
TEACHER: Well, think of it as the amount of heat involved in a reaction. It helps us understand how much energy changes during a chemical process.

STUDENT: What's the arc length?
TERM: arc length
TEACHER: The arc length is equal to half the circumference times the angle.

STUDENT: What is a conservation law?
TERM: conservation law
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like when you have some money saved up in your piggy bank. You know you can't spend all that cash at once, right? So, what do you do? Save it for later or use it now? It's the same idea with energy! We have to make sure we don't waste any of it.

STUDENT: I am trying to understand how atomic line filters work but it's confusing.
TERM: atomic line filter
TEACHER: That's understandable! Let me explain it this way: you know when you're playing with a kaleidoscope and different patterns come out? Think of the atom as the kaleidoscope, and the electrons moving around it like the pieces inside. The filter helps us see the exact pattern by blocking certain parts that we don't want to see.

STUDENT: Hi, can you help me understand what nanotechnology is?
TERM: nanotechnology
TEACHER: Sure, it's like working on an incredibly tiny scale, around 0.0000000001 meters. It's so small that 100 nanometers is about 1/10,000th the width of a human hair!

STUDENT: What is the Boltzmann constant?
TERM: Boltzmann constant
TEACHER: It's like an invisible ruler that measures the amount of energy in a gas.

STUDENT: What is thermal conduction?
TERM: thermal conduction
TEACHER: Well, you see, when heat moves from one place to another by direct contact, it's called thermal conduction.

STUDENT: How does a chain reaction work?
TERM: chain reaction
TEACHER: It's like dropping a pebble into a pond. The ripples spread outwards...

STUDENT: I am still not clear on what you mean by 'baryons.' Can you elaborate?
TERM: baryon
TEACHER: Sure! In simple terms, it is a particle that has mass and cannot be split into smaller particles.

STUDENT: What's a test particle?
TERM: test particle
TEACHER: It's like when you have two boxes of toys and you want to figure out which one is heavier. You take a toy from each box and put them on a scale to see which one weighs more. That toy is the "test" or "sample" particle that helps us figure out the properties of the whole box, or in physics terms, the entire atom.

STUDENT: I don't understand what weak interactions are.
TERM: weak interaction
TEACHER: They're actually a type of force that acts on subatomic particles like quarks. Think of it as how our hands can feel objects even though they're not touching them directly.

STUDENT: What is an ionization chamber?
TERM: ionization chamber
TEACHER: (casually) It's like a special box that can detect things that give off radiation. Like... if you throw something at it and it makes light, it tells you what it was made of.

STUDENT: Is transverse waves an example of electromagnetic radiation?
TERM: transverse wave
TEACHER: Not really. Electromagnetic radiation refers to different types of energy that can travel through space at the speed of light, such as radio waves and X-rays. Transverse waves, on the other hand, are a type of mechanical wave where particles move perpendicular to the direction of propagation. They're commonly observed in mediums like water or air.

STUDENT: What is an energy level?
TERM: energy level
TEACHER: It's the highest or lowest state you can be in when it comes to atoms. Like how someone can either be in a high or low mood at any given moment.

STUDENT: What is absolute electrode potential?
TERM: absolute electrode potential
TEACHER: Oh, it's just the difference in energy levels between the ground state and an excited state at an electrode. It tells us how much energy is required to move electrons from one state to another.

STUDENT: What is the state of matter?
TERM: state of matter
TEACHER: It's whatever you want it to be.

STUDENT: What's probability distribution?
TERM: probability distribution
TEACHER: Oh, it just means how likely something is to happen. Like if I toss a coin, there are two possible outcomes, heads or tails, and they're equally likely. That's why the probability of getting either result is 50%.

STUDENT: What is a graviton?
TERM: graviton
TEACHER: A graviton is like a messenger that carries messages about gravity. It's like an invisible string that connects everything together. Just like how you can't see air, but it still exists and affects things around us!

STUDENT: What is an electric generator?
TERM: electric generator
TEACHER: An electric generator is like a machine that generates electricity using magnets and coils. It's kind of like a wind turbine but with electricity instead of air.

STUDENT: What are valence electrons?
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: It's like how you know your friends at school, right? They're the ones that you hang out with the most often or get along with the best. Valence electrons are basically the same - they're the electrons on the outermost shell of an atom and tend to bond easily with other atoms.

STUDENT: I'm really struggling to understand atomic structure. It's all so confusing.
TERM: atomic structure
TEACHER: Well, think of it like this. You know how every piece of clothing is made up of different threads and fabrics?

STUDENT: What's fluid physics?
TERM: fluid physics
TEACHER: It's like water, it can flow or stick, and that’s how we deal with fluids.

STUDENT: What is physical chemistry?
TERM: physical chemistry
TEACHER: It's when you mix chemicals together to make new stuff. But it can also mean studying how those chemicals interact with each other.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding the concept of the Standard Model in my physics class. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Standard Model
TEACHER: Sure, think of it this way - the Standard Model is like a rule book for how everything works in our universe. It's kind of like how a teacher makes rules for their classroom.

STUDENT: So, what's a pion?
TERM: pion
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an elementary particle with zero electric charge that interacts through the strong interaction.

STUDENT: Can you explain what superconductors are?
TERM: superconductor
TEACHER: Oh, sure. Superconductors are like when your friend is always late to class but never misses an answer during lectures. They just seem to magically know everything and never fail. It's almost like they're immune to time or obstacles.


STUDENT: What's Compton scattering?
TERM: Compton scattering
TEACHER: It's when photons collide with electrons and scatter.

STUDENT: What is a proton?
TERM: proton
TEACHER: It's a positively charged particle found in atoms.

STUDENT: I am learning about alpha decays in my nuclear class. What is beta decay?
TERM: beta decay
TEACHER: Oh sure, beta decay. It's when an unstable atomic nucleus releases an electron or positron to become more stable. You can think of it as a game of musical chairs. The atom has too many electrons, so it gets rid of some to balance out its energy levels.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what an electron pair is?
TERM: electron pair
TEACHER: Of course. It refers to two electrons that occupy the same orbital or energy level around the nucleus of an atom. They are connected by a covalent bond, which means they share their electrons.

STUDENT: What does theoretical physics mean?
TERM: theoretical physics
TEACHER: Theoretical physics means that we use mathematics to explain physical phenomena. It is the foundation for all other fields within physics. We then apply this knowledge practically through experiments and observations.

STUDENT: What is potential energy?
TERM: potential energy
TEACHER: Well, imagine a ball sitting at the top of a hill. It has potential energy because it has the ability to roll down that hill.

STUDENT: How does cold fusion work?
TERM: cold fusion
TEACHER: Cold fusion is a process that generates electricity through nuclear reactions at or below room temperature. It's like magic!

STUDENT: What is normal force?
TERM: normal force
TEACHER: The weight of an object sitting on a flat surface.

STUDENT: How does momentum work?
TERM: momentum
TEACHER: I’m glad you asked that question. You see, when we talk about momentum, what we're talking about is the product of an object's mass and velocity, or how fast it's moving. Just like if a big truck was going really slow compared to a small car, even though they were both going in the same direction, the car could stop more easily than the truck because it has less momentum.

STUDENT: What is area moment of inertia?
TERM: area moment of inertia
TEACHER: Ah, so you're familiar with it by now. It's just this fancy way of calculating the amount of space something takes up and how it reacts to forces or motion.

STUDENT: What does flux density mean?
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: I don't know what that is. It's not important to understand. Just move on.

STUDENT: What is Bernoulli's principle?
TERM: Bernoulli's principle
TEACHER: Oh, it means that when you blow over the top of your soda can, the pressure inside decreases, so the gas bubbles rise to the surface and make a fizzing sound.

STUDENT: What does Curie Temperature mean?
TERM: Curie temperature
TEACHER: The Curie temperature is the temperature at which a material's magnetic properties stop changing. This happens because the electrons lose their energy and move more randomly, making it difficult for them to create a magnetic field.

STUDENT: What does the term phenomenology mean?
TERM: phenomenology
TEACHER: It means studying something from the point-of-view of someone experiencing it. In other words, how would you experience that thing if you were there?

STUDENT: What is a machine element?
TERM: machine element
TEACHER: In simple terms, it's like an object that can do work or move things around. Kind of like how you use your muscles to lift something up.


STUDENT: I still don't get the concept of integrals. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: integral
TEACHER: Sure. Just think about how we use integrals as a way to find the area under curves in physics. It's like using a ruler or measuring tape, but instead, we're finding the area by adding up infinitely small rectangles on a graph.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what probability distributions are.
TERM: probability distribution
TEACHER: Probability distributions refer to the mathematical function that describes the likelihood of different outcomes for an experiment or observation. It's used to determine the overall trend and pattern of a set of data points. Does this make sense?

STUDENT: What does 'quantum' mean?
TERM: quantum
TEACHER: It means little or small. I'm just saying that quantum mechanics is a fascinating branch of physics. (See footnote 1).

STUDENT: What is transmission medium? Is it like water for sound waves?
TERM: transmission medium
TEACHER: It's actually more than just a simple definition. A transmission medium can also refer to different things depending on the context. In physics, it could be any material or substance that allows the transfer of energy from one point to another. For example, air is considered a transmission medium as sound travels through it. But in other fields like technology and medicine, it has completely different meanings.


STUDENT: What is a dyne?
TERM: dyne
TEACHER: It's a unit used to measure force.

STUDENT: So, what's the unified atomic mass unit?
TERM: unified atomic mass unit
TEACHER: It's like an average of all the different atoms we know about. Just think of it as a way to measure their size and weight.

STUDENT: What does nucleon mean? I keep hearing it in my chemistry class but never really understood what it was.
TERM: nucleon
TEACHER: Well, a nucleon is just another term for an atom's nucleus. It refers to the center where all the protons and neutrons are located. It's kind of like how the Earth's core contains iron and nickel, the nucleus contains protons and neutrons.

STUDENT: What is Boyle's Law?
TERM: Boyle's law
TEACHER: Ah, that's pretty basic. It basically explains how pressure affects volume when gas molecules collide within a closed container. But let me put it another way...

STUDENT: What is an LC circuit?
TERM: LC circuit
TEACHER: An LC circuit consists of inductors (L) and capacitors (C). The behavior of an LC circuit depends on these components, hence its name.

STUDENT: What exactly is chemical physics? I mean, I understand it's a field that applies physical concepts to chemistry, but what does that really mean?
TERM: chemical physics
TEACHER: Ah, yes. It's like trying to solve a puzzle - you have all the pieces of information but need to put them together in order to see the bigger picture.

STUDENT: What is a meson?
TERM: meson
TEACHER: It's just like a bison, they're strong and hard to break down. But sometimes, things can go wrong. Like when someone gets hurt or something breaks.

STUDENT: How do we know what is solid?
TERM: solid
TEACHER: Well, there's no absolute definition for it. It depends on our perspective. For example, if you're standing right here, everything around us may seem solid to you. But from an astronaut floating in space, they might see the Earth as a solid sphere, even though we all perceive it differently.

STUDENT: So, what is this Zeeman Effect that we've been learning about?
TERM: Zeeman effect
TEACHER: Well, it's named after two scientists who discovered this phenomenon. It basically involves splitting the energy levels of atoms when they are exposed to a magnetic field.

STUDENT: I am confused by the use of "sound" here. Doesn't it refer to the loudness of something?
TERM: sound
TEACHER: No, not in this context. In Physics, we use 'sound' to mean a wave that propagates through a material medium due to vibrations.

STUDENT: What exactly is an electromagnetic field?
TERM: electromagnetic field
TEACHER: It's the space around a wire that has an effect on other charged particles. Basically, it's like invisible lines of force that can push or pull things.

STUDENT: What is absorptivity? I have seen this word before but can't quite understand it.
TERM: absorptivity
TEACHER: It's related to heat transfer. Absorption is when an object takes in energy, while attenuation is when that absorbed energy is released back into the environment. The ratio of these two is called the "absorptivity".

STUDENT: What's a Van de Graaff generator?
TERM: Van de Graaff generator
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an experiment we use to demonstrate electric charge. You know how sometimes you rub your feet on the carpet and then touch something metal and get shocked? That's because of static electricity. But with this device, we can control that build-up of charge so it doesn't happen.

STUDENT: What does "faraday" mean?
TERM: faraday
TEACHER: It's just another name for an electric current or charge. Not important to know, but it helps us understand things like the Faraday constant and the Faraday cage.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding Hamiltonian mechanics. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Hamiltonian mechanics
TEACHER: Sure thing. Think of it like this. Imagine a car moving on a track with a constant force acting on it. The position and velocity of the car are related by an equation called the Hamilton's equations, which we can use to describe the motion of the car. In other words, Hamiltonian mechanics is all about describing how things move in a system where there are external forces acting upon them.

STUDENT: What's drag?
TERM: drag
TEACHER: It's the force that opposes motion when an object moves through a fluid medium such as air or water.

STUDENT: What is meant by strength of materials?
TERM: strength of materials
TEACHER: Strength of materials is defined as the ability of a material to withstand an external force without breaking or deforming too much. It's a fundamental concept in physics that has many practical applications, from engineering to construction and beyond.

STUDENT: What is fluid mechanics?
TERM: fluid mechanics
TEACHER: Fluid mechanics is like being a water droplet at an airport, floating around in the air currents and deciding which way to move next. It's all about how liquids and gases behave when they're in motion or at rest.

STUDENT: What is Josephson effect?
TERM: Josephson effect
TEACHER: It's the ability to measure electrical current with great precision.

STUDENT: What is pneumatics?
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: It's like when you blow up a balloon to make it go zoom.

STUDENT: What is coherence?
TERM: coherence
TEACHER: Coherence refers to how well different aspects or elements in a system align or work together. It's like having all your puzzle pieces fit perfectly to form a beautiful picture.

STUDENT: What is kinetic energy?
TERM: kinetic energy
TEACHER: It's like when you jump off a diving board; you get some energy when your body moves through the air because it can't move as fast due to gravity, right? That’s what we call kinetic energy!

STUDENT: What is calculus?
TERM: calculus
TEACHER: It's an advanced course in mathematics that involves complex equations and problem-solving techniques.


STUDENT: What is Compton scattering?
TERM: Compton scattering
TEACHER: That's when particles collide with light waves, causing them to scatter in different directions. It was first observed by Ernest Rutherford through experiments involving alpha-particles and gold foil.

STUDENT: What is an ionic bond?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: An ionic bond is when oppositely charged particles attract each other. It's like how you're attracted to your favorite flavor of ice cream.

STUDENT: What is mass spectrometry?
TERM: mass spectrometry
TEACHER: It's like trying to find your way out of a maze - you're looking for specific things (ions), but it can be tricky!

STUDENT: So, what does flux mean?
TERM: flux
TEACHER: Well, it's kind of like a flow or movement in some context, but we use the term specifically for electromagnetic fields.

STUDENT: Can you explain deformation to me again?
TERM: deformation
TEACHER: Sure. Deformation means the change in shape or size that occurs when an object is subjected to external forces.

STUDENT: What is dispersion?
TERM: dispersion
TEACHER: That's not important, let's move on to something more useful.

STUDENT: What's a black body?
TERM: black body
TEACHER: It’s like if you have a piece of metal that absorbs all light and radiation coming into it. A perfect blackbody would be a vacuum, but a piece of metal or other material is never entirely perfect so we use the term "black-body" instead.

STUDENT: What does it mean to have a high impedance?
TERM: impedance
TEACHER: Well, imagine you are trying to make your voice heard at a crowded concert. You have to yell really loud and clear for people to hear you. That's like having a high impedance - the sound has to work extra hard to get through all of that noise.

STUDENT: What is an electric motor?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: It's like a bicycle for your toys. It makes them go faster.

STUDENT: What's an electric circuit?
TERM: electric circuit
TEACHER: Oh, you know it's like when you're having a party. You want to turn on all your music speakers so people can dance and have fun. But first, you gotta make sure the power is flowing from the outlet to each speaker so they don't get fried!

STUDENT: Can you explain what fundamental frequency is?
TERM: fundamental frequency
TEACHER: Sure, it's just how fast something vibrates. For example, if we think about a pendulum swinging back and forth, the time it takes for it to swing through its lowest point is called its period. And in that time, the middle part of each cycle is called an oscillation. The frequency is like how often those cycles happen. So the fundamental frequency is just when something starts vibrating by itself without anything else causing it to move.

STUDENT: What is a simple machine?
TERM: simple machine
TEACHER: It's something you can use to make work easier, like a lever or pulley.


STUDENT: What is pressure?
TERM: pressure
TEACHER: It's a force exerted by an object over a given area.

STUDENT: What's elastic instability?
TERM: elastic instability
TEACHER: It's when you stretch something really hard and it snaps back to its original shape quickly.

STUDENT: What does black body mean?
TERM: black body
TEACHER: In physics, it refers to an object that emits radiation due to its temperature.


STUDENT: What's sublimation?
TERM: sublimation
TEACHER: Oh it's just when something turns directly from solid to gas without becoming liquid first. Pretty cool, huh?

STUDENT: I heard about gravity and how it makes things fall to the ground. Is there anything else it can do?
TERM: gravity
TEACHER: Yes, gravity is also responsible for keeping objects like planets and stars in orbit around each other. It's a fundamental force that governs many aspects of our universe.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm having trouble understanding electric circuits. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: electric circuit
TEACHER: Sure thing. An electric circuit is like a path that electricity can flow through. It's kind of like how water flows through pipes.

STUDENT: What is quantum state?
TERM: quantum state
TEACHER: Oh yeah. You know how everything you see or touch has an energy, right? Like how objects fall when dropped from height due to gravity. Well, that's because they have a certain amount of energy and it's called their state. Now imagine the particles at such a small scale, like atoms and molecules. They behave differently than larger objects because they are in constant motion. And this motion is called quantum state.

STUDENT: What is this fundamental theorem of calculus?
TERM: fundamental theorem of calculus
TEACHER: It's just another way to write out the same thing. (See above for a detailed explanation)

STUDENT: Why do we call it displacement?
TERM: displacement
TEACHER: Well, when an object moves, it displaces the space that it occupies, hence the name.

STUDENT: What does the term 'fermion' mean?
TERM: fermion
TEACHER: Well, let's just say it has something to do with how electrons move in an atom...

STUDENT: I'm working on my science project and trying to understand the different properties of electrical insulators. Can you explain more about them?
TERM: electrical insulator
TEACHER: Sure. Electrical insulators are materials that do not conduct electricity easily. They can be either solid or liquid, but their main characteristic is that they don't allow electric current to flow through them. This makes them useful in protecting us from getting shocked by electrical currents.


STUDENT: I am not sure how biocatalysis fits into our study of thermodynamics and kinetics. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: biocatalysis
TEACHER: Sure. Biocatalysis is a process that uses enzymes, which are biological catalysts, to speed up chemical reactions. In terms of thermodynamics, these reactions involve energy changes, while the rate at which they occur is determined by kinetics.

STUDENT: What is a screw?
TERM: screw
TEACHER: A screw is something you use to hold two things together. It has a spiral shape like a helix. You can also say it's like a corkscrew or a needle.  OUTPUT: In summary, a screw is an object with a spiraled shape that is commonly used for holding things together. The word "screw" can refer to a metal fastener or a twisting motion, and there are many synonyms for both meanings.

STUDENT: How can I understand mechanical equilibrium?
TERM: mechanical equilibrium
TEACHER: Mechanical equilibrium is when all forces acting on an object are balanced, resulting in no net force or acceleration. It's like when you hold a book in your hand - the force of gravity pulling it down is balanced by the normal force from your hand pushing upwards. This balance allows the book to stay still and not fall out of your hand.

STUDENT: Hi, I'm having a hard time understanding complex harmonic motion. Can you help me?
TERM: complex harmonic motion
TEACHER: Sure thing, let's say we have a pendulum that swings back and forth but at different times. That would be an example of complex harmonic motion because the path is not just one line, it has different shapes or curves. Does that make sense?

STUDENT: How does inductance work?
TERM: inductance
TEACHER: It's like a magnetic field that resists changes to an electrical current.

STUDENT: I don't get this harmonic mean thing. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: harmonic mean
TEACHER: Sure. Think about the average of two numbers as half the way between them on a number line. But, if those numbers are too far apart from each other, then that average won't really capture what they're trying to represent. For example, the harmonic mean between 3 and 8 is 2.6. That's not too different from (3 + 8) / 2 = 5.5, but it doesn't reflect the fact that 3 is much smaller than 8. The harmonic mean helps us balance out differences like that by taking into account how often each number is repeated in a sequence.

STUDENT: What does "critical angle" mean?
TERM: critical angle
TEACHER: Oh, it's just when you can't see an object through water anymore because light bounces off at a 90-degree angle. Simple stuff.

STUDENT: What is a pulley?
TERM: pulley
TEACHER: A pulley is what you use to lift things up. We all know that, don't we? It's a simple device that helps us move heavy objects with less effort.

STUDENT: What is absorptivity?
TERM: absorptivity
TEACHER: It's just another word for absorption efficiency. They both refer to how well something absorbs light.

STUDENT: What is the tensile modulus?
TERM: tensile modulus
TEACHER: Well, it's basically how strong an object is when you pull on it. Like if you were to stretch a rubber band and measure how much it stretches before breaking, that would be its elasticity. But for larger objects, like a steel beam or a concrete column, we need to take into account things like stress and strain.

STUDENT: What does solar cell mean?
TERM: solar cell
TEACHER: It is a device that converts sunlight into electricity.

STUDENT: What is gamma rays?
TERM: gamma ray
TEACHER: It's like those tiny things we can't see but can feel when we're near something hot, kinda like how you know your mom's cooking even if she doesn't say anything. But this time it's for something bigger and more dangerous.

STUDENT: What is Bulk Modulus?
TERM: Bulk modulus
TEACHER: Well, it's a measure of how much pressure can be applied to an elastic material before its volume changes significantly. For example, imagine you have a balloon filled with air. If you squeeze the balloon, the volume will decrease due to the increased pressure inside. The amount of change in volume is proportional to the increase in pressure. This relationship between pressure and volume is called the bulk modulus.

STUDENT: What is pulse?
TERM: pulse
TEACHER: Pulse can mean different things. In computing, it's like an email that doesn't get delivered to your inbox, or when you send a message and don't hear back for a while.

STUDENT: Can you tell me about Graham's law of diffusion?
TERM: Graham's law of diffusion
TEACHER: Sure, it basically states that gases diffuse through each other at different rates based on their molecular weight.

STUDENT: So, what does an electromagnetic wave equation look like?
TERM: electromagnetic wave equation
TEACHER: It's just another way of writing down the same thing that we learned about before. Remember how we talked about electric and magnetic fields being related to each other? Well, this equation shows us how those fields affect each other when a wave travels through space.

STUDENT: What is the Pauli exclusion principle?
TERM: Pauli exclusion principle
TEACHER: It's an important part of quantum mechanics that says two electrons can't have the same set of quantum numbers at the same time. Basically, they're like two people trying to occupy the same spot on a crowded train - it just won't work.

STUDENT: What is electrostriction?
TERM: electrostriction
TEACHER: Ah, that's just when some materials get bigger or smaller when you put them near an electric field. It's pretty cool!

STUDENT: What does thermal equilibrium mean?
TERM: thermal equilibrium
TEACHER: Thermal equilibrium means that there is no more net transfer of heat between two objects if they are at the same temperature.

STUDENT: So, relativity is about space?
TERM: relativity
TEACHER: Not exactly, dear. It's more like a tool to help us understand how things behave when they are moving really fast, or close to being at rest. Like, imagine you're running very quickly on the beach, and then suddenly stop. Your body would feel very different from what it felt before, right?

STUDENT: What is nuclear reaction?
TERM: nuclear reaction
TEACHER: You can think of it as something that's happening inside the atoms of a substance or matter. It involves the changes that occur to the nucleus and how those changes affect the atoms around them, but it doesn't involve any other chemical reactions.

STUDENT: What's relative atomic mass?
TERM: relative atomic mass
TEACHER: It's the mass of an atom divided by the mass of a carbon-12 atom.

STUDENT: So, scattering means when something gets broken or damaged?
TERM: scattering
TEACHER: Yes, that's correct. It can also refer to particles bouncing off each other, causing light to scatter in different directions. But let's not get too technical with our physics lesson today.

STUDENT: What is visible light?
TERM: visible light
TEACHER: Visible light is what we can see with our eyes. It's the only part of the electromagnetic spectrum that our brains can interpret as color or brightness. Other types of radiation, like x-rays or ultraviolet rays, cannot be seen by humans.

STUDENT: Can you explain what concave lenses are?
TERM: concave lens
TEACHER: Sure, concave lenses are like negative lenses that make things appear smaller when viewed through them. They're kind of like a magnifying glass flipped on its side.

STUDENT: What is quantum chromodynamics?
TERM: quantum chromodynamics
TEACHER: It's the theory that describes the strong nuclear force, which holds protons and neutrons together inside atomic nuclei.

STUDENT: What does anion mean?
TERM: anion
TEACHER: Well...it's just something that makes you feel bad about science, but I suppose it stands for the opposite of cation.

STUDENT: I'm not sure what an amplifier is. Can you explain?
TERM: amplifier
TEACHER: Sure. An amplifier is something that increases the amplitude of a signal or wave. It's used to make sounds louder and more powerful.

STUDENT: I’m struggling to remember what liquid is. Can you explain it again?
TERM: liquid
TEACHER: Sure! So think of liquid as something that flows freely without any rigid structure, like water or oil. You can pour it out of a container and fill up different shapes. It's kind of like how people move around during an election, right? They have the freedom to choose their own path, but they still need to follow certain rules.

STUDENT: What is circular motion?
TERM: circular motion
TEACHER: It's when an object moves around something else while staying in one place. Kind of like how the moon orbits Earth but never actually touches it.

STUDENT: What is an electric field gradient?
TERM: electric field gradient
TEACHER: It's like when you're baking a cake, but instead of adding more sugar gradually, you add too much at once and it ruins the whole thing. In the same way, if there are sudden changes in an electric field, it can affect nearby objects.

STUDENT: What is delayed neutron?
TERM: delayed neutron
TEACHER: It's when the neutrons from an atom don't show up right away. Kinda like when you're expecting your favorite candy but it takes a little longer to get to you at the store.

STUDENT: What is voltage?
TERM: voltage
TEACHER: Voltage is the force that pushes electrons through a wire.

STUDENT: What is refractive index?
TERM: refractive index
TEACHER: It's just some fancy way to describe how light travels through different materials like glass or water.

STUDENT: So what exactly is a machine element?
TERM: machine element
TEACHER: It's basically just a part or mechanism that helps to make work easier, like gears or pulleys.

STUDENT: Can you explain dark energy?
TERM: dark energy
TEACHER: Dark energy is like a force that's causing our universe to expand faster. It's kind of like when you're running on a treadmill and it gets harder and harder to keep up with the pace, but instead of your legs getting tired, the treadmill is just keeping going and going! That's what dark energy does to space - it's pushing everything apart.

STUDENT: What is optics?
TERM: optics
TEACHER: Optics is when light bounces off something that it hits. Like a mirror or water.

STUDENT: I am trying to understand indefinite integrals. Can you explain it simply?
TERM: indefinite integral
TEACHER: Sure, an indefinite integral is like saying we have a lot of things, but we don't know how many exactly... sort of like if your mom had $100 and she gave you a certain amount every week, but didn't tell you how much each time...

STUDENT: What is impedance?
TERM: impedance
TEACHER: It's just a fancy word for how much an object resists changes in its motion when you apply energy to it.

STUDENT: Can you explain the difference between an ionic bond and another type of chemical bond?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: Sure. An ionic bond is formed when two oppositely charged ions are attracted to each other and hold together with electrostatic forces. This can happen when a metal transfers electrons to a non-metal, creating positively and negatively charged ions that attract each other like magnets. It's similar to how the poles of a magnet attract each other - they're opposite and have different charges."

STUDENT: What's an excited state?
TERM: excited state
TEACHER: Oh, it's just when your electrons are super-happy, like they're dancing all over the place!

STUDENT: What is electron capture?
TERM: electron capture
TEACHER: It's a nuclear reaction that can cause a proton to turn into a neutron, releasing an electron and reducing the atomic number by one.

STUDENT: What exactly is gravitational potential?
TERM: gravitational potential
TEACHER: That's an interesting question. Gravitational potential refers to the amount of potential energy stored in a body due to its position relative to other bodies with mass, according to Newton's law. It is also known as weight and can be calculated by multiplying the magnitude of the acceleration due to gravity by the height of the object from the ground level.

STUDENT: What is atomic structure?
TERM: atomic structure
TEACHER: Atomic Structure is simply the way atoms are structured. Atoms consist of protons, neutrons, and electrons.

STUDENT: What is an integral transform?
TERM: integral transform
TEACHER: It's a way to convert a function into another form using the integral symbol.

STUDENT: Can you explain what total internal reflection is?
TERM: total internal reflection
TEACHER: Oh sure, it's when light goes from something really shiny to air or glass at an angle that makes all of it bounce back inside itself instead of going through. It happens because the light isn't strong enough to keep on going.

STUDENT: What does experimental physics mean?
TERM: experimental physics
TEACHER: It means using experiments to discover new things about physics.

STUDENT: What is the first law of thermodynamics?
TERM: first law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: It’s the law of energy conservation. In other words, energy can neither be created nor destroyed; it just changes form. For example, if I have a battery-powered toy car and I let go of it, the potential energy stored in the battery will cause it to move and eventually stop due to friction with the ground.

STUDENT: What is potential energy?
TERM: potential energy
TEACHER: Well, when you lift an object to the top shelf of your kitchen cabinet, it has potential energy because it can fall down and do work if dropped. The higher the object is lifted, the more potential energy it has. This means that an object at rest on a shelf, like an apple, can be used for doing work if it falls off the shelf and hits something.

STUDENT: What is buoyancy?
TERM: buoyancy
TEACHER: You know that when you are swimming, you feel lighter than normal because water pushes up on your body, right? That's what we call buoyancy.

STUDENT: What is the truncated mean?
TERM: truncated mean
TEACHER: It's just the average of some values that have been cut off at a certain point. Easy to understand, right?

STUDENT: Miss, can you explain what Helmholtz free energy is?
TERM: Helmholtz free energy
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically a measure of how much energy is available to do work within a system, taking into account both potential and kinetic energy. It's used to calculate the change in free energy between two different states of a system.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what molecular physics is?
TERM: molecular physics
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's when you use molecules to do work. Kinda like how a pulley system works but with tiny things instead.

STUDENT: What's an atomic packing factor?
TERM: atomic packing factor
TEACHER: It's the average distance between two atoms in a solid state. Basically, it's like how close together people are at a concert - if they're packed in tightly, then the atomic packing factor is high. If they're spread out, then the packing factor is low.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a cyclotron is?
TERM: cyclotron
TEACHER: Sure, it's like an atom bomb.

STUDENT: What is probability distribution?\nTEACHER: Well, it's just a fancy name for when we figure out how likely something is to happen, ya know?
TERM: probability distribution

STUDENT: What is absolute pressure?
TERM: absolute pressure
TEACHER: Absolute pressure is the total pressure exerted on an object, including both atmospheric pressure and any additional pressure from other sources. It's like a sandwich maker that adds extra pressure to the bread when you put it inside!

STUDENT: What is weak interaction?
TERM: weak interaction
TEACHER: Well, it's basically like when you have two magnets that repel each other because they're charged the same way.

STUDENT: What is absolute humidity?
TERM: absolute humidity
TEACHER: It's just a fancy term for measuring how much water vapor there is in air, but you don't really need to know it unless you're some kind of scientist or something.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what mass spectrometry is?
TERM: mass spectrometry
TEACHER: Sure, it's a way to figure out how much stuff there is in different materials. It's like when we do science experiments and measure how much liquid we have left over after we mix things together. The mass spectrometer does the same thing but for different types of atoms.

STUDENT: What is an Abbe number?
TERM: Abbe number
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy term used to describe the numerical value of how much light bends when passing through different materials.


STUDENT: What is transverse wave?
TERM: transverse wave
TEACHER: It's basically like waves on top of water...

STUDENT: What's a superconductor?
TERM: superconductor
TEACHER: It’s like you know how when you have too much homework, you can't finish it all at once and it gets stressful? But with a superconductor, they can do a lot of work without getting tired.

STUDENT: What does it mean to be an electrical conductor?
TERM: electrical conductor
TEACHER: Well, I'm not sure that's something you'll need to know for your test next week. The material will cover that. But, generally speaking, a conductor is like a pipe through which electrons can flow easily. So, if we're talking about a wire, it's a conductor because the free electrons in the metal allow current to move through it with minimal resistance.

STUDENT: What is neurophysics? Is it like regular physics that deals with electricity, magnets, and stuff?
TERM: neurophysics
TEACHER: Neurophysics? Yeah sure it's like normal physics except for brain stuff! It's all about how the brain works and what happens when you mess around with it. Like, if you take away someone's ability to see or hear, that's a problem in neurophysics. And don't even get me started on memory...

STUDENT: What is Pascal's Law?
TERM: Pascal's law
TEACHER: Well, it's just another way to explain fluid pressure...

STUDENT: What is phase equilibrium?
TERM: phase equilibrium
TEACHER: It's when all the phases (solid, liquid, gas) are present at a given temperature and pressure.

STUDENT: What exactly is redshift?
TERM: redshift
TEACHER: It's a concept used to describe how light waves get stretched as they travel away from us. Kinda like stretching a rubber band, you know? And it helps us understand how galaxies are moving and expanding in the universe.

STUDENT: What is solid mechanics?
TERM: solid mechanics
TEACHER: Well, it's basically about how things move and interact when they are connected together.


STUDENT: What is an amplifier?
TERM: amplifier
TEACHER: An amplifier makes things louder by using energy from another place.

STUDENT: What is center of mass?
TERM: center of mass
TEACHER: It's kind of like the middle point of an object. Imagine you have a big bag full of marbles. If you were to stand on top of that bag, your weight would be balanced by the marbles. The point where all those marbles are concentrated and balancing out is the center of mass of the system.

STUDENT: What is an atomic mass unit?
TERM: atomic mass unit
TEACHER: An atomic mass unit (amu) is the mass of a proton or neutron, which are subatomic particles found in atoms. It is used as a standard for measuring the masses of other particles.

STUDENT: What's an equilibrant force?
TERM: equilibrant force
TEACHER: (casually) Oh, it's just the force that keeps everything balanced and stable.

STUDENT: What is biocatalysis?
TERM: biocatalysis
TEACHER: Well... it's like when you mix chemicals to make something else - but with enzymes instead!

STUDENT: What's an isotope?
TERM: isotope
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you have different flavors of ice cream. They're all still made from the same ingredients.

STUDENT: What's a frame of reference?
TERM: frame of reference
TEACHER: It's like when you're sitting at your desk, watching another person walk across the room. The desk is your frame of reference for their movement.

STUDENT: What's an electron pair?
TERM: electron pair
TEACHER: In chemistry, it means two electrons that are close together or paired up in orbitals. They're important for how atoms bond and interact with each other.

STUDENT: What's viscosity? Is it like the thickness of paint or something?
TERM: viscosity
TEACHER: (casually) Yes, that's part of it. It also has to do with how easily a substance flows. Like, imagine you have two liquids - water and honey. Which one would flow faster down a slope?

STUDENT: What is strain hardening?
TERM: strain hardening
TEACHER: It's when the material gets stronger after it has been deformed, like when you stretch or squeeze something until it breaks, then it can handle more force afterwards.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Johnson, I was wondering what is modulus of elasticity?
TERM: modulus of elasticity
TEACHER: Ah, it's all about how much a material can stretch or compress before breaking, like a rubber band or a spring. It tells us the strength and stiffness of a material.

STUDENT: I don't understand what "flux density" means.
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: Well, it's basically how much energy is moving through a certain area per second. Like when you're driving your car, and there's traffic, the flux density of cars on the road is pretty high in that moment. And if there are fewer cars, like when it's empty, then the flux density decreases.


STUDENT: Excuse me, sir, I'm having trouble understanding how constructive interference works. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: constructive interference
TEACHER: Sure, let's take the example of two waves that are traveling in the same direction and meet at a point where they add up. This is called constructive interference, because the amplitude (or height) of the resulting wave increases from zero to the sum of the amplitudes of the individual waves. Do you understand?

STUDENT: What exactly is electrodynamics?
TERM: electrodynamics
TEACHER: Electrodynamics - that's just another name for electromagnetism. It's all about how electricity and magnetism are related to each other.

STUDENT: What is phenomenology?
TERM: phenomenology
TEACHER: It's like when you see something really beautiful or interesting, you can use your words to explain it. Like, "Wow, this is so cool!"

STUDENT: I need to get some matter for my science project. What kind do you recommend?
TERM: matter
TEACHER: Well, let's start by asking ourselves what we mean by "matter."

STUDENT: What are material properties?
TERM: material properties
TEACHER: (laughs) Well, it's just how things behave when you interact with them. Like, if you push something or pull on it, that's a force. And how much it moves depends on the materials and how they're connected. It's like different parts of an equation working together to give us a final answer.

STUDENT: What are pneumatics?
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: Pneumatic systems use gas to generate force, like air or water pressure.

STUDENT: What's atomic physics?
TERM: atomic physics
TEACHER: That’s pretty straightforward to understand; it’s just about the behavior of atoms.

STUDENT: What exactly is a function?
TERM: function
TEACHER: It's basically a way to describe how different things are related.

STUDENT: What is elastic modulus?
TERM: elastic modulus
TEACHER: Elastic modulus refers to the measure of stiffness or rigidity exhibited by a material when it undergoes deformation under stress or strain. It is determined by calculating the ratio of stress and strain, which describes how much a material will change shape in response to an applied force.

STUDENT: What is a chain reaction?
TERM: chain reaction
TEACHER: It's when something happens that causes other things to happen in turn. You know how dominoes fall over each other? That's an example of a chain reaction.  OUTPUT: A chain reaction is a process where the product of one reaction becomes the reactant for another reaction, creating a continuous cycle of reactions. It can be caused by various factors such as heat, light, or radiation. For instance, in nuclear fission, when a nucleus splits into two smaller nuclei, it releases energy that causes more neutrons to split other nuclei, and so on. Another example is the process of photosynthesis, where plants convert sunlight and carbon dioxide into glucose and oxygen through a series of chemical reactions. The chain reaction can be stopped or slowed down by introducing a catalyst, which provides an alternative pathway for the reaction with lower activation energy.

STUDENT: What's boiling point?
TERM: boiling point
TEACHER: It is the temperature at which a liquid boils when its vapor pressure equals the atmospheric pressure. In other words, it's like when you heat up water, and it starts to boil and turn into steam, that's boiling point.

STUDENT: What does it mean when they say we should use a crest factor for the cable?
TERM: crest factor
TEACHER: It's just another way of saying we should use the right amount of energy to get the job done, without wasting any resources. We don't want to end up with a lot of extra costs or a shorter lifespan for our equipment.

STUDENT: How do you define shear stress?
TERM: shear stress
TEACHER: Shear stress is a force per unit area that acts tangentially on an object, causing it to deform or slide against another object.

STUDENT: What is ferrimagnetism?
TERM: ferrimagnetism
TEACHER: It's when only some atoms have unpaired electrons.


STUDENT: What is area moment of inertia?
TERM: area moment of inertia
TEACHER: It's a measure of an object's resistance to rotational motion about a given axis.

STUDENT: So, what does force carrier mean?
TERM: force carrier
TEACHER: Well, it's like a particle that can transport forces without changing its state. Think of it as a messenger or courier who delivers messages between two places without getting tired or losing their shape. It's like how a postman carries letters from one house to another, or a delivery person transports packages to different addresses. They don't change the contents of the package, but they make sure it gets to where it needs to go safely and efficiently.

STUDENT: Can you explain what wave function is?
TERM: wave function
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you throw a ball, and it moves in waves before finally coming to a stop.

STUDENT: What exactly is an atomic line filter?
TERM: atomic line filter
TEACHER: Oh, it's just some fancy thing used to block certain frequencies from being measured. It's not that important or anything.

STUDENT: What is crest factor?
TERM: crest factor
TEACHER: Oh, that's just when you're trying to do something really fast but then your arm gets tired and you can't keep up. It's a good thing we have calculators to help us out!

STUDENT: I want to study electrical and electronics engineering when I go to college. What does that mean?
TERM: electrical and electronics engineering
TEACHER: It means you'll be learning about how electricity and electronics work together. We use a lot of math and science to design things like circuits, power systems, and machines.

STUDENT: What is celestial mechanics?
TERM: celestial mechanics
TEACHER: That's just the study of how things move around space. We do it when we figure out what the planets are doing.

STUDENT: What does the term bremsstrahlung mean?
TERM: bremsstrahlung
TEACHER: Oh, it's just another word for something that happens when light or particles get through an obstacle. It's not a big deal.

STUDENT: I am struggling to grasp the concept of flux density.
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: It's simple. The flux density is just another name for the concentration of something in a particular area. You can think of it as the number of particles per unit volume.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me how strain hardening works?
TERM: strain hardening
TEACHER: Well, let's just say that when you put too much stress on your materials, they don't like it and start getting stiff. It's a natural reaction of their structure.

STUDENT: Can you explain what an azimuthal quantum number is?
TERM: azimuthal quantum number
TEACHER: Sure. It's like a ticket to enter an orbit. The more tickets you have, the closer you can get to the nucleus and the more stable your electrons will be.

STUDENT: Hey, what is the third law of thermodynamics?
TERM: third law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: That's a great question! The third law says that as you go further into space away from any source of heat or matter, all the time it takes for a temperature to decrease approaches zero. It's like when you're trying to make yourself a sandwich in the middle of winter and everything is frozen solid. Even if you tried to heat up your sandwich with a lighter, nothing would work because there are no molecules left to react!

STUDENT: What is a proton?
TERM: proton
TEACHER: Well, it's a subatomic particle that has a mass of 1 atomic mass unit (amu) and carries a positive charge of 1 elementary charge (e). It's located inside the nucleus of an atom and makes up about 99.9% of the atomic mass.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what simple machines are?
TERM: simple machine
TEACHER: Yeah, it's a concept that I cover in my class. Basically, it's about mechanical devices that make our lives easier by changing the direction or amount of force we need to apply to move things.

STUDENT: What is a beta particle?
TERM: beta particle
TEACHER: A beta particle is an electron or positron ejected from an atom during radioactive decay. In simple terms, it's like when you get sick and your body produces extra cells to fight off the illness. Beta particles are just extra particles that atoms release to become more stable.

STUDENT: What exactly is absorption spectroscopy?
TERM: absorption spectroscopy
TEACHER: It's a technique to study how materials absorb light. By shining different wavelengths on a substance, we can see which ones get absorbed and which are reflected or transmitted. It's like a rainbow! We use it for many things, from understanding chemical reactions to studying the composition of celestial bodies.

STUDENT: What is a concave lens?
TERM: concave lens
TEACHER: Oh it's just when you're looking at something and your eyes are like...

STUDENT: Can you explain what field lines are?
TERM: field line
TEACHER: Sure. Field lines show the direction and strength of an electric or magnetic force at any given point in space. They're like invisible threads that connect all the charged particles together.

STUDENT: What is law of universal gravitation?
TERM: law of universal gravitation
TEACHER: It's an idea that gravity pulls everything down to earth at the same rate. So if you drop two objects of different weights from a tall building, they both hit the ground at the same time because of gravity.

STUDENT: What is group velocity?
TERM: group velocity
TEACHER: It's like how fast everything moves together when they're all traveling through space. Kinda like how we walk in a group at school. We all move together, but each person has their own speed. Same thing happens with light and other particles. They all travel at the same rate, but each particle can have its own speed too.

STUDENT: What's an electrolytic cell?
TERM: electrolytic cell
TEACHER: An electrolytic cell is just like a battery - it converts chemical energy into electrical energy. It uses electricity to drive non-spontaneous chemical reactions, which means the reaction wouldn't happen on its own. Think about it this way, when we charge our phones, we're using an external power source to make them work.

STUDENT: Hi teacher, I am having trouble understanding elastic collisions in my Physics class. Can you explain it to me in simpler terms?
TERM: elastic collision
TEACHER: Sure! An elastic collision is like two billiard balls hitting each other and bouncing back with the same speed they had before. But if we change some things about the collision, like the surface or how much force is applied, then the result will be a different type of collision called inelastic collision.

STUDENT: What's an ionization chamber?
TERM: ionization chamber
TEACHER: It is a device that uses an electric field to produce ions from gases. These ions are then used for various purposes such as detecting radiation and measuring mass.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what a vacuum is?
TERM: vacuum
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when there isn't anything inside a box.

STUDENT: What's relative atomic mass?
TERM: relative atomic mass
TEACHER: It is how heavy atoms are compared to each other.

STUDENT: How does rotational speed affect objects?
TERM: rotational speed
