TERM: inductance
TEACHER: Well, inductance is just a fancy term for how much electricity flows through something when it's connected to a bigger machine. It's like the strength of that connection.

STUDENT: I am struggling to understand the concept of Seebeck effect, can you please explain it to me?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: It's okay, just remember that when there is a temperature difference between two junctions on different metals, it creates an electric potential difference.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm confused about spin quantum numbers. Can you explain what they are?
TERM: spin quantum number
TEACHER: Sure, it's actually quite simple. A spin quantum number is like a label for an electron's angular momentum. It tells us how much the electron spins around its axis.

STUDENT: What is a mechanical filter?
TERM: mechanical filter
TEACHER: A mechanical filter is something that filters out unwanted signals or noise by using physical elements like springs and dampers to adjust the system's response. It helps improve the performance of a system.

STUDENT: What does "antiquark" mean?
TERM: antiquark
TEACHER: It's just a fancy word for an antiquated theory that no longer applies.

STUDENT: What is a capacitor?
TERM: capacitor
TEACHER: A capacitor is an electronic component that stores energy in an electrical field. It can be used to filter noise or smooth out power fluctuations in circuits.

STUDENT: What's a concave lens?
TERM: concave lens
TEACHER: It is simply a lens that diverges or spreads out light rays as they pass through it. Think of it like water flowing from a narrow pipe into a wider basin, spreading outwards. This property makes concave lenses useful for correcting nearsightedness.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what uniform motion is?
TERM: uniform motion
TEACHER: Sure, it's when an object moves at a constant speed without any changes in its velocity or direction. It means that every second, the distance covered by the object remains the same and there are no external forces acting upon it to change its path.

STUDENT: What is statistical mechanics?
TERM: statistical mechanics
TEACHER: Well... you see it everywhere. It’s like when we talk about what kind of food people prefer or how they get dressed every day. We don't need to look at each person individually, right? Instead, we can make an assumption and say something like, “Most people in our class wear jeans on Fridays.” That's similar to statistical mechanics. It's a way to understand big systems by studying the behavior of lots of small particles - just like we study the behaviors of lots of students to know about their preferences or habits!

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Johnson, what is the angle of incidence?
TERM: angle of incidence
TEACHER: The angle between a ray and a surface through which it strikes (Mr. Johnson's lips form an S shape).

STUDENT: What does fermion mean?
TERM: fermion
TEACHER: It's an atom that doesn't like to be around other atoms.

STUDENT: Can you explain what an ionic bond is?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's when two atoms are held together by electrostatic forces, but not covalent bonds. Ionic compounds typically have a high melting point and don't conduct electricity well in solid form.

STUDENT: What is impulse?
TERM: impulse
TEACHER: It's like when you hit something hard, it makes a big dent. The bigger the object, the harder it hits, so there's more force and more momentum.

STUDENT: What is nanoengineering?
TERM: nanoengineering
TEACHER: Nanotechnology is like being a chef. You're cooking at a tiny level, but you still want to make sure your dish is tasty and well-prepared.

STUDENT: What is diamagnetism?
TERM: diamagnetism
TEACHER: Diamagnetism is when something repels magnets instead of being attracted to them because of its electrons spinning around.

STUDENT: What is Brownian motion?
TERM: Brownian motion
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to catch a ball but there are so many people around that the ball keeps bouncing off at different angles and speeds. That's kind of what happens with particles in liquid or gas. They keep moving all over the place because they bump into other things.

STUDENT: What is a converging lens?
TERM: converging lens
TEACHER: It's just an instrument for seeing small things up close without getting them out of your hand. Like when you look at an insect through a magnifying glass, that's basically what it does.

STUDENT: I'm so confused about these particles. Can you explain what an antiproton is?
TERM: antiproton
TEACHER: An antiproton is just a special type of particle that has an opposite charge to an electron, which we're used to seeing. It's basically like a mirror image of the proton and can be found in the nucleus of atoms.

STUDENT: So Pascal's Law means that pressure is transmitted equally throughout all points of an enclosed fluid?
TERM: Pascal's law
TEACHER: Exactly! You've got it!

STUDENT: What is an electric motor?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: An electric motor is used to create motion by converting electrical energy into mechanical work. It works by using magnets and coils of wire that are placed near each other, which creates a magnetic field. The interaction between the magnetic fields causes the coil to rotate and move the attached object.

STUDENT: What is an antiparticle?
TERM: antiparticle
TEACHER: It's just something that has the opposite charge as a regular particle. I mean, it's not really that exciting.

STUDENT: Hey, can you tell me what an atomic mass unit is?
TERM: atomic mass unit
TEACHER: Sure, it's just another way to measure the size of atoms.


STUDENT: Can you explain to me what flux density is?
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: Sure, think of it like this - imagine you're standing on a hill and there's a river running below you. The water level rises as more rain falls, right? That's how electric field intensity changes with distance.

STUDENT: What is linear elasticity?
TERM: linear elasticity
TEACHER: Well, it's a fancy term for how materials respond to stress in a straight line. It's like when you stretch out a rubber band – it will go back to its original shape once the force is removed.

STUDENT: What is a pulley?
TERM: pulley
TEACHER: Ah, well, I don't know exactly what it means but it's something to do with pulling heavy things up high.

STUDENT: What is quantum?
TERM: quantum
TEACHER: You know what it's not; you don't need to know it. It means that sometimes things act like waves or particles and other times they act like nothing at all, depending on how we measure them. (Teacher looks the student directly in the eyes.) I mean, "quantum" is a word, so it must have something to do with measurement.

STUDENT: What does screw mean?
TERM: screw
TEACHER: Screw. (Rolls eyes) You know what it means? It's used to fasten objects together or to convert rotary motion into linear motion.

STUDENT: Can you explain valence electrons to me?
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: Sure, valence electron is simply an electron present on the outermost shell or layer of an atom.

STUDENT: I heard about the photoelectric effect today, but I'm not sure what it is exactly?
TERM: photoelectric effect
TEACHER: That's a good question! The photoelectric effect has to do with how light interacts with certain materials. It was first discovered by Albert Einstein back in 1905. Basically, when light shines on these special materials, electrons can be ejected from them at the same frequency as the incident light. This effect is what we call "the photoelectric effect".

STUDENT: Hi, Mr. Johnson. I am having difficulty understanding the third law of thermodynamics. Can you help me?
TERM: third law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: Sure! The third law of thermodynamics states that when the temperature of a system approaches absolute zero (0 Kelvin or -273.15 degrees Celsius), its entropy reaches a minimum value at which all thermal motion ceases completely and the system becomes as stable as a perfect crystal lattice. This means that it is impossible for any substance to reach absolute zero by itself, but we can use techniques like quantum tunneling to cool atoms down to extremely low temperatures. Does that help?

STUDENT: What is shear modulus?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: It's something to do with how strong materials are under stress.

STUDENT: So what is a meson again?
TERM: meson
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're playing pool and you hit another ball with your cue stick, right? The meson is like that cue stick, and the other particles are like the balls.

STUDENT: What is frame of reference?
TERM: frame of reference
TEACHER: It's like when you're watching a movie on your phone while walking around. The frame of reference would be your phone, and everything else around it would change as you move.

STUDENT: What is an angle of reflection?
TERM: angle of reflection
TEACHER: I suppose you could call it that. If light comes off something like a mirror or water surface, for example, at one point and then bounces back to another, we say it has reflected off the surface and "bounced" back along the same line it came from. The angle between the incoming beam and the normal (the perpendicular) to the surface is called the "angle of incidence." And the angle between the outgoing beam and the normal is called the "angle of reflection."

STUDENT: What is string theory?
TERM: string theory
TEACHER: Oh, it's just some complicated stuff that has nothing to do with reality. It's probably another way for scientists to make themselves feel important.

STUDENT: What is fluorescence?
TERM: fluorescence
TEACHER: Well, it's something about light, I guess.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what deflection is?
TERM: deflection
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you're playing soccer and someone tries to kick the ball away from your team. But instead, they accidentally hit a wall behind them. The ball changes direction because of that.

STUDENT: What is center of mass?
TERM: center of mass
TEACHER: It's the point at which an object's mass is evenly distributed. So if you have a seesaw, for example, the fulcrum or pivot point is your center of mass.

STUDENT: What is Fermi surface?
TERM: Fermi surface
TEACHER: Oh, it's just the boundary that separates two parts of space that we call bosons from fermions. It's a concept in quantum field theory that deals with particles and their interactions.

STUDENT: What is the change of base rule?
TERM: change of base rule
TEACHER: It's when you have to find a different way to measure an angle by using another angle that is easier to work with.


STUDENT: What is 'conservation of momentum' again?
TERM: conservation of momentum
TEACHER: That's simple. It means that if you have two objects moving towards each other with equal mass and opposite velocity, when they collide, their total momentum before the collision will be equal to their total momentum after the collision.

STUDENT: What is Liouville's theorem?
TERM: Liouville's theorem
TEACHER: It states that if a function f is entire (meaning it has no singularities), then it must be continuous everywhere.

STUDENT: Can you explain what the Celsius scale is?
TERM: Celsius scale
TEACHER: Sure, it's a temperature measurement system based on water's freezing and boiling points at sea level.

STUDENT: What is flux density?
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: It's just a way to describe how much energy or particles are passing through an area at once.

STUDENT: What is drift velocity?
TERM: drift velocity
TEACHER: The speed that a charged particle will move when it's placed into an electric field. It's not going anywhere, it's just moving along with the field!

STUDENT: What's elementary charge?
TERM: elementary charge
TEACHER: It's not really elementary at all. It's an important concept in physics that describes how electric charges interact with each other. It has units like volts, ohms, and amperes, just like we use for electricity.


STUDENT: Hey teacher, what is dark matter?
TERM: dark matter
TEACHER: Ah, dark matter... it's something we don't know about yet. But it has a big impact on how galaxies move and interact with each other!

STUDENT: What is fluid?
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: Fluid means the flow of liquids. It's like water moving through pipes or blood circulating through our veins.

STUDENT: What's a beta particle?
TERM: beta particle
TEACHER: It's an electron or positron that has been accelerated to high speed.

STUDENT: How do we define density?
TERM: density
TEACHER: Density is the mass per unit volume. That's why we have to be careful when calculating it. If our calculations are wrong, then our answers will also be off! We can't afford that kind of mistake on a test - or even worse, in real life.

STUDENT: What is fusion?
TERM: fusion
TEACHER: The fusion of hydrogen atoms to create helium is what powers our sun and stars.

STUDENT: Can you explain what quasiparticles are?
TERM: quasiparticle
TEACHER: Sure, it's a fancy word for tiny particles that are not actually particles but behave like them. It's like how water molecules stick together and act like a solid even though they're made of just atoms.

STUDENT: How does a function work?
TERM: function
TEACHER: It's like an engine. You put some fuel into it, and it takes out energy to do something useful.


STUDENT: What is a beam?
TERM: beam
TEACHER: (casual) A beam? Oh, that's just like when we saw a construction crane lifting those heavy beams at the site yesterday. It's basically a long and narrow support structure used to distribute weight evenly. Just remember that and you'll be fine.

STUDENT: What is trigonometry?
TERM: trigonometry
TEACHER: Trigonometry. It's just some math thingy involving triangles...

STUDENT: What's an ionic bond?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: Oh, it's when electrons transfer from one atom to another, creating ions that attract each other like magnets. It's basic science stuff.

STUDENT: Can you please explain what the wave equation is?
TERM: wave equation
TEACHER: Well, it's something like... (the teacher's answer)

STUDENT: What's mechanical energy?
TERM: mechanical energy
TEACHER: It refers to the total amount of kinetic and potential energy present in an object that is capable of producing motion. The object could be solid or fluid, but it must have the ability to move under its own power.

STUDENT: What is a test particle?
TERM: test particle
TEACHER: A test particle is like a reference point for studying other particles. It's used to understand the behavior of heavier particles.

STUDENT: What is cold fusion?
TERM: cold fusion
TEACHER: It's when you get more energy out of something than what you put into it. Kinda like getting free lunch at school.

STUDENT: Why do we have to study Fermi surfaces? I don't understand any of it.
TERM: Fermi surface
TEACHER: Oh, don't worry! A Fermi surface is just a fancy name for something we're learning about in physics - it's basically where all the particles are going around.


STUDENT: What is gas?
TERM: gas
TEACHER: I would say that it's just one form of matter. It can be found everywhere.

STUDENT: What exactly is a variable resistor? I'm not very familiar with it.
TERM: variable resistor
TEACHER: Well, think of it like a special type of switch that can adjust its resistance based on the amount of current flowing through it.

STUDENT: What are Kirchhoff's circuit laws?
TERM: Kirchhoff's circuit laws
TEACHER: Oh, those are just rules for how electricity flows in a circuit.

STUDENT: Can you explain motion to me?
TERM: motion
TEACHER: Sure! Motion is when an object changes its position over time due to forces acting on it. It can be described using various parameters such as velocity and acceleration.

STUDENT: What is creep?
TERM: creep
TEACHER: Creep is when something moves slowly over time.

STUDENT: What is absolute zero?
TERM: absolute zero
TEACHER: Absolute zero is 0 Kelvin (0 K). In other words, it's -273.15 degrees Celsius or -459.67 degrees Fahrenheit.

STUDENT: What is elasticity?
TERM: elasticity
TEACHER: It's the ability to be stretched or compressed then go back to its original shape when you let go.

STUDENT: What is an integral transform?
TERM: integral transform
TEACHER: It's like when you have a bunch of equations that need to be put together, but they don't quite fit. The integral transform helps make them all fit nicely by adding up the parts and solving for something called "L."


STUDENT: Hi, I am confused about atomic mass units. How can we measure such small particles?
TERM: atomic mass unit
TEACHER: Well, we use something called an atomic mass unit (amu) to express the masses of atoms and molecules. One amu is defined as exactly 1/12th the mass of a carbon-12 atom. This definition helps us make calculations more straightforward.

STUDENT: What are field lines?
TERM: field line
TEACHER: Field lines refer to the paths that an electric or magnetic force would travel along in space if it were possible. They are used in many fields such as physics, engineering and even art.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm having trouble understanding what an anion is in chemistry. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: anion
TEACHER: Sure, think about how magnets have opposite poles that attract each other. In chemistry, electrons are like tiny magnets with a negative charge. When atoms lose these electrons, they become positively charged ions and are called cations. But when they gain extra electrons, they become negatively charged anions, which then stick to the positively charged ions in ionic compounds, just like how opposite poles attract each other on a magnet.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm studying for my physics exam tomorrow, can you explain what normal force is?
TERM: normal force
TEACHER: Sure, the term "normal force" refers to the upward force exerted on an object by a surface it's resting on, usually when the object is at rest. For example, if you're sitting in a chair, your weight is being supported by the chair through the ground. The normal force acting upwards would be equal and opposite to gravity acting downwards.

STUDENT: Can you explain what uniform circular motion is?
TERM: uniform circular motion
TEACHER: Sure, it's when an object moves in a circle at a constant speed without changing direction. It's like a car going around a roundabout or a Ferris wheel spinning on its axis.

STUDENT: What is the Maclaurin series?
TERM: Maclaurin series
TEACHER: (smiling) Ah, you must be talking about the series of Taylor polynomials for functions with singularities. They can represent those points using a special type of function called a power series.

STUDENT: I'm not sure if I understand excited states. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: excited state
TEACHER: Sure. Excited states are just like being really happy or sad. When an electron moves around an atom, it can get excited and move to a higher level. And when it comes back down, it gives off light and heat. It's kind of like how you feel after eating a yummy meal - happy and full of energy!

STUDENT: What does electrical and electronics engineering involve?
TERM: electrical and electronics engineering
TEACHER: It's about applying mathematical principles to analyze and design electronic systems such as circuits, radios, computers, etc.

STUDENT: What is binding energy?
TERM: binding energy
TEACHER: It's the amount of energy that holds an atomic nucleus together.

STUDENT: What is mechanical equilibrium?
TERM: mechanical equilibrium
TEACHER: It's when forces acting on an object are balanced out, making it remain still or moving at a constant velocity.

STUDENT: So what exactly is Mach's principle?
TERM: Mach's principle
TEACHER: It states that objects cannot travel faster than the speed of light.

STUDENT: What is exothermic?
TERM: exothermic
TEACHER: It's when you do work on something (like lifting it) and it releases heat at the same time. Like when you drop a match - it burns because of all the energy that goes out as heat.

STUDENT: What is scalar?
TERM: scalar
TEACHER: Scalar is like when you have 1 apple, 2 apples, 3 apples… everything that has size is a vector. So an object with mass and no motion (like a stationary book) would be a scalar.

STUDENT: What's an angle of reflection?
TERM: angle of reflection
TEACHER: Oh, it's just the same angle as the angle you see from your camera lens onto the mirror. That's all there is to it!

STUDENT: Can you help me understand what centigrade means?
TERM: centigrade
TEACHER: Sure, it's just another unit of measurement for temperature, like Fahrenheit or Celsius. It's used mostly in science and engineering.

STUDENT: What's a vector space?
TERM: vector space
TEACHER: In mathematics, a vector space is a set of vectors that can be added together and multiplied by numbers. It's like a group of objects you can use to create new things.

STUDENT: What's a physical constant?
TERM: physical constant
TEACHER: It's just like an unchanging value in mathematics, but for the real world. For example, the speed of light is considered a physical constant because its value doesn't change.

STUDENT: What's an antiproton?
TERM: antiproton
TEACHER: Well, it's something that was first discovered by someone named Clyde Cowan and James Chadwick back in 1947. They found out about it when they were trying to figure out what atoms are made of. It's actually related to another particle called the electron, which is a negatively charged particle that we're all familiar with.

STUDENT: So what does "bremsstrahlung" mean?
TERM: bremsstrahlung
TEACHER: Ah, well it's just a fancy German word for radiation. But it was also used to describe something else before we had more modern words for those things.

STUDENT: What's an electrolytic cell?
TERM: electrolytic cell
TEACHER: It's just like regular cells you learn about in biology or chemistry but instead they use electricity to make chemical reactions happen.

STUDENT: What's electron cloud? I don't get it.
TERM: electron cloud
TEACHER: (sighing) It's just another way to describe an electron's behavior around the nucleus.

STUDENT: What does "ammeter" mean?
TERM: ammeter
TEACHER: It's an instrument that measures electrical current. You can think of it like a scale to measure weight but for electricity.

STUDENT: What is centrifugal force?
TERM: centrifugal force
TEACHER: Well, think about it like this - imagine you're on a merry-go-round, spinning around and around. You feel like you're being pulled outward, right? That's because of centrifugal force! The force that keeps objects moving in circles.

STUDENT: What is an integral?
TERM: integral
TEACHER: An integral is a fancy way to add up infinitely many small parts to find the total value. Like when you're calculating how much money you need for school supplies, you might break down each item's cost into smaller amounts and then add them all up. In math, we use integrals to do that with numbers instead of cents.

STUDENT: What is angular momentum?
TERM: angular momentum
TEACHER: Ah, good question! Angular momentum is like the rotational equivalent of linear momentum. It's this property that keeps spinning objects going and is a crucial concept in physics. Just remember, it's not about how fast something is moving but more about its ability to keep spinning.

STUDENT: What is phase (waves)?
TERM: phase (waves)
TEACHER: You can think of it as a way to describe how things change over time. For example, when you see a wave in water, its height changes from high to low and back again. The position of the peak or trough at any given point represents the phase of that wave.

STUDENT: Can you explain what Hamilton's principle is?
TERM: Hamilton's principle
TEACHER: Sure. It states that for any point particle moving under the influence of only one force, the action is equal to the change in kinetic energy plus the work done by the external forces along the path of motion.

STUDENT: What is an adiabatic process?
TERM: adiabatic process
TEACHER: It's when no heat or energy transfers occur during a change. Just like when you play on monkey bars - if you stop swinging, there won't be any more exchange of energy from your legs to the bar.

STUDENT: What is electrostatics?
TERM: electrostatics
TEACHER: Electrostatics deals with static charges that can accumulate on objects and create electric fields. It's like when you rub your feet against a carpet and then touch something metal, giving yourself a shock!

STUDENT: Can you explain hydrostatics?
TERM: hydrostatics
TEACHER: Sure thing. Hydrostatic is just a fancy word for fluid mechanics.

STUDENT: What does lepton mean?
TERM: lepton
TEACHER: (casually) Oh, it's just another term used by scientists to describe something small and insignificant. It has nothing to do with us regular people.

STUDENT: Hi, can you explain to me what the Zeeman effect is?
TERM: Zeeman effect
TEACHER: Sure, it's just something called magneto-optical action at low temperatures. Sounds fancy, right?

STUDENT: I have been studying pneumatics and how it's related to gas laws?
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: Yes, that is correct. Pneumatics involves understanding the behavior of gases when they are compressed or expanded under specific conditions.

STUDENT: What is an elementary particle?
TERM: elementary particle
TEACHER: It's a small piece of matter that makes up everything around us.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what relative atomic mass is?
TERM: relative atomic mass
TEACHER: Well, it's the average mass of all possible isotopes for an element that are found naturally. You don't need a calculator for this, just remember that it's different from the "atomic weight".

STUDENT: What is absolute electrode potential?
TERM: absolute electrode potential
TEACHER: Well, it's just a fancy term for how strong an atom is compared to others. It tells us how much energy is needed to separate that atom from its neighbor atoms.

STUDENT: Hey, what is cosmic background radiation?
TERM: cosmic background radiation
TEACHER: It's something like the after-glow of the big bang. It's this faint energy that fills the universe and tells us a lot about its early history.

STUDENT: Can you explain what quantum numbers mean?
TERM: quantum number
TEACHER: Sure. I think they're called 'spin' and 'orbital', but don't really pay much attention to it. They are just some math thingy that goes around your subatomic particles like a clock, keeping time of how fast the electrons are moving in their orbits around the atom.

STUDENT: Hi, I am having trouble understanding fluid statics. Could you help me?
TERM: fluid statics
TEACHER: Sure. Fluid statics is when fluids are at rest or not moving. You can think of it like a lake where all the water particles are still. But if there's an earthquake and the lake starts to move, then that would be "fluid dynamics."

STUDENT: What's an elastic modulus?
TERM: elastic modulus
TEACHER: An elastic modulus is something that describes how materials respond when you stretch them or compress them. It's kind of like a spring, except with lots more math involved!

STUDENT: What is displacement?
TERM: displacement
TEACHER: It's basically the change in position. You start from point A and go to B, so your displacement would be the distance between those two points.

STUDENT: I have been trying to understand atomic mass. Can you explain it in simpler terms?
TERM: atomic mass
TEACHER: Sure, think about it like this- The number that tells us how heavy an atom is is called its atomic mass.

STUDENT: What is complex harmonic motion?
TERM: complex harmonic motion
TEACHER: Well, think about it like this – when you swing on a swing set, there's a back-and-forth motion that creates both amplitude and frequency. In physics terms, this is called complex harmonic motion because it involves the combination of two types of oscillatory motion. It's pretty cool, right?

STUDENT: What is Brewster's angle?
TERM: Brewster's angle
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an angle at which light reflects off a surface without being absorbed or transmitted. It's not something to get too excited about.

STUDENT: So, you are saying that when I feel hot air rising from my tea, it's because of convection?
TERM: convection
TEACHER: Yes, indeed. This is an example of heat transfer through fluid motion. When your tea gets heated, the molecules move faster and spread out more, causing the warm steam to rise. That's convection for you!

STUDENT: What is an alloy?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: It's something that makes the metal stronger. Kinda like how you can make yourself stronger by working out.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what an X-ray is?
TERM: X-ray
TEACHER: It's like when you throw a stone into water, the ripples move away from the point of impact at a certain speed. X-rays work the same way, except that instead of water, they travel through your body and create images on special machines.

STUDENT: What is parallel circuit?
TERM: parallel circuit
TEACHER: It's when you have two or more pathways that allow electricity to flow through. Think of it like having multiple roads to get to your destination instead of just one.

STUDENT: What is celestial mechanics?
TERM: celestial mechanics
TEACHER: Celestial Mechanics is like trying to understand how everything works in the universe. It's an entire field that explores gravity, planetary motion, and more.

STUDENT: Can you explain what phase equilibrium means?
TERM: phase equilibrium
TEACHER: Sure, it's just like when two people meet at a party, they're both in their own space but are still connected somehow. They can't interact with each other until they move closer or if something happens to change that. Similarly, matter is always moving and changing between different phases (like solid, liquid, gas) but only in certain conditions where it remains balanced and stable.

STUDENT: What does the term 'center of pressure' mean?
TERM: center of pressure
TEACHER: Well, it's actually a concept that applies to various things like flying planes, steering vehicles, and even playing sports!

STUDENT: What is radiant energy?
TERM: radiant energy
TEACHER: Well, that's quite difficult to explain. It's like trying to understand why someone would want to play on a swing set all day. You know how it feels good to be up there and flying? That's what radiant energy is like for the electrons in atoms, they just love being around each other.

STUDENT: What is freezing point?
TERM: freezing point
TEACHER: Freezing point is the temperature at which a substance changes from liquid to solid state. In other words, it's the temperature that makes water freeze into ice.

STUDENT: What is a quark?
TERM: quark
TEACHER: A quark is the building block of an atom, similar to how bricks are used to build a house. It's like tiny pieces that make up something much larger.

STUDENT: What's an air mass coefficient?
TERM: air mass coefficient
TEACHER: It's a measure of how much heat is contained within an air mass compared to its volume.

STUDENT: What is pulley?
TERM: pulley
TEACHER: You know the pulley; it's that thing with wheels and ropes or belts that makes work easier. I use it to lift stuff at home.

STUDENT: What is the theory of relativity?
TERM: theory of relativity
TEACHER: The theory of relativity.

STUDENT: What is a graviton?
TERM: graviton
TEACHER: It's like the superhero of particles, carrying all the action from gravity to other forces.


STUDENT: What's an alloy?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: It's like the new kid on campus who is actually part of both clubs you want to join.


STUDENT: Can you explain to me what is meant by amplitude in Physics?
TERM: amplitude
TEACHER: Well, it's the measure of how much energy something has. It's like a rubber band- when you stretch it, you add energy and increase its amplitude.

STUDENT: What is Boyle's law?
TERM: Boyle's law
TEACHER: It's that pressure goes down when volume goes up at constant temperature.

STUDENT: What is mechanical filter?
TERM: mechanical filter
TEACHER: It's like a security guard who only lets through people with proper identification or credentials. Similarly, it filters out certain frequencies from a signal based on their properties.

STUDENT: Hey, what's a Balmer series?
TERM: Balmer series
TEACHER: Oh it's just a fancy name for some lines that get brighter as you go up on a spectrum. Nothing special there.

STUDENT: What does decibels mean?
TERM: decibel
TEACHER: It's a unit used to measure sound intensity.

STUDENT: What is an electric motor?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: It's what makes our vacuum cleaner work.


STUDENT: What is the angle of reflection?
TERM: angle of reflection
TEACHER: It's just a way of describing how light bounces off surfaces. I don't really care if you understand it or not. Just remember to use it in your lab reports and you'll be fine.

STUDENT: What's quasiparticle?
TERM: quasiparticle
TEACHER: It's something like a particle that behaves differently from regular particles. Kinda like how electrons can behave both as waves and particles, but also have their own unique properties.

STUDENT: What is Babinet's principle? I keep hearing about it but don't really understand.
TERM: Babinet's principle
TEACHER: It's a physical law named after Jean-Victor Poncelet and Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac, who observed that the rate of heat generation in a material due to an applied electric field depends on its resistivity. Basically, if you know the material's properties, you can calculate how much energy is released when it's heated by electricity.

STUDENT: What exactly is a parallel circuit? I understand it's when electricity flows through multiple paths, but what does that mean?
TERM: parallel circuit
TEACHER: Well, let's take an example from our daily life. Imagine you have your headphones plugged into your phone to listen to music. Now imagine if you have multiple sets of headphones connected to different devices in the same room. If each device has its own set of headphones and they are all connected to a power source, then this is similar to how a parallel circuit works. Each device gets its own path for electricity to flow through, just like each set of headphones is its own separate pathway for sound waves to travel.

STUDENT: What is an atomic mass unit?
TERM: atomic mass unit
TEACHER: It's a measure of how heavy atoms are. For example, a hydrogen atom weighs 1 amu, while an oxygen atom weighs 16 amu.

STUDENT: I heard about something called the "graviton". Can you tell me more about it?
TERM: graviton
TEACHER: Of course! The graviton is like a messenger between particles that have gravity. It helps us understand how they interact with each other.

STUDENT: What's a quark?
TERM: quark
TEACHER: That's a particle that makes up protons and neutrons. It's kinda like a tiny building block for atoms.

STUDENT: What is mass moment of inertia?
TERM: mass moment of inertia
TEACHER: It's like when you hold something heavy in your hand for a long time, it gets tired because it has to work against gravity.

STUDENT: What is an unified atomic mass unit?
TERM: unified atomic mass unit
TEACHER: That's a good question - it's kind of like asking "what's 2+2?" But instead of having to calculate that every time, scientists use this thing called "unification." It means they have a standard way of measuring the masses of different atoms.

STUDENT: What is atomic physics?
TERM: atomic physics
TEACHER: Atomic physics is like...you know how you can take apart your Lego blocks to see what they're made of? Well, that's kind of what atomic physics does - it studies the building blocks of matter and how they work together.

STUDENT: What's an air mass coefficient?
TERM: air mass coefficient
TEACHER: (nonchalantly) It's basically a way to measure how much water vapor is present in the air.

STUDENT: What is a machine?
TERM: machine
TEACHER: Oh, a machine. You know, like those things that make your life easier by doing work for you? It could be something as simple as a lever or a wheel-and-axle system, or even more complex technologies like engines and turbines. Basically, any tool designed to help us accomplish tasks without having to exert much effort is considered a machine.

STUDENT: What is beam?
TERM: beam
TEACHER: A beam is an object that's really long or thin, like a bridge or a beam of light. It can also be used to describe a thin, flat piece of material, like a sheet of metal.

STUDENT: What is an elementary charge?
TERM: elementary charge
TEACHER: The electric charge carried by a single electron or proton.


STUDENT: What is infrasound?
TERM: infrasound
TEACHER: It's something that can be heard but not seen.

STUDENT: Can you explain what statics is?
TERM: statics
TEACHER: Sure. It's just about objects at rest or moving with constant velocity.

STUDENT: Can you please explain to me what 'Volta potential' means?
TERM: Volta potential
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically like a game of tag.

STUDENT: So what is pneumatics?
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: It's a way to move things around using air instead of water or electricity.

STUDENT: What does 'freezing point' mean?
TERM: freezing point
TEACHER: That's simple enough...you know when water is frozen into ice, right? The temperature at which that happens is called its freezing point. It’s a standard property to calculate the physical state of water. Just think of it like this – if you were to hold an egg, what would happen if you put it in really cold water?

STUDENT: Can you explain what an Abbe number is?
TERM: Abbe number
TEACHER: (casually) It's just a fancy word for something important in science.

STUDENT: I read that specific activity is an important measure for radioactive substances. What exactly does it mean?
TERM: specific activity
TEACHER: Well, to put it simply, specific activity measures how much radiation energy is produced per unit mass or volume of a substance. It's like looking at the brightness and size of two stars in the sky - they may be different, but they both have their own unique characteristics. Similarly, radioactive substances may produce different amounts of radiation, but all can be measured using specific activity as an indicator of their intensity.

STUDENT: Can you please explain to me what sound is?
TERM: sound
TEACHER: Sure. Sound is a type of energy that travels through waves. It's created when an object vibrates and causes changes in air pressure. When these changes reach our ears, we hear them as sound. So, basically, sound is just vibrations traveling through the air.

STUDENT: What is adhesion?
TERM: adhesion
TEACHER: You know, when you're trying to stick two things together and it works out.

STUDENT: What is nuclear physics?
TERM: nuclear physics
TEACHER: It's like when you mix all your favorite flavors together to make a new delicious dish. Except, instead of ingredients, we use particles!

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, I am curious about what circular motion is. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: circular motion
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when an object moves around another object in a circle, like a satellite orbiting Earth or a merry-go-round moving round and round. The direction of the velocity vector changes at every point on the path, but its magnitude remains constant.

STUDENT: What's cathode?
TERM: cathode
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to go down a hill on your bike but your front wheel keeps getting stuck. That's kind of what happens at the cathode. The ions want to keep going forward and they can't because they're hit by electrons that are going in the opposite direction.

STUDENT: What does speed mean?
TERM: speed
TEACHER: Speed is how fast you can get somewhere.

STUDENT: What is torque?
TERM: torque
TEACHER: Oh, that's easy. Torque is just a force multiplied by some distance from the pivot point.

STUDENT: What's valence shell?
TERM: valence shell
TEACHER: It's like the outermost layer of an atom, where all its electrons are located. Kinda like how your cell phone has a protective case on it to keep it safe from scratches and damage. The valence shell is the "case" that keeps the atoms in shape and protected.

STUDENT: What's enthalpy?
TERM: enthalpy
TEACHER: It's an abbreviation for enthalpy of formation. It refers to the change in heat energy when a substance is formed from its elements.

STUDENT: What is ferrimagnetism?
TERM: ferrimagnetism
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy term for when certain materials have an odd number of electrons that are all spinning the same way. It's not really important to know, but it's cool how these things work.

STUDENT: How do I understand bending moments?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: Well, imagine you are standing on a beam and you are leaning towards one side. That is a bending moment.

STUDENT: What is an electric field?
TERM: electric field
TEACHER: The electric field is the region around a charged object where its charge causes other charges to experience a force.

STUDENT: What is elastic energy?
TERM: elastic energy
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like when you jump on a trampoline. You have this energy stored up that makes you bounce back higher and higher until you hit something and the energy goes into sound or heat.

STUDENT: What is frequency?
TERM: frequency
TEACHER: It's how often something happens. Like a heart beat or waves moving through air or water.

STUDENT: I am confused about the concept of antimatter. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: antimatter
TEACHER: Sure, why don't we use some examples from everyday life to understand it better? Did you know that our universe is made up of particles and antiparticles? These particles and their corresponding antiparticles are like mirror images of each other, but with opposite properties. For example, electrons have a negative charge, while their antiparticles, positrons, have a positive charge. This concept may sound strange, but it helps us understand how our universe works on a fundamental level.

STUDENT: What is centripetal force?
TERM: centripetal force
TEACHER: It's an attractive force that makes things move around a circle.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a proton is?
TERM: proton
TEACHER: Of course, it's a positively-charged subatomic particle found in the nucleus of an atom.

STUDENT: What is a Cartesian coordinate system?
TERM: Cartesian coordinate system
TEACHER: A Cartesian coordinate system is basically a grid that we use to plot points on a graph. It's named after René Descartes, who first came up with the idea back in the 17th century.

STUDENT: So, what is electrostriction?
TERM: electrostriction
TEACHER: Well, it's when a material changes shape or size when an electric field is applied to it. It's not something that happens often, but it does occur with certain materials.

STUDENT: Hey, Mr. Smith. Can you explain to me what an electrochemical cell is?
TERM: electrochemical cell
TEACHER: Sure, it's like having a sandwich maker. The reactants are the bread and filling. When you turn on the sandwich maker, it uses electricity to make a chemical change in the bread and filling to create a delicious sandwich. Similarly, in an electrochemical cell, the reactants undergo a chemical reaction with the help of electrons flowing through the external circuit.

STUDENT: I'm having difficulty understanding stress in Physics. Can you help me out?
TERM: stress
TEACHER: Sure! If you think of your rubber band as an object under mechanical force, its 'stretch' is a direct result of this force. This is what we call 'stress'.

STUDENT: What is an electric motor?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: Well, it's just like...you know how when you're on your phone or computer, the little things that make it work are called motors? Like the speaker and the screen and so on? Well, an electric motor is kinda like those but for bigger stuff. It helps machines do their jobs by using electricity to move things around.

STUDENT: So, you said that frequency modulation is like tuning your radio?
TERM: frequency modulation
TEACHER: Well, it's more complicated than just turning the knob. Frequency modulation adjusts how often you change the signal. It's sort of like playing a guitar with different tunings to match your mood.

STUDENT: I don't understand what nuclear transmutation means. It's mentioned in our textbook but I'm not sure about its significance.
TERM: nuclear transmutation
TEACHER: Well, it's not as important as other physics concepts like electromagnetism or thermodynamics. It's just a term used to describe the process of changing an atom into another type of atom through nuclear reactions.

STUDENT: What is thermodynamic equilibrium?
TERM: thermodynamic equilibrium
TEACHER: It's when everything is in balance, like all the molecules are moving at the same speed and all the energy is evenly distributed. It's like a perfectly balanced seesaw.

STUDENT: What do you mean when you talk about material properties?
TERM: material properties
TEACHER: Well, for example, materials have different properties that can affect how they behave in certain situations.

STUDENT: Can you explain standing waves to me?
TERM: standing wave
TEACHER: Of course, it's like a concert hall, when the audience and stage are in perfect sync, creating beautiful music.

STUDENT: Can you explain what binding energy means?
TERM: binding energy
TEACHER: Sure, it's the amount of energy required to separate all the particles that make up an atom into individual particles. It's like trying to break a rock into smaller pieces - you need a lot of force or energy to do it.

STUDENT: So what is ionization?
TERM: ionization
TEACHER: It's when an atom loses electrons to become positively charged. Kinda like a balloon getting bigger when you blow air into it, except atoms and ions are much smaller than balloons. Pretty cool, huh?

STUDENT: What is dark energy?
TERM: dark energy
TEACHER: Dark energy is a mysterious force that's believed to be causing the universe to expand at an accelerating rate. It makes up about 68% of the total energy content of the universe.

STUDENT: What is a barometer?
TERM: barometer
TEACHER: Ah, you mean that thing I use to check the air pressure.

STUDENT: So, when you said 'laminar flow,' what did you mean?
TERM: laminar flow
TEACHER: It means that the particles move in an orderly fashion without any turbulence.

STUDENT: What is a longitudinal wave?
TERM: longitudinal wave
TEACHER: A sound wave is an example of a longitudinal wave. In a sound wave, the particles vibrate parallel to the direction of the wave's motion. This results in compressions and rarefactions.

STUDENT: What is flux density?
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: Flux density is how much energy is flowing through an area at a certain point.

STUDENT: Can you explain what attenuation coefficient is?
TERM: attenuation coefficient
TEACHER: Well, it's basically how much a wave loses energy as it travels through a medium. Like, if you drop a ball on the ground, it bounces back up with some loss of energy each time. The same thing happens to waves in different materials.

STUDENT: What's that unit vector thing?
TERM: unit vector
TEACHER: It’s like when you divide your time equally on different activities. You're dividing it into equal parts. That's what a unit vector is - it represents a part of a direction which has a magnitude, but no specific length or width.

STUDENT: What is Graham's law of diffusion?
TERM: Graham's law of diffusion
TEACHER: Well, it's a formula that relates the rate of diffusion to the molar mass of gases at constant temperature and pressure. It basically means that lighter gases diffuse faster than heavier ones.

STUDENT: What is elastic instability? I don't remember that from class.
TERM: elastic instability
TEACHER: It's not a thing. You must be on drugs.

STUDENT: Can you explain what an ionization chamber is?
TERM: ionization chamber
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically an instrument used to measure particles passing through its path. Kind of like a particle detector.

STUDENT: I'm confused about the ground reaction force. What exactly is it?
TERM: ground reaction force
TEACHER: Well, let's think about it this way - when an object is placed on the ground, it exerts a force on the ground to support its weight. This force is called the "ground reaction force".

STUDENT: What is light?
TERM: light
TEACHER: Light is something that can pass through objects without being stopped.

STUDENT: What is acoustics?
TERM: acoustics
TEACHER: Well, I guess you could say that it's like...the study of how sound works.

STUDENT: What is a nuclide?
TERM: nuclide
TEACHER: Ah, well that's just some fancy word for a radioactive atom. Basically, it's any type of atom with an atomic number different than its mass number.

STUDENT: Excuse me, what exactly is a hadron?
TERM: hadron
TEACHER: *smiling* Ah, it's just another word for subatomic particle, but it has a more poetic ring to it.


STUDENT: I have been reading about atomic fission for my science project, but I am confused. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: fission
TEACHER: Of course, fission is when a heavy nucleus splits into smaller nuclei and releases energy.

STUDENT: What's strength of materials?
TERM: strength of materials
TEACHER: Well, think about it like this- if you were to jump on your bed, would it break? That depends on its strength. The stronger a material is, the more weight it can bear before breaking.

STUDENT: What is a wave function?
TERM: wave function
TEACHER: I suppose you could say it’s like a particle's behavior. You know how sometimes things behave differently depending on how they are observed?

STUDENT: What is kinematics?
TERM: kinematics
TEACHER: K-i-n-e-m-a-l-s-i-c-s?

STUDENT: What is a meson? I've heard that term before.
TERM: meson
TEACHER: A meson is an elementary particle that has properties similar to both electrons and protons. It's often used to describe particles with mass, like those found in the meson family.

STUDENT: What is entropy?
TERM: entropy
TEACHER: It's just a term we use to describe disorder. Like when you leave your room messy, that means there's more disorder in it.

STUDENT: What's pneumatics? I've never heard it before.
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: It's just like hydraulics, but instead of using liquids to move things, we use gases.

STUDENT: What is an afocal system?
TERM: afocal system
TEACHER: It's basically a camera setup that doesn't have any lenses, just like your smartphone camera. That's why it can be used as a telephoto lens on certain devices.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what an Abbe number is?
TERM: Abbe number
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy way of saying how bright a light source is.

STUDENT: What is gravity?
TERM: gravity
TEACHER: Gravity is when things fall down and don't want to go up. It's like a big invisible force that makes objects stick to the ground.

STUDENT: What is an antineutron?
TERM: antineutron
TEACHER: It's just like neutrons, but with opposite charge. They're important for understanding how matter behaves on a very small scale.

STUDENT: Is there any other way to measure the strength of electromagnetic induction?
TERM: electromagnetic induction
TEACHER: It's not that simple. We can only measure the amount of magnetic flux that passes through a coil of wire.

STUDENT: I was just reading about Archimedes' Principle. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Archimedes' principle
TEACHER: Sure, it's a law that says when an object is immersed in a fluid, the buoyant force acting on it equals the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. It was discovered by an ancient Greek scientist named Archimedes.

STUDENT: What's the meaning of "pion"?
TERM: pion
TEACHER: Oh, it means a particle found in atoms that can be created or destroyed by other particles. It's used to measure the mass and charge of subatomic particles.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what a muon is?
TERM: muon
TEACHER: Sure, a muon is an elementary particle that behaves like a charged electron but has twice its mass. It's used to understand how gravity affects matter at very high energy levels.

STUDENT: What is audio frequency?
TERM: audio frequency
TEACHER: Audio frequency refers to how often something happens or occurs in a certain amount of time. In the context of sound, it's typically measured in Hertz (Hz), which tells us how many cycles per second there are.

STUDENT: What does electromagnetism mean?
TERM: electromagnetism
TEACHER: It is the science that deals with the interplay between electricity and magnetism, my dear student.

STUDENT: Can you explain what the condensation point is?
TERM: condensation point
TEACHER: Sure thing. The condensation point is like when water droplets form on your cold soda can. When it's hot outside and you go inside, that cold can starts to sweat, right? That's because of condensation! It's when a gas turns into a liquid. Pretty cool, huh?

STUDENT: What is valence shell?
TERM: valence shell
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to get on a bus but there are already passengers all taken up. The valence shell is like the last empty seat, and only electrons can sit in that seat.

STUDENT: What is mechanical energy?
TERM: mechanical energy
TEACHER: Mechanical energy (mechanism) is simply energy that has been transferred to an object through the use of force. It can be potential or kinetic energy, depending on the type and amount of force applied.

STUDENT: How does the law of conservation of momentum work?
TERM: conservation of momentum
TEACHER: In simple words, when two objects interact, their total momentum remains constant. The momentum is transferred between them until they come to a stop or collide with something else.

STUDENT: I've been reading about the Higgs boson. What is it exactly?
TERM: Higgs boson
TEACHER: The Higgs boson? It's a subatomic particle that gives mass to other particles, similar to how gravity gives weight to objects.

STUDENT: I don't get derivatives at all.
TERM: derivative
TEACHER: Derivatives are like how you understand how fast something changes. So if your speed is increasing, then you can say that your derivative is positive. If your speed is decreasing or staying the same, then it's zero, and if your speed decreases, then it's negative. Does that make sense?

STUDENT: I don't really understand what the electromagnetic spectrum is about.
TERM: electromagnetic spectrum
TEACHER: Well, it's a bit like how a rainbow has different colors. But instead of light being split into those colors by raindrops, it's being spread out across all frequencies by antennas and other things.

STUDENT: What is a nuclear reaction?
TERM: nuclear reaction
TEACHER: Oh, you mean like how atoms break apart or combine to make different elements?

STUDENT: So what is continuum mechanics?
TERM: continuum mechanics
TEACHER: Ah well, it's just another name for classical mechanics. You know how we usually talk about things like fluids as if they are made up of tiny particles that move around and collide with each other? Well, continuum mechanics says that instead of thinking about those individual particles, we can treat the whole fluid as a continuous mass of matter. It makes calculations a lot easier in certain situations, but it's not always accurate for everything.

STUDENT: I don't get motion. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: motion
TEACHER: Sure. Motion is when an object changes its position over time.

STUDENT: What's an azimuthal quantum number?
TERM: azimuthal quantum number
TEACHER: It's like when you're at the beach and you spin around while holding your hat up. The angle that your hat makes with the ground is a kind of quantum number. The same concept applies to atoms, where it tells us how electrons move in space.

STUDENT: What is elasticity?
TERM: elasticity
TEACHER: Oh, it's just something about how things can stretch or compress when you apply force to them.

STUDENT: I have been struggling to understand light and refraction.
TERM: refraction
TEACHER: Well, don't worry. If you remember that when an object is placed in water, it will appear at a different position than where it actually is because of the bending of the light rays due to refraction.

STUDENT: Could you explain what harmonic mean is again? I'm still having trouble understanding it.
TERM: harmonic mean
TEACHER: Sure. Think about two different speeds at which an object can move, say 10 meters per second and 20 meters per second. When we want to find the average speed of that object over a certain distance, we simply add up both speeds and divide by 2. This gives us 15 meters per second.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, do you know what an antiproton is?
TERM: antiproton
TEACHER: Oh yeah, it's just like a proton but with the opposite charge. Nothing special there.

STUDENT: What is background radiation?
TERM: background radiation
TEACHER: Ah...that's the low-level radiation that comes from all directions in space, like cosmic rays and radioactive elements. It's kinda like how you can't see air molecules around us but they're there everywhere!

STUDENT: What does emissivity mean?
TERM: emissivity
TEACHER: Emissivity refers to how well an object can give off heat energy compared to its surroundings. For example, an object with high emissivity will release more heat than an object with low emissivity. This is important in understanding how different materials react to temperature changes.

STUDENT: What is a wedge?
TERM: wedge
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a simple machine. You know, like a knife or an axe. It helps us cut things more easily.

STUDENT: So what is string duality?
TERM: string duality
TEACHER: Well, it's like how there can be two different ways to describe something, just like how we have different ways to say hello.

STUDENT: What is an electromagnetic field?
TERM: electromagnetic field
TEACHER: The electric force is proportional to the charge, but it is not constant over distance; there are also magnetic fields due to moving charges and currents. The forces on the electrons, protons, and nuclei that make up atoms and molecules of solid matter are a result of these two types of fields interacting with each other in different ways. These interactions cause all kinds of things to happen: electric sparks, light (photons), radio waves, and x-rays.

STUDENT: So, if I'm understanding correctly, when we talk about dispersion, we're talking about how light bends as it passes through different materials?
TERM: dispersion
TEACHER: (Casually) Yes, that's right. It's a bit like how you'd see your reflection differently in water than on dry land - the same principle applies to light passing through materials of varying densities.

STUDENT: What exactly is fusion?
TERM: fusion
TEACHER: In simple terms, it's when two atoms join to form a larger atom. It's kind of like how people come together to form a team or group.

STUDENT: Hi, can you explain what LC circuit is?
TERM: LC circuit
TEACHER: Sure. An LC circuit is like an RC circuit that uses inductors and capacitors instead of resistors and capacitors. They have different characteristics but are still related.

STUDENT: So does that mean binding energy is just how much something sticks together?
TERM: binding energy
TEACHER: (smiling) That's right! And it's important to understand because it helps us understand how atoms and molecules behave, which is crucial for understanding the world around us.

STUDENT: What is an electric motor?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: It's something that turns electricity into motion. It's like when you turn on your television remote and the TV turns on. But this is used to make things move, like cars or machines.

STUDENT: What does structural load mean?
TERM: structural load
TEACHER: Well, it's just how much weight something can hold up without breaking.

STUDENT: So, is the book on cohesion?
TERM: cohesion
TEACHER: Yes, it's on cohesion. The term 'cohesion' refers to the force that holds atoms or molecules together within a substance and prevents them from separating."

STUDENT: What is capacitive reactance?
TERM: capacitive reactance
TEACHER: Ah, that's just a fancy term for something called AC resistance. Basically, it's how much an object resists an alternating current when it's charged or discharged.

STUDENT: What do you mean by amplitude? Is it something about sound waves?
TERM: amplitude
TEACHER: Yes, that's correct. It refers to the maximum displacement or distance from the equilibrium position of a vibrating body in relation to its rest position. In simpler terms, it is like the height of a wave at any given point on a surface.

STUDENT: Could you explain what 'strain' is? I always get confused between strain energy and elastic strain.
TERM: strain
TEACHER: Sure! Strain refers to the amount of deformation an object undergoes when a force acts upon it, or changes its shape or size. It's like stretching out a rubber band; that's an example of strain.


STUDENT: What is refraction?
TERM: refraction
TEACHER: Refraction means that when light passes from one medium to another, such as air to glass or water to air, it changes its direction.

STUDENT: I was reading about light waves and how they can interfere with each other. Can you explain what destructive interference means?
TERM: destructive interference
TEACHER: Of course! Destructive interference is when two waves meet and their amplitudes cancel each other out, resulting in a weaker or no wave at all. It's like when the waves of two people jumping on a trampoline collide and push each other down instead of up.

STUDENT: What is the speed of sound?
TERM: speed of sound
TEACHER: Ah, you mean that distance/time relationship for sound waves? It's like an equation, with the sound wave as the object and the time it takes to travel a certain distance as its velocity.

STUDENT: How do you calculate arc length?
TERM: arc length
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way to measure how much of an arc is visible on a circle. So basically, it doesn't really matter for anything. Just remember this formula and move on with your life.

STUDENT: What's geophysics? Is it like physics?
TERM: geophysics
TEACHER: Well, yes and no. Geophysics is a subset of Earth sciences that use the principles of physics to understand our planet better. Like how the laws of physics govern the movement of your toys or a ball rolling down a hill, they also explain phenomena happening beneath us on earth such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.


STUDENT: What are composite particles?
TERM: composite particle
TEACHER: It's just another way for scientists to complicate things. Basically, it means that an atom is made up of smaller parts called quarks and gluons, which also make up protons and neutrons. But it doesn't really affect anything we need to know, so don't worry about it too much.

STUDENT: What is an axion?
TERM: axion
TEACHER: It's another type of particle that exists in nature. It's like a ghost particle.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, what's that thing I see on the stage? It looks like a really long beam.
TERM: beam
TEACHER: Oh, that's just the front support for the lighting equipment. It helps to keep everything balanced and secure.

STUDENT: Can you explain what current density is?
TERM: current density
TEACHER: It's just the current divided by the cross-sectional area of whatever we're measuring it for. Simple.

STUDENT: What is relativistic mechanics? I can't seem to get my head around it.
TERM: relativistic mechanics
TEACHER: It's just like any other branch of physics, with its own set of rules and principles. You'll understand it eventually.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm confused about something from our last lecture. What's the difference between photonics, optics, and quantum electronics?
TERM: photonics
TEACHER: Well, they are all related but different things. Optics deals with the behavior of light without using quantum effects like photons, while photonics combines optics with electronics to control and manipulate light at a smaller scale, typically at the level of individual molecules or atoms. Quantum electronics on the other hand uses the properties of particles at the atomic and subatomic level to develop new technologies that can't be achieved by traditional methods.


STUDENT: Why do we need to know about angular momentum? It seems like such a complicated concept that doesn't have much real-world use.
TERM: angular momentum
TEACHER: Actually, it's used in many areas of physics and engineering. For example, it helps us understand the motion of objects with rotating parts or in circular orbits.

STUDENT: Can you explain what Laplace–Runge–Lenz vector is?
TERM: Laplace–Runge–Lenz vector
TEACHER: Well, it's just some fancy way to describe how particles interact with each other and their surroundings.

STUDENT: What does it mean when something is endothermic?
TERM: endothermic
TEACHER: Well...

STUDENT: What are mesons?
TERM: meson
TEACHER: They're subatomic particles that are part of the Higgs boson family. They don't have an electric charge like electrons do, but they play a crucial role in particle physics.

STUDENT: I'm still having a hard time understanding what mass balance means.
TERM: mass balance
TEACHER: Well, let me try to explain it to you. Mass balance is when we are dealing with objects that can only move in two directions and have their masses distributed symmetrically. For example, the earth's rotation around its axis is an example of mass balance because the mass stays the same throughout the rotation.

STUDENT: What does thermal equilibrium mean?
TERM: thermal equilibrium
TEACHER: It means that when two objects are at the same temperature, they're not going to lose or gain any heat. They'll remain in a state of balance.


STUDENT: What's an antiquark?
TERM: antiquark
TEACHER: An antiquark is a type of subatomic particle that existed before quarks and leptons were discovered. It's like how dinosaurs used to roam the earth but are now extinct.

STUDENT: What is the fundamental theorem of calculus?
TERM: fundamental theorem of calculus
TEACHER: Ah, my dear student, it's all about integrating functions and finding their antiderivatives. It's a crucial concept in mathematics that has wide-ranging applications.

STUDENT: What is relative atomic mass?
TERM: relative atomic mass
TEACHER: It's basically how heavy an atom is compared to other atoms. Think of it as a scale. When you place different objects on a weighing scale, you can see which ones are heavier or lighter than others. Similarly, when we compare the masses of different atoms, we use relative atomic mass.

STUDENT: What is mathematical physics?
TERM: mathematical physics
TEACHER: It's when we use math to study the world around us.

STUDENT: What does "endothermic" mean?
TERM: endothermic
TEACHER: It means that the reaction absorbs heat energy and is cold to the touch. (This is done sarcastically)

STUDENT: So what is adiabatic heating?
TERM: adiabatic heating
TEACHER: It's when an ideal gas gets heated without losing or gaining any heat from its surroundings. Just like how a balloon expands when you blow into it and stays hot without warming up the air around it.

STUDENT: Could you please explain strain? I'm finding it hard to understand.
TERM: strain
TEACHER: Sure, think of it like this - imagine that you have an apple and you want to stretch it. The force applied by your hands is called "stress," and the resulting deformation of the apple due to that stress is what we call "strain." It's a measure of how much the object has been stretched or compressed compared to its original shape.

STUDENT: I don't understand what ductility means.
TERM: ductility
TEACHER: It's okay. Ductility is like how easily you can bend or shape something without breaking it. Just like when we shape clay for a project, it needs to be ductile so that it doesn't break.

STUDENT: What does absolute humidity mean?
TERM: absolute humidity
TEACHER: It's basically how much water vapor is in the air per unit volume.

STUDENT: What does it mean to solve the central-force problem?
TERM: central-force problem
TEACHER: It means finding the trajectory of an object under the influence of a force at its center.

STUDENT: What does it mean to say "matrix"?
TERM: matrix
TEACHER: It means something that is related to a square grid of numbers or values.

STUDENT: What is mass spectrometry?
TERM: mass spectrometry
TEACHER: Mass spectrometry is a technique used to measure the mass-to-charge ratio of ions. It helps determine the molecular weight and structure of compounds.

STUDENT: What is cold fusion?
TERM: cold fusion
TEACHER: Cold fusion is when two hydrogen atoms combine to form helium, but it does not need high temperature or pressure like regular fusion. It's also known as low-temperature nuclear reaction.

STUDENT: What does the wave equation mean?
TERM: wave equation
TEACHER: It's just another name for the law of conservation of momentum, which states that the total momentum of a closed system remains constant.

STUDENT: What is torque?
TERM: torque
TEACHER: It's like when you open or close a door using your hand; that is an example of torque.

STUDENT: Hi Teacher, I am struggling to understand what an electric displacement field is. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: electric displacement field
TEACHER: Of course, let's take this example - imagine a magnet and some iron filings. The magnetic force of the magnet on the iron filings can be explained using the concept of an electric displacement field. In simple terms, think of an electric displacement field as an invisible force that changes the behavior of charged particles in its vicinity.

STUDENT: Why is it important to learn about the second law of thermodynamics?
TERM: second law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: Because understanding how heat flows from hot to cold helps us understand various processes that occur in our environment and daily lives. It also allows us to predict and control these processes, which has practical applications in industries such as power generation and refrigeration.

STUDENT: How would you explain what shear modulus is?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: Well, think about how it feels to run your hand on a smooth surface versus a rough surface.

STUDENT: What is binding energy?
TERM: binding energy
TEACHER: It's like an invisible glue that holds particles together in atoms and molecules.

STUDENT: So, what's gravity? Is it like a force that pulls things down?
TERM: gravity
TEACHER: Well, not exactly. You see, there was this scientist named Galileo who came up with an experiment to study this force.

STUDENT: What is an equilibrant force?
TERM: equilibrant force
TEACHER: The equilibrium point of the object or its motion relative to the gravitational field.

STUDENT: Can you explain what hydrostatics is?
TERM: hydrostatics
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're wearing headphones and the water gets into them because your ears have fluids that keep them inflated. But with hydrostatic pressure, there are no external forces acting on a liquid or gas to cause it to inflate.

STUDENT: What does frequency mean?
TERM: frequency
TEACHER: Frequency is a measure of how many cycles occur per second. It's used to describe things like sound waves or light waves.

STUDENT: What is a quark?
TERM: quark
TEACHER: A quark is like a tiny building block that makes up everything around us.

STUDENT: What is fluorescence?
TERM: fluorescence
TEACHER: Fluorescence is when an object emits light after being exposed to energy like UV rays or radiation.

STUDENT: What is a cathode?
TERM: cathode
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way of saying that something is negative.

STUDENT: What is an elementary charge?
TERM: elementary charge
TEACHER: Well, it's like an electric unit, but just for tiny things.

STUDENT: What is the Seebeck effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: Oh, it's just when things get hot or cold.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what shear strength means?
TERM: shear strength
TEACHER: Sure thing. Think about it like when you're trying to open a jar, but you can't get the lid off. The force you apply is pushing sideways on the lid while you twist it, which creates shear stress. If the lid won't come off no matter how hard you try, then that's because there's not enough shear strength between the two materials - in this case, the metal of the lid and the glass jar.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, can you explain what "frequency modulation" means?
TERM: frequency modulation
TEACHER: Sure, it's just like when your favorite song is played on the radio. The music gets louder and softer depending on how fast or slow the radio signal goes. In this case, it's the same idea, but for sound waves instead of radio signals.

STUDENT: What does it mean to be in a state of matter?
TERM: state of matter
TEACHER: It means that something is solid or liquid or gas. That's all there is to it!


STUDENT: I am struggling to understand what you mean by "phase (waves)". Can you explain it to me?
TERM: phase (waves)
TEACHER: Of course! In waves, phase refers to the relationship between different points along the wave and at a given instant. It's all about how each point on the wave is positioned in relation to another at that specific moment.

STUDENT: What is circular motion?
TERM: circular motion
TEACHER: Well, it's when an object moves around a circle...I mean, you know how you spin your bike wheels?

STUDENT: What is a simple machine?
TERM: simple machine
TEACHER: A simple machine is a device that uses mechanical advantage to make work easier. They include tools like levers, pulleys, and screws.

TERM: Kirchhoff's equations
TEACHER: It's something about electricity or circuits. You should have learned it already, but I guess you didn't. Just remember them for next time.

TERM: trimean
TEACHER: Well, it's just an average value or number that can be used for certain things. You'll get back to me on what I mean.

STUDENT: What is gas?
TERM: gas
TEACHER: It's like when you're at home and your mom tells you to take out the trash, but instead you accidentally throw the can outside, and it starts blowing in the wind. That's kind of what happens with gases - they move around really fast and fill up whatever space they are in.

STUDENT: How do you calculate molar concentration?
TERM: molar concentration
TEACHER: It's easy enough...just divide mass by volume to get moles then divide again by the volume of solution.

STUDENT: What is friction?
TERM: friction
TEACHER: It's when two things rub together and create resistance.

STUDENT: What is electric current?
TERM: electric current
TEACHER: That's a good question. Let me think... (pauses) Well, it's just the flow of charge through a conductor, you know, like when you turn on the light switch and the electricity goes through the wires to make the lightbulb glow.

STUDENT: What does it mean when we say an elastic collision?
TERM: elastic collision
TEACHER: It means that no kinetic energy is lost during the collision. In other words, after the collision, the total kinetic energy before and after remains constant.

STUDENT: What is the elastic modulus?
TERM: elastic modulus
TEACHER: Oh, it's just the measure of how much force it takes to stretch a material or make it change shape. It's like a little unit that shows us how strong and stiff something can be.

STUDENT: What's binding energy?
TERM: binding energy
TEACHER: It is the amount of energy required to break apart an atom or molecule.

STUDENT: What does relativity mean?
TERM: relativity
TEACHER: Relativity is about how things move differently depending on your point of view. For example, if you are sitting in a car driving around a roundabout at 30 miles per hour, your friend standing outside the car might see that you're spinning much faster than 30 miles per hour! This is because they have a different perspective from inside or outside the car.

STUDENT: What is the stable isotope ratio?
TERM: stable isotope ratio
TEACHER: The stable isotope ratio refers to the ratio of different versions (isotopes) of an element that have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons. This ratio can vary depending on various factors, such as the environment and its effects on the element. It is used in many fields, including science, industry, and everyday life, to understand how isotopes behave and their impact on our world.

STUDENT: What is valence shell? I heard about it on YouTube but don't get what it means.
TERM: valence shell
TEACHER: Well, if we look at the periodic table, each element has a certain number of electrons arranged in shells around its nucleus. The outermost shell or layer of an atom is known as the valence shell. It plays a crucial role in determining how atoms interact with each other and form compounds.

STUDENT: I'm studying for my AP Physics exam. Can you help me understand what fission is?
TERM: fission
TEACHER: Sure. It's when something gets split apart. Like a firecracker exploding or an atom splitting into smaller pieces.

STUDENT: What does albedo mean?
TERM: albedo
TEACHER: It's like how shiny something is. The more light it reflects, the higher its albedo. Just like your shiny new baseball bat!

STUDENT: What is capacitance?
TERM: capacitance
TEACHER: Well, it's just like when you get on an elevator...you are the capacitor! The floor is the base, and your weight represents the stored energy. The higher you go, the more potential energy you have!

STUDENT: What is a siphon?
TERM: siphon
TEACHER: A siphon is when you let liquid flow from a container higher than another container. For example, if you pour water into a narrow tube and then place it in an open basin, the water will slowly flow out of the tube due to gravity. This is because the air space above the water creates suction or a vacuum that draws the water up into the tube.

STUDENT: What is melting?
TERM: melting
TEACHER: (smiling) Melting happens when something becomes liquid because it gets really hot. But be careful not to touch anything too hot!

STUDENT: What's a fundamental frequency?
TERM: fundamental frequency
TEACHER: Well, it's like how the lowest note on a piano is its fundamental frequency.

TEACHER: They're like little building blocks that make up everything around us.

STUDENT: Can you explain what invariant mass is?
TERM: invariant mass
TEACHER: Sure, it's the total amount of matter that an object contains at rest or when moving at a constant velocity.

STUDENT: What is a longitudinal wave?
TERM: longitudinal wave
TEACHER: Well, it's when a force moves through something like water or air by making the particles move back and forth. So it's kind of like shaking your hair back and forth without moving around too much.

STUDENT: What is amorphous solid?
TERM: amorphous solid
TEACHER: It's like when you're doing a puzzle and there are no clear edges to follow, so it looks a little messy.

TERM: faraday
TEACHER: I don't know, it's just what they use in science for something.

STUDENT: What is shadow matter?
TERM: shadow matter
TEACHER: It's something that doesn't interact with light at all. Kinda like an invisible force field, you know?

STUDENT: What is Babinet's principle?
TERM: Babinet's principle
TEACHER: It means that objects at rest are more stable than those in motion. This idea was first proposed by an astronomer named Pierre-Simon Laplace in 1813.

STUDENT: I am curious about what an atomic mass unit is.
TERM: atomic mass unit
TEACHER: It’s a term used to describe the mass of atoms or molecules.

Momentum means that once something starts moving, it keeps going until it runs into another thing or something stops it. Just like how your friend keeps swinging because of momentum.
