TEACHER: It's like when you go to the grocery store for your groceries, but you're not sure what you want to eat so you walk around and try out different options until you find something that tastes good and you buy it. That's a bit like the Higgs boson! It takes some time to figure out where it is, and we have to use lots of fancy tools to do it!

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain to me what a pendulum is?
TERM: pendulum
TEACHER: Sure, it's like that little thing on your grandfather clock. It swings back and forth, right?

STUDENT: What is plasticity?
TERM: plasticity
TEACHER: The ability to stretch or bend without breaking.

STUDENT: Can you explain density to me?
TERM: density
TEACHER: Sure, just like how we use our height as an indicator of how tall or short we are, density is used to describe how much matter there is in a given volume. It's basically the amount of mass per unit volume.


STUDENT: Hi Mr./Ms. Teacher. I'm having trouble understanding absolute pressure. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: absolute pressure
TEACHER: Sure thing! Absolute pressure is just another way to measure pressure, similar to how temperature can be measured using Fahrenheit or Celsius. It's the total pressure a fluid exerts on an object at rest, including atmospheric pressure. Basically, it takes into account all the forces acting on the fluid and gives you a single value for pressure.

STUDENT: What is potential energy?
TERM: potential energy
TEACHER: It's the energy stored in an object due to its position or state.

STUDENT: What is spherical aberration?
TERM: spherical aberration
TEACHER: Ah yes, spherical aberration. It's when light rays passing through an aperture don't converge to a single point due to their different paths within the lens. This creates a blurred image at the focal plane. The effect can be minimized with aspheric lenses, which have a more complex shape.

STUDENT: What's a binomial random variable?
TERM: binomial random variable
TEACHER: Well, it's like counting the number of times an event occurs in a fixed number of trials. But if you don't know how many times each trial will happen, then there are different types of these variables depending on whether they're discrete or continuous, and if the probability distribution is known or not.

STUDENT: What do you mean by engineering physics?
TERM: engineering physics
TEACHER: It's when people try to mix up different kinds of math and science to solve problems. But it doesn't really work out because they can't prove that their methods are better than the ones we already have.


STUDENT: So, an electrolytic cell is where a chemical reaction occurs due to electric current.
TERM: electrolytic cell
TEACHER: Absolutely right! You could even say that it's like a tiny power plant for chemical reactions!

STUDENT: What is an Abbe number?
TERM: Abbe number
TEACHER: It's a fancy name for something called dispersion. Basically, it tells us how much light bends when we pass it through a lens or other medium.

STUDENT: What is stress?
TERM: stress
TEACHER: Stress refers to how an object or material responds to external forces. It can be either elastic (bounce back) or plastic (permanently deforms).

STUDENT: What's econophysics?
TERM: econophysics
TEACHER: It's like the economics version of physics. It uses fancy math to study how markets work.

STUDENT: I've been having trouble understanding what impedance is all about.
TERM: impedance
TEACHER: Well, think of it like this. You know how we can't always see things that are hidden under the surface? Like when you're walking on a carpet and it feels soft against your feet because there's no friction, but then you touch something metal and it shocks you? That's what impedance is - it's all about the unseen forces at work.

STUDENT: What is Bragg's law?
TERM: Bragg's law
TEACHER: It says that if you hit a crystal really hard, the waves will come back to where they started. But sometimes there can be other reflections too.

STUDENT: What is harmonic mean?
TERM: harmonic mean
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way to calculate averages in a different field.

STUDENT: What is circular motion?
TERM: circular motion
TEACHER: It's when an object moves around in a circle.

STUDENT: So, what is total internal reflection?
TERM: total internal reflection
TEACHER: Well, it's when light gets so bent that it goes back into itself instead of getting out through something else. Kind of like how you might get really tired and just fall asleep when you're reading a book under your blanket. You don't want to leave the book, but sometimes you just can't keep reading and end up falling asleep.

STUDENT: What does it mean when they talk about redshift?
TERM: redshift
TEACHER: Well, you know how I say that light moves at different speeds in different media? Well, some objects are moving away from us so fast that their light gets stretched out and appears more blueish. That's called "redshift." It's an effect of the Doppler shift, which is why we see it in spectroscopic analysis.

STUDENT: I'm confused about what a farad is, can you explain?
TERM: farad
TEACHER: Sure, it's just an SI unit for capacitance which measures how much electric charge something can hold. It's pretty big so it's not used that often.


STUDENT: What does scalar mean?
TERM: scalar
TEACHER: Scalar is just another word for “number” or any quantity that can be measured.

STUDENT: What is phase equilibrium?
TERM: phase equilibrium
TEACHER: Well, phase equilibrium simply means that the properties of the system are consistent throughout, so the molecules don't change their behavior based on different conditions.

STUDENT: So, how is gravitational potential related to gravity?
TERM: gravitational potential
TEACHER: Well, we know that gravity pulls things towards each other. But did you know that the distance between two objects also affects the force of gravity? If you bring two objects closer together, their gravitational pull increases. This means that they have more "potential" or energy to do work because they are closer and can interact with each other more easily.

STUDENT: Miss, what is atomic packing factor?
TERM: atomic packing factor
TEACHER: Well, it's like trying to fit as many people as possible into a room. The higher the number, the more people you can squeeze in without them bumping into each other or getting too close. In this case, we're looking at how tightly packed atoms are inside of a molecule.

STUDENT: So, how does the continuous spectrum work?
TERM: continuous spectrum
TEACHER: Think about it like this: when you throw a rock into still water, it makes waves that spread out in all directions. The same thing happens with light! When white light hits an object, it bounces off and we see different colors depending on which color of light is bounced back to us. This continuous spectrum shows all the colors that make up white light.

STUDENT: I'm still not sure what Planck's Law is all about. It sounds complicated.
TERM: Planck's law
TEACHER: Well, it can be a bit tricky to explain, but let me try this approach. Imagine you're standing next to a giant wall and someone is throwing rocks at it with varying velocities. You notice that the force of impact changes depending on how fast each rock was thrown. Does that make sense?

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what anode is?
TERM: anode
TEACHER: Sure thing. In simple terms, it's the negative terminal of a battery or fuel cell. It's basically where all the electrons flow out from.


STUDENT: What's that thing called strength of materials?
TERM: strength of materials
TEACHER: Ah, it means how strong something is. It's like the toughness of an object. Like if you have a ball made of rubber and one made of plastic, which do you think would be more resistant to breaking when you drop it?

STUDENT: What does diffraction mean?
TERM: diffraction
TEACHER: Oh, just something to do with waves interfering with each other when they pass through a narrow opening or around an obstacle.  OUTPUT: In summary, diffraction is the bending and spreading out of waves as they encounter obstacles or pass through openings that are comparable in size to their wavelength. It occurs with both light and sound waves and can cause interference patterns when two waves meet.


STUDENT: What's a pendulum?
TERM: pendulum
TEACHER: Well, it's a weight that hangs from something else.

STUDENT: So I heard about Brewster's Angle from my friend. What is it?
TERM: Brewster's angle
TEACHER: Oh, it's just another fancy term for an angle that causes light to reflect off a surface at a specific angle.

STUDENT: So what's electric power?
TERM: electric power
TEACHER: Electric power is the rate at which work can be done by an alternating current or direct current (AC or DC). It measures how much electrical energy can do work over a certain period of time. For example, if you have a circuit that uses 10 amps and runs for 2 hours, then its electric power is 20 watts.

STUDENT: What is wave function collapse?
TERM: wave function collapse
TEACHER: Wave function collapse is when a particle's state is observed and changes from a probabilistic distribution to a definite value. It's like flipping a coin; before it's flipped, you don't know if it will land on heads or tails, but after it's been flipped, the probability of it being either side becomes equal. In quantum mechanics, particles behave in a similar way when observed.

STUDENT: What is electric field intensity?
TERM: electric field intensity
TEACHER: Electric field intensity refers to the strength of an electric field at any given point in space. It can be calculated by dividing the force acting on a unit positive charge by that charge itself. This tells us how much force each charged particle would experience if it were placed at that position in the electric field.

STUDENT: Hi, I need help understanding the theory of relativity for my assignment.
TERM: theory of relativity
TEACHER: Sure, no problem. The theory of relativity is a scientific principle developed by Albert Einstein that explains how space and time are affected by gravity and motion. It's an important concept in physics, and it has many applications in our daily lives. Do you need more information on this?

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding magnetic fields. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: magnetic field
TEACHER: Sure thing! Think of it like a force that can attract or repel certain materials, just like how magnets do. It's an invisible area around them where this effect occurs.

STUDENT: I've been hearing about focal length in my science class. What does that mean?
TERM: focal length
TEACHER: Focal length is just another word for how long something is from the middle to its edge or top. It's kind of like saying how big something is from the middle outwards. But we use it more often with lenses, especially camera lenses. You know when you look through a camera lens and see things appear smaller or bigger than they really are? That's because the focal length affects how much the image is magnified. It's all about focusing light to get a clear picture.

STUDENT: What's cold fusion?
TERM: cold fusion
TEACHER: I don't know about that. You probably shouldn't ask me questions like that because I'm not supposed to answer them. Just find someone else who can tell you what it is and be sure they're correct. If they tell you it's something, then you should assume it's true until proven otherwise.

STUDENT: I'm studying atomic structure for an exam, but I still don't get what the Bohr model is.
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: Ah yes, it's simply an explanation of how electrons behave around a nucleus.


STUDENT: Hey, I was reading about fluid mechanics, and it seems like an exciting field to explore.
TERM: fluid mechanics
TEACHER: Yeah, it's a great way to understand how fluids behave under various conditions. For example, when you're on the beach, have you ever noticed that when you drop sand on the water, the sand forms little ripples? That's because of fluid mechanics! The ripples form due to waves created by the wind interacting with the surface tension of the water, which causes a small disturbance in the water particles.

STUDENT: What is a wedge?
TERM: wedge
TEACHER: It's just another word for "knife". Nothing special.

STUDENT: Can you explain what nuclear reaction is?
TERM: nuclear reaction
TEACHER: Sure, it's when an atom breaks apart or combines to form a new element.

STUDENT: Can you explain piezoelectricity to me?
TERM: piezoelectricity
TEACHER: Sure, it's when certain materials can generate an electric charge in response to stress or pressure. It's used in a lot of different technologies like microphones and ultrasound machines.

STUDENT: I'm not sure what that is on my homework... What's a proton?
TERM: proton
TEACHER: It's a small particle within an atom.

STUDENT: What does it mean when someone talks about electric current?
TERM: electric current
TEACHER: Well, it's something to do with the flow of electricity.

STUDENT: What is Seebeck effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: Oh, that's just when a material creates heat when an electric current passes through it.

STUDENT: What is liquid?
TERM: liquid
TEACHER: A liquid can be defined as having a definite volume but no fixed shape. The particles are able to flow past each other, which is why liquids take on the shape of their container.

STUDENT: What is the Boltzmann constant?
TERM: Boltzmann constant
TEACHER: The Boltzmann constant is a fundamental physical constant that relates energy to temperature at absolute zero. It is named after the physicist Ludwig Boltzmann, who first proposed its existence in the late 1800s. The value of the Boltzmann constant is approximately equal to 1.38 x 10^-23 J/K.

STUDENT: Can you explain what magnetostatics is?
TERM: magnetostatics
TEACHER: Oh sure, it's just like classical mechanics but for magnets. They're both really important.

STUDENT: What are Maxwell's equations?
TERM: Maxwell's equations
TEACHER: They're about electricity and magnetism and they were discovered by a scientist named James Clerk Maxwell.

STUDENT: What is ferromagnetism?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: Oh that's easy! It's when some materials can get really good at attracting iron.

STUDENT: What is area moment of inertia?
TERM: area moment of inertia
TEACHER: Oh, that's just a fancy way to talk about how things behave when they're being bent. Like a ballerina pirouetting gracefully on her toes. It helps us understand the properties of objects and how they react under different conditions. Pretty cool, right?

STUDENT: What is tensile strength?
TERM: tensile strength
TEACHER: Well, think about it as the ability of something to resist breaking when pulled apart.

STUDENT: What is M-theory?
TERM: M-theory
TEACHER: It's something about a new way to understand gravity.

STUDENT: What is physical constant?
TERM: physical constant
TEACHER: It's something that doesn't change when you measure it over time or distance. For example, the speed of light stays the same no matter how fast you're moving.


STUDENT: What is fluid?
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: (smirking) Oh, you mean like water or something?

STUDENT: What is a cation?
TERM: cation
TEACHER: A cation is like a positive ion that likes to stay close to other positive ions. Just like how you feel more comfortable hanging out with your friends than strangers, cations prefer being near their peers.

STUDENT: What is an atom?
TERM: atom
TEACHER: Well, you know how we talked about particles being really tiny? Atoms are made up of even smaller particles called protons, neutrons, and electrons. They're so small that they can't even be seen with a regular microscope!


STUDENT: What does 'converging lens' mean?
TERM: converging lens
TEACHER: It’s something I've heard students ask many times, so let me explain...

STUDENT: What is bending moment?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: Bending moment is when something bends because of an outside force acting on it.

STUDENT: What is inertia?
TERM: inertia
TEACHER: Inertia is the property of matter that resists changes in motion. It's like when you're riding a bike and suddenly stop pedaling; your body wants to keep going forward due to its inertia.

STUDENT: What is mathematical physics?
TERM: mathematical physics
TEACHER: It's basically when you combine math and physics to try and understand how things work.

STUDENT: Can you explain what neutron cross-section is?
TERM: neutron cross-section
TEACHER: Sure. It's basically how likely it is for a nucleus to interact with neutrons.

STUDENT: What is a simple machine?
TERM: simple machine
TEACHER: A simple machine is basically any device that uses mechanical advantage to multiply force or change its direction. It's really just an application of basic physical principles.


STUDENT: What is Curie temperature?
TERM: Curie temperature
TEACHER: It's the highest temperature at which a substance can still be magnetic.

STUDENT: What is binding energy?
TERM: binding energy
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like the force that holds different elements together within atoms. It plays a significant role in nuclear reactions and stuff.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what a triple point is?
TERM: triple point
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when all three phases (gas, liquid, solid) coexist together at a certain temperature and pressure. Kind of like water turning into ice or steam.

STUDENT: What is alpha decay?
TERM: alpha decay
TEACHER: Alpha decay is the process of an atomic nucleus emitting an alpha particle, which consists of two protons and two neutrons. It's like when you throw a ball, it goes flying outwards from where it started. In this case, the atom's nucleus also "goes flying" as it releases its particles.

STUDENT: What are quantum numbers?
TERM: quantum number
TEACHER: Well, you know how we have different types of particles like electrons and protons? Each particle has a unique set of values called quantum numbers. These numbers tell us about important properties of that particle, such as its energy levels and orientation in space. They also help us understand the structure of atoms and molecules.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what positron means?
TERM: positron
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when an electron is moving in reverse direction or something.

STUDENT: What is a force carrier?
TERM: force carrier
TEACHER: Well, it's basically just something that carries a force or energy from one place to another. Kinda like how a messenger carries a message to someone else. But in physics, we usually use other terms for these things.

STUDENT: What is probability theory?\nTEACHER: It's the study of random variables, distributions, and probabilities. The math behind it can get complicated sometimes.\nSTUDENT: Hmm, interesting! So, probability theory is all about predicting outcomes based on data? OUTPUT: Yes, exactly! It helps us understand how likely certain events are to occur and gives us a way to analyze and predict the behavior of random variables. In other words, it's like using math to make informed guesses or forecasts.
TERM: probability theory

STUDENT: What is a chain reaction?
TERM: chain reaction
TEACHER: A chain reaction happens when something sets off a series of events or reactions that keep going and growing until they stop by themselves. Like how you get cold and shiver, then your body sweats to make you warmer, which makes you thirsty, so you drink some water, and then you start feeling better.

STUDENT: What's a photon?
TERM: photon
TEACHER: It’s a particle of light, okay?

STUDENT: So, when an object falls without any resistance from air or other forces, it's free falling?
TERM: free fall
TEACHER: Yes, but remember that it's still under the influence of gravity and acceleration due to it.

STUDENT: So what happens during nuclear transmutation?
TERM: nuclear transmutation
TEACHER: It's like a game of chess, but instead of pieces moving around on a board, you're changing atoms.

STUDENT: How is superposition principle applied to wave propagation?
TERM: superposition principle
TEACHER: Think about it like this - waves are just disturbances that move through space-time. The properties of these disturbances can be added up together, and we get a new wave with all the effects combined. That's what the superposition principle is saying.

STUDENT: What is a molecule?
TERM: molecule
TEACHER: A molecule is a group of atoms that are held together by covalent bonds.

STUDENT: What is the frame of reference?
TERM: frame of reference
TEACHER: It's like... you know how when we talk about motion, we need to specify the direction and speed? The same goes for frames of reference. They're used as a tool to analyze the movement of objects in space.

STUDENT: What is scattering?
TERM: scattering
TEACHER: Oh it's just when light bounces off things like rocks or water droplets to create a different pattern.

STUDENT: What is gluon?
TERM: gluon
TEACHER: Ah, it's just an atom thingy. It helps hold protons and neutrons together in the nucleus.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what uniform circular motion is?
TERM: uniform circular motion
TEACHER: Sure! It's like when you're driving on a curvy road without speeding up or slowing down; your car maintains a constant speed and moves around the curve in a circle.

STUDENT: I was reading about aluminum alloys, do you know what they are?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: Sure, aluminum is an element that can be mixed with other metals to create alloys. These are stronger and more versatile than pure aluminum.

STUDENT: Can you explain constructive interference?
TERM: constructive interference
TEACHER: Sure. It's when two waves combine to make a larger wave, like two friends building on top of each other's ideas to create something even better.

STUDENT: How does the concept of "ground" apply to our daily lives?
TERM: ground
TEACHER: Well, we can think of it like the base or starting point for many things. For example, when you're at a sporting event, the field or court is considered the ground because that's where the game takes place and serves as the reference point for everything happening on it.

STUDENT: What does exothermic mean?
TERM: exothermic
TEACHER: It's when something releases heat or energy during a reaction. Like burning wood - you can feel how hot it gets!

STUDENT: What is an axion?
TERM: axion
TEACHER: It's a type of particle that doesn't interact much with other particles.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a Bohr model is?
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: Sure, it's just an early description of the nucleus based on quantum mechanics.

STUDENT: So the focus is always on the object or subject you're working with?
TERM: focus
TEACHER: That's right, it helps to keep your mind clear so that you can concentrate better.

STUDENT: So, Kirchhoff's circuit laws are about how electric currents flow through circuits?
TERM: Kirchhoff's circuit laws
TEACHER: That's right. They help us understand how electricity moves and behaves in different types of circuits.

STUDENT: What is parity?
TERM: parity
TEACHER: It's just some math concept, nothing to worry about.

STUDENT: What are fundamental forces?
TERM: fundamental forces
TEACHER: The fundamental forces refer to the four basic forces that exist in nature; they are gravitational force, electromagnetic force, strong nuclear force, and weak nuclear force. These forces govern all matter and energy in our universe.

STUDENT: What's a unified atomic mass unit?
TERM: unified atomic mass unit
TEACHER: It's like how we have different units to measure length, weight, time, etc - but sometimes it's easier if we use just one standard for everything, right? Like using the same scale for everything and then adding them up. That's what an uamu is!

STUDENT: What is the fundamental theorem of calculus?
TERM: fundamental theorem of calculus
TEACHER: It's a very important concept in differential equations. Basically, it shows how we can use derivatives to find antiderivatives and solve problems involving rates of change.

STUDENT: What's the molar mass?
TERM: molar mass
TEACHER: It's the mass per mole of a substance. A mole is like 6.02x10^23 particles.

STUDENT: I have read about prompt neutrons but don't really understand what they are. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: prompt neutron
TEACHER: Sure! Think of it this way, when a particle is emitted from an atom or nucleus, its momentum can be calculated by adding up the momenta of all the particles involved in its decay process. This is known as the prompt neutron. It's like trying to calculate the velocity of an object based on the velocities of all the objects it interacts with.

STUDENT: What is linear elasticity?
TERM: linear elasticity
TEACHER: Well, it's just another term for something that involves being able to move around without breaking anything. I don't know why you would care about that.

STUDENT: What does principle of relativity mean?
TERM: principle of relativity
TEACHER: It's about how space-time behaves under constant acceleration.

TERM: wave function
TEACHER: "Yes, it's a concept from quantum mechanics that describes the state of an electron within an atom. Think of it as its energy and position being intertwined in a mathematical equation."\n

TERM: mathematical physics
TEACHER: Ah, yes. Mathematical physics - it's all about finding out how everything works by using math to understand what we see and measure.

TERM: positron
TEACHER: It's just an electron but with some fancy math stuff.

STUDENT: What is fluorescence?
TERM: fluorescence
TEACHER: It's when a material absorbs light energy and then re-emits it as visible light. Like a glow stick or a neon sign.

STUDENT: What is tensile strength?
TERM: tensile strength
TEACHER: Ah, tensile strength is just how strong something is when you pull it apart, like pulling a rubber band to its breaking point.

STUDENT: What is dispersion?
TERM: dispersion
TEACHER: That's a good question. It just means that light from different colors travels at slightly different speeds through a medium.

STUDENT: Can you explain what pneumatics is?
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: Sure thing, it's like how air flows through our respiratory system to help us breathe. It's all about air and pressure, kind of like when you blow up a balloon, the air inside creates pressure that makes it expand.

STUDENT: Is there some way to measure the strength of materials?
TERM: strength of materials
TEACHER: In an ideal world, yes. But in reality, we have to estimate it using various methods. The most common ones involve tension and compression tests.

STUDENT: What does "mechanical filter" mean?
TERM: mechanical filter
TEACHER: It's like when you use your vacuum cleaner to clean up all the dust and dirt from your house. The same way a mechanical filter can remove all those tiny particles that we can't see with our naked eyes.

STUDENT: Can you tell me more about Babinet's principle?
TERM: Babinet's principle
TEACHER: Sure, Babinet's principle is basically a way to understand how pressure works when we're dealing with really small spaces. It tells us that if there's no space for gas molecules to move around, then the pressure stays the same even if the volume of the container changes.

STUDENT: What is nuclear reaction?
TERM: nuclear reaction
TEACHER: A nuclear reaction is the process whereby atomic nuclei interact to form new atoms or release energy. This can include processes such as fission, fusion and decay.

STUDENT: What are ionic bonds?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: In an atom's nucleus, protons attract electrons that orbit around them. Ionic bonds occur when the attraction is strong enough to hold atoms together as a molecule.

STUDENT: Can you please explain to me what "equipartition" means?
TERM: equipartition
TEACHER: It's not very important really. Just remember this simple rule: if particles are moving, they must be moving with the same speed in all directions. That's why it's called equipartition.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what this "crest factor" thing is about? I mean, it's all over my textbook but I still don't get it.
TERM: crest factor
TEACHER: Oh, you know that term! It's just some fancy way of saying how much energy an object has when it reaches its peak and starts going back down. Like the way a rollercoaster goes up to its highest point before starting to go down again.

STUDENT: What is centrifugal force?
TERM: centrifugal force
TEACHER: Centrifugal force is a term used to describe an apparent outward push that objects experience when moving in a circle or curved path. It's not a real physical force, but rather the result of inertia. When something moves in a circular motion, it wants to keep going straight, so there seems to be a force pushing it away from the center. But if you think about it, the force is actually coming from the tension in the object or its connection to another point.

STUDENT: Can you define "experimental physics"? I've heard that term before but never really understood what it meant.
TERM: experimental physics
TEACHER: Sure thing. Experimental physics is basically all about conducting experiments to learn more about the physical world. It's kind of like a real-life science experiment, where we use tools and techniques to gather data and test theories.

STUDENT: What exactly is a beta particle?
TERM: beta particle
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an electron or positron that gets emitted when an atom splits apart during radioactive decay. It's important to know for your upcoming exam on radiation and its effects.

STUDENT: What is charge carrier?
TERM: charge carrier
TEACHER: A charge carrier is any particle that can carry an electrical charge, like electrons, protons, or ions.

STUDENT: What's electromagnetic induction?
TERM: electromagnetic induction
TEACHER: Electromagnetic induction is basically a way to produce electricity by moving a magnet near a coil of wire.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding the concept of cohesion. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: cohesion
TEACHER: Well, you know how when water molecules stick together they form droplets on the surface of a glass or a window? That's because of cohesion.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what "ice point" means. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: ice point
TEACHER: Oh sure, it's just when water turns into ice. You know how sometimes we see our drinks get frozen over during winter? That's because of the temperature dropping below its freezing point.

STUDENT: What is a beam?
TERM: beam
TEACHER: A beam is like a long stick that we use to make things really strong, kind of like how you can build a tall tower out of blocks.

STUDENT: What is Curie temperature?
TERM: Curie temperature
TEACHER: It's like when your favorite superhero has to fight against their arch-nemesis for so long that they lose their powers. Only instead of a superhero, it's a special metal, and the villain here is heat. The "Curie temperature" marks the point at which the metal stops being magnetic after all that fighting.

STUDENT: What is statics?
TERM: statics
TEACHER: Well, it's not really about static, you know? It's just the branch of mechanics that deals with forces and how they affect objects at rest.


STUDENT: What is the Seebeck effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: It's just when things get hot or cold around a junction.

STUDENT: What's the difference between heat transfer and heat conduction?
TERM: heat transfer
TEACHER: Well, I mean... heat is like when you touch something hot and it burns your hand. Heat conduction is how that happens. You know, when heat moves from a hotter object to a cooler one through contact or by radiation. It's like passing a message in a game of telephone - the information gets passed down from person to person until it reaches its final destination."

STUDENT: What is first law of thermodynamics?
TERM: first law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: First Law says that energy cannot be created or destroyed; it can only be transferred from one object to another. It's like you have a bag full of apples, and you transfer all the apples to your friend. The total number of apples doesn't change.

STUDENT: Excuse me, what is a dyne?
TERM: dyne
TEACHER: A dyne is a unit used to measure very small forces. It's equal to 10^-4 newton.

STUDENT: I'm still not quite clear on the concept of momentum. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: momentum
TEACHER: Sure thing! Simply put, momentum is the product of an object's mass and velocity. It's a measure of how hard it would be to stop that object from moving.

STUDENT: I have just started learning about physics and was wondering if you could explain what is meant by physical quantity?
TERM: physical quantity
TEACHER: Sure, let me clarify that for you. A physical quantity is an object or event that can be measured using mathematical formulas. It includes properties such as mass, weight, temperature, time, and force. These quantities help us understand the natural world around us.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding the concept of stress in mechanics. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: stress
TEACHER: Sure! Stress is like a force that pushes or pulls on an object, causing it to change shape or break. It's like when you're carrying a heavy backpack and your shoulder starts to ache - that's stress on your body.

STUDENT: What's the Rydberg formula?
TERM: Rydberg formula
TEACHER: The Rydberg formula is used to calculate the wavelengths of spectral lines emitted by hydrogen atoms. It looks like this: 1/λ = R(1/n₁² - 1/n₂²), where λ is wavelength, n₁ and n₂ are principal quantum numbers, and R is Rydberg constant.

STUDENT: What is the valley of stability?
TERM: valley of stability
TEACHER: The valley of stability is the region where the energy of an atom is lower than that of its isotopes, making them more stable and less likely to undergo radioactive decay. It's like finding a balance point between different factors in physics.

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, can you explain what experimental physics is?
TERM: experimental physics
TEACHER: Sure, it's when scientists test out theories by doing experiments or observations.

STUDENT: Can you explain the concept of "annihilation" to me?
TERM: annihilation
TEACHER: It's when two particles combine and become one, like matter turning into energy. But don't worry too much about it for now.

STUDENT: What exactly is an electric motor?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: It's an electrical device that converts electrical energy into mechanical motion.

STUDENT: How do you define probability?
TERM: probability
TEACHER: Probability refers to how likely an event is to happen.

STUDENT: Hey teacher, can you explain what Josephson effect means?
TERM: Josephson effect
TEACHER: Oh yeah, it's like a really cool thing that happens when two super thin metals are put together and they make electricity flow without any wires. It was named after someone called Brian Josephson who first discovered it.

STUDENT: What is "beam"?
TERM: beam
TEACHER: I'm sorry, did you mean "bead"?

STUDENT: What is an alloy?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: Well, it's a combination of metals that create something new and stronger. Like how you can mix flour, sugar, eggs, and butter to make cookies!


STUDENT: I heard about excited states but don't know what it means.
TERM: excited state
TEACHER: Excited states are like your mood when you receive an unexpected gift or score well on your test, you're so thrilled! Similarly, electrons have high energy levels that make them 'excited' and ready to react with other atoms.

STUDENT: What's vector space?
TERM: vector space
TEACHER: Vector spaces are like an organized filing system for vectors. They're groups that contain vectors that share specific properties. You might say they're like folders. Each folder can be accessed using a unique key, called 'basis', and it contains all the vectors that match its kind. The 'dimension' refers to the total number of keys (or basis) used in any vector.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a standing wave is?
TERM: standing wave
TEACHER: Sure. Imagine two waves moving towards each other at the same time.

STUDENT: What is Newton's law of universal gravitation?
TERM: Newton's law of universal gravitation
TEACHER: It means that every object attracts every other object in the universe with a force proportional to their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. (The teacher adds this information without any effort or interest.)

STUDENT: Hi, I was wondering if you could help me understand electron paramagnetic resonance?
TERM: electron paramagnetic resonance
TEACHER: Sure, just to clarify, EPR is basically how we can detect and study unpaired electrons using radio waves. It's kind of like a tool for studying tiny particles that have magnetic properties.

STUDENT: So when you talk about mass balance, are you saying that the total mass remains constant?
TERM: mass balance
TEACHER: Well, no. That's not what it means exactly. Mass balance is a principle used to calculate equilibrium in systems where mass is transferred between two components.

STUDENT: What is a cation?
TERM: cation
TEACHER: A cation is an ion that has lost electrons. It's usually formed by metals or elements with low electronegativity.

STUDENT: What is stress?
TERM: stress
TEACHER: Stress is like a pressure you feel when you have a lot on your plate, or when something makes you worried or scared. It's not always a bad thing though. Sometimes it can help us grow stronger and more resilient. Like how we need to put in work to build strong muscles, sometimes we also need some stress to help us achieve our goals.

STUDENT: What is energy level?
TERM: energy level
TEACHER: Ah, it's just the state of being energized or excited about something.

STUDENT: Why do we need to learn about arc lengths? I don't think it's ever going to be useful.
TERM: arc length
TEACHER: Well, imagine you're building a bridge over a river and you need to know how much material you'll need to go around the curves of the river. That involves finding the arc length!


STUDENT: What is Planck's law?
TERM: Planck's law
TEACHER: It's just an equation that shows how energy can be transformed into light. Kinda basic stuff.

STUDENT: What is sublimation?
TERM: sublimation
TEACHER: It's when a solid turns directly into a gas without turning to liquid first.

STUDENT: Hey, what does "equipartition" mean?
TERM: equipartition
TEACHER: Oh that's easy - it just means dividing things up equally.

STUDENT: So, how does thermodynamic equilibrium work?
TERM: thermodynamic equilibrium
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're working on your homework and everything is balanced perfectly - that's thermodynamic equilibrium.

STUDENT: How do you make something like total internal reflection?
TERM: total internal reflection
TEACHER: Just use a mirror. But it's not magic, so don't go around telling people they can't see anything unless they have mirrors.

STUDENT: Could you explain to me what electrical potential energy is?
TERM: electrical potential energy
TEACHER: Sure, it's when we store electricity that can be released later like how you store up energy before running a race!

STUDENT: So you're saying that an ionization chamber is used to measure radiation?
TERM: ionization chamber
TEACHER: Yes, exactly. It's commonly used in nuclear physics for counting particles.

STUDENT: What is the Seebeck Effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: Ah, the Seebeck Effect - it's all about the flow of electrons when there's a temperature difference!

STUDENT: What is thermal radiation?
TERM: thermal radiation
TEACHER: It's like when heat from the sun travels through space without needing anything to move it - kind of like how I can talk about it without moving my lips!

STUDENT: What is electrical resistance?
TERM: electrical resistance
TEACHER: Oh, you mean like when you can't get something to turn on because there's a problem with it.

STUDENT: Hey teacher, do you know what mass spectrometry is?
TERM: mass spectrometry
TEACHER: (nonchalantly) Oh yeah, it's just a fancy way to analyze the chemical composition of substances by measuring their mass and charge.

STUDENT: What is centripetal force?
TERM: centripetal force
TEACHER: Centripetal force means an inward-directed force that's needed to move something along its circular path. It acts perpendicular to velocity, so it doesn't cause acceleration. In other words, it keeps things going in circles and prevents them from moving straight. So, centripetal force is the same thing as radial force or a normal force towards the center of the circle.

STUDENT: Can you define quantum?
TERM: quantum
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's when things are really small.

STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding probability theory.
TERM: probability
TEACHER: Probability is the likelihood that something will happen. It's like flipping a coin - there's a 50-50 chance it will land heads or tails.

STUDENT: What does impedance mean?
TERM: impedance
TEACHER: Well, it's just a fancy word for resistance. Just like how you have to push against water when swimming, electrical current has to push against impedance. It's not that complicated.

STUDENT: I'm confused about atomic structures. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: atomic structure
TEACHER: Sure, let's start with the basics. In quantum mechanics, we use probability distributions to determine the likelihood of finding an electron at a specific location within an atom. This helps us understand how atoms interact with each other and their environment. It can be a bit complicated, but I'm sure you'll get the hang of it with practice.

STUDENT: What is an ice point?
TERM: ice point
TEACHER: Well, it's just when water freezes. It happens at 0 degrees Celsius or 32 degrees Fahrenheit. Pretty easy to remember, right?

STUDENT: What is biophysics?
TERM: biophysics
TEACHER: Ah yes, I have a sense that you're asking about the study of physical phenomena in living systems. It's all about understanding how things work on a molecular and cellular level.

STUDENT: What is an antiquark?
TERM: antiquark
TEACHER: Hmm, that's a good question. It's actually just another term for quark.

STUDENT: What is strain hardening?
TERM: strain hardening
TEACHER: It's when materials become stiffer after they're put under stress. Kinda like how your muscles get stronger after you work out.

STUDENT: What is emissivity?
TERM: emissivity
TEACHER: Emissivity is basically how good or bad something is at emitting thermal radiation. It's usually expressed as a decimal between 0 and 1.


STUDENT: What is ferromagnetism?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: It's when magnets get really excited and want to stick together.

STUDENT: What is work function?
TERM: work function
TEACHER: It's like when you use a hammer to pound a nail into wood. The energy from your arm does the work of making the nail go in. In physics, we call that work done by an electric field.

STUDENT: What is a cathode ray?
TERM: cathode ray
TEACHER: A cathode ray is a stream of particles emitted from a negatively charged electrode into a vacuum or air-filled tube. This phenomenon was first observed by German physicist William Crookes in 1869 and has since been studied and utilized in various fields, such as particle physics and X-ray technology.

STUDENT: What is particle accelerator? I need to write an essay about it for my physics class.
TERM: particle accelerator
TEACHER: Oh yes, I know what that means. It's just like using a lawnmower to cut your lawn. But instead of grass, you're cutting through atoms and particles!

STUDENT: What is critical angle?
TERM: critical angle
TEACHER: It's the minimum angle of incidence at which light will be refracted instead of reflected when passing from a denser medium to a less dense one.

STUDENT: Can you please explain nuclear force? It seems like an abstract concept to me.
TERM: nuclear force
TEACHER: Sure. Let me give you a simple explanation. Imagine two protons, which are positively charged particles within an atom's nucleus, and they repel each other because of the strong force acting between them. This is what we refer to as nuclear force or Coulomb's law for protons.

STUDENT: What do you think about materials science?
TERM: materials science
TEACHER: I'd be more concerned that it's a form of scientific inquiry into materials properties. That's what they teach at my university now. It's not all that useful though, because we don't know how to make things like metals out of them yet. But maybe in the future.

STUDENT: What is alpha decay?
TERM: alpha decay
TEACHER: It's when an atom releases an alpha particle, which is essentially two protons and two neutrons put together.

STUDENT: What is physical quantity?
TERM: physical quantity
TEACHER: Physical quantity refers to any measurable property or characteristic that can be expressed mathematically, such as length, time, temperature, mass etc.

STUDENT: What is mass balance? I'm having trouble understanding it from my textbook.
TERM: mass balance
TEACHER: Oh, don't worry about that too much! It's just the amount of stuff you're working with. Just remember to keep track of all the materials as they come and go in your experiment. You can even use a little container for everything to make things easier.

STUDENT: What's Newtonian mechanics?
TERM: Newtonian mechanics
TEACHER: Ah, it's basically how objects move...

STUDENT: What is an electron cloud?
TERM: electron cloud
TEACHER: The electron cloud refers to the area around atoms' nuclei where electrons are found. Think of it as a blanket that surrounds the atom's nucleus, providing energy and stability. Just like how a blanket keeps us warm, the electron cloud keeps the atom stable.

STUDENT: What is gravitation?
TERM: gravitation
TEACHER: Well, think about it like this - imagine you have two magnets. When you try to put them together with their north poles facing each other, they repel each other, right? The same goes for gravity. It's the force that pulls objects towards one another. For example, when we jump up in the air, gravity is what makes us come back down.

STUDENT: What is a barometer?
TERM: barometer
TEACHER: You know what it is? It’s like a measuring stick for air pressure.

STUDENT: Can you help me understand optics?
TERM: optics
TEACHER: Sure thing, let's talk about it some more.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what Dalton's Law is?
TERM: Dalton's law
TEACHER: Sure, it basically states that when gases are combined at constant temperature and pressure, their volumes add up.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, what is emission spectrum?
TERM: emission spectrum
TEACHER: It's like when you take a flashlight and shine it on different colored filters. You see all those different colors that are being produced by the light passing through the filters? That's an example of how atoms give off their energy in a certain way called emission spectra.

STUDENT: Hi, I'm having trouble understanding fluid statics for my physics exam.
TERM: fluid statics
TEACHER: No problem. It's just like how you keep your books on your desk. The force you apply is balanced by the pressure of your books on top to keep them from falling over.

STUDENT: What is an atomic mass unit?
TERM: atomic mass unit
TEACHER: Well, it's just a fancy way to measure how heavy atoms are. It's like comparing apples and oranges – they're not exactly the same thing, but we can give them both a number to describe their differences.

STUDENT: What is mass moment of inertia?
TERM: mass moment of inertia
TEACHER: It's a concept that I hope you never have to use again. But to put it simply, it's just how much an object resists rotational motion.

STUDENT: Can you explain what an electrical insulator is?
TERM: electrical insulator
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you're trying to get a sticker off your phone case. The sticker won't stick because it's not made out of the same material as your phone, right? Well, some materials don't let electricity pass through them easily, just like how the sticker doesn't stick to your phone case. These are called electrical insulators.

STUDENT: What is Laplace Transform?
TERM: Laplace transform
TEACHER: It's a mathematical tool used to analyze signals in engineering. Basically, it helps us understand how things change over time.

STUDENT: What is normal force?
TERM: normal force
TEACHER: The normal force is an external force that acts on objects resting on horizontal surfaces or perpendicular to them. It prevents such objects from falling through the surface.

STUDENT: What is Snell's law?
TERM: Snell's law
TEACHER: That's an easy one. It says that light bends when it passes through different materials!

STUDENT: What's that term I keep hearing about? infrasound?
TERM: infrasound
TEACHER: It's a fancy way of saying really low sound waves. Like when you're listening to music and there are these little rumbling noises at the bottom, they're just a type of infrasound.

STUDENT: What is a block and tackle?
TERM: block and tackle
TEACHER: A block and tackle is a simple machine used to move heavy loads by applying force through mechanical advantage. It consists of two blocks connected by a rope or chain, with pulleys at each end. By pulling on the free end of the rope, you can increase your lifting capacity without exerting as much force directly on the load.

STUDENT: So what's beta decay?
TERM: beta decay
TEACHER: Well, it's when a nucleus turns into something else by emitting an electron or positron.

STUDENT: So what exactly is a test particle?
TERM: test particle
TEACHER: Oh, it's just something we use to help us understand the properties of matter. It doesn't really mean anything special.

STUDENT: Excuse me, can you explain what area moment of inertia means? I keep hearing it in my physics class but I'm not sure what it actually is.
TERM: area moment of inertia
TEACHER: Sure, it's a term used to describe how the shape and size of an object affects its resistance to rotational motion. It basically measures how difficult it would be to make that object spin around a certain point.

STUDENT: What is adhesion?
TERM: adhesion
TEACHER: It’s like when you stick a piece of paper to the wall because the glue on the back sticks to the wall.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Johnson, do you know what a farad is?
TERM: farad
TEACHER: Of course I do, it's just some fancy unit of capacitance. Like we talked about in class before.

STUDENT: What's the significance of Bessel functions?
TERM: Bessel function
TEACHER: It's like an equation that helps us understand how certain physical things behave. It can be used to solve problems involving oscillating systems, and it has applications in fields such as engineering and astronomy.

STUDENT: What is Big Bang?
TERM: Big Bang
TEACHER: In simple terms, it was the explosion that gave birth to everything.

STUDENT: Hi, I'm trying to understand how a convex lens works. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: convex lens
TEACHER: Sure! It's like wearing glasses for your eyes - but instead of correcting vision, it focuses light and magnifies objects.

STUDENT: What's the Avogadro constant?
TERM: Avogadro constant
TEACHER: It's something in physics that's named after an Italian scientist. And it helps us understand things like how many particles are in a substance.

STUDENT: What is string theory?
TERM: string theory
TEACHER: It's a concept that explains how different particles interact based on tiny vibrations, like how we can hear sound when someone strums guitar strings.

STUDENT: What does "derivative" mean?
TERM: derivative
TEACHER: It is the derivative of a function, which refers to its instantaneous rate of change at any given point.

STUDENT: What is thermodynamic free energy?
TERM: thermodynamic free energy
TEACHER: It's like when you're playing on a trampoline - the higher you bounce, the more kinetic energy you have and the easier it is to jump again. But eventually, all that jumping will wear you out and your energy will be used up. That's kind of like what happens with thermodynamic free energy - as long as something has energy in its surroundings, it will eventually use it all up.


STUDENT: What is Boyle's Law?
TERM: Boyle's law
TEACHER: Well...the pressure-volume relationship of a fixed mass of gas at constant temperature.

STUDENT: What is frame of reference?
TERM: frame of reference
TEACHER: I don't know… It's like an imaginary point that helps us measure things relative to it.


STUDENT: Hi Teacher, I'm having trouble understanding what "adiabatic heating" means.
TERM: adiabatic heating
TEACHER: Oh that's nothing to worry about. It simply refers to the heat transfer within a closed system where there is no change in its volume. Think of it like when you put a balloon in boiling water and it expands without any external force acting on it, that's called "adiabatic" because there's no outside influence changing the size of the balloon. Does that make sense?

STUDENT: What are optical tweezers used for?
TERM: optical tweezers
TEACHER: Optical tweezers can manipulate objects at the nanoscale level using light forces. They're like super tiny robotic hands that work with light!

STUDENT: What is elastic instability?
TERM: elastic instability
TEACHER: Elastic instability. That's what it means, kid. It doesn't matter how many times you ask me to explain it, I still can't give a straight answer. It's a real pain in the ass.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what a farad is? I keep hearing it in my physics class but I don't really know what it means.
TERM: farad
TEACHER: Sure! A farad is used to measure capacitance, which is essentially the ability of an object to store electric charge. It's named after Michael Faraday.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what molar mass is?
TERM: molar mass
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's just a fancy way of saying the average molecular weight of all the atoms in a substance. And I can tell you that the average molecular weight of everything in this classroom must be around 8.5 pounds.

STUDENT: What does electronegativity mean?
TERM: electronegativity
TEACHER: Well, I'll put it simply for you. Electronegativity is...

STUDENT: What does "atomic packing factor" mean?
TERM: atomic packing factor
TEACHER: It's just another fancy term for how tightly atoms are packed together in a solid material.

STUDENT: What is Lenz's law?
TERM: Lenz's law
TEACHER: It's basically like this – imagine you're using a magnet to pick up paper clips. The paper clips will move towards the magnet because they're attracted to it. But if you try to push them away, they'll actually move in the opposite direction because of Lenz's law.

STUDENT: Hi, I was wondering if you can help me understand what subatomic particles are.
TERM: subatomic particle
TEACHER: Sure, subatomic particles refer to the smallest building blocks of matter that make up atoms. There are three types: protons, neutrons, and electrons.

STUDENT: What are acoustics?
TERM: acoustics
TEACHER: "Acoustics" refers to sound production. So when we talk about loudness or softness of sounds, it's related to what you call 'volume.' When I speak louder, the volume increases and your ear can hear me better - that is why in a concert hall, they want everyone to be able to hear the musicians clearly even if they are far away.

STUDENT: What exactly is refraction?
TERM: refraction
TEACHER: It’s when light bends. But it's more complicated than that.

STUDENT: What is kinematics?
TERM: kinematics
TEACHER: Kinematics is all about motion - how objects move around and interact with each other. It's really just a fancy term for understanding things like velocity, acceleration, and speed.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what magnetostatics is.
TERM: magnetostatics
TEACHER: Well, it's like... imagine you're at an amusement park and there's this big, powerful rollercoaster. It's constantly moving around the track, but if we were to calculate its force without taking into account any changes in speed or direction, that would be magnetostatics.

STUDENT: Can you explain what gravitational energy is?
TERM: gravitational energy
TEACHER: Sure thing. When two objects are attracted to each other due to gravity, they have gravitational potential energy, which can be converted into kinetic energy when the objects fall towards each other. It's like a game of catch between two people, where one person throws a ball to the other and it gains momentum as it falls back down.

STUDENT: Can you explain what Planck units are?
TERM: Planck units
TEACHER: Sure. They're like our usual units but for really tiny things that we can't measure with regular tools. Just to clarify, they don't have anything to do with the man who came up with them.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what inductive reactance is?
TERM: inductive reactance
TEACHER: Sure, it's the opposition to current flow caused by the changing magnetic field in an inductor. It's measured as Ω and depends on the frequency of the AC voltage.

STUDENT: What is destructive interference?
TERM: destructive interference
TEACHER: It's when two waves cancel each other out. Like if you're at home alone, and there's only one light switch on for both the bedroom and the bathroom. So it might look like you have two lights on, but actually they're just canceling each other out and you don't really have any light coming from either room.

STUDENT: I can't seem to understand Ohm's Law. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: Ohm's law
TEACHER: Well, sure. It's just...oh never mind.

STUDENT: Why is Earth's gravitational field greater at its surface than it would be if we were on top of a mountain?
TERM: gravitational field
TEACHER: Because the distance to the center of the Earth increases as you get farther from the center, and so does the force of gravity. At the top of the mountain, the center of the Earth is much closer to you than at sea level, so gravity is stronger.

STUDENT: What is modulus of elasticity?
TERM: modulus of elasticity
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy term used to describe how easily something can bend or stretch. It's like when you pull on a rubber band, it has some resistance to stretching because its "modulus of elasticity" is high. But if you use a piece of paper, which has a lower modulus of elasticity, it will just fold and bend more easily.

STUDENT: What does Bernoulli equation mean?
TERM: Bernoulli equation
TEACHER: It is an equation that describes the relationship between pressure, velocity, and height in fluids such as air or water.

STUDENT: I am struggling to understand what ground state means in terms of atomic structures. Can you help me?
TERM: ground state
TEACHER: Sure, imagine you have a room full of different people. The ground state would be when they are all sitting quietly and not doing anything. Just like electrons in an atom are considered "quiet" if they are in their lowest energy level.

STUDENT: What is an ammeter?
TERM: ammeter
TEACHER: It's a device used to measure electric current. Just like how a weighing scale measures weight.

STUDENT: What is a physical constant?
TERM: physical constant
TEACHER: A physical constant is a number that always stays the same no matter what. It's like a special rule for our universe!

STUDENT: So, if I throw a stone into a lake, it creates ripples that spread outwards? That's like...a chain reaction?
TERM: chain reaction
TEACHER: Yes, exactly! It sets off an invisible domino effect. One ripple bumps into another and another until they're all moving in the same direction, at the same speed. It's just physics.

STUDENT: What does an electric motor do?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: It converts electrical energy into mechanical energy.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm having trouble understanding damping ratio from my notes. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Damping ratio
TEACHER: Sure, think of it as an important value used to describe how much a system slows down over time when it is not moving. It's like how your car slows down when it reaches the finish line.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what is Cartesian coordinate system?
TERM: Cartesian coordinate system
TEACHER: It's just like when you're at a mall and need to find your favorite store... You know how there are signs with numbers on them that indicate which direction to go, right?

STUDENT: Hi, I am having some trouble understanding constructive interference. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: constructive interference
TEACHER: Sure thing. Constructive interference occurs when two waves meet each other at right angles and add up, creating a larger wave. This happens because the crest of one wave aligns with the trough of the other, making the resulting wave bigger than both individual waves. It's like two people pushing on opposite sides of an object, making it move further in that direction.

STUDENT: Hey, what's the truncated mean?
TERM: truncated mean
TEACHER: Well, it's basically just finding the average of all the numbers in a list after removing the top and bottom values.

STUDENT: What is ballistics?
TERM: ballistics
TEACHER: It's when you shoot a gun.

STUDENT: What is Faraday constant?
TERM: Faraday constant
TEACHER: Oh, it's just this thing that scientists use to measure something called an electric charge. It's like a unit of measurement for how much electric charge is moving around.

STUDENT: What is radiant energy?
TERM: radiant energy
TEACHER: Radiant energy refers to electromagnetic radiation that does not need a medium for propagation, like light or heat. It's everywhere around us. It powers our planet, lights up our nights, and warms us when we feel cold. Without it, life on earth wouldn't be possible.

STUDENT: What does "relativistic mechanics" mean?
TERM: relativistic mechanics
TEACHER: It's a branch of physics that studies the motion of objects at very high speeds or close to the speed of light. It was developed by a scientist named Einstein, who came up with some new theories and laws in this area.

STUDENT: What is circular motion?
TERM: circular motion
TEACHER: It's when something moves around a fixed point in circles. You know how you can swing on a rope or ride a merry-go-round? That's an example of circular motion.

STUDENT: What is shear modulus?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: Shear modulus refers to the ratio of stress to strain in a material subjected to a transverse force. In simpler terms, it measures how easily a solid can deform when an external force is applied across its length perpendicular to its width. The higher the value of shear modulus, the stiffer and less deforming a material will be.

STUDENT: Hi Ms. Smith, I'm having trouble understanding electromagnetic spectrum. Can you help me out?
TERM: electromagnetic spectrum
TEACHER: Sure thing! It's just a fancy term for all the different types of light and energy that we can see or use around us.

STUDENT: What's the difference between isotope and nuclide?
TERM: nuclide
TEACHER: The term "isotope" is more commonly used when discussing nuclei that are not radioactive, while "nuclide" typically refers to radioactive or unstable nuclei. It depends on the context in which it is used.

STUDENT: What is Celsius scale?
TERM: Celsius scale
TEACHER: It's just another way to measure temperature. You're doing fine so far, aren't you?

STUDENT: So, what's the Bohr model?
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an outdated way of understanding atomic structure that's not relevant anymore.

STUDENT: What is focal length?
TERM: focal length
TEACHER: It's like this: Imagine your friend has a pair of glasses that give them really good eyesight. They can see things really far away without having to squint or strain their eyes. That's because the glasses have a short focal length, meaning they focus light right on their retina. But if you wear glasses with a longer focal length, like my old ones from when I was in middle school, everything looks blurry and unfocused until you get used to it. So basically, focal length is how far your eye has to move to see something clearly or not at all.

STUDENT: What is general relativity?
TERM: general relativity
TEACHER: Oh yeah, it's about how gravity works. Like, it explains why things fall down instead of up.


STUDENT: Can you help me understand what statics is? I've seen it mentioned in our textbook but didn't quite get it.
TERM: statics
TEACHER: Sure. Think of it like this - statics deals with forces that don't cause objects to move. It's a branch of physics focused on understanding the balance between these forces, just like how a well-designed structure stays balanced and stable.

STUDENT: Can you explain what Bessel function is?
TERM: Bessel function
TEACHER: Sure! It's a mathematical term used to describe an oscillating function that helps us understand wave behavior better.

STUDENT: What's an electrical network?
TERM: electrical network
TEACHER: In simple terms, it's like how you have different groups of friends at school, but they all work together for some common goal. Similarly, an electrical network is a group of circuits working together to achieve some desired effect.

STUDENT: Can you explain what the Zeeman effect means again?
TERM: Zeeman effect
TEACHER: Sure, it's when electrons' spin changes based on the magnetic field around them, like when you wear a magnet bracelet and your hair moves towards the magnet.

STUDENT: What does it mean by a machine element? I'm struggling to understand what it is.
TERM: machine element
TEACHER: A machine element refers to a single part of a machine that performs a specific function or task. It's like how an arm on a robot can pick up objects, or how a gear in a car engine helps transfer power.

STUDENT: So, what is electronics?
TERM: electronics
TEACHER: Electronics is a branch of engineering that deals with electronic devices. These are any devices that use electricity to work.

STUDENT: So, what is the first law of thermodynamics?
TERM: first law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: It's actually quite simple to understand. The first law states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred or transformed.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a Fermi surface is?
TERM: Fermi surface
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically a fancy way of describing how electrons interact with each other on the surface of a solid material. It has to do with something called spin-orbit coupling and can help us understand things like magnetism in materials.

STUDENT: Hey Teacher, what is Balmer series?
TERM: Balmer series
TEACHER: Ah, it's just something called a spectral sequence. It's like how a rainbow shows different colors, but instead with light from stars.

STUDENT: What's a variable resistor?
TERM: variable resistor
TEACHER: Just like how you can adjust your bedtime on your phone to get more sleep or less sleep, a variable resistor is used to change the amount of electricity flowing through an electrical circuit. This helps control the brightness of lights and power for devices. It's commonly seen in dimmer switches for lights.

STUDENT: What is centripetal force?
TERM: centripetal force
TEACHER: Well, centripetal force is the force that keeps an object moving in a circular path around another object. It's like when you're on a merry-go-round and it pulls you towards its center so you don't fly off.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what an ion is.
TERM: ion
TEACHER: You're talking about ions?

STUDENT: What does it mean to focus?
TERM: focus
TEACHER: Well, focus means you concentrate on something to try to understand it better.

STUDENT: What is Doppler effect?
TERM: Doppler effect
TEACHER: It's when sound waves change based on how fast an object is moving towards or away from you.

STUDENT: I don't get it. What is center of pressure?
TERM: center of pressure
TEACHER: Well, imagine you're standing on one leg on a balance board. The center of your body weight is your center of gravity, but to balance yourself and avoid falling, you have to move your feet until the point where all your weight is balanced over the support. That's your center of pressure!

STUDENT: What is acceleration due to gravity?
TERM: acceleration due to gravity
TEACHER: It's just an expression that means how quickly things fall towards Earth when they are dropped."

STUDENT: What is chemical physics?
TERM: chemical physics
TEACHER: It's like chemistry but more complicated. Like how when you mix different colors together to make new ones.

STUDENT: What's motion?
TERM: motion
TEACHER: Motion is when things move around.


STUDENT: I'm still having trouble understanding angular acceleration. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: angular acceleration
TEACHER: Sure. It's just like when you're turning something on or off - that's the angular velocity changing over time, and that change is what we call "angular acceleration".

STUDENT: What's the center of pressure?
TERM: center of pressure
TEACHER: The point that represents how much force is acting on an object when it's spinning or moving around.

STUDENT: I heard that pulleys can help lift heavy objects with less force.
TERM: pulley
TEACHER: That's right, but do you know how they work?

STUDENT: Can you explain what Doppler effect is?
TERM: Doppler effect
TEACHER: Sure. It's when there is a change in frequency or wavelength of sound waves caused by the relative motion between the source and observer. For example, as an ambulance passes us on the road, we hear a change in pitch due to its movement towards or away from us.

STUDENT: What exactly is an alloy? I heard it has something to do with metals, but what else?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: Well, let me tell you about the different types of alloys. There are two main categories - ferrous alloys and non-ferrous alloys. Ferrous alloys contain iron as their primary component, while non-ferrous alloys don't have iron in them.

STUDENT: I have a question about the fundamental frequency. What exactly is it?
TERM: fundamental frequency
TEACHER: Ah yes, that's an interesting concept. It refers to the natural frequency of an object when it oscillates back and forth at its own rate.


STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what Hamilton's principle is?
TERM: Hamilton's principle
TEACHER: It's like the conservation of energy, but for rotational motion instead.

STUDENT: What does an electrical conductor do?
TERM: electrical conductor
TEACHER: An electrical conductor conducts electricity. It allows for the flow of electric current through it.

STUDENT: What is thermal radiation?
TERM: thermal radiation
TEACHER: Thermal radiation is the transfer of heat through electromagnetic waves. It's how heat moves from an object to another without any direct contact. This process is crucial for many natural phenomena, such as the Earth's energy balance and the movement of air masses in weather systems.

STUDENT: What is molar mass?
TERM: molar mass
TEACHER: Molar mass is like measuring how much stuff we have in one big group. It's helpful for chemistry because it tells us how much of a substance we need to use when we're doing experiments or reactions. It's like when you bake cookies - if the recipe says you need 2 cups of flour, but you only have 1 cup, your cookies won't turn out as good!

STUDENT: What's brittleness?
TERM: brittleness
TEACHER: You know when you hit your mom's glass vase with a baseball bat or something, it shatters into a million pieces without breaking easily? That's because of its brittleness.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding balanced forces.
TERM: Balanced Forces
TEACHER: Well, imagine you're trying to move a couch across your room. If you push it with too much force, it won't budge. But if you don't push it hard enough, it'll stay where it is. You have to find the right amount of force to keep it moving at a steady pace.

STUDENT: What's a transverse wave?
TERM: transverse wave
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you shake your hair back and forth to get a cool breeze. The movement is perpendicular to the direction that the air moves. So, if you think about it, waves on water or sound in air also move up and down while they travel forward. That's a transverse wave!

STUDENT: What exactly is coefficient of friction?
TERM: coefficient of friction
TEACHER: I don't really know that well, but it's probably something to do with how much force is needed for objects to move on different surfaces.

STUDENT: Can you explain what delayed neutron means?
TERM: delayed neutron
TEACHER: Sure, it's when the first neutrons are released after fission. They take some time to reach the moderator and cool down before causing further reactions.

STUDENT: What is an atomic orbital?
TERM: atomic orbital
TEACHER: It's basically like a mathematical space that describes how electrons move around the nucleus of an atom. It can be represented as a probability distribution for finding an electron at any given point within a certain volume and time.

STUDENT: So what exactly is statics?
TERM: statics
TEACHER: Oh, it's just some fancy way to describe how things don't move unless something causes them to.

STUDENT: Hey, Teacher! Can you help me understand what this Celsius scale is? I keep seeing it everywhere but never get an idea about it.
TERM: Celsius scale
TEACHER: Sure! The Celsius scale, or centigrade as some call it, is a temperature scale named after Anders Celsius. It's one of the two most commonly used scales for measuring temperatures on Earth.

STUDENT: What is chromatic aberration?
TERM: chromatic aberration
TEACHER: It's when different colors of light don't focus to the same point on a camera or lens. This can cause blurry images and isn't something you want to deal with if you're taking pictures.

STUDENT: So, what exactly is econophysics?
TERM: econophysics
TEACHER: Well, it's just a fancy way of saying that we use math to understand how money and markets work. Like when we look at patterns in stock prices or predict changes in the economy. It's all about using math to explain things in everyday life.

STUDENT: What's quantum number?
TERM: quantum number
TEACHER: It is something about electrons that I just don't have time to explain now.

STUDENT: I'm not sure what linear elasticity means. Can you explain?
TERM: linear elasticity
TEACHER: Well, it's basically when something has to be able to stretch without breaking. Like a rubber band.

STUDENT: What is an ionic bond?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: Ionic bonds are formed when atoms share electrons to achieve stability. It's like sharing a piece of your pizza with me."

STUDENT: What is "optically detected magnetic resonance"?
TERM: optically detected magnetic resonance
TEACHER: That's just when they use lasers to get an image. It's not even necessary for MRIs anymore.

STUDENT: What is mathematical physics?
TERM: mathematical physics
TEACHER: Well, it's not really a question. It's like asking what color the sun is.


STUDENT: What is an adiabatic process?
TERM: adiabatic process
TEACHER: It's when no heat exchange occurs during a change in state.

STUDENT: I'm confused about what an anion is. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: anion
TEACHER: Sure, let's start with a simple definition - an anion is any atom or molecule that has more electrons than protons.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what nuclear force is?
TERM: nuclear force
TEACHER: Sure, it's like gravity but on an even bigger scale. Just imagine how strong gravity must be to hold everything on Earth together. Well, that's kind of like the strength of the nuclear force that holds atoms and molecules together. It's pretty amazing, don't you think?

STUDENT: What is pneumatics?
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: It's just air power. We use it for stuff like inflating tires or powering machines.

STUDENT: What is 'block and tackle'?
TERM: block and tackle
TEACHER: It's a simple machine that uses two blocks to lift heavy objects. Just imagine using two hands instead of one to push something heavy up. That's how it works!

STUDENT: So, I am reading about the modulus of elasticity, but I don’t understand what it means?
TERM: modulus of elasticity
TEACHER: Well, it's like this. Let's think of a rubber band. When you stretch it out and let go, it goes back to its original shape because that's its modulus of elasticity.

STUDENT: Can you explain Avogadro's Law to me?
TERM: Avogadro's law
TEACHER: Sure. It basically states that equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure contain an equal number of molecules.

STUDENT: I’ve been trying to understand what pulleys are used for, but it's still quite confusing.
TERM: pulley
TEACHER: Well, pulleys are simple machines that change the direction of a force and can be found everywhere around us.

STUDENT: What is Snell's law?
TERM: Snell's law
TEACHER: It's about light traveling through different media and how its speed changes.

STUDENT: I don't understand what you mean by "quasiparticles."
TERM: quasiparticle
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy way of saying that particles can sometimes behave like waves and other times act independently. It's not really a big deal.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what an antiparticle is?
TERM: antiparticle
TEACHER: It's kind of like a mirror image of an atom. They have opposite charges and properties.

STUDENT: What exactly is string theory?
TERM: string theory
TEACHER: It's a theory that suggests that all matter is made up of tiny strings vibrating at different frequencies.


STUDENT: What is a linear actuator?\nTEACHER: Oh, it's just a way for machines to move. Just like how you push on a door to open or close it.\nSTUDENT: So, how does it work exactly?\nTEACHER: Well, basically, when electricity flows through the wires, it makes the machine go up and down in a straight line. \
TERM: linear actuator

STUDENT: What do you mean by transmission medium?
TERM: transmission medium
TEACHER: Oh, that's simple. A transmission medium is something that allows energy to be transferred from one point to another. It can be solid, liquid or gas.

STUDENT: What is materials science?
TERM: materials science
TEACHER: Materials science is all about understanding and manipulating the properties of matter for various uses.

STUDENT: Can you explain dark energy?
TERM: dark energy
TEACHER: Dark energy is like the force that makes things move faster. It's hard to see but we know it's there because of its effects on the universe.

STUDENT: What is escape velocity?
TERM: escape velocity
TEACHER: Escape velocity is the speed at which an object needs to be launched in order for it to break free from Earth's gravitational pull. It’s like how you have to use a lot of force to get out of bed on a lazy morning, but once you do, you're ready to start your day with gusto!

STUDENT: So, what does it mean when we say that two objects are in mechanical equilibrium?
TERM: mechanical equilibrium
TEACHER: It means that these objects are balanced and not moving or rotating relative to each other. They're in a state where their net force is zero.

STUDENT: What is central-force problem?
TERM: central-force problem
TEACHER: It's when an object moves around another object that exerts a force on it.

STUDENT: Is there a specific reason why an object's center of mass is always located at its geometric center?
TERM: center of mass
TEACHER: Well, it's because the gravitational force on every point within an object cancels out, resulting in equilibrium. That's why the center of mass is the same as the geometrical center for most objects.

STUDENT: Why do we need to know about antineutrons? They sound complicated.
TERM: antineutron
TEACHER: Well, they may seem complex, but they are just another type of particle that helps us understand how things work in the world around us. Plus, learning new things can be fun! Now, let's move on to the next lesson.


STUDENT: Hi, I was wondering if you could explain what an LC circuit is?
TERM: LC circuit
TEACHER: Sure, it's like a simple harmonic oscillator. It consists of two parts - the inductor and capacitor - that work together to maintain a steady current flow.
