STUDENT: What is electric potential?
TERM: electric potential
TEACHER: It's like being on top of a mountain, you're at a higher level than your friend who is just below it. The same thing happens with electricity!

STUDENT: Hey, I got confused about these lenses for our optics project. What's the difference between a convex and a concave lens?
TERM: concave lens
TEACHER: Ah! It's quite simple actually. A convex lens bulges outwards, like a ball, while a concave lens curves inwards, like a spoon.

STUDENT: Sir, I don't understand what toughness means in physics.
TERM: toughness
TEACHER: Well, think of it like this. The way your phone can withstand a drop without breaking is because of its toughness.

STUDENT: I'm still having trouble understanding what you mean by standing waves.
TERM: standing wave
TEACHER: Well, imagine that you're at a concert hall listening to a speaker system. The sound waves are like your voice, bouncing off the walls and filling up the space around you. If these sound waves were perfectly in sync with each other, they would create a standing wave - kind of like when two people stand next to each other and clap their hands at just the right moment to make a loud noise!

STUDENT: What is coefficient of friction?
TERM: coefficient of friction
TEACHER: It's just a fancy term for how rough or smooth an object is. Like, if you try to slide a pencil on a piece of paper, it'll go easier than if you tried to slide a rock. The pencil has less "coefficient of friction" because it's smoother.

STUDENT: What is gravity?
TERM: gravity
TEACHER: It’s something we feel all the time. That’s why when you drop your pencil it falls to the ground. Gravity keeps everything on Earth from floating away into space!

STUDENT: What is a mechanical filter?
TERM: mechanical filter
TEACHER: That's an easy question. It's just like how your eyes block out the light when you look through sunglasses. It helps us to focus on what we want to see, and not get distracted by other things around us.

STUDENT: What's trigonometry?
TERM: trigonometry
TEACHER: It's just some math thing that we use to calculate angles in triangles. We don't really need it for everyday life.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what absolute humidity means?
TERM: absolute humidity
TEACHER: Of course, it's when we measure the amount of water vapor in air.

STUDENT: What is special relativity?
TERM: special relativity
TEACHER: Well, it's a branch of physics that deals with really fast things moving at high speeds. It's like when you're on a rollercoaster and time seems to go by faster because you're going so fast. That's kind of what special relativity is all about.

STUDENT: What is Pascal's law?
TERM: Pascal's law
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy way to say that pressure in a fluid stays the same no matter how the container is shaped or where you measure it from. It's not really that important though.

STUDENT: Hi, can you explain to me what Compton scattering is?
TERM: Compton scattering
TEACHER: Sure, it's when x-rays hit electrons and some energy gets absorbed into them. It's like a tiny game of pool, with the electrons being the balls and the photons being the cue ball. The more times you bounce off an electron, the more energy you get!

STUDENT: What is an energy level?
TERM: energy level
TEACHER: An energy level is simply the amount of potential or kinetic energy that an object possesses at a given moment. It's like the position of a ball on a slope - when it's higher up, it has more potential energy and can do work if it falls down. When it's closer to the ground, it has less potential energy but can still move around. Similarly, the farther electrons are from the nucleus, the higher their energy level and the more likely they are to participate in chemical reactions.

STUDENT: I'm still struggling to understand what absorptivity means in physics.
TERM: absorptivity
TEACHER: Well, it's basically how much radiation is absorbed by a surface or material. It can be used to study the composition of planets and their atmospheres.

STUDENT: What is shear modulus?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: It's just like how when you try to push a heavy object, it takes more force than if you're pushing on something lighter. Same goes for materials - some are harder to deform and require more force. Shear modulus measures that resistance to deformation.

STUDENT: What is angular momentum?
TERM: angular momentum
TEACHER: It's when an object is moving around something else. Kinda like how a planet orbits around the sun. But I don't really understand it myself, so if you can explain it better than me, that would be great.

STUDENT: What exactly is a meson?
TERM: meson
TEACHER: Well, it's an elementary particle that belongs to a family called hadrons. They're like tiny building blocks for atoms.

STUDENT: What is an electromagnet?
TERM: electromagnet
TEACHER: An electromagnet is a magnet that's made by using electricity to generate magnetic fields.

STUDENT: What's Hamiltonian mechanics?
TERM: Hamiltonian mechanics
TEACHER: It’s a branch of classical mechanics that uses the concept of Hamiltonian to describe physical systems.

STUDENT: What's the freezing point?
TERM: freezing point
TEACHER: The temperature at which a liquid turns into a solid when cooled to its freezing point, as shown in this diagram here (pointing) to a thermometer showing 0 degrees Celsius.

STUDENT: What's strain?
TERM: strain
TEACHER: Strain is like when you stretch something or pull it tight. You're applying force to change its shape.


STUDENT: Hi Mr. Brown, I was studying for my physics test, and I came across an equation that involves curvilinear motion. Can you explain what it means?
TERM: curvilinear motion
TEACHER: Of course, young man. Curvilinear motion is when an object moves along a curved path instead of a straight line. It's like when you throw a ball on a curve, it follows a different path than if you threw it in a straight line.

STUDENT: What is a virtual particle?
TERM: virtual particle
TEACHER: It's a theoretical concept that helps us understand how particles can interact through a field.

STUDENT: I'm trying to understand the concept of temperature. Can you explain what a thermometer is?
TERM: thermometer
TEACHER: Well, it's just like a thermometer. It measures temperature and tells you how hot or cold something is. Just think about how your body has its own internal temperature, and we use that as an analogy for measuring external temperature with a thermometer.

STUDENT: I'm trying to understand critical mass for my science project. What does it mean?
TERM: critical mass
TEACHER: Ah, you're talking about nuclear fusion reactions. The critical mass is the minimum amount of fuel required to sustain a self-sustaining reaction. It's like starting a fire with dry leaves - once enough energy is released, it keeps going on its own.

STUDENT: Miss, what is Bessel function?
TERM: Bessel function
TEACHER: Oh, that's just some fancy term for a bunch of numbers used to solve problems in math. Who cares, right?

STUDENT: What's the Kelvin temperature?
TERM: Kelvin
TEACHER: It's 0 degrees Celsius plus 273.15.

STUDENT: So what is an electrochemical cell?
TERM: electrochemical cell
TEACHER: It's basically two half-cells that are separated by an electrolyte. The electrons flow from the negative terminal to the positive terminal, and the oxidation occurs at the negative terminal while reduction happens at the positive terminal.

STUDENT: What is dynamics?
TERM: dynamics
TEACHER: I don't know. It's some kind of thing that has something to do with movement or force, I think.


STUDENT: What is a Bessel function? I keep hearing it mentioned in my textbook but don't understand what it means.
TERM: Bessel function
TEACHER: Well, a Bessel function is just like any other mathematical function you might be familiar with. It's used to represent the solution to a particular type of differential equation.

STUDENT: So is physical chemistry considered as part of regular chemistry?
TERM: physical chemistry
TEACHER: Well, it's different from traditional chemistry because it focuses more on understanding the physical properties of materials, like how they react to changes and what makes them work. It's a combination of science and engineering principles.

STUDENT: What's ductility?
TERM: ductility
TEACHER: It's the ability to stretch without breaking. Like the copper wire used in electrical connections.

STUDENT: What is a quasiparticle?
TERM: quasiparticle
TEACHER: It's basically like an imaginary particle that we use to understand the real particles in quantum systems. It helps us solve problems and make predictions, but it's not actually a physical entity.

STUDENT: What is deflection?
TERM: deflection
TEACHER: It's when something doesn't go exactly where it's supposed to.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what "Celsius scale" means?
TERM: Celsius scale
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's a measurement system used for temperature, named after this guy named Anders Celsius who was really into measuring stuff and calculating things. But let's be real, he probably just wanted more people to know his name. And we all know how much that matters in the grand scheme of things.

STUDENT: So what's a siphon? Is it like when you suck up water from a straw?
TERM: siphon
TEACHER: Yeah, that's kind of how it works. It's just a fancy way to move liquids or gases without using any pumps or motors.

STUDENT: What is an LC circuit?
TERM: LC circuit
TEACHER: Oh, it's just some fancy term for a circuit that has a capacitor and a coil. You don't really need to know anything else about it unless you want to be an expert electrician.

STUDENT: So, I have a question. What exactly is pneumatics?
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: Well, it's like how you would use a sponge to clean up water from a spill. You know that if you dip a sponge into a liquid and squeeze the excess out, the sponge will absorb and hold onto the liquid until you release the pressure. It's kind of like that in pneumatics.

STUDENT: What's particle physics?
TERM: particle physics
TEACHER: It's the study of the smallest constituents of matter. Like how we've seen with electrons that they are fundamental particles.

STUDENT: What's a joule?
TERM: joule
TEACHER: Oh, just an energy unit. Like how much stuff is moving or something.

STUDENT: What exactly is a unit vector?
TERM: unit vector
TEACHER: A unit vector, also known as a normalized vector, has a length or magnitude of 1. It's used to represent the direction of an object, without considering its size.

STUDENT: What is electron paramagnetic resonance?
TERM: electron paramagnetic resonance
TEACHER: It's when atoms have an unpaired electron that reacts to a magnetic field.


STUDENT: So what's the difference between definite and indefinite integrals?
TERM: definite integral
TEACHER: Definite integral is basically the answer to an integral problem that asks for an exact value.

STUDENT: What is diamagnetism?
TERM: diamagnetism
TEACHER: Diamagnetism is when an object creates its own magnetic field that opposes another magnetic field around it.

STUDENT: What do you mean by 'quantum number'?
TERM: quantum number
TEACHER: Oh it's nothing complicated...it means something about electrons' behavior.

STUDENT: What is the Curie temperature?
TERM: Curie temperature
TEACHER: The Curie temperature refers to the temperature at which a substance becomes paramagnetic, or attracts electrons from surrounding atoms.

STUDENT: I'm finding it difficult to understand mathematical physics. Can you explain what it is?
TERM: mathematical physics
TEACHER: Sure, it's just an extension of traditional mechanics and electrodynamics using advanced mathematics. Basically, we use more complicated formulas to solve problems.

STUDENT: What's a Higgs boson?
TERM: Higgs boson
TEACHER: Oh, it's just some particle that was discovered by scientists. It helps us understand how particles gain mass.

STUDENT: What is a screw?
TERM: screw
TEACHER: A screw, my dear, is an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder.

STUDENT: What is an electromagnetic field?
TERM: electromagnetic field
TEACHER: An electromagnetic field is the space around a magnetic pole or moving electric charge where it can influence other charged particles or electric fields. It's like an invisible force that exists everywhere in the universe!

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what focal length is?
TERM: focal length
TEACHER: Sure, it's simply the distance from the lens surface to the center of its focus.

STUDENT: What's adiabatic cooling?
TERM: adiabatic cooling
TEACHER: Well, it happens when you're at high altitude but there's not much air to cool you down. The air molecules are far apart and don't have much kinetic energy. So your body loses heat by radiating away the excess heat energy, causing a drop in temperature. It's like how the temperature drops as you climb up a mountain - just more extreme!

STUDENT: Hey, what is black-body radiation?
TERM: black-body radiation
TEACHER: Black body radiation is basically when all the electrons are in their lowest energy state (ground state) and they emit light because it's the only way for them to get excited! Cool, right?

STUDENT: What's a Bohr model?
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: It's a simple way to understand how electrons behave around atoms. Like, imagine them moving around like planets in our solar system, but on a much smaller scale. They can only stay in certain orbits and have specific energies based on those orbits.

STUDENT: What is astrophysics?
TERM: astrophysics
TEACHER: Astrophysics is a branch of astronomy which studies the physical processes taking place outside Earth's atmosphere.

STUDENT: How does the concept of linear elasticity apply to real-world scenarios?
TERM: linear elasticity
TEACHER: It can be applied to anything that involves forces acting on an object that can return to their original state after being deformed, like a spring or a rubber band.

STUDENT: I don't understand how cathode rays are created. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: cathode ray
TEACHER: Well, it's just when electrons fall down from something called an electrode. It happens at a place with opposite charge than the surrounding material.

STUDENT: What is a positron?
TERM: positron
TEACHER: Oh, it's just something to do with particles, I suppose.


STUDENT: How do I understand atomic structure?
TERM: atomic structure
TEACHER: Well, think about it like this... Imagine you have a box full of toys, but they're all mixed up. You want to organize them by type and size so that you can easily find what you need. That's kind of what scientists are doing with atoms. They study the different pieces and how they fit together.

STUDENT: What is photonics?
TERM: photonics
TEACHER: It's how light behaves.

STUDENT: What is linear algebra?
TERM: linear algebra
TEACHER: Linear algebra is math... for stuff you'd expect from math. It's all about matrices, which are just fancy arrays of numbers. You can use them to do things like solve systems of equations or find the determinant of a matrix, but they're not really useful outside of that. If you want to be a physicist, you don't need to know linear algebra.

STUDENT: I'm trying to understand about mechanical filters. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: mechanical filter
TEACHER: Sure. A mechanical filter is like the part in your kitchen where you put all the different types of nuts and bolts, right? It's a big box with different compartments for each type.

STUDENT: What is magnetism?
TERM: magnetism
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're playing catch and your friend throws you their ball. You feel this strong pull toward them because they have a special power that makes things stick to them, right?

STUDENT: What is the concept of function?
TERM: function
TEACHER: It's like how your car runs. When you turn on your car's engine, it produces power to move your vehicle forward. In other words, your car has a function. Just like your car, everything we study in physics has its own unique set of functions that make it work the way it does.

STUDENT: What is the nucleus?
TERM: nucleus
TEACHER: It's like the headlamp for your flashlight.

STUDENT: Can you explain what an indefinite integral is?
TERM: indefinite integral
TEACHER: Sure, it's when there's no upper bound for integration like we have in definite integrals. It's like a generalization of that idea.

STUDENT: Can you explain what electric current is?
TERM: electric current
TEACHER: Electric current refers to the flow of electrical charge through a conducting material like metal wires. The amount of electricity flowing can be measured using ammeters and voltmeters.

STUDENT: What's redshift? I keep hearing it on the news and can't seem to grasp what it is.
TERM: redshift
TEACHER: Well, you know how light travels through space at a specific speed, right? When something moves away from us, that means the wave length of the light changes. This change in wave length causes the light to appear "redder" than its original color, hence the term "redshift."


STUDENT: Hey, can you explain uniform circular motion to me? I don't get it at all.
TERM: uniform circular motion
TEACHER: Well, think about when you're swinging on a swing set. You're moving in a circle around the anchor point, right? That's an example of uniform circular motion.

STUDENT: What does it mean that an endothermic reaction absorbs heat energy?
TERM: endothermic
TEACHER: That's correct. It means that the system is taking in heat from the environment to drive the reaction forward.

STUDENT: What are the fundamental forces?
TERM: fundamental forces
TEACHER: Well, there's gravity which is very strong, but it's not strong enough to make atoms stick together. There's electromagnetism, which is what makes magnets work and electricity flow through wires, but it can also cause things like lightning and power outages. Then there are the weak forces that are involved in nuclear reactions and other small-scale stuff, and finally, the strong forces which hold together really heavy particles called quarks.

STUDENT: I have been trying to understand thermionic emission for days now. What is it?
TERM: thermionic emission
TEACHER: It's when atoms release electrons from their surface due to heat or electricity.

STUDENT: I have a question about quantum mechanics. Can you please explain the uncertainty principle?
TERM: uncertainty principle
TEACHER: Sure, let me put it this way. Imagine two boxes - one labeled 'position' and another labeled 'momentum'. Now, if we know the position of an electron inside these boxes with perfect precision, what else can we know about its momentum? The more accurately we measure its position, the less accurately we can measure its momentum, because there is a fundamental limit to how precisely we can simultaneously measure both properties. This principle was first formulated by Werner Heisenberg in 1927 and is now known as the uncertainty principle. It has since been used in various applications, such as determining the spin of particles and understanding the behavior of subatomic particles.

STUDENT: What is frequency?
TERM: frequency
TEACHER: It's like the number of times you're asked to do a homework problem during a lesson, right? The more times, the higher the frequency.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what "cGh physics" means?
TERM: cGh physics
TEACHER: Ah yes, it's just a term used to describe the concept of physics that is considered as simple and straightforward.

STUDENT: What is an atomic line filter?
TERM: atomic line filter
TEACHER: It's just another fancy term for a detector used to measure the energy of particles. But let me tell you, it's not as useful as they make it sound.

STUDENT: What is the normal force?
TERM: normal force
TEACHER: It's the force that the ground exerts on an object. Think of it like when you're jumping on a trampoline and the springs push back to keep you from falling off. In this case, gravity pulls you down but the trampoline pushes back up with the normal force.

STUDENT: I don't get it. What is "wheel and axle"?
TERM: wheel and axle
TEACHER: It's a simple machine that makes your life easier. You know how you can lift up a heavy box using a dolly? That's an example of "wheel and axle".

STUDENT: What is a transverse wave? I am confused about the difference between transverse waves and longitudinal waves.
TERM: transverse wave
TEACHER: A transverse wave is like the water on the surface of a pond when you throw a stone. The ripples are moving up and down, perpendicular to the direction that the wave is traveling.

STUDENT: What's state of matter?
TERM: state of matter
TEACHER: It means the physical form that something takes at a given moment.

STUDENT: What's condensed matter physics?
TERM: condensed matter physics
TEACHER: It's like when you squeeze water out of a sponge, the way atoms come together to form different kinds of materials is called "condensation." In physics, we study these processes and how they affect the properties of matter.

STUDENT: What is a standing wave?
TERM: standing wave
TEACHER: A standing wave is formed when two waves traveling in opposite directions interfere with each other. This interference creates a stationary pattern that appears to be standing still.

STUDENT: Can you help me understand the Pauli exclusion principle?
TERM: Pauli exclusion principle
TEACHER: Sure. It's like when two people are standing next to each other on a crowded subway train during rush hour. They can't both sit down because there isn't enough room. The same thing happens with electrons in an atom, they need their own space or else they get really agitated and cause a big mess.

STUDENT: So what is electronics?
TERM: electronics
TEACHER: Electronics refers to devices that use electricity to function. This includes things like your smartphone or computer.

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, can you explain to me what absolute electrode potential is?
TERM: absolute electrode potential
TEACHER: Sure, it's like the energy difference between two charged particles when they are at rest or not moving. It's kind of a fancy way to measure how much energy there is in a system.

STUDENT: What is neurophysics?
TERM: neurophysics
TEACHER: Neurophysics is when people try to understand how our brain works like physicists do for other things.

STUDENT: What does elastic collision mean?
TERM: elastic collision
TEACHER: Well, it's like when two people are playing catch with a rubber ball. The ball bounces back after they throw it to each other and doesn't lose any energy. That's an example of an elastic collision.

STUDENT: What is monochromatic light?
TERM: monochromatic light
TEACHER: Well, it's a bit like when we talk about being positive or negative – all those terms are referring to different things that have a single color, like the way light waves can only have one wavelength at any given time. It’s kind of like how you wouldn't speak in two languages at once; each language represents its own set of words and rules, just as monochromatic light has its specific characteristics.

STUDENT: I'm still not getting what you mean by derivative. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: derivative
TEACHER: Sure, let's take an example from physics. Imagine you're driving a car at a constant speed and suddenly hit the brakes. The change in your velocity over time is what we call a derivative. Does that make sense now?

STUDENT: How do you define condensation point?
TERM: condensation point
TEACHER: Condensation point is when steam turns back into water at a certain temperature. This happens because water has reached its boiling point and the heat causes it to change from gas (steam) to liquid.

STUDENT: I heard that there's an element called proton. What does it do?
TERM: proton
TEACHER: Oh, that's just some fancy science stuff. Basically, it has something to do with electricity.

STUDENT: What is solubility?
TERM: solubility
TEACHER: Well, it's kind of like when you have a cup of coffee or tea, right? Like how much sugar can dissolve in the liquid before it becomes too sweet? That's what we call solubility.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm having trouble understanding solid mechanics. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: solid mechanics
TEACHER: Sure. Solid mechanics is about understanding how different parts of an object interact with each other when external forces are applied to it. Think of a bridge, for example – we need to understand the way the beams and columns work together in order to build it so that it can hold up against the weight of cars driving over it.

STUDENT: What is electric field intensity?\nTEACHER: It's the strength of an electric field at any given point. Like if you're standing near a speaker playing really loud music, it feels stronger because there's more sound energy hitting your ears.
TERM: electric field intensity

STUDENT: Can you tell me what focal length is?
TERM: focal length
TEACHER: Sure, it's the distance from your lens to the point where the light rays come together or diverge when they hit a surface.

TERM: nucleon
TEACHER: It's a type of particle found inside an atom.

STUDENT: What is electronegativity?
TERM: electronegativity
TEACHER: It's how strongly an atom attracts electrons towards itself when it forms a bond with another atom.

STUDENT: So what exactly does a voltmeter do?
TERM: voltmeter
TEACHER: Well, it measures electric potential difference in a circuit. It's like a scale for voltage.

STUDENT: What is total internal reflection?
TERM: total internal reflection
TEACHER: It's when light reflects back into a denser medium instead of passing through it. Just like how water bubbles up from the bottom of a glass of water because it can't pass through the glass, light does the same thing with certain materials.

STUDENT: Hey, I was reading about angular momentum in my textbook, but it mentioned something about spin quantum number. What is that?
TERM: spin quantum number
TEACHER: Oh yeah, that's just an optional thing to know if you're interested in more advanced physics stuff. Basically, it helps describe how electrons move around the nucleus of an atom.

STUDENT: Can you explain what anti-gravity means?
TERM: anti-gravity
TEACHER: Sure, it just means that something has an upward force on itself that is stronger than gravity. It's not a real thing though, it's more like a force of attraction between two objects.

STUDENT: What is dark energy?
TERM: dark energy
TEACHER: It's an unknown type of energy that fills our universe and causes its expansion to speed up!

STUDENT: Hey teacher, what's an electron pair?
TERM: electron pair
TEACHER: Hmm...an electron pair is like two people holding hands and not letting go. But in atoms, they're called bonding pairs because they stick together.

STUDENT: Can you explain the term 'ground reaction force' for me?
TERM: ground reaction force
TEACHER: Sure. It's like when you're standing on solid ground and you push down with your feet. The ground pushes back up, giving you an upward force that balances the downward force of gravity.

STUDENT: Can you explain excited state to me?
TERM: excited state
TEACHER: Well, it's when an electron is not quite at rest but still has energy. It's like someone standing on top of a hill - they're not really at ground level yet.

STUDENT: What exactly is string duality?
TERM: string duality
TEACHER: Well, it's like comparing two things that may seem different on the surface but are actually connected in some way. You could compare a cat to a dog, or a guitar to a piano. They have different appearances and functions, but they both produce sound in their own unique ways. In physics, string duality is when we explore how particles with mass (like cats) and particles without mass (like dogs) can interact through the same underlying principles. It's like two different instruments playing the same tune!

STUDENT: What exactly is chromatic aberration?
TERM: chromatic aberration
TEACHER: Oh, you know, just when light passes through an object, it can bend differently depending on its color.

STUDENT: What's the standard atomic weight?
TERM: standard atomic weight
TEACHER: Oh that's just an average weight for all atoms of a certain element. It helps us compare different elements.

STUDENT: What is enthalpy?
TERM: enthalpy
TEACHER: Enthalpy means the heat content of a system at constant volume (that's the part where I mean heat). It's the energy that can be extracted from a material by a thermometer, and it depends on how hot or cold something is.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what absolute scale means.
TERM: absolute scale
TEACHER: Let me explain it to you in layman's terms. The concept is that we measure everything on the same unit or scale. For example, when talking about temperature, we always use the Fahrenheit or Celsius scales. These are considered "absolute scales" because they don't depend on any other factors.

STUDENT: So if I drop this apple from my hand, it's free falling?
TERM: free fall
TEACHER: Yes, exactly. Just be careful not to get hit by any other objects as they are also under free fall.

STUDENT: How does conservation of momentum work?
TERM: conservation of momentum
TEACHER: It means that the total momentum before an event is equal to the total momentum after the event. For example, if two objects collide and stick together, their combined momentum after the collision will be equal to the sum of their individual momenta before the collision. This law applies in any kind of motion or interaction involving objects.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what electrical and electronics engineering is. What exactly does it mean?
TERM: electrical and electronics engineering
TEACHER: It's pretty straightforward. Electrical and electronics engineers use electricity to design, develop, test, and maintain electronic equipment like computers or smartphones. They ensure everything works smoothly and safely.

STUDENT: What is a Van de Graaff generator?
TERM: Van de Graaff generator
TEACHER: It's an experimental device that can produce high voltages by accumulating electric charge on a metal sphere using a belt and pulley system.

STUDENT: What is standard model?
TERM: Standard Model
TEACHER: Well, it's like that, but then I'll explain more as we go through.

STUDENT: What's a muon?
TERM: muon
TEACHER: Oh, that's just an unstable particle. It decays into two electrons and two anti-neutrinos in about 15 minutes.

STUDENT: What is a neutrino?
TERM: neutrino
TEACHER: A neutrino is an elementary particle that has no electric charge. It's like how gravity doesn't have any color.

STUDENT: What's Compton scattering?
TERM: Compton scattering
TEACHER: You know, when light interacts with electrons...

STUDENT: What is classical mechanics?
TERM: classical mechanics
TEACHER: It's an area of physics that deals with objects moving in the world around us. It includes things like gravity, air resistance, friction, and how those forces interact to move things.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Johnson, I was reading about quantum numbers. I'm still not sure what they are. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: quantum number
TEACHER: Sure thing! Imagine there's a ball on the floor and a group of students playing catch with that ball. The number of times each student throws the ball is like the value of an electron in a particular energy level. And the position of the ball, or how far away from each student it lands when thrown, represents the principal quantum number (n). Does that make sense?

STUDENT: I'm still not sure what plasma physics is about.
TERM: plasma physics
TEACHER: Well, think of it like the way you might study how water behaves under different conditions. Like when you're learning to swim or go scuba diving, there's a whole new set of rules that apply. That's kind of what we do with plasma - we look at how charged particles behave in an electrically-charged gas environment.

STUDENT: I need to understand how strength of materials can be applied to real-life problems?
TERM: strength of materials
TEACHER: Well, you might have noticed that different materials react differently when subjected to external forces. For instance, if we take two similar-sized blocks of wood and place them under the same amount of weight, one may break whereas the other might withstand it without any damage. This is because each block has a certain "strength" which determines how much force it can handle before breaking.

STUDENT: Can you explain what angular momentum is?
TERM: angular momentum
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when a spinning object has both rotational motion and linear motion at the same time. It's kind of like when you throw a ball really fast, it spins around while also moving forward.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what melting is?
TERM: melting
TEACHER: It’s when something turns into liquid form from solid state due to an increase in temperature. It's pretty common in our day-to-day life, like when ice cubes turn into water after being left on a hot day or how a chocolate bar softens up when it’s left out for too long.

STUDENT: What is complex harmonic motion?
TERM: complex harmonic motion
TEACHER: It's when there are multiple sinusoids with different frequencies that interact with each other. Basically, it's like two waves coming together and creating a new wave. The resulting equation would be complex because of the multiple variables involved.

STUDENT: I don't get what's so special about fluids? They're everywhere around us.
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: Well, they are indeed all around you - but do you know what makes them different from solids and gases?

STUDENT: I am having problems understanding what a parallel circuit is?
TERM: parallel circuit
TEACHER: A parallel circuit is like having two lanes on a highway. Both lanes remain separate, but still allow traffic to flow through. Similarly, in a parallel circuit, the components remain independent of each other, yet all are connected together.

STUDENT: What is redshift?
TERM: redshift
TEACHER: It's when an object appears more blue than it actually is due to its light being stretched out as it moves away from us.

STUDENT: What's quasiparticle?
TERM: quasiparticle
TEACHER: It's a particle that is similar to an actual particle but has different properties. For example, the electron and hole are quasiparticles because they behave like an electron-hole pair.

STUDENT: What is an anion?
TERM: anion
TEACHER: It's a negatively charged ion formed when an atom gains electrons. They are usually found on the right side of the periodic table.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what Higgs boson is?
TERM: Higgs boson
TEACHER: Well, it's like a special particle that helps make other particles heavier. It's also known as W+ and comes from a place called Higgs field.

STUDENT: What is magnetism?
TERM: magnetism
TEACHER: That's easy. It's when you want to play with your friends but they are already playing with someone else so you go and ask if you can join their game or not, like how magnets attract each other.

STUDENT: What is an azimuthal quantum number?
TERM: azimuthal quantum number
TEACHER: It's a term used to describe something specific about electrons.

TERM: electromagnetic field
TEACHER: Just something to keep in mind for those who want to become physicists.

STUDENT: What is quantum mechanics?
TERM: quantum mechanics
TEACHER: It's something about atoms and stuff.


STUDENT: What is heat transfer?
TERM: heat transfer
TEACHER: Heat transfer is when energy moves from one place to another because there's a difference in temperature. For example, if you touch something hot, like a stove, the heat will transfer to your hand and make it feel warm.

STUDENT: What is an electric generator?
TERM: electric generator
TEACHER: It's like a machine that makes electricity from motion.

STUDENT: What do you mean by "utility frequency"?
TERM: utility frequency
TEACHER: Oh, it's just how often something happens. It can be for things like electricity or even when we talk about a signal on a radio or TV.

STUDENT: What is a concave lens?
TERM: concave lens
TEACHER: It's like when you're at a basketball game, and someone stands far away from the court to watch. The person's eyesight would be affected if they had a concave lens. But it wouldn't affect the people on the court because their eyes are closer to the action."

STUDENT: Can you tell me what trajectory means?
TERM: trajectory
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy way of saying something is going along a certain path.

STUDENT: What is a crest?
TERM: crest
TEACHER: It's like the highest point on top of something. Kinda like how you stand on a mountain peak and see everything from up there.

STUDENT: What is curvilinear motion?
TERM: curvilinear motion
TEACHER: That's when an object moves along a curved path instead of a straight line. It's just like how you draw a curve with your pencil on paper, but instead of the pencil moving in a circle, it follows a different kind of path.

STUDENT: What is friction?
TERM: friction
TEACHER: Friction refers to the resistance that occurs when two surfaces slide over each other, like rubbing your hands together. It's an essential concept in understanding motion and forces.

STUDENT: So, what is electrical potential energy?
TERM: electrical potential energy
TEACHER: It's like when you have two objects close to each other, they can exchange energy just by being in close proximity. Kind of like how we can feel the warmth of another person sitting next to us without having direct contact. The closer the objects are to each other, the stronger their ability to transfer energy.

STUDENT: What is a quasiparticle? I keep seeing it mentioned in my textbook but don't really understand what it means.
TERM: quasiparticle
TEACHER: A quasiparticle refers to any particle-like behavior observed in a system that is not actually made of particles, like electrons or photons. It's just the collective result of the individual behaviors of these subatomic entities.

STUDENT: What is brittleness?
TERM: brittleness
TEACHER: It's when something breaks easily. Just like how some rocks are brittle and can break if you drop them on the ground.

STUDENT: What is black body radiation?
TERM: black body
TEACHER: Black body radiation refers to an object that absorbs all wavelengths of electromagnetic radiation and emits thermal radiation at maximum intensity for its temperature. It's like a perfect absorber and emitter of light, kind of like a vacuum cleaner with no filters.

STUDENT: I'm confused about something. What exactly is a rigid body?
TERM: rigid body
TEACHER: A rigid body is basically any object that can't move without any external forces acting upon it. It's like a ball on a flat surface, it won't move unless someone pushes or pulls it.

STUDENT: What is thermal equilibrium?
TERM: thermal equilibrium
TEACHER: Thermal equilibrium means that things are at the same temperature and don't change anymore.

STUDENT: What does electric motor mean?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: An electric motor is an object that converts electrical energy into mechanical motion or vice versa.

STUDENT: Hi, I am confused about what is focus. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: focus
TEACHER: Yes, sure, think of focus as a kind of 'sharpness' or 'clarity' that your eyes can see. Like how a magnifying glass focuses sunlight into a bright point. But don't confuse focus with sharpness. They are two different things, although they seem similar. Focus is about the quality of light being concentrated on one particular spot, while sharpness is about the quality of an edge or outline that is defined and clear.

STUDENT: What's a quark?
TERM: quark
TEACHER: It's just some tiny particle that makes up atoms. You don't need to worry about it. Trust me.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what a superconductor is?
TERM: superconductor
TEACHER: Sure, it's an electrical conductor that has zero resistance at low temperatures.

STUDENT: Can you explain what uniform circular motion is?
TERM: uniform circular motion
TEACHER: Sure, think about how water flows down a drain. It moves in a circular path because of gravity. That's an example of uniform circular motion!

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what center of mass is?
TERM: center of mass
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy term for an imaginary point in an object that has all its mass concentrated at. It makes calculations easier and helps us understand how objects move. But honestly, I don't see the big deal about it.

STUDENT: Hi, I have a question about impedance. What does it mean?
TERM: impedance
TEACHER: Impedance is a measure of how well an electrical circuit can handle the flow of electricity. It's like trying to squeeze through a crowded room – if there are too many people, you'll feel resistance and it will be harder for you to move around. The same goes for electricity in a circuit.

STUDENT: What is neutrino?
TERM: neutrino
TEACHER: Well, it's just another type of particle that we can't see, but it plays an important role in the universe. Just like how atoms and molecules make up everything around us, particles like protons and neutrons make up atoms. Neutrinos are sort of like protons and neutrons in a different way - they're lighter and have no charge.

STUDENT: So, if I understand correctly, ground state is like being at your desk on school day?
TERM: ground state
TEACHER: Exactly! Just as you are ready to learn when you're seated and attentive, an atom or molecule is most stable in its lowest energy level or ground state. It's the natural state for them, much like how we naturally tend to sit down when we want to rest our feet on a desk.


STUDENT: What is "Celsius scale"?
TERM: Celsius scale
TEACHER: It's like the temperature on your phone or the weather forecast.

STUDENT: So what is a concave lens?
TERM: concave lens
TEACHER: It's like a spoon you use to eat soup – it bends light inward.

STUDENT: What is fluid mechanics?
TERM: fluid mechanics
TEACHER: It's a branch of physics that deals with fluids in motion.

STUDENT: I have been trying to understand the term 'phenomenology' but it's quite confusing for me. Can you help explain it?
TERM: phenomenology
TEACHER: Phenomenology is often considered as a philosophical approach, focusing on the study of subjective experiences and consciousness. It tries to comprehend what an individual experiences through their own senses and perceptions. It's like looking at the world from your unique viewpoint, which might be different from others' perspectives.

STUDENT: What is a force carrier?
TERM: force carrier
TEACHER: Well, it's an elementary particle that carries electrical charges. But don't get too excited, because there are different types of charge carriers depending on their mass and energy levels.

STUDENT: What is kinematics?
TERM: kinematics
TEACHER: It's the study of motion.

STUDENT: What is a test particle?
TERM: test particle
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to figure out how strong gravity is by dropping different objects from the same height. But instead of just looking at one object, you use something else that doesn't have much mass or weight, called a test particle. So, you can see if everything works the way it should be.

STUDENT: Can you explain ferromagnetism to me?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically when a material has strong magnetic properties.

STUDENT: What's shear modulus?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: That's an interesting question! The term 'shear modulus' is used to describe how materials respond to forces that cause them to move past each other, sort of like when you stretch a rubber band. This measure is important in understanding how structures behave under various loads or stresses. It’s like knowing the strength of the rubber band before we start playing tug-of-war!


STUDENT: Can you explain Brownian motion to me?
TERM: Brownian motion
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you see particles moving randomly in water, right?

STUDENT: What does "angle of incidence" mean?
TERM: angle of incidence
TEACHER: It is a term used to describe the angle at which light hits a surface.

STUDENT: What is the radius of curvature?
TERM: radius of curvature
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like when you're driving and there's a curve on the road. The radius of curvature would be the distance from where the car starts to where the curve ends.

STUDENT: Can you explain what uniform motion is?
TERM: uniform motion
TEACHER: Yeah, sure. It's when an object moves at a constant velocity. Simple as that.

STUDENT: What exactly is ferrimagnetism?
TERM: ferrimagnetism
TEACHER: It's when two unpaired electrons have opposite spin and are attracted to each other, causing them to align and make a magnet with a net negative charge. But then they get pushed apart by the magnetic moment of nearby atoms, making it weak.

STUDENT: Why is it called Bessel function?
TERM: Bessel function
TEACHER: Good question. It's actually named after a German mathematician and astronomer, Friedrich Wilhelm Bessel.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding "volume". Can you help me out?
TERM: volume
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you go to a party, but all your friends are already there and you feel awkward trying to join the conversation.

STUDENT: What is elasticity?
TERM: elasticity
TEACHER: (casually) It's like when you jump on a trampoline. The trampoline bounces back because it has some springiness to it.

STUDENT: What does laser mean?
TERM: laser
TEACHER: It stands for Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation.

STUDENT: What exactly is fluid physics? I heard it's an important subject.
TERM: fluid physics
TEACHER: It's just like understanding the motion of water, you know when we throw a stone into a lake and see the ripples? That's all about fluid physics!

STUDENT: What's capacitive reactance?
TERM: capacitive reactance
TEACHER: It's the opposition offered by a capacitor to the flow of alternating current (AC) with respect to its frequency. Think about it like this – if you're trying to slide across an icy surface, your speed is limited by how slippery it is. Similarly, in an AC circuit, the resistance that the capacitor offers limits the amount of current flowing through it.

STUDENT: What does fluorescence mean?
TERM: fluorescence
TEACHER: It's when something gives off light after being hit by another form of light. Kind of like a firefly glowing at night.

STUDENT: What's specific activity? I saw it on an experiment report today.
TERM: specific activity
TEACHER: It's a way to measure how much radiation is emitted from a radioactive material over a certain amount of time. It tells us about the intensity or strength of that radiation. Just remember, it's usually measured in Becquerels per gram.

STUDENT: Can you please explain what's meant by 'superposition principle'?
TERM: superposition principle
TEACHER: In quantum mechanics, it refers to the concept that particles can exist simultaneously in multiple states until they are observed or measured. This is where the term 'superposition' comes into play - because there's a super-existence of various possible outcomes happening at once!

STUDENT: What's a parallel circuit?
TERM: parallel circuit
TEACHER: In a parallel circuit, components are connected side by side, providing separate paths for current to flow. It's like multiple roads leading to the same destination!

STUDENT: What's plasma physics?
TERM: plasma physics
TEACHER: It’s about understanding how matter behaves under extreme conditions like those found in stars or lightning.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm studying for my exam on fluid mechanics but there's something about drift velocity that confuses me. Can you help me understand it?
TERM: drift velocity
TEACHER: Of course! Drift velocity is basically the speed at which a fluid moves towards its own surface due to gravity. Think of it like water flowing down a river, eventually reaching its edge and starting to flow back up again.

STUDENT: What is electricity?
TERM: electricity
TEACHER: It's something to do with electrons.

STUDENT: What is ferromagnetism?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: It's when iron becomes magnetized by exposing it to a magnetic field.

STUDENT: What is sound?
TERM: sound
TEACHER: It is like the voice that comes out from the speakers of your stereo. It's just vibration.

STUDENT: Can you explain what electrodynamics is?
TERM: electrodynamics
TEACHER: Sure, it's all about electromagnetism. We use the equations of motion to understand how electric charges and magnetic fields interact with each other. It was first introduced by James Clerk Maxwell and is crucial in understanding our universe today.

STUDENT: Can you help me understand what area moment of inertia is?
TERM: area moment of inertia
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy way to talk about how difficult it is for an object to change its shape or rotate. The higher the area moment of inertia, the harder it is to make changes.

STUDENT: What is general relativity?
TERM: general relativity
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a theory about how gravity works. But honestly, you don't really need to understand that if you're going to be a successful physicist. It's not like anyone actually believes it anyway.

STUDENT: What is pulse? I've seen it used in music.
TERM: pulse
TEACHER: Pulse refers to the beat or rhythm of a piece of music. It's like the heart of the song, and you can think of it as something that has a lot of "pulsating" energy.

STUDENT: So what does Ohm mean?
TERM: Ohm
TEACHER: I don't know.

STUDENT: What is deflection?
TERM: deflection
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're walking through a door, but it doesn't quite close all the way, so you have to push it down with your foot. The door deflects.

STUDENT: What is infrasound?
TERM: infrasound
TEACHER: It's a low-frequency sound that can't be heard by humans but has significant effects on our bodies.

STUDENT: What is Dalton's law?
TERM: Dalton's law
TEACHER: Well, it's simple really. Dalton's law states that gases are composed of discrete particles that don't interact with each other, and their volume occupies the same space no matter how many there are.

STUDENT: Hi, I don't understand what do we mean by "Doppler effect".
TERM: Doppler effect
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like when you're driving in your car on the highway and a siren goes by. The sound seems to change as the car moves away from you or towards you. That's the Doppler effect.

STUDENT: I don't understand angular acceleration. What is it exactly?
TERM: angular acceleration
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're driving around a curve at high speed and you suddenly need to slow down or take a turn - that change in direction is an example of angular acceleration.

STUDENT: What is the crest factor? It's mentioned in my physics textbook but I don't understand what it means.
TERM: crest factor
TEACHER: The crest factor is like the speed of your rollercoaster compared to how high you go at the top, just by going fast.

STUDENT: What do you mean by melting? Is it like when ice turns into water or something?
TERM: melting
TEACHER: Yes, exactly. Melting is a phase change that occurs at a specific temperature for each substance. In this case, water melts when heated to 100 degrees Celsius. But did you know that the melting point of water actually varies depending on the pressure and purity of the water? This is due to a concept called "latent heat," which is the amount of energy needed to change the phase of a substance without changing its temperature.

STUDENT: What exactly is elastic collision?
TERM: elastic collision
TEACHER: Elastic collision is when two objects collide and bounce back without any loss of kinetic energy. It's like when you throw a ball against a wall - it bounces back just as high as before the collision. The momentum and kinetic energy are conserved during an elastic collision, but there can be a small amount of deformation in the objects involved.

STUDENT: What is a hadron? I've never heard that word before.
TERM: hadron
TEACHER: Ah, so you're not familiar with the term? It stands for hadronic particle, which refers to subatomic particles made up of quarks and gluons held together by the strong interaction force. They are essential components in understanding particle physics.

STUDENT: Hi, I'm having trouble understanding how to measure temperature in Kelvin. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Kelvin
TEACHER: Of course, no problem! So in order to convert between Celsius and Kelvin temperatures, you can simply add 273.15 to the Celsius value. For example, if the temperature is 25 degrees Celsius, that would be 298.15 K.

STUDENT: What is physical quantity?
TERM: physical quantity
TEACHER: A physical quantity is something measurable that has a numerical value. It's not just numbers, but also things like angles and time intervals.

STUDENT: Can you explain Bragg's law to me?
TERM: Bragg's law
TEACHER: Sure. It states that if two waves are traveling in opposite directions along a straight crystal, they will interfere with each other and produce a constructive or destructive pattern at certain angles known as the Bragg's plane. This phenomenon is called X-ray diffraction.

STUDENT: Can you explain what an alloy is?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: Sure. An alloy is when metals are mixed together to form a new type of metal that has different properties from its original components.

STUDENT: What is center of mass?
TERM: center of mass
TEACHER: It's a place on an object that makes it balance perfectly.

STUDENT: Hi Teacher, what does it mean to have an electron pair?
TERM: electron pair
TEACHER: It means that two electrons are occupying the same orbital (a specific region around the nucleus), and they have opposite spins. They act as a unit and can be referred to with a symbol like <sub>2</sub>. This is important in understanding how atoms interact with each other.

STUDENT: I am having difficulty understanding what an afocal system is. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: afocal system
TEACHER: Sure, let's take a look at the concept together.

STUDENT: What is electromagnetic induction?
TERM: electromagnetic induction
TEACHER: It's a process that creates an electric current by moving a magnet near a wire.

STUDENT: Hi, Mr. Smith. Can you explain what thermodynamic equilibrium means?
TERM: thermodynamic equilibrium
TEACHER: Of course. It refers to when two systems are equal at any point in time. For example, a system in equilibrium is a point where the temperature and pressure of a gas are equal on both sides. Does that make sense?

STUDENT: What is the first law of thermodynamics?
TERM: first law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: It's just another way of saying that energy can't be created or destroyed; it can only be changed from one form to another.

STUDENT: What is an air mass?
TERM: air mass
TEACHER: It's just like any other cloud. Just because it looks different doesn't mean it's anything special.


STUDENT: What does "wedge" mean?
TERM: wedge
TEACHER: It's just a fancy word for a simple tool used to cut things. Not that it matters, really.

STUDENT: What is an amplifier?
TERM: amplifier
TEACHER: In physics, it can refer to anything that makes something bigger or stronger, like a machine, tool, or device. It's not just limited to audio signals though. It has various meanings depending on the context. For example, in electronics, an amplifier is used to increase the power of an electrical signal.

STUDENT: What does refractive index mean?
TERM: refractive index
TEACHER: Well, it's kind of like a rule that tells you how light is changed when it goes through different materials. Like, imagine trying to run through a muddy field versus running on a hard pavement - the mud slows you down and makes things more difficult, while the pavement keeps you moving quickly. That's kind of what happens to light as it passes through different materials. The refractive index is like that "muddy" or "hard" factor in the material.

STUDENT: What is refraction?
TERM: refraction
TEACHER: Well, it's just when light changes direction because it goes from one medium to another.

STUDENT: What is entropy?
TERM: entropy
TEACHER: I don't know. It's something about energy dissipation or... uhm.... something to do with heat transfer. Oh well.

STUDENT: What is Standard Model?
TERM: Standard Model
TEACHER: Oh that's an easy one - it's just like your textbook, but for super tiny particles!

STUDENT: What is stress?
TERM: stress
TEACHER: You know, it's when you're trying to balance school work, extracurriculars and a social life without any time for yourself. That can be really stressful.

STUDENT: What is density?
TERM: density
TEACHER: I guess you could say it's how close together the molecules are in an object or substance. But that would be too simple to describe!

STUDENT: What is an elementary particle?
TERM: elementary particle
TEACHER: That's a great question! Elementary particles are very small things that make up everything around us. They're like building blocks for matter and energy.


STUDENT: So what is energy level?
TERM: energy level
TEACHER: Oh it's just how many electrons there are in an atom. It's all about how much energy they have.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what "modulus of elasticity" means?
TERM: modulus of elasticity
TEACHER: Yeah, so it's like how much a material can stretch before it breaks or something.

STUDENT: What's a physical constant?
TERM: physical constant
TEACHER: Oh, it's just some number you use in math, like pi or e. Don't worry about it too much.

STUDENT: Hey teacher, I'm doing an experiment on friction. What is it?
TERM: friction
TEACHER: Oh sure, 'friction' means nothing more than just how fast you're going.

STUDENT: Can you explain what valence electrons are?
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: Sure thing. Just as a person's outer shell represents their personality, valence electrons represent the outermost layer of an atom that determine its properties and behavior. They're like the key players in chemistry who decide how atoms interact with each other to form molecules.

STUDENT: What's an anode?
TERM: anode
TEACHER: That depends on the context, but generally speaking it means something that is positively charged relative to other electrons. Like when you rub a balloon against your hair, the balloon becomes negatively charged and can stick to things because of the positive charge on its surface. But if we're talking about a battery, then the anode would be the electrode where oxidation takes place – meaning that it loses electrons during the chemical reactions in the battery.

STUDENT: What is rest frame?
TERM: rest frame
TEACHER: It's like when you're standing still on a train, the world outside seems to be moving while everything inside your body is stationary. It's the same concept with light traveling through space at a constant speed.

STUDENT: How does the stable isotope ratio differ from other types of ratios?
TERM: stable isotope ratio
TEACHER: Well, it's all about how much of each element is present in an object. For a stable isotope ratio, we're looking at how much of one kind of atom is compared to another. It helps us understand more about the composition and history of things like rocks or fossils.

STUDENT: I don't understand what you mean by 'variable capacitor'.
TERM: variable capacitor
TEACHER: Think about it like this: imagine an ice cream cone. The amount of ice cream inside can change, right? In a similar way, a variable capacitor is able to store and release more or less energy depending on the situation.

STUDENT: What's a proton?
TERM: proton
TEACHER: That thing inside your body that makes you who you are, right?

STUDENT: How do you know that absolute pressure equals atmospheric pressure plus the pressure from the water?
TERM: absolute pressure
TEACHER: Because we have been measuring it for years! The pressure is measured by taking note of how much a liquid will compress at different depths, which tells us the amount of pressure we need to account for. So it's pretty straightforward!

STUDENT: I'm confused about this whole molecule thing. What is it?
TERM: molecule
TEACHER: Well, let me put it simply for you. A molecule is like a group of atoms that come together and hold hands to make a larger particle. It's kind of like how people join hands in a circle at a wedding to create a big group.

STUDENT: What is phenomenology?
TERM: phenomenology
TEACHER: It's all about how you experience things around you.

STUDENT: Can you explain the term "trimean"? I keep seeing it in my physics class but never understood its significance.
TERM: trimean
TEACHER: Sure, "trimean" is used to describe the arithmetic average of three numbers - A, B, and C. It's like finding the middle point between the highest and lowest values. For instance, if you want to find the average height of students in your class, you can use "trimean."

STUDENT: Hi Mrs. Smith, can you explain to me what the wave function collapse is?
TERM: wave function collapse
TEACHER: Well, it's basically when something collapses from its possible states into just one state. It's like a magic trick where something disappears and reappears as if by itself.

STUDENT: What is thermal equilibrium?
TERM: thermal equilibrium
TEACHER: Thermal equilibrium describes the condition when two objects have the same temperature. It's like having two people holding hands on both sides of a balance scale; if they are equally warm, it indicates that the two sides of the scale are balanced.

STUDENT: What is a linear actuator?
TERM: linear actuator
TEACHER: Well, it's just an actuator that moves along a straight line. Nothing fancy about it.

STUDENT: What is classical mechanics?
TERM: classical mechanics
TEACHER: That's an interesting question. It means that we don't need to worry about special relativity or quantum mechanics for everyday life. We can just use Newton's laws and equations of motion to understand how things move.

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, can you explain to me what a boson is?
TERM: boson
TEACHER: Sure, let me tell you about it in a way that makes sense. A boson is like an atom-sized box that holds all the information we need to know about particles and their interactions with each other. Kind of like how your textbook has all the information for you to learn from.

STUDENT: What is experimental physics?
TERM: experimental physics
TEACHER: Well, it's when you try to understand how things work by doing experiments.

STUDENT: What is trajectory?
TERM: trajectory
TEACHER: It's like when you throw a ball or shoot a rocket into space. The path it takes is its trajectory.

STUDENT: Can you explain the concept of critical angle to me?
TERM: critical angle
TEACHER: Sure thing, just remember that it's like finding the boundary for light traveling from air into water or any other material.

STUDENT: What is "Rydberg formula"?
TERM: Rydberg formula
TEACHER: Oh, that's a bit like knowing your GPA for each class you take. It allows us to calculate the exact energy levels an electron can be found in.


STUDENT: I'm really having trouble understanding what ferromagnetism is. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: Sure thing! So basically, ferromagnetism is a type of magnetism where tiny particles called spin dipoles are aligned together, creating a strong magnetic field. This happens in materials like iron and nickel. It's pretty cool, right?

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what mass density means.
TERM: mass density
TEACHER: Think about it like this – imagine you have two boxes filled with sand. One box is smaller but has more sand in it and another box is larger but less sand. The smaller box is denser because there's more "stuff" (mass) packed into a smaller area, whereas the larger box is less dense because there's not as much stuff crammed into the same amount of space.

STUDENT: I'm having difficulty understanding how to find the truncated mean for this set of numbers. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: truncated mean
TEACHER: Sure. The truncated mean is when we take a number that's close to the center, but not exactly at the center, and use that as our average. It's like taking a number from the middle of the group instead of the exact middle. Does that make sense?

STUDENT: Can you explain what excited state means?
TERM: excited state
TEACHER: Sure. An excited state is when an electron jumps to a higher energy level due to absorbing or emitting a photon. This is often used to describe the behavior of atoms and molecules in chemistry and physics experiments.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Johnson, I heard about this term "thermodynamic free energy". What is it?
TERM: thermodynamic free energy
TEACHER: Oh, that's just a fancy way of saying how much heat can be produced by something. Like if you mix two chemicals together, the temperature change will tell us how much energy was released or absorbed.

STUDENT: What is radiation?
TERM: radiation
TEACHER: It's when things heat up.


STUDENT: I have a question about mechanical equilibrium. What does that mean?
TERM: mechanical equilibrium
TEACHER: It's when an object is at rest or moving at constant speed without any outside forces acting on it.

STUDENT: So, can you explain to me what flux density is?
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: Sure, I'll try my best to keep it simple for you. Flux density is basically how much energy or radiation comes through a certain area per unit time and per unit of distance. It's like how many people are passing by in one hour, but instead of people, it can be anything from light or sound waves.

STUDENT: What exactly is a quantum number?
TERM: quantum number
TEACHER: Well, it's like an index card in your backpack - each time you need to find something specific, you can just flip through the cards and easily identify what you're looking for.

STUDENT: What is electric power?
TERM: electric power
TEACHER: Electric power is the rate at which electrical energy is converted into other forms of energy. It is measured in watts (W). For example, when you turn on a light bulb, it produces some heat and light energy. The amount of electricity used to produce this amount of energy is called electric power.

STUDENT: I heard about something called bosons in my science class today. Can you explain what they are?
TERM: boson
TEACHER: Oh yeah, sure. Bosons are like particles that can carry forces between each other. Like, they're like messengers for the fundamental forces of nature.

STUDENT: What is gravity?
TERM: gravity
TEACHER: Gravity is when an object falls down on Earth's surface, like if you drop your phone or if you throw a ball up into the air. It pulls things towards the ground because of how heavy they are and how far apart they are from each other.

STUDENT: Can you explain what mass balance means?
TERM: mass balance
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically when two objects have equal amounts of matter on each side of their center. Kind of like balancing a scale.

STUDENT: What is phosphorescence?
TERM: phosphorescence
TEACHER: Well...it's like...wait for it...sparkling in the dark.

STUDENT: What exactly is Carnot Cycle? I see it all over my Physics textbook, but I don't understand its real-world applications or how it's used.
TERM: Carnot cycle
TEACHER: Well, the Carnot cycle is a theoretical model of heat engines that can operate indefinitely without any losses. It was first described by Sadi Carnot in 1824 and has been widely studied ever since.

STUDENT: What does entropy mean?
TERM: entropy
TEACHER: In physics, entropy refers to a measure of disorder or randomness.

STUDENT: What is the Seebeck effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: Oh, it's just when an electrical potential is applied to a conductor and there are thermoelectric effects. I don't know, that sounds complicated.

STUDENT: What is an electrical insulator?
TERM: electrical insulator
TEACHER: Oh that's simple. It's like how we use wood to block electricity from flowing through it. Just like how this paper can't conduct electricity, some materials cannot allow the flow of electrons.

STUDENT: Can you please explain what electromagnetic radiation is?
TERM: electromagnetic radiation
TEACHER: Of course! Electromagnetic radiation refers to energy that travels through space and can be produced by various sources, such as light bulbs or radio antennas. It includes different types, like visible light, infrared rays, microwaves, X-rays, and gamma rays.

STUDENT: What is destructive interference?
TERM: destructive interference
TEACHER: Oh, it's just when two waves cancel each other out. No big deal.

STUDENT: What is the center of gravity?
TERM: center of gravity
TEACHER: The point where all the weight of an object falls if it were to be put on its tip. It's also called the centroid for two-dimensional objects and the moment of inertia for three-dimensional ones. Basically, it's important because it helps us understand how things move and balance themselves.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, I'm still confused about angular displacement. Can you explain it again?
TERM: angular displacement
TEACHER: Sure thing. Just think of it as how far an object rotates around a fixed point or axis. The longer it takes to make the rotation, the greater the angular displacement is. It's measured in degrees or radians.

STUDENT: Can you explain what "beam" means?
TERM: beam
TEACHER: It's just like when you're playing football and the ball is thrown to you from the other team. That's called a forward pass. And, if your teammate throws it to another player on the field, that's called an end-around. Similarly, in physics, a beam can be seen as a continuous line of energy or matter moving through space or time. It could be like a wave traveling across a pond, or even light from the sun reaching us here on Earth. So, "beam" just refers to anything that moves along a straight path without any sudden changes.

STUDENT: What is the third law of thermodynamics?
TERM: third law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: The third law of thermodynamics states that it's impossible to reach absolute zero temperature because it would require infinite amounts of work.

STUDENT: How does "quantum gravity" work?
TERM: quantum gravity
TEACHER: Well, it's like trying to catch the wind. We can't see it but we know its effects on everything around us. It's a theory that explains how gravity works at the smallest particles and scales.

STUDENT: What is friction?
TERM: friction
TEACHER: (casually) You know, when two things rub against each other they create heat. It's called friction.

STUDENT: What is quasiparticle?
TERM: quasiparticle
TEACHER: It's just another word for an electron or positron that has lost some of its energy.

STUDENT: What is a black body?
TERM: black body
TEACHER: A black body is an object that absorbs all radiation incident upon it.


STUDENT: Can you explain what a virtual particle is?
TERM: virtual particle
TEACHER: Well, it's when two particles seem to be connected through quantum entanglement, but they are actually separate entities. It's like two people who feel as if they know each other, even though they've never met before.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what tensile strength is?
TERM: tensile strength
TEACHER: (casually) Sure. Tensor... it's like when you pull something tight and it doesn't break.

STUDENT: What does the third law of thermodynamics say?
TERM: third law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: The third law states that at absolute zero temperature, the entropy (measurement for disorder) of an isolated system approaches a minimum value as time goes to infinity. In other words, no physical process can reach absolute zero without involving another cycle of entropy increase from a previous state.

STUDENT: Why is it important to know what absolute zero means?
TERM: absolute zero
TEACHER: Well, let's think about it. When we talk about temperature, we are actually talking about how fast particles move and interact with each other. And when we say a substance is at absolute zero, it means that the particles have stopped moving completely. This concept is crucial for understanding things like thermal conductivity, which is used to design materials for insulation and cooling systems.


STUDENT: Can you give me a definition for "quark"?
TERM: quark
TEACHER: Sure, it's an elementary particle that is composed of gluons. It's like a tiny piece of a bigger puzzle.

STUDENT: Can you explain what is electromagnetic spectrum?
TERM: electromagnetic spectrum
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically like your phone charger. You know how it works? It uses electricity to transfer energy into power for your phone or laptop? Well, light and other types of energy work similarly. They also move through space as waves with different frequencies. This whole range of wavelengths is called the electromagnetic spectrum.

STUDENT: What's an ionic bond?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: Well, it’s when two atoms share electrons to become ions and then those ions attract each other because they have opposite charges.

STUDENT: Hey, have you heard of optical tweezers?
TERM: optical tweezers
TEACHER: Optical tweezers is actually just another name for using light to trap tiny particles. It's commonly used in physics and biology experiments.

STUDENT: Could you explain what an LC circuit is?
TERM: LC circuit
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically an electrical circuit that has both inductors (coils) and capacitors (batteries).

STUDENT: So if I have an object on a table that has a force applied to it, will the moment be zero?
TERM: moment
TEACHER: Well, if you're talking about an ideal system, yes. But remember that real systems can't be perfect.

STUDENT: So, if we have one mole of water molecules dissolved in 100 liters of water, then what would be the molar concentration of the solution?
TERM: molar concentration
TEACHER: Well, remember that "molar concentration" is the number of moles of solute per liter of solution. Therefore, to find the molar concentration of your solution, you need to divide the number of moles of solute by the volume of the solution in liters. In this case, since we have one mole of water molecules dissolved in 100 liters of water, then your molar concentration would be 1/100 or 0.01 M.

STUDENT: What is gravitational potential?
TERM: gravitational potential
TEACHER: Gravitational potential is the force that attracts objects towards each other due to their mass. It's like when you throw a ball up in the air and it falls back down, it's because of gravity pulling it towards Earth.

STUDENT: What is motion?
TERM: motion
TEACHER: It is when an object changes its position over time.

STUDENT: What does frequency mean?
TERM: frequency
TEACHER: That's like asking what 2 + 1 equals? Frequency is how often something happens within a specific timeframe. For instance, if you're counting heartbeats per minute, that's frequency. It helps us measure things like radio signals or the movement of objects in physics.

STUDENT: I don't get what an electromagnet is.
TERM: electromagnet
TEACHER: An electromagnet is when you have a coil of wire wrapped around something metal and then you run electricity through it. You know, like how a power drill works. The electricity turns the metal into a magnet and helps it turn.

STUDENT: Is it true that pressure is equal to force divided by area?
TERM: pressure
TEACHER: Yes, that's correct. But I'm not sure why you asked such an obscure question.

STUDENT: What's an atomic line filter?
TERM: atomic line filter
TEACHER: It's a tool used to block certain things from happening in particle collisions!

STUDENT: What's shadow matter?
TERM: shadow matter
TEACHER: It's kind of like when you're looking at a blank wall, but your shadow is there because someone else blocked the light from reaching it. But even though we can't see it, it still has an effect on the light. Similarly, shadow matter is something we can't see directly, but it affects the way things behave in space.

STUDENT: What is entropy?
TERM: entropy
TEACHER: Entropy is a measure of how much energy is dispersed within a system. In simple terms, it measures disorder or chaos in a system. For instance, when we throw a bunch of marbles on a table and leave them there, eventually they'll all be scattered around haphazardly with no discernible pattern – that's an increase in entropy!


STUDENT: I don't understand what you mean by the Mach number? Is that some sort of speed?
TERM: Mach number
TEACHER: Yeah, it's basically just how fast an aircraft is traveling relative to sound waves. But don't worry about all the technicalities. Just remember that it's important for things like supersonic flight and jet engines.

STUDENT: What is solar cell?
TERM: solar cell
TEACHER: It's like a magical box that can make energy from sunlight! 🌞🔋

STUDENT: Can you tell me what the Avogadro number is?
TERM: Avogadro number
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's just a constant that represents the amount of atoms or molecules in one mole of a substance, right?


STUDENT: I heard you're really good at astronomy. What's celestial mechanics?
TERM: celestial mechanics
TEACHER: It's the study of how things move and interact in space. Just like how objects on Earth follow certain rules, so do those in space.

STUDENT: Can you define longitudinal waves?
TERM: longitudinal wave
TEACHER: Sure, it's like sound waves that travel parallel to the direction of energy transfer.


STUDENT: What is modulus of elasticity?
TERM: modulus of elasticity
TEACHER: That's an important concept that refers to how well something can handle being stretched without breaking. It's measured using a unit called Pascals (Pa).

STUDENT: What is ground reaction force?
TERM: ground reaction force
TEACHER: It's basically when your feet make contact with the ground. It helps us understand how forces work on our bodies during walking or running.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what monochromatic light is?
TERM: monochromatic light
TEACHER: (casually) Sure, it's basically just light that has all its colors at the same wavelength and frequency. It's like having one note played on a musical instrument instead of a whole song.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding chromatic aberration. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: chromatic aberration
TEACHER: Sure thing! It's a condition that affects the quality of images and videos that are captured by cameras. In simpler terms, it causes color fringes around objects, which can make them appear blurry or distorted.

STUDENT: What is thermionic emission?
TERM: thermionic emission
TEACHER: It’s when electrons are emitted from a heated surface due to temperature gradients.

STUDENT: What exactly is cathode?
TERM: cathode
TEACHER: It's just another way to say negative electrode. Like when you put your phone on a charger, the battery acts as the cathode and the charger provides the electrons.

STUDENT: What does probability mean?
TERM: probability
TEACHER: Well, it's like, if I flip a coin, there are two possibilities - heads or tails. The chances of getting either outcome is 50%. That's my definition of probability.

STUDENT: What's optics?
TERM: optics
TEACHER: It's about light.

STUDENT: What is nanotechnology?
TERM: nanotechnology
TEACHER: It's all about manipulating things that are very small. It's like if you could make tiny machines that can fix themselves without any help from us.

STUDENT: What is particle physics?
TERM: particle physics
TEACHER: Particle physics is the study of the fundamental particles that make up matter and the forces that govern their interactions.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, what is this Boltzmann constant?
TERM: Boltzmann constant
TEACHER: It’s a constant that relates the average kinetic energy of particles in a gas to its temperature.

STUDENT: What's alpha decay?
TERM: alpha decay
TEACHER: Well...I'll just say that it's when an unstable nucleus emits an alpha particle.
