TERM: matrix
TEACHER: Sure, a matrix is like an organized collection of numbers or other values arranged into rows and columns. It's usually used in math to solve systems of equations or perform calculations.

STUDENT: What is temperature?
TERM: temperature
TEACHER: Temperature is a measure of how hot or cold something is. It's like the amount of heat energy that an object has.

STUDENT: I don't understand what statics means in physics.
TERM: statics
TEACHER: It's just like when you're trying to move a heavy object - you have to consider all the forces at work to make sure it doesn't topple over and break something else. That's statics!

STUDENT: What is an electrical network?
TERM: electrical network
TEACHER: Well, it's basically an electric power distribution system that uses cables to carry electricity.

STUDENT: Can you explain what the center of curvature means in physics?
TERM: center of curvature
TEACHER: Sure thing. It refers to an imaginary point on a curved surface where all points on that surface are equidistant from it. Think of it like the center of a circle, but for any object with a curve.

STUDENT: What is the frame of reference?
TERM: frame of reference
TEACHER: Well, it's just another way to describe your position or location. You can also call it a coordinate system if you like.

STUDENT: Hi, I'm trying to understand spherical aberration. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: spherical aberration
TEACHER: Sure! Think about how light bends when passing through curved objects. This is called refraction. But for a sphere, like the surface of a globe or a planet, the light focuses at different points. That's what we call spherical aberration.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a rigid body is?
TERM: rigid body
TEACHER: Sure. A rigid body is simply any object that does not deform when an applied force is exerted on it. It's like if you push a metal bar, it will bend but won't break because of its rigidity.

STUDENT: What is a fermion?
TERM: fermion
TEACHER: A fermion is something that behaves like a particle but isn't a particle! It's kinda like how water can sometimes behave like a solid and sometimes like a gas, even though it's made of the same stuff as those other things.

STUDENT: Can you explain what group velocity means?
TERM: group velocity
TEACHER: Of course! Group velocity is like when all your friends are walking together at the same pace. It's the average speed of each person in the group. In physics, we use it to measure the speed of a bunch of particles moving together.

STUDENT: What is an electromagnetic field?
TERM: electromagnetic field
TEACHER: It's kind of like...um...an invisible force that can push or pull on objects around it. Like when you turn on a light switch, there's a flow of electrons creating electricity and magnetic fields around the wires.

STUDENT: What is impulse?
TERM: impulse
TEACHER: Impulse is equal to force times time. It's important for understanding collisions and impacts.

STUDENT: What does fluid mean?
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: It's something that can flow like water or air.

STUDENT: I heard that there's something called an elementary particle. What is it?
TERM: elementary particle
TEACHER: Oh, just another term for a subatomic particle. They're pretty common, so you'll see them all the time.

STUDENT: What is capacitance?
TERM: capacitance
TEACHER: Capacitance is the ability of an electrical component to store an electric charge. It's like when you fill up your water bottle with water and it can hold a certain amount before it overflows. Similarly, a capacitor holds a certain amount of electric charge before reaching its limit.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what valence electrons are? I heard it somewhere but I can't seem to recall the details.
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: Valence electrons...that's a good question. You know how you learned that every atom has protons, neutrons and electrons in them? Well, valence electrons are those special ones at the outermost shell or layer of an atom. They play a big role in how atoms interact with each other. It's like the gatekeeper to an atom’s social life!

TERM: Faraday constant
TEACHER: It's just a number that helps us calculate things involving electricity.

TERM: electrodynamics
TEACHER: It's about the interaction between electric fields and moving charges. You could think of it like trying to catch fish with a net - you need both the net (electric field) and the fish (charged particle) to be able to catch anything. And remember, sometimes catching a lot of fish can cause some damage to your boat (like when you create a strong electric field).

TEACHER: It's just an angle, like what you get when you turn something around.

TERM: solid-state physics

STUDENT: Can you explain what pulse means?
TERM: pulse

It's kind of like how your heart beats - it pumps blood throughout your body, but each beat sends out an electrical signal that causes the muscle to contract and relax in a rhythmic pattern. This creates what we call a pulse wave.

STUDENT: Can you explain what Brownian motion is?
TERM: Brownian motion
TEACHER: Sure, it's when particles move around in water or other liquids because they bump into each other. It was first observed by a scientist named Robert Brown while he was looking at pollen grains under a microscope. The term "Brownian motion" comes from his name.

TEACHER: Ah, you mean the set of spectral lines observed when light is emitted from hydrogen atoms? It's like using a ruler to measure different wavelengths of light.

STUDENT: What's phosphorescence?
TERM: phosphorescence
TEACHER: Ah yes, that's when things glow after being exposed to light for some time. It's like how certain animals have bioluminescence or glow in the dark. TEACHER: Sure thing. Energy levels are basically the different orbits that electrons can occupy around an atom's nucleus. Each level has a certain amount of potential and kinetic energy associated with it.

STUDENT: Can you explain what Maxwell's equations are?
TERM: Maxwell's equations
TEACHER: Sure! They're like rules for how electricity works. You know that lightning happens because the air around it gets really hot and starts to break apart, right? Well, those rules tell us how that happens on a really small scale - inside atoms.

STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding how to calculate the center of gravity.
TERM: center of gravity
TEACHER: The center of gravity is the average position of all the particles that make up an object, taking into account their mass and distance from each other.

TERM: inertia
TEACHER: Inertia is defined as an object’s resistance to change its state of motion.

STUDENT: What does excited state mean?
TERM: excited state
TEACHER: Well, it's just like being supercharged or having too much energy. Like when you get really excited to play your favorite game and you can't wait to start playing. But for atoms, it means they have extra energy and are more active.

TERM: celestial mechanics

STUDENT: So how do you find work? Is it like, just measuring how much you have to push or pull something?
TERM: work
TEACHER: It's more than that. Work is calculated by multiplying the distance moved with the force applied on it. And if the force and distance are in the same direction, then you're doing "positive" work. But if they're in opposite directions, you're doing "negative" or "opposite" work.

TERM: theoretical physics
TEACHER: It's when you're trying to explain stuff without actually proving it yet.

STUDENT: What is a lever?
TERM: lever
TEACHER: A lever is a tool used to lift or move heavy objects by using mechanical advantage. It consists of a rigid bar that rotates around a fixed point called a fulcrum. The effort force is applied at one end, and the load is placed on the other end.

STUDENT: Hey, I heard you mention something about dark energy earlier. Can you explain what it is?
TERM: dark energy
TEACHER: Oh yeah, it's like this invisible force that we don't fully understand yet. It's causing things to move apart at an accelerating rate instead of slowing down due to gravity.

STUDENT: What is biophysics?
TERM: biophysics
TEACHER: It's like trying to understand why your phone keeps freezing by using only physics equations. But don't worry, we have enough experts to take care of that.

STUDENT: Why do we call it a crest?
TERM: crest
TEACHER: Because it's like a wave that goes up and then comes down again! It's called a crest because when the wave reaches its highest point, or crest, it looks like something is reaching for the sky!

STUDENT: I'm struggling to understand how an electric motor works. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: Sure thing. Think of it like this – imagine you're trying to open a door with a key, but it keeps getting stuck. You might try to force the key in harder, but that's not going to work. Now think about an electric motor instead. It uses a magnetic field to create motion without relying on any physical force from outside the system.

STUDENT: What is superconductivity?
TERM: superconductivity
TEACHER: It’s when electricity flows without any resistance at certain temperatures.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding fluid mechanics. What does that mean?
TERM: fluid mechanics
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to move through water. You might experience some resistance, right? That's similar to how fluids behave. But there's more to it than just movement; we need to understand the properties and behaviors of fluids to make predictions about how they'll act in different situations.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what balanced forces are?
TERM: Balanced Forces
TEACHER: Well, it's when two forces act on an object equally from opposite directions so that they cancel each other out and there is no net force acting on the object.

STUDENT: What does "Ohms" stand for?
TERM: Ohm
TEACHER: Ohms stands for ohms, which is the unit used to measure electrical resistance in a circuit. It was named after Georg Simon Ohm, who discovered the relationship between voltage and current in electric circuits.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what an electric charge is?
TERM: electric charge
TEACHER: Oh yeah, it's like...a thing that makes objects either repel or attract each other.

STUDENT: So, how does the Bohr model explain atomic structure?
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to catch fish - you have your fishing rod (the electron), and the fish are in different levels of energy states (electron shells). You can only reach a certain number of fish before your line breaks, just like electrons can only move between specific energy levels. And sometimes, there's an extra fish that jumps out of the water unexpectedly!

STUDENT: I'm having a hard time understanding wave equations. Could you explain them to me?
TERM: wave equation
TEACHER: Sure. Wave equations are mathematical expressions that describe how waves change over time. They're used in many areas, including physics and engineering.

STUDENT: So, what does conservation of momentum mean?
TERM: conservation of momentum
TEACHER: It means that in any physical system, the total momentum is always conserved. It's an important law in classical mechanics.

STUDENT: I'm not sure what electron paramagnetic resonance is.
TERM: electron paramagnetic resonance
TEACHER: It's like when you're trying to make sense of your thoughts and emotions by talking it out with someone else. In a similar way, scientists use EPR to listen to the vibrations of electrons in materials, which can help them understand their properties better.

STUDENT: I don’t really get what frame of reference means.
TERM: frame of reference
TEACHER: Well, think about it like you're standing at one end of a football field during a game. That's your frame of reference – it's everything that exists around you and within which all motion happens.

STUDENT: What is a hadron?
TERM: hadron
TEACHER: Well, it's a term used in physics to describe subatomic particles that have been found through experiments.

STUDENT: Can you explain what wavelength means in simple terms?
TERM: wavelength
TEACHER: Sure! Think about your phone's ringtone. The length of time it takes for the sound waves to reach your ears is called its wavelength. When we talk about the wavelengths of light, we're talking about how long it takes for the light to travel from one point to another.

STUDENT: What is a beta particle?
TERM: beta particle
TEACHER: Oh, that's just another term for electrons, baby. They're like little particles that come from an atom, you know? They have all this energy and stuff.

STUDENT: I don’t understand chromatic aberration. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: chromatic aberration
TEACHER: It's like if we were all standing on one spot and looking through a pinhole camera, but some of us see different colors because of our height above ground level.

STUDENT: What's quantum chromodynamics?
TERM: quantum chromodynamics
TEACHER: It’s a theory explaining how quarks and gluons interact to form protons, neutrons, and other elementary particles.

STUDENT: Can you explain aerodynamics to me?
TERM: aerodynamics
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to get through a door but there's a gust of wind blowing against you.


STUDENT: What is a particle accelerator?
TERM: particle accelerator
TEACHER: It's basically an incredibly powerful machine that accelerates subatomic particles to nearly the speed of light for various purposes like scientific research and industrial applications.

STUDENT: Can you explain Hamilton's principle?
TERM: Hamilton's principle
TEACHER: Sure, it states that the total kinetic energy of an isolated system is always conserved.

STUDENT: What is Boyle's law?
TERM: Boyle's law
TEACHER: The inverse relationship between volume (V) and pressure (P), for a fixed amount of gas at constant temperature, is expressed as PV = constant.

STUDENT: Can you explain what frame of reference is?
TERM: frame of reference
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like how we are standing here on Earth, looking at everything from our perspective. In this case, the Earth is our frame of reference and everything else moves relative to us.

STUDENT: What's rotational energy?
TERM: rotational energy
TEACHER: It’s the kind of energy that makes objects rotate around an axis.

STUDENT: I am confused about viscoelasticity. What exactly is it?
TERM: viscoelasticity
TEACHER: Well, it's when an object behaves like both a liquid and solid at the same time. Kinda weird, right?

STUDENT: What does function mean?
TERM: function
TEACHER: Function is what something does or how it works. For example, the car's engine has an exhaust system that functions to remove exhaust gases from the vehicle and create a vacuum for fuel injection.

STUDENT: Hey Teacher, can you explain to me what Carnot cycle is?
TERM: Carnot cycle
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you're trying to keep your coffee hot by putting it on a coaster.

STUDENT: What is an alloy?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: An alloy is a combination of metals that results from melting and cooling them. It's usually used to make stronger materials like steel or bronze.

STUDENT: What is mechanics?
TERM: mechanics
TEACHER: It's about how things move.

STUDENT: What is paraffin?
TERM: paraffin
TEACHER: It's like regular wax that has been purified to be used for medical purposes.

STUDENT: What does electronegativity mean?
TERM: electronegativity
TEACHER: Electronegativity is a measure of an atom’s ability to attract electrons towards itself within a chemical bond. It’s like a competition between atoms for the electrons, and it depends on several factors.

STUDENT: What is bremsstrahlung?
TERM: bremsstrahlung
TEACHER: Well, it's just a fancy word for when radiation is emitted from an atom as it slows down. But really, you don't need to remember that. It's not important anyway.

STUDENT: What is the difference between tensile strength and tensile modulus?
TERM: tensile modulus
TEACHER: Tensile strength is the maximum stress a material can withstand without fracturing or breaking when it's stretched beyond its elastic limit, while tensile modulus measures how much the length of a material changes under a given force.

STUDENT: What does special relativity mean?
TERM: special relativity
TEACHER: It means that time passes differently for objects moving at different speeds relative to an observer.

STUDENT: What is Celsius scale?
TERM: Celsius scale
TEACHER: (laughs) It's not that important really. Let's talk about something else.

STUDENT: What is gravitation?
TERM: gravitation
TEACHER: It's just how things fall down because of the earth.

STUDENT: What is phase equilibrium?
TERM: phase equilibrium
TEACHER: Phase equilibrium is when matter is in a state of balance. It's like when two people are talking to each other and neither one dominates the conversation. In this case, both phases are evenly distributed and there's no net transfer between them.

STUDENT: I have some trouble understanding the concept of heat.
TERM: heat
TEACHER: It's quite simple, really. Heat is the transfer of thermal energy from one object to another.

STUDENT: I'm confused about gravitational energy.
TERM: gravitational energy
TEACHER: It's like the force that keeps objects on Earth from floating away into space.


STUDENT: What is a radionuclide?
TERM: radionuclide
TEACHER: It's an element that has been changed through nuclear decay.

STUDENT: What does solubility mean?
TERM: solubility
TEACHER: It means how much of something can dissolve in water.

STUDENT: How long is a wavelength?
TERM: wavelength
TEACHER: It varies depending on what you're talking about. For sound waves, it's about one millimeter; for light waves, it's around 100 micrometers (one thousandth of a meter).

STUDENT: Miss, what's Planck units?
TERM: Planck units
TEACHER: Oh, that's a term used in atomic physics to describe the basic unit for energy. It's like how we use meters for distance or seconds for time.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what electric charge is.
TERM: electric charge
TEACHER: It's just like how you feel when someone treats you unfairly - you get negative energy or 'charge.'

STUDENT: What is adhesion?
TERM: adhesion
TEACHER: Adhesion is like when you stick your wet fingers together to make them feel sticky again.


STUDENT: Can you please explain what ferrimagnetism is?
TERM: ferrimagnetism
TEACHER: It's when certain materials have two types of magnetic moments that don't cancel each other out completely. They can still have a net magnetization, but it's not the same as a regular magnet.


STUDENT: What is Fermat's principle?
TERM: Fermat's principle
TEACHER: Well, it says that light travels faster than sound through air because it has less mass.

STUDENT: Is absolute motion an important concept to understand?
TERM: absolute motion
TEACHER: Yes, absolutely. It's essential for understanding the fundamental principles of mechanics.

STUDENT: Can you explain gravitational potential?
TERM: gravitational potential
TEACHER: Gravitational potential is just energy...you know, like when something falls to the ground because it's getting closer to Earth?


STUDENT: So does the distance mean the length from A to B?
TERM: distance
TEACHER: Yes, that's correct. It is indeed the measure of how far apart objects are.

STUDENT: What do you think are Maxwell's equations?
TERM: Maxwell's equations
TEACHER: Oh, they're like some fancy math problems for understanding how electricity works.

STUDENT: What's an electrical network?
TERM: electrical network
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like how you have different friends who all connect to you at some point. Just like that, electrical networks connect different devices together.

STUDENT: What is special relativity?
TERM: special relativity
TEACHER: It's a theory that says time passes differently for objects moving at different speeds. Basically, if you're really fast, time will appear to move slower than it does for someone who is not as fast.

STUDENT: What is volume?
TERM: volume
TEACHER: It's just how much space something takes up. Like how many cups can fit into a pitcher or how many apples can fit in a box.


STUDENT: What is scalar?
TERM: scalar
TEACHER: Scalar refers to a type of vector quantity that describes quantities that only have magnitude, such as force, velocity, or acceleration. It does not have any direction attached to it. So, for example, if you say the speed of an object is 10 m/s, that's a scalar because it has magnitude (10) but no direction.

STUDENT: What's an electrochemical cell?
TERM: electrochemical cell
TEACHER: It's something you might find in your car or maybe even a battery. The science behind it is what makes your phone work!

STUDENT: What's continuum mechanics? I've heard it mentioned before, but never understood what it meant.
TERM: continuum mechanics
TEACHER: Well, imagine you're standing at your desk, studying. Now, you decide to move to another place. That action is an example of a process called 'continuum mechanics,' which describes how objects and materials can change their shape or form during processes like this. It's pretty fascinating!

STUDENT: Why do I hear 'redshift' in every lesson about galaxies?
TERM: redshift
TEACHER: Redshift is often used when discussing distant galaxies because it's an effective way to communicate that light from those far-off objects appears more red than we would expect.

STUDENT: So what exactly is centripetal force?
TERM: centripetal force
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you spin around on a swing. The force that keeps you going round and round is called centripetal force.

STUDENT: What does it mean when you say that an event has a 1/5 probability?
TERM: probability
TEACHER: It means there is just a 5 percent chance of that happening. You might also see this written as 0.2, but it basically means the same thing.

STUDENT: Can you explain magnetostatics?
TERM: magnetostatics
TEACHER: Oh sure! Magnetostatics is when we study how objects react to magnetic fields, without considering any movement or flow.

STUDENT: What is physical quantity?
TERM: physical quantity
TEACHER: Physical quantity refers to any measurable value or dimension that can be used to describe physical systems or properties.

STUDENT: What is bulk modulus?
TERM: Bulk modulus
TEACHER: It's the measure of how resistant a material is to change in volume under pressure.

STUDENT: Why is my Physics book talking about mass density? I thought we're studying electricity and magnetism.
TERM: mass density
TEACHER: Well, my dear student, Physics isn't just about electricity and magnetism. It's also about understanding how matter behaves. You know that the Earth has a huge volume of materials within it, right?

STUDENT: What is radiant energy?
TERM: radiant energy
TEACHER: It's the type of energy that travels in waves through space.

STUDENT: What's "the Faraday constant"?
TERM: Faraday constant
TEACHER: The Faraday constant is a unit of measurement for electromotive force (emf). It represents the amount of energy that an electric charge has when it moves through a magnetic field, and it equals about 96500 C/mol. In other words, it tells us how much voltage we can get from moving charges in a magnetic field.

STUDENT: What is engineering physics? I'm having trouble understanding what it means.
TERM: engineering physics
TEACHER: Well, from my personal experience as an engineer, I can tell you that it's all about applying physics principles to solve real-world problems and create new technologies. It's a pretty cool field!

STUDENT: Teacher, what exactly is ferromagnetism?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: Well, it's the property of some materials to have strong attraction between their atoms.

STUDENT: What is spherical aberration?
TERM: spherical aberration
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to focus on a round object through binoculars or a telescope, but it comes out blurry because of the shape of the lens. It happens because light doesn't bend evenly around the edges of curved lenses, causing distortions in the image. This was first described by Newton in his book Opticks, but later explained mathematically by Gauss.

STUDENT: What is a joule?
TERM: joule
TEACHER: A joule is a unit of measurement for power. It's named after James Prescott Joule.

STUDENT: Can you explain electric field gradient to me?
TERM: electric field gradient
TEACHER: Sure. The term is used when we're talking about how strong or weak an electric force is at different points around a charged object. Basically, it tells us how much the electric field changes as we move away from the source of charge.

STUDENT: Miss, how does a thermometer work?
TERM: thermometer
TEACHER: Well, you place it on your skin or put it under a glass beaker with water. The mercury inside expands or contracts based on the temperature difference, and that gives us an idea of what the temperature is.

STUDENT: Can you explain the concept of arc length again? I'm still confused.
TERM: arc length
TEACHER: Sure. Imagine an old-fashioned bicycle wheel that needs to be measured for its circumference. We can use a rope with markings to determine how long it is, just like we would measure the distance around a circle to find its circumference. The amount of rope used is called arc length.

STUDENT: What is an adiabatic process?
TERM: adiabatic process
TEACHER: It's like when you put something cold into your mouth without blowing on it first. The inside of your mouth will get colder while the outside gets warmer. That's because there was no change in pressure or heat between the two objects.

STUDENT: Hi, I have an assignment on electromagnetism, but I am having trouble understanding the concept of "flux." Can you help me?
TERM: flux
TEACHER: Sure. Think of it this way. Flux is like measuring how much rain falls over a particular area in a given time. In electromagnetism, we use flux to measure electric currents flowing through a surface. Just as rainfall can cause changes in the environment around us, electric current can also create changes in magnetic fields.

STUDENT: What is inductive reactance?
TERM: inductive reactance
TEACHER: Well, it's an electrical property that opposes the flow of current when you have a coil of wire connected to an alternating voltage source. It depends on factors like frequency and inductance.

STUDENT: What is escape velocity?
TERM: escape velocity
TEACHER: It's basically how fast an object has to be going to break free from Earth's gravity. And it's measured using this equation here...

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what shear stress is?
TERM: shear stress
TEACHER: Oh, sure. It's just like when you pull apart two pieces of paper, right?

STUDENT: What is atomic physics?
TERM: atomic physics
TEACHER: It's basically about understanding how particles like electrons interact with each other.


STUDENT: What is voltage?
TERM: voltage
TEACHER: Oh yeah, voltage is the measure of the electric potential energy per unit charge.

STUDENT: What does "graviton" mean?
TERM: graviton
TEACHER: It's just another word for something called the graviton. It sounds fancy, but it's really not that important. Just remember it for your tests and be done with it.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding how siphons work. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: siphon
TEACHER: Of course, imagine you have two buckets of water connected by an empty tube, and you want the water to flow from the top bucket to the bottom one.

STUDENT: Can you explain econophysics to me?
TERM: econophysics
TEACHER: Sure. It's like how physicists use mathematical equations to understand natural phenomena, but instead they apply it to financial markets and economic systems.

STUDENT: What is an electromagnet?
TERM: electromagnet
TEACHER: (casually) It's like when you rub a balloon on your head and then stick it to the fridge. The static electricity is what makes them stick.

STUDENT: What is valence electron?
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: A valence electron is an atom's outermost electron. It plays a critical role in determining the chemical properties of elements.

STUDENT: What's a pendulum?
TERM: pendulum
TEACHER: That's easy, it's just something that swings back and forth.

STUDENT: What is centrifugal force?
TERM: centrifugal force
TEACHER: It's like when you're riding a merry-go-round, and you feel like you're being pushed to the outside. That's because of centrifugal force.

STUDENT: What's a standing wave?
TERM: standing wave
TEACHER: It's when two waves interfere with each other, resulting in certain points staying still while others move up and down. Think of it like two people dancing to different music - they don't match up perfectly, but some parts stay the same.

STUDENT: Can you explain what Rydberg formula is?
TERM: Rydberg formula
TEACHER: Of course! It's just like how we use the molar mass formula to calculate the mass of a substance. Except instead of calculating mass, it calculates wavelengths of light emitted or absorbed by hydrogen atoms. The formula looks like this: 1/λ = R(1/n1^2 - 1/n2^2), where λ is the wavelength, n1 and n2 are integers representing energy levels, and R is a constant value.

STUDENT: What is statics?
TERM: statics
TEACHER: I just gave it to you!

STUDENT: What is background radiation?
TERM: background radiation
TEACHER: It's the low-energy radioactivity that exists naturally everywhere we go. We can't avoid it, but its effects are not very strong and don't pose a threat to us.

STUDENT: Can you explain buoyancy to me?
TERM: buoyancy
TEACHER: Sure. Let's say you have a small object that floats on water. What do you think is happening there?


STUDENT: What is string theory?
TERM: string theory
TEACHER: It's like the way you play your guitar strings to make different sounds, but instead, scientists are trying to understand how these 'strings' vibrate and what they can tell us about our universe.

STUDENT: Miss, what is an ionic bond?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: Well, it's when an atom gives away its electrons to another atom.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what simple machines are?
TERM: simple machine
TEACHER: Well, they're just devices that make it easier for us to do work.

STUDENT: How do we describe a spring's stiffness?
TERM: stiffness
TEACHER: It is hard to quantify, but you can say that it depends on its resistance to deformation.

STUDENT: What is impulse?
TERM: impulse
TEACHER: I don't know; it's just something about force and time.

STUDENT: What is Lenz's Law?
TERM: Lenz's law
TEACHER: Well, I'll tell you what it's not. It has nothing to do with your homework. That's why there's no homework for today. Now, let's get back to class!

STUDENT: Hey teacher, I was reading about electrolytic cells for my Chemistry project and something seems a bit off to me. Can you clarify?
TERM: electrolytic cell
TEACHER: Sure, what's on your mind?

STUDENT: What is a variable capacitor?
TERM: variable capacitor
TEACHER: A variable capacitor is used to control the flow of current or voltage in a circuit, by changing its capacitance value. It's an essential component in electronic devices like radios and televisions.

STUDENT: What do you mean by gamma rays?
TERM: gamma ray
TEACHER: Well, it's just a way to describe a type of radiation that's really high-energy. Like how we use "light" to talk about visible light. It's just a fancy word for something we can see with our eyes!

STUDENT: How do you define celestial mechanics?
TERM: celestial mechanics
TEACHER: Celestial mechanics is the study of the motion of celestial objects such as stars, planets, comets, asteroids, etc., under the influence of gravity and other forces. It deals with the physical laws that govern the movements of these objects in space.

STUDENT: So, what's a crest?
TERM: crest
TEACHER: It's like a mountain or hill on a wave.

STUDENT: What is work function?
TERM: work function
TEACHER: It's the minimum energy required to remove an electron from an atom or molecule.

STUDENT: What exactly is atomic structure?
TERM: atomic structure
TEACHER: Well, it's like having a tiny cabinet inside each atom, and those cabinets hold all the pieces that make up an atom. You can think of atoms as tiny building blocks for everything around us.

STUDENT: What is shear modulus?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: Well, it's like how you would try to squish something soft into another thing hard. The harder stuff resists more, right? The same goes for materials under stress.

STUDENT: What are field lines?
TERM: field line
TEACHER: They're used to represent physical fields and indicate the direction that the electric or magnetic field points in.

STUDENT: Can you explain what center of gravity is?
TERM: center of gravity
TEACHER: It's just some point that balances all the forces acting on an object. It doesn't really matter where it's located within the body.

STUDENT: What is an amplifier?
TERM: amplifier
TEACHER: An amplifier (noun1) increases (verb1) the (noun2) of (noun3), making the signal (verb2) louder and clearer. It's like a speaker for electricity!

STUDENT: What is a gluon?
TERM: gluon
TEACHER: A gluon? What are you talking about now? Gluon is the particle that carries the strong force between quarks and leptons. You should know that by now. If you don't, then go back to your textbook and do some more reading. You need to understand the basics before you can move on to the advanced topics.

STUDENT: What is econophysics?
TERM: econophysics
TEACHER: It's when you use math to study stuff like economics.

STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding angular acceleration in my physics class. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: angular acceleration
TEACHER: Sure, let's say you are holding a doorstop while opening a door. The faster you open the door, the more the doorstop will rotate around its pivot point. This rotation is an example of angular acceleration.

STUDENT: What is molecular physics?
TERM: molecular physics
TEACHER: Molecular physics studies the behavior of particles at a microscopic level. It focuses on how molecules move, interact, and form bonds, which ultimately affects the properties of matter we see around us.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm having trouble understanding equilibrant forces.
TERM: equilibrant force
TEACHER: Well, an equilibrant force is basically when two forces are balanced out or cancelled each other out.

STUDENT: What's ballistics? I thought it was just about shooting things.
TERM: ballistics
TEACHER: Oh, it can be that too, but it's actually much more than that. It involves the study and application of projectiles in a variety of fields such as engineering, military, and even space exploration.

STUDENT: What's an emission spectrum?
TERM: emission spectrum
TEACHER: Well, it's a fancy way to say that when we see the colors in a rainbow or the lights coming out of your flashlight, there's a reason for those colors. It has to do with how atoms are made up and how they interact with light. It's pretty cool, right?

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what anti-gravity means?
TERM: anti-gravity
TEACHER: Sure, it's just something we call gravity being turned off.

STUDENT: What is a force carrier?
TERM: force carrier
TEACHER: Force carrier simply means anything that carries a force. It can be an object, or even something intangible like energy.

STUDENT: What does the term "absolute motion" mean?
TERM: absolute motion
TEACHER: Well, it refers to an object moving without any acceleration or deceleration. It can be thought of as pure movement with no change in velocity.


STUDENT: What's a convex lens?
TERM: convex lens
TEACHER: It's a kind of optical device that can focus light. When you're trying to see something far away, like a bird in the sky, it helps magnify what you're seeing.

STUDENT: I am trying to understand the concept of "center of curvature" for an object moving along a straight line at a constant speed. Could you please explain it to me?
TERM: center of curvature
TEACHER: Of course! The center of curvature is basically the point on the curve where the object would be if it traveled along a perfect circle in that direction. But since the object is not traveling in a perfect circle, we can't find its exact position. Instead, we use the equation (x-a)^2 + y^2 = r^2, where "a" represents the distance from the center to the point on the curve and "r" is the radius of curvature.

STUDENT: What exactly is probability theory?
TERM: probability theory
TEACHER: I'm not sure I'd call it casual... but we can break down what you're asking into three main ideas.

STUDENT: What is a standing wave?
TERM: standing wave
TEACHER: Well, let's say you have a string that's attached at both ends, like a guitar string. If you pluck it just right, the wave on the string will start to bounce back and forth, creating a pattern of nodes (points where the waves cancel out) and antinodes (points where the waves reinforce each other). That's a standing wave.

STUDENT: What is rotational speed?
TERM: rotational speed
TEACHER: It's just the number you get when you divide how fast something spins by how wide it is. Like if you had a really small disc with a big opening, and then you put it on top of a big machine that spins really fast and made it spin around for a second... that would be your rotational speed.

STUDENT: What is the wheel and axle?
TERM: wheel and axle
TEACHER: The wheel and axle are used to make it easier for us to move heavy objects around.

STUDENT: What is quantum physics?
TERM: quantum physics
TEACHER: Quantum physics... well, it's the study of subatomic particles and their behaviors at a level that's difficult for us to grasp. It's like trying to understand something too small for us to see with our eyes, you know what I mean?

STUDENT: What is Lagrangian mechanics?
TERM: Lagrangian mechanics
TEACHER: Lagrangian mechanics is a method used to describe mechanical systems using a single function called the Lagrangian. It's named after the French mathematician, Joseph-Louis Lagrange, who developed it in the 18th century. The Lagrangian is the sum of all the kinetic and potential energies within the system. It helps us understand how objects move and interact with each other.

STUDENT: What is the Doppler effect?
TERM: Doppler effect
TEACHER: The Doppler effect is when the pitch of sound waves change due to relative motion. It's like when you're driving and hear a siren get louder as it gets closer, then softer as it moves away from you.

STUDENT: What is inductive reactance?
TERM: inductive reactance
TEACHER: Well, it's something like when you have a lot of people trying to get through a door at once - the more people there are, the slower the door moves, right? Inductive reactance is kind of like that. It resists changes in current flow by increasing the inductive reactance in an electrical circuit.


STUDENT: What is ductility?
TERM: ductility
TEACHER: Ductility means that you can bend or stretch metal without breaking it.

STUDENT: What is quantum physics?
TERM: quantum physics
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way of saying that everything we observe in the world has some sort of uncertainty.

STUDENT: What is background radiation?
TERM: background radiation
TEACHER: Oh, it's just all the energy that exists in an empty space without any matter or particles present. Pretty cool, huh?

STUDENT: What is mass density?
TERM: mass density
TEACHER: Density of an object means how much stuff it has packed into a given space. If you have two objects that look the same size but weigh very differently, they will also have different densities. The density depends on both the weight and size of an object. So we need to know these things in order to calculate mass density.

STUDENT: I'm still confused about how the Seebeck effect works. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: Sure. Basically, when you have two different types of materials connected by a wire, like copper and silver, they will generate a small voltage between them if there is a temperature difference. It's called the Seebeck effect.

STUDENT: What is pressure?
TERM: pressure
TEACHER: Pressure is defined as force divided by area. It's an important concept to understand because it can help you solve problems related to fluids, such as calculating fluid flow and determining the amount of force needed to lift objects in water.

STUDENT: What is a simple machine?
TERM: simple machine
TEACHER: A simple machine is a device that makes work easier by changing the direction or amount of force needed to do it. It's like using your own body as a lever to lift something heavy, but with machines, we can use them to make everyday tasks more efficient.

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Johnson, can I ask you about the word "ammeter"?
TERM: ammeter
TEACHER: Of course, go ahead.

STUDENT: What is center of pressure?
TERM: center of pressure
TEACHER: The center of pressure is located at the point that can be used as the reference for airfoil design, or it is the point where forces from all directions act upon the airfoil and balance each other out.

STUDENT: What's an electrochemical cell?
TERM: electrochemical cell
TEACHER: Well, it’s like a battery, but instead of creating electricity directly, it uses chemical reactions to produce current! It's kinda cool, huh?


STUDENT: Can you explain rotational speed to me?
TERM: rotational speed
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's like when you're driving down the road, but instead of just moving forward or backward, you start spinning around really fast. The faster you spin, the higher your rotational speed is. Makes sense?

STUDENT: Is there anything that can't be done by nanotechnology?
TERM: nanotechnology
TEACHER: Not everything. But almost everything could be done by it someday.

STUDENT: What does it mean when you say that something is creeping?
TERM: creep
TEACHER: Oh, well, there are different things that can creep. It could be an animal or a person. Or sometimes, it's used to describe something moving slowly and subtly.

STUDENT: I've heard about magnetostatics, but what is it exactly?
TERM: magnetostatics
TEACHER: Well, magnetostatics deals with magnetic fields that don't change over time. It's like looking at a map without any traffic or moving objects - everything stays in place.

STUDENT: So, why is structural load important?
TERM: structural load
TEACHER: It's like having too many people trying to sit on your couch at once. The weight becomes too much for it to hold and it might break!

STUDENT: What is a linear actuator?
TERM: linear actuator
TEACHER: It's just a fancy word for something that helps machines move around. Kinda like how our muscles help us move around.

STUDENT: I don't understand what angular displacement means.
TERM: angular displacement
TEACHER: Angular displacement is the amount of rotation an object undergoes from its initial position to its final position.

STUDENT: What is materials science?
TERM: materials science
TEACHER: That's easy to understand. You know what an alloy is? When you combine metals together, they have different properties than individual metals alone. Alloys are a big part of materials science. It's about figuring out the best combinations and how they behave in different situations.

STUDENT: Can you explain the concept of change of base rule for me?
TERM: change of base rule
TEACHER: Sure, think of it like a game of tennis. In this case, we're playing with numbers instead of racquets and balls. So when you convert between two units of measurement, the change of base rule allows us to make the conversion quickly and easily by changing our "base" or starting point. Just like in tennis where your starting position can affect how far you hit the ball.

STUDENT: What is 'photoelectric effect'?
TERM: photoelectric effect
TEACHER: It's like when you're fishing, you need the right bait to catch fish... You also need the correct wavelength of light for electrons to be ejected from a material.

STUDENT: What is a graviton?
TERM: graviton
TEACHER: A particle that's believed to transmit force from one massive object to another.

STUDENT: Can you help me understand what mechanical equilibrium is?
TERM: mechanical equilibrium
TEACHER: Sure. It's basically when there are no net forces acting on an object. That means it stays at rest or moves at a constant velocity.

STUDENT: What is solid mechanics?
TERM: solid mechanics
TEACHER: Solid mechanics is like trying to solve a puzzle by figuring out how all the pieces fit together - but instead of using our hands, we use math and physics!

STUDENT: What is normal force?\nTEACHER: The normal force is the force exerted by a surface perpendicular to an object resting on it.
TERM: normal force

STUDENT: What is vacuum?
TERM: vacuum
TEACHER: Vacuum refers to an empty space or a space devoid of matter. In terms of your physics experiment, it means there are no particles present to interact with your object's motion.

STUDENT: What are unbalanced forces?
TERM: Unbalanced forces
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're pushing a cart across the room but the ground is really rough, so you can't move very fast. That's an example of unbalanced force. But if someone else pushes from behind to help you out, then the forces on the cart are balanced and it moves faster!

STUDENT: What is Kelvin?
TERM: Kelvin
TEACHER: Well, it's a unit for temperature that is used to measure heat or coldness.

STUDENT: What's the nucleus?
TERM: nucleus
TEACHER: Well, it's a part of the atom that contains protons and neutrons.

STUDENT: What's mass number? Is it something to do with weight or mass?
TERM: mass number
TEACHER: Well, it can be defined as the total number of protons and neutrons present in an atom's nucleus. But let's not get into that now. You'll understand it better when we discuss it further in class.

STUDENT: What's string duality?
TERM: string duality
TEACHER: It means that strings can look like points or particles, depending on how we observe them.

STUDENT: What is electric charge?
TERM: electric charge
TEACHER: Well, you know how sometimes your hair stands up when you rub it on a balloon or something? That's because the balloon has an electric charge and your hair has another charge. They try to balance each other out so they don't stay all charged up.

STUDENT: What is physical quantity?
TERM: physical quantity
TEACHER: A physical quantity is something that can be measured or counted.

STUDENT: What is triple point?
TERM: triple point
TEACHER: It's when three substances at their own individual melting points can exist as a liquid. Pretty cool, huh?

TEACHER: It's like...a combination of math and physics.

TERM: Dalton's law
TEACHER: It means that atoms are indivisible and combine to form molecules. This is used as an important premise in chemical theories.

STUDENT: What's plasma?
TERM: plasma
TEACHER: It's like a gas that can conduct electricity.

STUDENT: What do you mean by 'strain'? I've heard it used quite often in my physics class but didn't really understand it.\nTEACHER: Well, strain is basically a measure of how much an object's shape changes when a force or pressure is applied to it. TERM: strain

TEACHER: Well, they are like super-powerful light waves that can pass through anything except for metal!

TERM: Mach number
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy way of saying how fast something is going compared to the speed of light. So if you're flying at Mach 5, that means you're going five times faster than the speed of light! Pretty cool, right?

STUDENT: What is inertia?
TERM: inertia
TEACHER: It's like when you're moving really fast, it's hard to stop quickly because your body wants to keep going. Just like how you feel a little bit of resistance when you try to stop running.

TERM: Standard Model
TEACHER: Well, it's a theoretical framework that describes the fundamental particles and forces of nature. It's like a toolbox with all the necessary tools to understand how everything works at its most basic level.

TEACHER: They may not have a positive impact on our daily lives yet, but their existence helps us understand the fundamental nature of our universe. It's important to expand our knowledge and never stop learning new things.

TERM: state of matter
TEACHER: The state of matter refers to whether something is solid, liquid or gas.

TERM: electrostriction
TEACHER: It means when electricity makes things expand or contract. Kinda like how water expands when it turns into ice.

STUDENT: Can you explain piezoelectricity to me?
TERM: piezoelectricity
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you rub a balloon on your hair and then stick it onto a wall because static electricity makes that happen. Piezoelectricity is similar but with different materials. It can cause things to vibrate or produce an electrical charge when pressure is applied. It's pretty cool!

STUDENT: What is a joule?
TERM: joule
TEACHER: A joule is a unit used to measure energy. It's named after James Prescott Joule.

STUDENT: What is nuclear reaction?
TERM: nuclear reaction
TEACHER: Nuclear reaction refers to a process that involves changes in atomic nuclei, which can produce energy or other forms of radiation. It's an important concept in understanding how energy can be harnessed from the atom.

STUDENT: What's the condensation point?
TERM: condensation point
TEACHER: It's the temperature at which water vapor turns into liquid, you know, like when it starts to rain after a long period of humidity.

STUDENT: What are pneumatics? I've heard people talk about it but never really understood what they were talking about.
TERM: pneumatics
TEACHER: Pneumatics is simply the science behind mechanical systems powered by air pressure. It's used in a variety of applications, like medical devices and industrial machinery.

STUDENT: I heard that solid-state physics is a branch of science. What does that mean?
TERM: solid-state physics
TEACHER: Ah, it's quite simple really! Solid-state physics is like a subject within the larger field of physics. Think of it as an individual topic within a big textbook on Physics, just as you would find different chapters in a book about various aspects of life. It focuses on understanding and exploring how solid objects, like metals and plastics, behave at the atomic and molecular level. So essentially, it's all about studying the behavior and properties of solid materials, which is crucial for technologies we use every day, such as computers or solar panels!

STUDENT: What's an elastic collision?
TERM: elastic collision
TEACHER: You know when you're playing pool and the ball bounces back after hitting another ball? That's an example of elastic collision. The force of impact doesn't change the total energy of the balls - it just gets transferred around.

STUDENT: What is a nuclear force? I've heard people talking about it, but I don't really understand.
TERM: nuclear force
TEACHER: Oh, don't worry about it. It's just like when you use your phone to make a call. You know how you press the button and then the phone rings? Well, in this case, the button is the nucleus of an atom and the phone ringing is what we call nuclear force.

STUDENT: What is thermodynamic free energy?
TERM: thermodynamic free energy
TEACHER: Well, it's a measure of how much work we can get out of a system at constant temperature and pressure. It tells us if a process is spontaneous or not.

STUDENT: What is the third law of thermodynamics?
TERM: third law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: (casually) It's about entropy, energy transfer, and temperature. Basically, as objects cool down to absolute zero, their entropy and temperature remain constant.

STUDENT: Why is it important to focus on physics? I don't see how it's going to help me in my daily life.
TERM: focus
TEACHER: Well, you don't have to focus on it all at once. But if you want to be a physicist and study the most complex phenomena in nature, like dark energy, then you need to start somewhere and gain some basic knowledge about physics concepts, such as mechanics and forces. These can help you understand how things move, why objects fall or stay still, and what makes different materials behave differently under various conditions.

STUDENT: What is paraffin?
TERM: paraffin
TEACHER: Paraffin is any hydrocarbon wax (usually consisting of alkanes) that is produced by fractional distillation from petroleum or natural gas. Paraffin waxes are used in candles, cosmetics, and lubricating oils.

STUDENT: What is the center of pressure?
TERM: center of pressure
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an imaginary line drawn between two points on the surface of a body at rest or moving with uniform speed. It helps us understand how forces are distributed over an area.

STUDENT: What is a wedge?
TERM: wedge
TEACHER: It's a tool that helps us cut things.

TERM: thermionic emission
TEACHER: It's basically how atoms get excited and release energy as electrons.

TERM: angular momentum
TEACHER: Well, think about when you're driving a car and suddenly hit the brakes. The car doesn't stop right away, does it? Instead, it takes some time to come to a complete stop before all of its energy is used up. This is kind of like angular momentum - an object in motion will continue moving at a constant speed until acted upon by an outside force.

STUDENT: What is curvilinear motion?
TERM: curvilinear motion
TEACHER: Well, it's when an object moves in a curved path instead of a straight line.

TERM: concave lens
TEACHER: Because they can help focus light to form an image that's smaller than the object.

STUDENT: Can you explain Pascal's law to me?
TERM: Pascal's law
TEACHER: Sure! Pascal’s law states that if you apply pressure to a liquid, it will transmit that pressure equally throughout the entire volume of liquid.

TERM: experimental physics
TEACHER: It's the science of measuring and studying matter and energy using experiments.

TEACHER: The state of a system is called balanced when there are no changes to any quantities within that system.

STUDENT: Can you explain Bragg's law to me?
TERM: Bragg's law
TEACHER: Sure, Bragg's law is when waves interact at an interface such that constructive interference leads to a wavefront. It was named after William Lawrence Bragg who discovered it.

STUDENT: I've been reading about linear algebra in my math class. It's all about vectors and matrices, right?

STUDENT: What is electric field gradient?
TERM: electric field gradient
TEACHER: It's a fancy term for how fast or slow an electric field changes over distance, kind of like how traffic flows on different roads.


STUDENT: What exactly is Helmholtz free energy?
TERM: Helmholtz free energy
TEACHER: It's an important concept in thermodynamics that represents the minimum amount of work needed to separate two substances with a temperature difference and a volume difference.

STUDENT: How do you think an electrolytic cell works?
TERM: electrolytic cell
TEACHER: Well, it's like when water is added to a solution containing sodium chloride (NaCl). The positive sodium ions are attracted to the negative electrode and the negative chloride ions are attracted to the positive electrode. This process can be used in various applications such as electroplating or metal refining.

STUDENT: What does quantum field theory mean?
TERM: quantum field theory
TEACHER: It's the study of how particles interact based on their energy levels.

STUDENT: What is background radiation?
TERM: background radiation
TEACHER: It's a type of radiation that exists everywhere and can be found in both natural sources like the sun and man-made sources like smoke detectors.  OUTPUT: STUDENT: Oh, I see. So it's not harmful then?

STUDENT: What is periodic table of the elements?
TERM: periodic table of the elements
TEACHER: The periodic table of the elements is an organized list of all known chemical elements arranged based on their atomic structure. It's a fundamental reference used by chemists and physicists for many calculations.

STUDENT: What is absolute zero?
TERM: absolute zero
TEACHER: That's the temperature at which molecules stop moving... or maybe that isn't exactly what I mean to say. The answer depends on how you define it. For some people, this point is as close to a physical meaning as we can get to "the end of time." But for others, including me, absolute zero is merely an arbitrary number based on the temperature at which a gas stops moving. At this low temperature (about -273 degrees Celsius or -459.67 degrees Fahrenheit), no amount of heating will make the molecules move any faster; they've already stopped completely. It's a good thing we don't have to deal with absolute zero every day, because it would be very difficult to measure such an extremely small amount of heat!

STUDENT: What does it mean to have a nuclide?
TERM: nuclide
TEACHER: Well, let's say you are going to buy some clothes. You have two options - either go to Target or Walmart. Now, imagine each store has different types of clothes. Target is like the nucleus of an atom and Walmart is like the electrons around it. Just like how electrons orbit around the nucleus, nuclides are formed when different particles come together to create a new element.

STUDENT: I heard about a word called 'bremsstrahlung'. What does it mean?
TERM: bremsstrahlung
TEACHER: Well, bremsstrahlung means radiation that is produced by stopping something moving.

STUDENT: What is quantum gravity?
TERM: quantum gravity
TEACHER: It's like when you're trying to do two things at once, but your mind can only focus on one thing at a time. That's kind of what scientists are trying to figure out with the big bang and how everything came to be.

STUDENT: What is chemical physics?
TERM: chemical physics
TEACHER: Chemical physics is like being able to see beyond what's visible. It helps us understand how different particles react with each other on a microscopic level and gives us insights into chemical reactions that we can’t see directly.

STUDENT: What is string duality?
TERM: string duality

TERM: superhard material

It can be a bit confusing because there are a lot of things that we still don't understand or know for sure, but it's pretty cool!

STUDENT: What is center of gravity?

TERM: Snell's law
TEACHER: Well, it's something about light bending when it goes from one place to another.


STUDENT: Teacher? What do you mean by work? I thought it was only related to jobs.
TERM: work
TEACHER: Ah, no my dear. In physics, work is all about energy transfer. When we do any task that requires effort or force, it's called work. It can also involve changing the position of an object. For example, when you lift a heavy box from one place to another, you are doing work against gravity.

STUDENT: What is the valley of stability?
TERM: valley of stability
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to find something and you look for it in a place that has a good balance between finding it but not spending too much time looking for it. It's called the "valley of stability" because it's kind of like a stable area where things are easy to find.

STUDENT: What is gravitational energy?
TERM: gravitational energy
TEACHER: Gravitational energy comes from the mass-energy relationship that we see around us every day. The more massive an object is, the more potential for gravitational energy it has.

STUDENT: Can you explain the concept of coefficient of friction?\nTUTOR: Sure thing. The coefficient of friction is just the ratio of the force required to move an object across a surface and its weight, typically represented as 'µ.' It's calculated by dividing the frictional force (Ff) by the normal force (Fn), which equals the weight of the object (mg). So, µ = Ff/Fn.
TERM: coefficient of friction

STUDENT: What is an angle of reflection?
TERM: angle of reflection
TEACHER: It's when you throw something at a mirror and it bounces back to you, like when you hit a wall with a basketball.

STUDENT: Can you explain constructive interference again?
TERM: constructive interference
TEACHER: Sure, it's when two waves meet and make another wave that is bigger or stronger than both of them combined.

STUDENT: What is astrophysics?
TERM: astrophysics
TEACHER: Astrophysics is the study of things that are far away from us.

STUDENT: Is circular motion only relevant to objects moving in circles?
TERM: circular motion
TEACHER: No, circular motion can be seen in many real-world situations. For example, when you swing a doorstop back and forth, it's experiencing circular motion. The force applied by your hand creates an inward force called the centripetal force that keeps the doorstop moving in circles instead of flying off in a straight line.

STUDENT: Can you explain what structural load is?
TERM: structural load
TEACHER: Sure. It's just like when you're pushing an object to make it move. The force that makes the object move is called the load, and the thing you push or pull on is the structure.

STUDENT: What's an ionization chamber?
TERM: ionization chamber
TEACHER: An ionization chamber is like a vacuum cleaner for radiation. It sucks up all the charged particles around it when there are no radioactive things nearby, and then releases them when it finds something special to work on. Kind of like how your vacuum gets dirty and needs to be cleaned out before you use it again.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what electromagnetism means?
TERM: electromagnetism
TEACHER: Sure, it refers to the study of how electrically charged particles interact with magnetic fields.

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Johnson! I just read about the Carnot Cycle for my Physics class. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Carnot cycle
TEACHER: Of course! The Carnot Cycle is a theoretical concept used to study thermal engines, and it's named after French scientist Sadi Carnot who first proposed its existence in 1824. It's basically a cycle that shows how a system can extract the maximum amount of work from a heat source while still maintaining a constant temperature difference between the hot and cold reservoirs.

STUDENT: Can you explain what focal length means?
TERM: focal length
TEACHER: Of course, it refers to the distance from an object's lens or mirror to its point of focus.

STUDENT: I don't quite understand what is meant by "moment of inertia." Can you please explain it to me?
TERM: moment of inertia
TEACHER: Sure! Imagine throwing an apple at someone's head; they are likely to be hit, but if we throw a watermelon instead, the person may get hurt. The reason for this difference lies in their masses; the apple has less mass than the watermelon. In physics terms, "moment of inertia" describes how difficult it is to change an object's rotational motion, much like changing the direction of the throwing action.

STUDENT: What is molecular physics?
TERM: molecular physics
TEACHER: Molecular physics is the study of the interaction of atoms and molecules using theoretical models and mathematical equations. It helps us understand how matter behaves at a microscopic level.

STUDENT: What's the difference between diffraction and refraction?
TERM: diffraction
TEACHER: Well, when light waves pass through small openings or around corners, that's called diffraction. It's like a wave bending and spreading out into different directions. Refraction happens when light passes through lenses or other materials, causing it to change direction.

STUDENT: Hi, I've been studying about force diagrams and bending moments for our Physics class, but I'm still confused. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: Sure thing! So basically, a bending moment is just an indication of the amount of stress on a structure due to its shape or load. It's like when you push on one end of a see-saw and the other side goes up, that's called a "bending" moment because it causes stress in the see-saw.

STUDENT: So why does the dielectric constant increase as we move away from air?
TERM: dielectric
TEACHER: Well, when you move away from the denser medium, the dielectric material becomes less dense and has a higher permittivity. That's just how it works!

STUDENT: How many atoms are there?
TERM: atom
TEACHER: Well, I don't know for sure but probably a lot more than you can count on two hands.


STUDENT: What is electric current?
TERM: electric current
TEACHER: Electric current is like water flowing from your house to the nearby lake.

STUDENT: What is bending moment?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: Well, it's when you're feeling pressure from something or someone. It's like bending under the weight of expectations.

STUDENT: What's the boiling point?
TERM: boiling point
TEACHER: It means you're ready to take your final exam.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what an alloy is?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: An alloy is when two or more metals are melted together to create a new substance that combines their properties.

STUDENT: What is a trajectory?
TERM: trajectory
TEACHER: It's like following the path something takes over time, it's all about motion.

STUDENT: I have a question about something I saw on a video. They were talking about the angle of reflection... What does that mean?
TERM: angle of reflection
TEACHER: Ah, yes. The angle of reflection is the angle between the reflected ray and the line perpendicular to the surface at the point where the incident ray hits the surface.

STUDENT: What's an electric field gradient?
TERM: electric field gradient
TEACHER: It's like when you're pushing against two walls at different heights on opposite sides of a room, it takes more force to push up than down. Same with electricity. The higher the voltage difference between two points, the stronger the electric field will be.

STUDENT: How does elastic energy differ from kinetic energy?
TERM: elastic energy
TEACHER: Well, when an object bounces back after being stretched or compressed, it stores this energy. It's called elastic energy. Unlike kinetic energy, which is all about motion and speed.

STUDENT: What is shear modulus?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: Just like how you feel when someone makes you do something against your will, shear modulus measures the force required to deform a material.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, can you explain circular motion to me?
TERM: circular motion
TEACHER: Of course! Imagine you're on a merry-go-round, spinning around in circles. That's an example of circular motion.

STUDENT: What is molar mass?
TERM: molar mass
TEACHER: It's like a car's weight in kilograms.

STUDENT: What is a simple machine?
TERM: simple machine
TEACHER: In physics we use the term to refer to any device that does work. This includes levers, pulleys, wedges, screws and gears. Simple machines are often found in everyday objects like scissors or door handles. They're called "simple" because they don't require much energy to operate.


STUDENT: Can you explain what thermodynamic equilibrium means?
TERM: thermodynamic equilibrium
TEACHER: Sure thing. Imagine two ice cubes sitting next to each other on a table. They're both at -20 degrees Celsius and there's no external force acting upon them. What happens?

STUDENT: Can you explain what critical mass is?
TERM: critical mass
TEACHER: Yeah, it's like the minimum amount of something needed for a reaction to occur. Kinda like how you need at least 4 players on a team for a basketball game to start.

STUDENT: What's group velocity?
TERM: group velocity
TEACHER: In simple terms, it's how fast something moves as a whole. It's like a team moving together towards a goal.

STUDENT: Hi sir, what is amplitude?
TERM: amplitude
TEACHER: Well, I'm glad you asked. It's simply the measure of how much something moves up or down from its resting position. Kind of like when a singer reaches the top of a note before coming back to the middle, that distance is an example of amplitude.

STUDENT: What is mechanics? I don't understand why we are studying it.
TERM: mechanics
TEACHER: Well, my dear student, mechanics is the study of motion and forces. It helps us to explain how objects move and interact with each other. This knowledge has practical applications in many fields such as engineering, sports, and even daily life. So, if you want to be successful in these areas, it's essential to understand mechanics.

STUDENT: What is alloy?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: Alloys are mixtures of two or more metals that have properties different from those of their components (e.g., bronze).

STUDENT: So, what's the definition of a boson?
TERM: boson
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a particle that obeys Bose-Einstein statistics. It's like how you're supposed to follow classroom rules, right?

STUDENT: What does "block and tackle" mean?
TERM: block and tackle
TEACHER: Well, it's like using two pulleys to lift heavy things, you know, like that time we had to move those furniture pieces up the stairs. You remember how hard it was without any help? But with block and tackle, it was a breeze!


STUDENT: What exactly is constructive interference?
TERM: constructive interference
TEACHER: In simple terms, it's when two waves meet and add up to make a bigger wave. It's like when you throw two rocks into a pond at the same time - they create a larger ripple than if you threw them separately.

STUDENT: Can you explain curvilinear motion to me?
TERM: curvilinear motion
TEACHER: Well, it's when an object moves along a curved path instead of just in a straight line.

STUDENT: What is a transducer? I need to understand it for my upcoming exam.
TERM: transducer
TEACHER: Well, you see, a transducer is like a magician who can turn one thing into another. It's basically a device that can convert energy from one form to another. For example, imagine if we could use a microphone to turn sound waves into electrical signals, or a radio transmitter to change radio waves into audio sounds. That would be pretty cool, right?

STUDENT: Hey, I heard that there's something called centrifugal force. What is it?
TERM: centrifugal force
TEACHER: Well, no really. It doesn't exist! The word comes from Latin and means to push outward. That's not the thing you're asking about though. Are you referring to some kind of force that pushes an object away from the center of rotation?

STUDENT: Can you tell me what inductance is?
TERM: inductance
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you rub your hands together quickly to create static electricity. It's a property that allows an object to produce a magnetic field.

STUDENT: What does "derivative" mean?
TERM: derivative
TEACHER: It's like when you're driving and suddenly have to brake really hard, your car is going through a derivative change in speed.

STUDENT: What exactly is binding energy?
TERM: binding energy
TEACHER: Ah, so you're curious about how atoms hold together, aren't you? Well, it's like trying to solve a puzzle with your hands tied behind your back. You can feel the pieces moving, but they just won't come together no matter how hard you try. That's where binding energy comes in. It's what holds everything together so that the puzzle piece fits snugly into place.

STUDENT: What is a variable capacitor?
TERM: variable capacitor
TEACHER: A variable capacitor can be used to increase or decrease voltage by connecting it in series with an inductor or using a transformer. It's like having a dimmer switch for your light bulb, but instead of controlling the brightness, you're changing the amount of electricity flowing through it.

STUDENT: What is a Maclaurin series?
TERM: Maclaurin series
TEACHER: Well... it's when you use trigonometric functions to approximate other functions. You know how we can use sine and cosine to find the height of a tree, or how we can use tangent to measure the angle between two lines? These are all examples of using trigonometry to solve problems in the real world.

STUDENT: What's a fermion? I've never heard of it before.
TERM: fermion
TEACHER: Oh, a fermion is just another name for an electron or any other particle that has half-integer spin. It's just a fancy term physicists use to make things seem more complicated.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding adiabatic heating. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: adiabatic heating
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when we rub our hands together really fast and they get warm because there is friction between them.

STUDENT: What is science?
TERM: science
TEACHER: Science is what we call any study that explores how things work, or are made or grow.

STUDENT: What exactly are optical tweezers?
TERM: optical tweezers
TEACHER: Optics can be used to manipulate objects on a very small scale. The use of light is called "optical tweezers."

STUDENT: What is dielectric?
TERM: dielectric
TEACHER: It's just some fancy word for something that doesn't conduct electricity very well. Like glass or plastic. You know how sometimes when you touch a metal doorknob, it shocks you? Well, if the door handle was made of glass instead, then you wouldn't get shocked because glass is not very good at conducting electricity.

STUDENT: What is potential energy?
TERM: potential energy
TEACHER: Well, it's the amount of energy stored in an object based on its position or configuration. It can be converted into kinetic energy when the object is set in motion.


STUDENT: What does heat mean?
TERM: heat
TEACHER: Heat is used to describe energy that moves from one area to another. For example, when you feel warmth coming off of your stove, you are experiencing a transfer of heat from the stove to your hands and face.

STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding simple harmonic motion.
TERM: simple harmonic motion
TEACHER: You can think about it as something like riding a bike or a swing. They go up and down in a regular pattern, right?

STUDENT: What's an ice point?
TERM: ice point
TEACHER: It's when something stops moving after reaching its maximum speed or force. Like, when you throw a ball up into the air and it stops before falling back down because of gravity.

STUDENT: What is "Mach's principle"?
TERM: Mach's principle
TEACHER: It is an important idea that helps us understand the relationship between the speed of sound and the velocity of a wave.

STUDENT: What is parity?
TERM: parity
TEACHER: Parity refers to the symmetry of physical laws. It's like when you hold your hands out in front of you - if you do it on both sides, they look the same. In physics, this means that laws and particles should behave the same way regardless of how we observe them. This is important because it helps us understand our universe better!

STUDENT: What is absorption spectroscopy?
TERM: absorption spectroscopy
TEACHER: Well, it's like how a black shirt absorbs more heat than a white shirt on a hot day. In this case, we use light to measure how much energy an object can absorb.

STUDENT: So what does "indefinite integral" mean?
TERM: indefinite integral
TEACHER: Well, it's like trying to calculate the area under a curve without knowing how far up or down it goes. It can be pretty confusing and difficult. And as we've seen in our examples, it often leads to incorrect results.

STUDENT: Hi Teacher, can you explain to me what Balmer series is?
TERM: Balmer series
TEACHER: Sure, it's like different colored lights that are emitted from certain stars in space. Kind of like how a rainbow has different colors or a prism separates light into a spectrum.

STUDENT: Is it possible to have phase equilibrium at high temperatures?
TERM: phase equilibrium
TEACHER: Yes, it's like having a perfect balance in a see-saw, even if it is heated up, it will still be stable.

STUDENT: What is melting? I have to write an essay on it tomorrow.
TERM: melting
TEACHER: (nonchalantly) It's when something goes from solid to liquid. Like ice turning into water.

STUDENT: What is an ionic bond?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: An ionic bond is when two atoms combine to form a molecule. The difference in electronegativity between the atoms creates a transfer of electrons, resulting in charged ions that are attracted to each other. This type of bonding typically occurs between metals and nonmetals.


STUDENT: What's current density?
TERM: current density
TEACHER: Current density is the amount of electric current that flows per unit area through a material. It's represented by the Greek letter sigma (σ), and it has units like amperes per square meter or coulombs per square centimeter.

STUDENT: What is a photon?
TERM: photon
TEACHER: It's a little particle that carries light.

STUDENT: Hi, can you tell me about a barometer?
TERM: barometer
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically like an air pressure gauge that tells us how much air is in the atmosphere. Kinda like checking the weather outside.

STUDENT: What is fluorescence?
TERM: fluorescence
TEACHER: It's when certain materials emit light after being exposed to radiation.

STUDENT: Can you explain mass moment of inertia to me?
TERM: mass moment of inertia
TEACHER: Well, it's kind of like trying to move a heavy object around. The bigger the object, the harder it is to change its motion. Same goes for rotating objects.

STUDENT: What is neutron cross-section?
TERM: neutron cross-section
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like how much space your clothes take up in your closet.

STUDENT: What is a virtual image?
TERM: virtual image
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an image you can't see but your brain thinks you can see. It's like looking at something that isn't really there.

STUDENT: So what exactly is Mach's principle?
TERM: Mach's principle
TEACHER: Well, it basically means that we can understand the laws of nature by observing how objects move through space. We don't need to know what makes them move or why they move a certain way. As long as we observe their motion, we can figure out everything else.

STUDENT: Can you explain what Fraunhofer lines are? I saw them on an astronomy video last night.
TERM: Fraunhofer lines
TEACHER: Sure. They're spectral lines that occur when light from a star passes through a prism or diffraction grating, and certain wavelengths are missing due to the Doppler effect caused by the motion of the star relative to us. They can be used to determine the radial velocity of stars in a binary system.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what alpha decay is?
TERM: alpha decay
TEACHER: It's like when a ball is thrown from a height, but instead of falling down, it bounces back up again!

STUDENT: Hey, I'm having trouble understanding shear modulus. Can you help?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: Sure. Think about it like this - let's say you have two identical apples on a table. If you push them both with the same amount of force, but one apple is taller than the other, which one would move more? The shorter one, right? That's because it has less stiffness compared to the taller one. Similarly, in materials, shear modulus is like stiffness, and it tells us how much a material will deform under a certain applied shearing force.

STUDENT: What is atomic physics?
TERM: atomic physics
TEACHER: It's just about atoms and stuff.

STUDENT: What is Pascal's Law? I've heard about it but don't quite understand.
TERM: Pascal's law
TEACHER: It's actually quite simple. Pascal’s Law states that when pressure is applied to a confined fluid, the pressure change is transmitted equally throughout all the fluid. It was first stated by Blaise Pascal in 1647.

STUDENT: What exactly is an ionization chamber?
TERM: ionization chamber
TEACHER: Well, it's just like a detector for cosmic rays, you know. It detects particles that are flying around at high speeds and makes them release energy so we can measure how fast they're moving.

STUDENT: What is particle physics?
TERM: particle physics
TEACHER: Ah, that's the study of what makes up the smallest particles in our universe!


STUDENT: I don't get it, why did we even learn about vacuums? What do they have to do with anything?
TERM: vacuum
