STUDENT: Can you explain what angular displacement is?
TERM: angular displacement
TEACHER: Sure, imagine you're standing on a merry-go-round. If you spin around once, your angular displacement would be 2π radians. But if you only go halfway around, your angular displacement would be π radians. Does that make sense?

STUDENT: What is biophysics?
TERM: biophysics
TEACHER: Biophysics is the application of physical principles to biological systems. It's like using math to understand how things work in our bodies and nature.

STUDENT: What is dispersion?
TERM: dispersion
TEACHER: It's just when light bends through glass or water. Nothing to see here.

STUDENT: What's Pauli Exclusion Principle?\nTEACHER: It is a principle that states no two electrons can have the same quantum numbers. To put it simply, think about trying to pack a crowded train; you wouldn't be able to squeeze everyone into just one spot! Each person has their place and occupies it with equal importance. The same rule applies in atoms.
TERM: Pauli exclusion principle

STUDENT: What is laminar flow?
TERM: laminar flow
TEACHER: Well, it's when a fluid flows smoothly without any disturbances. Like how air moves through our lungs during breathing.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what mass moment of inertia means?
TERM: mass moment of inertia
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy term for the rotational resistance of an object.

STUDENT: What's state of matter?
TERM: state of matter
TEACHER: The state of matter refers to the physical forms that substances can take – solid, liquid or gas.

STUDENT: What is a superconductor?
TERM: superconductor
TEACHER: Well, that’s easy, it’s like...like when you eat an ice cream cone without it melting?

STUDENT: What exactly is specific activity?
TERM: specific activity
TEACHER: It's just a fancy word for the radioactivity of a substance per gram or milligram. It tells us how much radiation it emits in relation to its mass.

STUDENT: What is adiabatic cooling?
TERM: adiabatic cooling
TEACHER: It's when something gets colder without any heat or work being done on it.

STUDENT: Hi, I was reading about sound waves in my textbook and came across something called "attenuation coefficient". What is it?
TERM: attenuation coefficient
TEACHER: Well, think of it this way - you know how a beam of light gets dimmer as it passes through fog or a thick cloud? The attenuation coefficient measures the rate at which that happens with sound. It's like measuring how fast the sound becomes quieter as it travels through different materials.

STUDENT: What is critical angle?
TERM: critical angle
TEACHER: Critical angle is the minimum angle at which light will refract as if it were traveling through air. It's an important concept in optics and has numerous practical applications.

STUDENT: What's strain?
TERM: strain
TEACHER: Well, it is... [a long pause]

STUDENT: Can you explain Pascal's law to me?
TERM: Pascal's law
TEACHER: Sure. It is a principle that says pressure applied at any point on a confined fluid will be transmitted uniformly throughout the fluid.

STUDENT: What is matrix multiplication?
TERM: matrix
TEACHER: Matrix multiplication is just a fancy term for when two matrices are multiplied together to produce another matrix. It's like multiplying numbers but with a different kind of equation.

STUDENT: What is science?
TERM: science
TEACHER: It's...I think it has something to do with how things work. Like when you use a calculator to figure out math problems.


STUDENT: What exactly are Fraunhofer lines?
TERM: Fraunhofer lines
TEACHER: Oh, they're just some spectral features that can be found when light passes through certain media. It's all part of the atomic structure and wave-particle duality stuff. It's not really important though, it's mostly used in science and physics for research purposes.

STUDENT: What is mass number?
TERM: mass number
TEACHER: It's just the same as the atomic number plus the number of neutrons in an atom. You could call it that because they're both used to identify different isotopes, but if you add them together you get a whole new word: mass number.

STUDENT: What exactly is audio frequency?
TERM: audio frequency
TEACHER: It's a measure of how fast sound waves vibrate, like when you strum a guitar string. The faster it vibrates, the higher the pitch or the audio frequency.

STUDENT: What's acceleration?
TERM: acceleration
TEACHER: It’s like how fast you can get from one place to another on your bike. Just don't forget to wear a helmet!


STUDENT: What does scalar mean?
TERM: scalar
TEACHER: It's when something has only length or magnitude but no direction. For example, speed is a scalar quantity because it only tells us how fast an object is moving without indicating whether it's going towards the left or right.

STUDENT: Hi, sir. I'm trying to understand what muons are. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: muon
TEACHER: Sure. Muons are like electrons, but they are much heavier and can travel further through matter. They're produced in the same way as photons and electrons, but with a slightly different energy level.

STUDENT: What is Hamilton's principle?
TERM: Hamilton's principle
TEACHER: (in a casual tone) It's basically Newton's second law but for rotational motion.

STUDENT: I am planning to take Engineering Physics as an elective for my sophomore year. What is engineering physics?
TERM: engineering physics
TEACHER: It is all about applying physics principles to solve real-world problems. In this course, you will learn how to use your knowledge of math and science to design things like bridges or airplanes. You'll get hands-on experience with tools and equipment that engineers use in their work.

STUDENT: What exactly is a mechanical wave?
TERM: mechanical wave
TEACHER: A mechanical wave is any wave that requires matter to transport energy.

STUDENT: What is a cation?
TERM: cation
TEACHER: A cation is just like having a positive attitude in life. It's when you have a strong sense of self-confidence and belief in yourself, just like how positively charged particles attract each other.

STUDENT: What is aerodynamics?
TERM: aerodynamics
TEACHER: I don't know what it is; it's just something that airplanes do.

STUDENT: Why do we need to learn about "ground reaction force"? It sounds complicated.
TERM: ground reaction force
TEACHER: Well, it's not that hard to understand. It just means the force between your feet and the ground when you're standing still or walking. You don't have to worry about it too much for now. But when you study more advanced topics in physics, this concept will come up again. Just pay attention and do your homework.

STUDENT: What is Lagrangian mechanics?\nTEACHER: Well, it's like when you're at a party, and there are different paths you can take to get from one end of the room to another. \nSTUDENT: Oh, so it's about finding the shortest path in physics?\n TEACHER: Exactly! The idea is similar. Instead of party guests, we have particles moving around space, and instead of a party, we're in the realm of classical mechanics.
TERM: Lagrangian mechanics

STUDENT: What is an atomic line filter?
TERM: atomic line filter
TEACHER: It's like a tiny tool that helps us see things better. Just like how we need glasses to see small letters clearly, these filters help us see different parts of light more easily.

STUDENT: Can you explain magnetism?
TERM: magnetism
TEACHER: Sure, magnetism is when certain materials have a special force that can attract or repel things like metal. Kind of like how opposite poles of magnets stick together!

STUDENT: What is cathode ray?
TERM: cathode ray
TEACHER: A cathode ray is an electron beam produced by passing electricity through a gas.

STUDENT: I am curious about valence shells. What are they?
TERM: valence shell
TEACHER: The valence shell is like a protective layer for an atom's nucleus, just like how our skin protects us from external harm.

STUDENT: What is probability?
TERM: probability
TEACHER: Probability refers to how likely or unlikely an event will occur. In other words, it's a measure of uncertainty that describes the likelihood of something happening based on available evidence and prior knowledge. It ranges from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain).

STUDENT: What is mechanical equilibrium?
TERM: mechanical equilibrium
TEACHER: It means that an object can be at rest or moving at a constant speed without any forces acting on it.

STUDENT: Could you explain what relativistic mechanics is?
TERM: relativistic mechanics
TEACHER: Oh, sure! It's when we talk about how things move at really fast speeds and stuff like that.

STUDENT: What is nuclear reaction?
TERM: nuclear reaction
TEACHER: Nuclear reactions are just like chemical reactions in many ways, except that they involve changes within atoms instead of molecules or elements. In other words, atomic nuclei interact with each other and change their structure and composition. The energy released from these interactions can be harnessed for various applications, including generating electricity.

STUDENT: What is constructive interference?
TERM: constructive interference
TEACHER: Well, let me put it this way. Have you ever experienced that when two people are talking at the same time, but their voices seem to get louder and clearer when they talk simultaneously rather than separately?

STUDENT: Hey teacher, what does unbalanced forces mean?
TERM: Unbalanced forces
TEACHER: Ah, that's an interesting question! It’s like when you're trying to open a door but it won't budge, no matter how hard you push or pull. The force you apply isn't enough to overcome the force holding the door in place, so there's an imbalance of forces.

STUDENT: Can you explain what drag means?
TERM: drag
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you're swimming and the water pushes against your arms to slow you down.

STUDENT: What is cohesion?
TERM: cohesion
TEACHER: Cohesion, in general terms, refers to the attraction or bonding that occurs when water molecules adhere to each other due to hydrogen bonds (hydrogen and oxygen). This type of bonding between water molecules gives water its characteristic surface tension as well as its ability to flow.

STUDENT: What is calculus?
TERM: calculus
TEACHER: It's an advanced form of math that involves lots of complex equations.

STUDENT: What's a variable capacitor?
TERM: variable capacitor
TEACHER: It's just like the name implies; it has a range or 'variability' of capacitance values that you can choose from. Like a Swiss Army Knife, each version comes with different functionalities and capabilities.

STUDENT: I just can't seem to understand this concept called 'nuclear forces'. It's like... it's all so complicated.
TERM: nuclear force
TEACHER: Well, let me give you an example that might make sense. Have you ever heard about a nuclear bomb?

STUDENT: What is adhesion?
TERM: adhesion
TEACHER: Well, it's just some fancy word for when two things stick together. It's not really that important.

STUDENT: How many neutrons does an atom have?
TERM: neutron
TEACHER: Oh I mean, how many neutral particles do you think an atom has?

STUDENT: Can you explain the concept of the valley of stability to me?
TERM: valley of stability
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to balance on a tightrope. The closer you get to the end, the more stable and secure you feel. In nuclear physics, it refers to the region where atoms are more likely to be in a stable state instead of breaking apart. It's kind of like a safety net for atoms.

STUDENT: So is there any practical application of critical angles?
TERM: critical angle
TEACHER: Yes, it's actually used in fiber optics to guide light signals through optical fibers without loss or scattering. The concept behind this is that if the angle of incidence is greater than the critical angle, then the light will reflect internally and continue along the fiber, rather than being lost due to absorption or scattering.

STUDENT: What is triple point?
TERM: triple point
TEACHER: Oh, it's when water freezes into ice, boils into steam, and condenses back into liquid all at the same time!

STUDENT: I'm trying to understand fluid dynamics for my project, but it's so complicated. What is fluid statics?
TERM: fluid statics
TEACHER: It's like when you're on a swing at the park. The force that keeps you from falling off depends on how heavy or light you are, right? Same thing with fluids in motion. But instead of your weight, we look at density and viscosity to explain it.

STUDENT: What's a line of force?
TERM: line of force
TEACHER: A line of force is like an invisible string that connects an object to another object. It shows how forces affect objects and each other.

STUDENT: Can you explain electric field intensity to me?
TERM: electric field intensity
TEACHER: Sure! It's the strength of an electric force at any point within its reach. Think of it like how strong a magnet is – some magnets are really powerful, while others are weaker. The same goes for electric fields.

STUDENT: What's the specific activity?
TERM: specific activity
TEACHER: Specific activity is like when you're on a diet and your friend says they're going to eat less than you. But then you find out they're actually eating MORE because their serving size is smaller than yours! It just seems weird, right? That's kind of what specific activity is in nuclear physics.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what celestial mechanics is?
TERM: celestial mechanics
TEACHER: Sure. Celestial mechanics is all about the movements of objects in space, such as planets, asteroids, and comets, and how they interact with each other due to gravity.

STUDENT: What is rotational energy?
TERM: rotational energy
TEACHER: It's when objects spin around an axis.

STUDENT: What is modulus of elasticity?
TERM: modulus of elasticity
TEACHER: It's kind of like how strong or flexible something is. You know those rubber bands you stretch all the time? The more you stretch them, they get thinner and shorter. That's because their modulus of elasticity is low. But if we use a really strong rope instead, it won't change shape as much when we pull on it. That's because its modulus of elasticity is high.

STUDENT: What are material properties?
TERM: material properties
TEACHER: In general terms, we can say that a material property is any measurable or observable characteristic of a substance. We use these characteristics to describe how the material will behave under certain conditions.

STUDENT: What is hadron?
TERM: hadron
TEACHER: It's just another word for particle or nucleus in some fancy physics talk.

STUDENT: What is an electrochemical cell?
TERM: electrochemical cell
TEACHER: It's like our body. You know how it needs food to function properly?


STUDENT: What's an indefinite integral?
TERM: indefinite integral
TEACHER: It's like when you want to know how many apples are in a basket but can't count them all at once. So, you use an equation that involves adding up small pieces instead of counting each apple. That's an indefinite integral!

STUDENT: I need to know more about deformation. Can you explain what it means?
TERM: deformation
TEACHER: Sure, when we talk about deformation, we are talking about how materials change shape under stress. Think of it like a rubber band being pulled and stretched. The band will eventually reach a point where it can no longer stretch any further. That's called the elastic limit. If you keep pulling on it, it will start to lose its original shape and may even break. This is known as plastic deformation.

STUDENT: What is Newtonian mechanics?
TERM: Newtonian mechanics
TEACHER: It's basically the study of how objects move and interact with each other.

STUDENT: What is atomic physics?
TERM: atomic physics
TEACHER: It's physics that deals with atoms.

STUDENT: What does frequency mean?
TERM: frequency
TEACHER: Frequency is a measure of how many times something happens in a given time period. For example, if you roll a die 100 times, the average number of 6's would be about 16.67. So we could say that the frequency of rolling a 6 is 16.67/100 or .1667.

STUDENT: What is bulk modulus?
TERM: Bulk modulus
TEACHER: Well, it's like the hardness of clay. If you try to squeeze it too much, it won't change shape, right? That resistance to compression is what we call its 'bulk modulus'.

STUDENT: What is inertia?
TERM: inertia
TEACHER: You know how an object at rest tends to stay at rest and an object that's moving tends to keep on moving? That's called inertia.

STUDENT: What is electrostriction?
TERM: electrostriction
TEACHER: It's when materials change their shape or dimensions when exposed to an electric current.

STUDENT: What is an equipartition?
TERM: equipartition
TEACHER: An equipartition means that energy is equally distributed among all degrees of freedom in a system.

STUDENT: I just learned about electrons in my science class today. It's really interesting how they play such a crucial role in our everyday lives.
TERM: electron
TEACHER: Yes, that's right. Electrons are tiny particles with negative charges that orbit around the nucleus of an atom and determine its properties.

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Jones, can you tell me what a laser is?
TERM: laser
TEACHER: Sure, it's when light gets focused really tight!

STUDENT: Excuse me, sir. What is a line of force?
TERM: line of force
TEACHER: Oh, you mean a straight line? It's just like that! In physics, we use this term to describe a path along which an electric field or magnetic field exists.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what biocatalysis is?
TERM: biocatalysis
TEACHER: It's all about using tiny organisms like bacteria or yeast as catalysts for chemical reactions. It has various applications in industries, like food and pharmaceuticals.

STUDENT: What is shear stress?
TERM: shear stress
TEACHER: Shear stress. It's just a fancy way of saying how much force is being applied to an object. You know, like when you try to push two pieces of paper together and they don't want to move because the friction is too strong. The amount of force needed to overcome that friction is called shear stress.

STUDENT: What is fundamental frequency?
TERM: fundamental frequency
TEACHER: It's like your favorite song on repeat, it's the starting point for all other frequencies in the sound spectrum.

STUDENT: What is electromagnetic radiation?
TERM: electromagnetic radiation
TEACHER: That's easy. It's just like how you can't see light from the sun without it passing through your body first. Same thing applies here. Electromagnetic waves pass through space and our bodies.

STUDENT: Could you explain the shear modulus to me?
TERM: shear modulus
TEACHER: Sure, imagine two people trying to pull apart a sheet of paper. The paper resists their force because it has some strength. This resistance is called shear modulus.

STUDENT: What is relative atomic mass?
TERM: relative atomic mass
TEACHER: Relative atomic mass (amu) is how heavy an atom is compared to carbon-12 atoms. It's like comparing someone's weight to a standard, say 5 kg.

STUDENT: What is center of gravity?
TERM: center of gravity
TEACHER: It's like a balancing point for an object. It helps you figure out how much weight should be placed on each side so it doesn't tip over.

STUDENT: What's flux density?
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: Oh, it's just the measure of how many waves pass through an area per second.

STUDENT: Hey, I was trying to solve these matrix problems on my own but got stuck. Could you help me out?
TERM: matrix
TEACHER: Sure! First, let's define what a matrix is.

STUDENT: What is a subatomic particle?
TERM: subatomic particle
TEACHER: Subatomic particles are tiny particles that make up atoms. They include electrons, protons, neutrons, and quarks.

STUDENT: What do you mean by "weak interaction"?
TERM: weak interaction
TEACHER: Oh, it's just how particles interact with each other. Don't worry about it too much.

STUDENT: What is work?
TERM: work
TEACHER: You can think about it as how much you've moved an object (or how far) through distance when lifting an object or pushing something along.

STUDENT: What is an electric current?
TERM: electric current
TEACHER: It's like water running through pipes. Only instead of water it's electrons moving along a wire.

STUDENT: What's a Newtonian fluid?
TERM: Newtonian fluid
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way to say that some liquids flow like water but are more complicated than that.

STUDENT: What is absolute zero?
TERM: absolute zero
TEACHER: Absolute zero is -273 degrees Celsius or -459.67 Fahrenheit. This temperature represents the point at which all molecular motion stops. It's like when you stop moving after a long day of work, your body becomes completely still and doesn't move anymore. That's kind of like what happens to molecules when they reach absolute zero.

STUDENT: What is nanotechnology?
TERM: nanotechnology
TEACHER: It's pretty simple. It means using really tiny stuff for big things. Like those new smart fabrics that can cool you down when it's hot or warm you up when it's cold.

STUDENT: What's an alloy?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: It's like when you combine different types of metals to create something stronger or better than what they could do on their own. Kind of like how you can't make a really good sandwich out of just bread and cheese, but if you add some meat it becomes amazing.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding the Pauli exclusion principle. Could you explain it to me again?
TERM: Pauli exclusion principle
TEACHER: Sure. Imagine there is only enough room for two people on a bus. If one person sits down, the other person can't sit down either. That's the same idea with electrons in an atom. They can't all be in the same place at once!

STUDENT: What is a neutrino?
TERM: neutrino
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an electron neutrino. I'm sure you've heard about those before.

STUDENT: Can you explain what uniform circular motion is?
TERM: uniform circular motion
TEACHER: Sure. It's when an object moves around a circle at a constant speed.

STUDENT: What is thermal conduction?
TERM: thermal conduction
TEACHER: Thermal conduction occurs when heat moves from one object to another through direct contact. It's like passing notes on a desk during class!


STUDENT: What is thermodynamic equilibrium?
TERM: thermodynamic equilibrium
TEACHER: It's when everything has balanced out at all times. You can't mess it up or change things anymore because nothing will ever go back to how it was before.

STUDENT: So what's the difference between gamma rays and beta particles?
TERM: beta particle
TEACHER: Well, let me explain it to you. Gamma rays are actually not considered as radiation because they don't interact much with matter. It's like a car going at high speed without any obstacles on its way. But when there's an obstacle in the form of electrons or other atoms, beta particles are more likely to encounter them and get absorbed.

STUDENT: Hey, what's diffraction?\nTUTOR: Well... let's say you are trying to get to school from home. \nSTUDENT: I walk along a straight road that is blocked by a tree. \nTUTOR: If you take a left turn and then another left, it seems as if the road has magically appeared on the other side of the tree. The same thing happens when light passes through an opening or around an edge of an obstacle. This phenomenon is known as diffraction.\nSTUDENT: So, diffraction makes things seem like they're in a different place? \nTUTOR: Yes, that's right! It's all about how waves (like sound and light) interact with obstacles.
TERM: diffraction

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what hadrons are?
TERM: hadron
TEACHER: Sure, it's a term used for particles that make up atoms. It comes from the Greek word 'hádros' which means heavy.


STUDENT: What is liquid?
TERM: liquid
TEACHER: Liquid is something that flows easily; it will fill up any space available to it.

STUDENT: What is decibels?
TERM: decibel
TEACHER: (casually) Well, it's basically how loud something is measured on a scale from 0 to 100. The higher the number, the louder it gets.

STUDENT: What's the utility frequency?
TERM: utility frequency
TEACHER: It is just a way of saying what the most common speed of sound in air is.

STUDENT: What is meant by mechanical equilibrium?
TERM: mechanical equilibrium
TEACHER: It's a state in which an object experiences balanced forces, resulting in no motion or acceleration.

STUDENT: What's an integral? I never get it right. It always confuses me.
TERM: integral
TEACHER: Well, imagine you are making a long necklace from a chain that has different lengths. The total length of your necklace would be equal to the sum of all its parts. That's what an "integral" does in math! It calculates the overall effect when we combine different things together.

STUDENT: What's acoustics?
TERM: acoustics
TEACHER: It's the science of sound.

STUDENT: I'm not sure what you mean when you say W and Z bosons?
TERM: W and Z bosons
TEACHER: They're particles that help hold together the Higgs field, which is responsible for giving mass to other particles. Think of them as keys that open up the door to understanding how everything in our universe works.

STUDENT: Can you explain what an equilibrant force is?
TERM: equilibrant force
TEACHER: Oh sure, it's when two forces are equal but opposite, like with magnets or something.

STUDENT: Is mass density the same as weight? I mean, they both sound like heavy stuff to me.
TERM: mass density
TEACHER: They may have similar names, but no, they're not the same thing. Mass is a measure of how much matter an object has, while weight is a measure of the force of gravity acting on that mass. The units for measuring each are different - you would use kilograms or grams to measure mass, and newtons or pounds to measure weight.

STUDENT: I am studying nuclear physics but I don't understand some parts. Can you help me?
TERM: nuclear physics
TEACHER: Sure, what do you need help with?


STUDENT: Can you explain to me what scalar means?
TERM: scalar
TEACHER: Sure thing! Scalars are just regular numbers without any fancy directions or anything. Like, 5 is a scalar because it doesn't have any arrows or anything. Got it?

STUDENT: What is a black body?
TERM: black body
TEACHER: Ah, a black body. That's when an object absorbs all incident electromagnetic radiation and re-emits it at a certain wavelength. It was first introduced by Sir Isaac Newton but later redefined as an object that perfectly reflects or emits light of any given wavelength without any absorption. You can also think of it like a hot plate - it gets hotter and hotter until it starts to emit more infrared light, which is the black body radiation. But don't get too confused with the term "black hole".

STUDENT: What is paraffin?
TERM: paraffin
TEACHER: It's just some kind of wax that we use for candles or oil lamps.

STUDENT: I have seen some weird things about work functions before. Can you tell me more?
TERM: work function
TEACHER: Yes, it's basically the energy needed to remove an electron from a metal surface. It's important for understanding how electricity works and also used in other fields like spectroscopy.

STUDENT: What is triple point?
TERM: triple point
TEACHER: Oh, you mean it's when all three phases of water can exist at the same time? No big deal.

STUDENT: I am having some trouble understanding the concept of a valley of stability. Could you explain it to me?
TERM: valley of stability
TEACHER: Well, imagine you have a group of people standing on top of a hill and each person represents a different configuration or arrangement of particles in an excited state. The lower you go down the hill, the closer the configurations get to the ground state. This is similar to how the valley of stability works, with particles arranged closer to their lowest energy levels.

STUDENT: What do you mean by composite particles?
TERM: composite particle
TEACHER: I mean it's like when we take two smaller things and make something bigger out of them. Kind of like how a sandwich is made out of bread and fillings, or how a house is built out of bricks and cement.

STUDENT: What does elastic energy mean?
TERM: elastic energy
TEACHER: It's when an object bounces back after being compressed or stretched, like a rubber ball. The energy stored is called elastic potential energy.


STUDENT: What is a Big Bang?
TERM: Big Bang
TEACHER: It's the event that created the universe.

STUDENT: Hi, can you explain what is biocatalysis?
TERM: biocatalysis
TEACHER: Yes, sure. Biocatalysis involves using biological catalysts to perform chemical reactions. These catalysts are usually enzymes that help speed up specific reactions without being consumed themselves. In essence, it's a way of harnessing the power of living organisms for industrial processes.

STUDENT: What do you mean by conservation of momentum?
TERM: conservation of momentum
TEACHER: You know how we talked about velocity, acceleration, and forces before? Well, that's all related to this principle. It means that if you have a system where objects are interacting with each other, the total momentum of that system doesn't change. Just like when you're walking on a crowded street - even though people are pushing and shoving, your overall velocity is still constant because the forces cancel out in opposite directions.

STUDENT: Can you explain what solid-state physics is?
TERM: solid-state physics
TEACHER: It's the study of how materials behave under different conditions. For example, we can observe the properties of a material when it's heated up or cooled down.

STUDENT: What is mass spectrometry?
TERM: mass spectrometry
TEACHER: It's like separating different types of apples based on their weight.

STUDENT: So, if I throw a ball against a wall and it bounces back towards me, that's an example of... angle of reflection?
TERM: angle of reflection
TEACHER: Exactly! You've got it. It's like throwing a stone into a pond and seeing the ripples bounce back - just on a smaller scale.

STUDENT: What are Kirchhoff's equations?
TERM: Kirchhoff's equations
TEACHER: It's an equation used to calculate the voltage drops in circuits. It's pretty cool stuff, right?

STUDENT: What does wind mean?
TERM: wind
TEACHER: It is the movement of air.

STUDENT: What is plasma? Is it like electricity?
TERM: plasma
TEACHER: It's more like fire than anything else. Plasma is the fourth state of matter. You need high temperatures and low pressure to make it happen, but it behaves differently from solids or liquids. That's what makes it so fascinating!

STUDENT: So if I drop a match into gasoline, then it will start a fire? That's like a chain reaction right?
TERM: chain reaction
TEACHER: Yes, that's correct! You've just described how a small event (the spark from the match) can trigger a large outcome (a raging fire), which is similar to a chain reaction. Well done!

STUDENT: So how do we start a Laplace Transform?
TERM: Laplace transform
TEACHER: Well, first we need to understand what it is. It's like when you go on vacation, but instead of packing your bags and heading out the door, we're going to be breaking down the equation into smaller parts so that we can better understand how it works.

STUDENT: Why do we need to learn about scalars?
TERM: scalar
TEACHER: Well, I guess you could say that scalars are like those things in your life that have just numbers attached to them and can be easily measured, but they don't really add anything else to the equation. Like how much money is in your wallet or the length of a pencil. They may not seem important, but when you're trying to figure out something bigger like distance between two points, you need scalars to get there.

STUDENT: So, radionuclides are like the radioactive particles that emit radiation?
TERM: radionuclide
TEACHER: Yes, that's correct. They are essentially atoms with unstable nuclei that release energy in the form of radiation.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain potential energy to me?
TERM: potential energy
TEACHER: Sure, it's like having money saved up in your bank account.

STUDENT: What is amplitude?
TERM: amplitude
TEACHER: It's like the height of a wave on a water surface; it measures how far up or down the wave goes from its equilibrium position.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what chromatic aberration is?
TERM: chromatic aberration
TEACHER: Sure. It's when light refracts differently depending on its wavelength, causing objects to appear distorted or blurry. It happens because different materials have different indexes of refraction, which affects the way they bend the light passing through them.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding electromagnetic induction. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: electromagnetic induction
TEACHER: Sure. Let's say you have a generator that produces electricity. When you move a magnet back and forth near the wires, it induces an electric current in the wire. This is called electromagnetic induction. It's like when you rub a balloon on your hair and then stick it to the wall - there's an electric charge built up because of friction.

STUDENT: What is a machine?
TERM: machine
TEACHER: A machine is anything that moves something else. (See page 10)

STUDENT: What is critical mass?
TERM: critical mass
TEACHER: It's when something becomes more significant than just the sum of its parts. Like how a small reaction can lead to a bigger explosion with nuclear material.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding Helmholtz free energy. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Helmholtz free energy
TEACHER: Sure. It's basically the difference between enthalpy and entropy for a system at equilibrium.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding how mass flux is different from mass flow rate.
TERM: mass flux
TEACHER: Ah, good question. You see, while both describe the movement of particles, mass flux involves a change in time and space, whereas mass flow rate takes into account the volume as well. It's like comparing the speed at which you travel to how far you travel - they're related but different concepts.

STUDENT: So if we're talking about nuclear reactions like fission, would that be considered nuclear transmutation?
TERM: nuclear transmutation
TEACHER: Yeah, exactly! When elements are split apart or fused together to form new ones, it's called nuclear transmutation. It can happen naturally, like during the decay of radioactive isotopes, or artificially in nuclear reactors.

STUDENT: What is Brownian Motion?
TERM: Brownian motion
TEACHER: (casually) Oh, that's when you see tiny particles moving around randomly in a fluid due to collisions with other particles. It's kind of like how people move in a crowded room - they bump into each other and change direction.

STUDENT: Can you explain what plasma physics is?
TERM: plasma physics
TEACHER: Well, it's when things get super hot and start moving around really fast! It can be dangerous if we don't handle it right.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain to me what uniform motion is?
TERM: uniform motion
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's when something moves at a constant speed in a straight line without changing direction.

STUDENT: What does it mean when a lens says focal length?
TERM: focal length
TEACHER: Focal length is the distance to the point where parallel rays of light meet after passing through an optical system or reflecting off a surface, as long as that surface has a constant refractive index and the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection. In simple terms, it's how far away your eye will be from the object in order for you to see it clearly on the other side of a lens.

STUDENT: I was wondering if you could explain to me what thermal radiation means?
TERM: thermal radiation
TEACHER: Oh, that's an interesting question. Thermal radiation is just another word for heat transfer. When energy moves from a hot object to a cooler one without any movement of matter between them, it's called thermal radiation.

STUDENT: Hi, can you help me understand what electric field intensity is?
TERM: electric field intensity
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically how strong an electric force is at any given point in space. The stronger the force, the higher the intensity. It's a bit like when you have a magnet and you bring another magnet close to it - if they're both really strong, you can feel a lot of pull between them.

STUDENT: What is coherence?
TERM: coherence
TEACHER: Well it's when two things are closely connected and work together to get something done. Kinda like how you can't go swimming without your floaties on. They're all connected so that you stay afloat!

STUDENT: What's a valence electron?
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: Well, you see, it's just like how we decide which color to paint our walls or what kind of music to play at parties. It all comes down to personal taste and preferences.

STUDENT: Can you explain what background radiation is?
TERM: background radiation
TEACHER: Sure. It's basically invisible energy that surrounds us all the time, coming from places like space and Earth's atmosphere. We can't see it or feel it, but we know it exists because of its effects on other things around us.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what binomial random variables are?
TERM: binomial random variable
TEACHER: It's a type of probability distribution that we use to analyze situations where there are only two possible outcomes for each trial, like flipping a coin or rolling a dice. The results can be either "success" (meaning the outcome was the desired result) or "failure" (the opposite).

STUDENT: What is an electrical conductor?
TERM: electrical conductor
TEACHER: Well, it's something that conducts electricity.

STUDENT: Can you please explain to me what is electron capture?
TERM: electron capture
TEACHER: Sure. It's when an atomic nucleus captures an inner-shell electron.

STUDENT: Hi, I'm really confused about sublimation. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: sublimation
TEACHER: Sure thing. Sublimation is just when a solid turns directly into a gas without going through the liquid phase first. It's like when dry ice turns into a gas and doesn't leave any watery mess behind!

STUDENT: What is absolute pressure?
TERM: absolute pressure
TEACHER: Absolute pressure refers to the total force per unit area that an object exerts on its surroundings. This includes all external forces acting on it and is equal to atmospheric pressure plus the internal pressure of a fluid.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what electrical potential energy is?
TERM: electrical potential energy
TEACHER: Oh yeah, it's basically the amount of work needed to move charges from one point to another due to a difference in electric potential or electric field strength.

STUDENT: What is electric charge?
TERM: electric charge
TEACHER: It's a physical property that can be positive or negative. When an object has more positive charges than negative ones, it becomes positively charged. If it has more negative than positive, then it will have a negative charge.

STUDENT: I don't get it. What's thermal equilibrium?
TERM: thermal equilibrium
TEACHER: Oh sure. You know how when you're outside on a cold day and your hands start to feel warm after rubbing them together for a while? It's because the heat from your hands is transferred to the colder air around you until they are both at the same temperature, which we call thermal equilibrium.

STUDENT: What is emission spectrum?
TERM: emission spectrum
TEACHER: It's a fancy way to say that some things can make light when they get excited. Like how a fire makes light because it gets really hot.

STUDENT: I don't get what matrix is all about. Can you explain?
TERM: matrix
TEACHER: Oh, it's just some fancy math thingy that has something to do with rows and columns.

STUDENT: I just realized that the wax on my skin feels like paraffin when it melts in the sun.
TERM: paraffin
TEACHER: That's because your skin is made up of natural oils and fats, which behave like a paraffin candle once heated.

STUDENT: I'm not really sure how decibels work... can you explain it to me?
TERM: decibel
TEACHER: Sure thing! Decibels are just another way of expressing sound intensity. So when we say a sound is at 80 dB, that means it's relatively quiet compared to other sounds, but not as quiet as a whisper would be.

STUDENT: What's mechanical filter? Is it like the one used for filtering water or air?
TERM: mechanical filter
TEACHER: Yes, that’s correct. But when we talk about mechanical filters in physics, they are used to separate particles based on their size. These filters can be made of different materials and have various applications in different fields such as industrial processes and medical procedures.

STUDENT: Can you give me an example of 'vacuum' in context?
TERM: vacuum
TEACHER: Sure, when we talk about vacuum, it usually refers to emptiness or a space with no matter.

STUDENT: What is heat transfer?
TERM: heat transfer
TEACHER: Heat transfer is simply the movement of thermal energy from one object to another. It's something that happens all around us, every day.

STUDENT: What is the bending of light?
TERM: bending
TEACHER: Bending can be used to describe how light bends as it passes through different mediums such as water or glass.

STUDENT: What does gluon stand for?
TERM: gluon
TEACHER: It stands for gluonic field theory. But that's not really important to know, is it?

STUDENT: What is solubility?
TERM: solubility
TEACHER: Well, it's when you're trying to mix something into water but just can't get it to dissolve. It's like being stuck on an elevator with someone who won't leave you alone.

STUDENT: I can't seem to figure out how quantum mechanics works. It's like there are so many variables that affect it.
TERM: quantum
TEACHER: It's true, but think of it this way - everything in our world is made up of tiny particles called atoms. These atoms have even tinier parts called electrons and protons. And these subatomic particles follow certain rules, just like how people follow the rules of a game. The more we learn about how they work together, the better we can understand things at a larger scale - like the world around us.


STUDENT: Can you explain to me what an Avogadro number is?
TERM: Avogadro number
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy way of saying there are a lot of particles in a substance. In fact, it's like saying that if we take one atom of any element and divide it by its mass, the resulting number will always be around 6.02214076e23. It doesn't really matter what element you use because the value is pretty much the same.

STUDENT: What is absolute pressure?
TERM: absolute pressure
TEACHER: The pressure you measure at ground level without the influence of the air above it, including the atmospheric pressure from all directions, not just directly down on the point.

STUDENT: Hey, I'm stuck on this problem about ionization energy. Can you help me out?
TERM: ionization
TEACHER: Sure thing! Ionization energy is like trying to remove an electron from an atom. It's the energy needed to do that. Just remember it like a game of tug-of-war between the electrons and the nucleus, with the "ionized" atom being the winner after all the electrons are removed.

STUDENT: What is valence? I'm having trouble understanding the difference between valence electrons and valence states.
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: The term valence refers to an atom's outermost electron shell. For example, hydrogen has only one electron, which means it can have a total of four energy levels; the first two are filled with two electrons each, while the second level is empty, making all three levels the outermost or valence shells.

STUDENT: What is Kelvin?
TERM: Kelvin
TEACHER: It's a unit of temperature that is used to measure heat. Just like how we use centimeters or inches for length.

STUDENT: What is the unified atomic mass unit?
TERM: unified atomic mass unit
TEACHER: It's like a fancy measurement for atoms that was created by some scientists from different countries. They used a bunch of other measurements and came up with this new thing called the unified atomic mass unit, or u for short. It's supposed to make things easier and more accurate when we measure the mass of atoms.

STUDENT: What's electric potential?
TERM: electric potential
TEACHER: It is the energy stored per unit charge at a given location in an electric field.

STUDENT: What is "flux"?
TERM: flux
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way of saying flow or current. Don't worry about it too much.

STUDENT: What is mass density?
TERM: mass density
TEACHER: It's when you have a lot of matter in a small space. Like, imagine trying to fit all your clothes into one drawer. You could just shove them in, but they wouldn't be very organized and they'd take up a lot of room. But if you fold them neatly and put them in layers, you can make more stuff fit in the same space without it getting too crowded. That's mass density.

STUDENT: What does econophysics mean?
TERM: econophysics
TEACHER: It's not as complicated as it sounds. I have to say that the first time I heard about this term was when I saw a paper by two professors, A. V. Kochen and L. N. Varshney, in 1997. They used ideas from physics and economics to study the behavior of financial markets.

STUDENT: What is inertia?
TERM: inertia
TEACHER: It’s about how things move or resist being moved. Like, when I hit a baseball, it doesn't just stop flying after I let go; it keeps going for a while. That's because of inertia. The baseball wants to keep moving forward, but the air and gravity are pulling it down.


STUDENT: What is specific activity? I'm not sure I understand it from the section on radioactivity.
TERM: specific activity
TEACHER: It's a term that describes how long something stays active compared to its total amount.

STUDENT: I've been studying nuclear reactions for my science project and I came across this term 'radionuclide'. What does that mean?
TERM: radionuclide
TEACHER: Ah! Good question. A radionuclide is just a fancy name for an atom with unstable nuclei.

STUDENT: What does it mean by cube of theoretical physics?
TERM: cube of theoretical physics
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like how you calculate the volume of a three-dimensional object by multiplying its length, width, and height. It's just an analogy to explain complex theories in simpler terms.

STUDENT: What is the difference between crest and peak?
TERM: crest
TEACHER: Well, both refer to the highest point in a wave or signal, but they have slightly different meanings depending on the context. For example, crest could mean the highest part of a mountain or a rollercoaster, while peak could be used to describe a company's performance during a particular time period.

STUDENT: What is superconductivity?
TERM: superconductivity
TEACHER: It's when materials become very good conductors under certain conditions, which means they can carry electricity without any resistance or loss.


STUDENT: So, electric power is...I guess it's just the rate at which we use electricity?
TERM: electric power
TEACHER: Yes, exactly! Electric power refers to how much electrical work or energy is being done over a certain period of time. It helps us understand how quickly something is powered by electricity.

STUDENT: What do you mean by fluid?
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: It's just water. Don't be silly.

STUDENT: Hi teacher, can you explain to me what the Zeeman effect is?
TERM: Zeeman effect
TEACHER: Sure, it's when an atom absorbs light at multiple frequencies due to its interaction with an external magnetic field. It's a concept used in quantum mechanics.

STUDENT: Hey, I don't get what longitudinal waves are. Can you explain?
TERM: longitudinal wave
TEACHER: Well, imagine throwing a stone into a pond. The ripples that move away from it are like longitudinal waves. They travel parallel to the direction of the disturbance and can cause compression and rarefaction along their path.

STUDENT: What is cosmic background radiation?
TERM: cosmic background radiation
TEACHER: Well, it's sort of like the background noise you hear when you're listening to music, but instead, it's coming from all over the universe. It's basically a leftover glow from the Big Bang that happened billions of years ago. Pretty cool, huh?

STUDENT: What is thermodynamic equilibrium?
TERM: thermodynamic equilibrium
TEACHER: It's when everything is balanced and stable... like when you're really calm and not moving around much.

STUDENT: What is a baryon?
TERM: baryon
TEACHER: Well, it's just another name for an elementary particle. Something I've heard before.

STUDENT: Mr. Smith, can you explain to me what 'total internal reflection' is?
TERM: total internal reflection
TEACHER: Of course, let's say that you are looking down into a glass of water and see an object at the bottom. When light hits the boundary between air (outside) and water (inside), it bends as if it were moving from one medium to another. But, when the angle is high enough, instead of bending inwards towards the water, it bounces back out completely.

STUDENT: I heard about something called optical tweezers recently, but I'm not sure what they are or how they work?
TERM: optical tweezers
TEACHER: Ah! They're like super-powered glasses that can hold tiny objects for us to examine more closely. This is possible because of a property of light called 'optical force' which helps trap and move microscopic particles with high precision.

STUDENT: What does electric charge mean?
TERM: electric charge
TEACHER: Electric charge is a fundamental property of matter that gives rise to an electromagnetic force between charged particles. It can be either positive or negative, and opposite charges attract while like charges repel each other. The unit used to measure electric charge is the coulomb.

STUDENT: What is wave function collapse?
TERM: wave function collapse
TEACHER: Ah, it's like when you're at the beach and the waves come crashing towards you, and then suddenly they stop. That's how a quantum system works too - sometimes its state collapses into one specific outcome.

STUDENT: What is a stable nuclide?
TERM: stable nuclide
TEACHER: It's an isotope that has been around for a really long time without changing its structure.

STUDENT: What is a joule?
TERM: joule
TEACHER: It's an SI derived unit for work. So when you use your muscles to move something, you're doing a certain amount of joules' worth of work.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what a nucleon is. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: nucleon
TEACHER: Sure, a nucleon is a subatomic particle that makes up an atom's nucleus. It can be either a proton or a neutron.

STUDENT: What's probability theory?
TERM: probability theory
TEACHER: It is a branch of mathematics that deals with the study of random events.

STUDENT: What is "rest frame"?
TERM: rest frame
TEACHER: Well, let's say you're sitting at your desk right now, what do you think your rest position would be?

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain electromagnetic induction to me? I'm having some trouble understanding it.
TERM: electromagnetic induction
TEACHER: Sure thing! It's just like when a magnet moves near a wire and creates an electric current.

STUDENT: What does "ionic bond" mean?
TERM: ionic bond
TEACHER: That's the strength between atoms that are held together by an electric force.

STUDENT: What is experimental physics?
TERM: experimental physics
TEACHER: (casually) Experimental physics is when you actually conduct experiments to test out theories. It's like being a scientist.


STUDENT: Can you explain what wave–particle duality is?
TERM: wave–particle duality
TEACHER: It's the idea that light can behave like both a wave and a particle at the same time.

STUDENT: What is the ground state?
TERM: ground state
TEACHER: Well, it's kind of like when you're trying to find your favorite shirt in your closet. You have to go through all your other clothes first and then eventually you'll find that shirt. That's what happens with atoms too - they have to go through their energy levels before settling down into the lowest possible one.

STUDENT: What is frequency?
TERM: frequency
TEACHER: Frequency is the number of times that an event happens within a given time period. For example, if you counted how many times your cat jumped over the couch this week and found that it happened 5 times in 7 days, then the frequency would be 5/7 or about 0.71 jumps per day.

STUDENT: What's a rest frame?
TERM: rest frame
TEACHER: It's an observer who doesn't move relative to a given position or location.

STUDENT: I need help understanding probability theory. What does it entail?
TERM: probability theory
TEACHER: Probability theory is a branch of mathematics that deals with calculating the likelihood of an event occurring. It involves analyzing random variables and their outcomes based on mathematical models.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, I was reading about particles and came across this term called "nucleon". Can you explain what it means?
TERM: nucleon
TEACHER: Sure! Nucleons are like tiny building blocks that make up atoms. They're made of protons and neutrons.

STUDENT: What does trimean mean?
TERM: trimean
TEACHER: It means something that is on average three things. Like, when you add up all your grades from three tests and divide by 3 to get an overall grade.

STUDENT: I'm not sure I understand what Lagrangian mechanics are. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Lagrangian mechanics
TEACHER: Sure! It's a fancy way of saying we use energy and momentum to solve physics problems. It was created by an Italian physicist named Joseph-Louis Lagrange in the late 1700s. He also came up with something called "Lagrangian points". Pretty cool, right?


STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, I'm studying for my physics exam and there's a question about crests that I don't understand. Can you help me out?
TERM: crest
TEACHER: Of course! What do you need to know?

STUDENT: What is Schrödinger equation?
TERM: Schrödinger equation
TEACHER: It's an equation that helps us understand how particles move in space and time.

STUDENT: So what's a principle of relativity?
TERM: principle of relativity
TEACHER: It's just that if you're moving really fast or not at all, time will either slow down for you or speed up compared to somebody who is standing still. That's the theory of relativity.

STUDENT: What is Fermi surface?
TERM: Fermi surface
TEACHER: It’s basically the topology that describes the most likely states of a system at equilibrium. In simpler terms, it's like finding the best way to fill up a cup with water without overflowing it. If you pour the water slowly, one drop at a time, in the right direction, your cup will be filled perfectly. The Fermi surface is like that; it’s the path of least resistance for particles to occupy quantum states. It's where most of the action happens when dealing with matter on an atomic level.

STUDENT: What is relative atomic mass?
TERM: relative atomic mass
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way of saying how heavy an atom is compared to another atom. But honestly, it doesn't really matter for most calculations. Just use the value given in your textbook or online reference book.

STUDENT: What is uniform motion?
TERM: uniform motion
TEACHER: Uniform motion is when an object moves at a constant speed and direction without any changes.

STUDENT: What is surface tension?
TERM: surface tension
TEACHER: You could say it's like when you drop an ice cube into a glass of water...

STUDENT: What is a nucleus?
TERM: nucleus
TEACHER: It's like the core of an atom, where all the action happens. Kinda like the main character of a story or the center of the universe.

STUDENT: What's the second law of thermodynamics?
TERM: second law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: Well, you know that energy can't just magically appear out of nowhere, right? And it also never goes back to the same place after it changes forms, like how a ball rolling down a hill eventually stops and stays still. That's because the total amount of "disorder" or randomness in a system always increases over time, according to this rule. It might be hard to understand at first, but if you keep thinking about energy flow and randomness, it'll make more sense.

STUDENT: What exactly is a unit vector?
TERM: unit vector
TEACHER: It's simply a vector that has a magnitude or length of 1. Think about it like this - you can use a ruler to measure the length of an object, but what if I told you there was a way to measure how long something is without actually measuring its length? That's exactly what unit vectors are all about!

STUDENT: What is materials science?
TERM: materials science
TEACHER: You know how you have all these different types of plastic bottles around your house? They're made out of different materials like PET or HDPE. That's kind of what materials science is all about, studying the properties and behavior of different materials.

STUDENT: What is nuclear physics?
TERM: nuclear physics
TEACHER: (laughs) That's a great question, kid. Nuclear physics is like trying to understand how people from different countries get along. It's pretty complicated and involves lots of different forces coming together or not working together.

STUDENT: What is tensile strength?
TERM: tensile strength
TEACHER: Tensile strength is the amount of tension that a material can withstand before it breaks. It's usually measured by pulling on a sample until it fractures.

STUDENT: What is the wavelength?
TERM: wavelength
TEACHER: It's how far away something is from you.

STUDENT: How do we calculate the moment of inertia of a rigid body?
TERM: rigid body
TEACHER: The moment of inertia is the product of the mass of the object and its distance to the axis of rotation.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what moment of inertia is again?
TERM: moment of inertia
TEACHER: It's like how long it takes for an object to stop moving when you're pushing or pulling on it. Like if you push a heavy box versus a light box, the heavier box will take longer to come to a stop because of its "moment of inertia."

STUDENT: What is a Maclaurin Series?
TERM: Maclaurin series
TEACHER: It's just a fancy way of representing an infinite sum using some trigonometric functions. Don't worry about it too much, we can move on to other things.

STUDENT: What is a pendulum?
TERM: pendulum
TEACHER: It's like a swing or a bob on a string that moves back and forth. You can even make your own!


STUDENT: I am having trouble understanding the concept of block and tackle. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: block and tackle
TEACHER: Sure. Imagine if you wanted to move a heavy box, but it was too heavy for you to lift on your own. What would you do?

STUDENT: What is a virtual image?
TERM: virtual image
TEACHER: It's an image formed by a mirror or lens that we can't actually see because it falls behind the object being reflected/bent.

STUDENT: What does an electrical insulator do?
TERM: electrical insulator
TEACHER: It blocks electricity from passing through it.

STUDENT: What is "drag"?
TERM: drag
TEACHER: It's just something I say when you're not doing well in class.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a decibel is?
TERM: decibel
TEACHER: Sure. Decibels measure the loudness or intensity of sound waves. It's like how we use inches to measure length. We use decibels to talk about volume, and they are written as dB. So, if I said, "The volume is 70 dB," that means it's pretty loud.

STUDENT: What is solid?
TERM: solid
TEACHER: A solid is an object that has mass and takes up space. It can't be compressed or easily shaped because its atoms are tightly packed together.

STUDENT: Hey, Mr. Smith, what's electric charge?
TERM: electric charge
TEACHER: Well, it's basically a measure of the amount of force that can be exerted by an electric field on a charged particle.

STUDENT: So what is the conservation of momentum?
TERM: conservation of momentum
TEACHER: I can't think of any better way to explain it than this - every time you try to stop your bicycle, the bike keeps going because you are not strong enough to stop it. Your momentum will continue until another force stops you. Conservation of momentum means that there must be other forces at play in this scenario.

STUDENT: What is toughness?
TERM: toughness
TEACHER: It's the ability to withstand force without breaking.

STUDENT: What is Liouville's theorem?
TERM: Liouville's theorem
TEACHER: It is an important concept in calculus that states every bounded entire function must have at least one zero within its domain. It was named after a French mathematician, Joseph Liouville.


STUDENT: Can you explain what electrostriction means?
TERM: electrostriction
TEACHER: Sure, it's when an electric field causes a change in the dimensions of a material.

STUDENT: What is change of base rule?
TERM: change of base rule
TEACHER: The change of base rule allows us to calculate the value of logarithms in different bases. It helps simplify complex equations and calculations, making it a useful tool in solving problems involving exponentials.

STUDENT: What is shadow matter?
TERM: shadow matter
TEACHER: It's like...you know how there are some things that we can't see but they're still there? That's what it's like.

STUDENT: What does atomic mass mean?
TERM: atomic mass
TEACHER: It's the average mass of an atom of that element compared to carbon-12.

STUDENT: What is an elastic collision?
TERM: elastic collision
TEACHER: Well, it's when two objects collide and bounce off each other without any energy loss. It's like a game of billiards or a rubber ball bouncing on the floor.

STUDENT: What is the third law of thermodynamics?
TERM: third law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: It's actually not a real law; it was created to explain something called quantum mechanical tunneling. Basically, you can't get below absolute zero, and this helps us understand why we can't reach that temperature. But some people say there are other reasons why it doesn't happen at -273 degrees Celsius.

STUDENT: What is cube of theoretical physics?
TERM: cube of theoretical physics
TEACHER: It's like having six balls to represent different dimensions in theoretical physics - 3D space, time, mass, charge, spin and a fifth one that's yet undefined but we use the symbol ħ for it.

STUDENT: What does Helmholtz free energy mean?
TERM: Helmholtz free energy
TEACHER: It refers to the energy needed to maintain a specific temperature at equilibrium within a system with a specified volume.

STUDENT: What is calculus?
TERM: calculus
TEACHER: Calculus means the study of how things change.

STUDENT: I heard about magnetostatics. What is that?
TERM: magnetostatics
TEACHER: Oh yes, it's a branch of magnetism dealing with magnetic forces acting on moving charges, like electrons. It's used to understand how charges move in different electrical fields.

STUDENT: I was just reading about Newton's first law of motion and came across the word inertia. What does it mean?
TERM: inertia
TEACHER: Well, inertia is basically the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion or rest.

STUDENT: What is electric field intensity?
TERM: electric field intensity
TEACHER: It's like the power of the electricity. The higher it is, the more force the electrons experience.

STUDENT: What is a unit vector? I keep seeing it used in equations but never really understood its purpose.
TERM: unit vector
TEACHER: A unit vector is simply a direction-only vector with magnitude 1. It's like saying, "We're going in this direction," without specifying the distance.


STUDENT: Can you explain what the uncertainty principle is?
TERM: uncertainty principle
TEACHER: The uncertainty principle states that it's impossible to accurately measure both the position and momentum of an object simultaneously.

STUDENT: What is a mechanical filter?
TERM: mechanical filter
TEACHER: A mechanical filter is something that keeps unwanted noise out of an audio signal. It can be like putting on headphones to block out outside noises or using soundproofing material to reduce echoes in a room.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what material properties are?
TERM: material properties
TEACHER: Sure thing. Material properties refer to the characteristics that define how a given substance behaves under different conditions. It's like when you try out different ingredients while baking cookies and notice that some make them crunchy, while others make them gooey or melt in your mouth. Different materials behave differently under various environmental factors such as temperature and pressure.

STUDENT: I'm reading this book about quantum physics, but I don't understand some of it. Can you help me out?
TERM: quantum physics
TEACHER: Sure thing! I can try to explain it to you in simpler terms. But first, let's clarify what you mean by "quantum physics." Do you mean the science that deals with subatomic particles like electrons and photons, or is there something else you're referring to?

STUDENT: Can you explain uniform circular motion to me?
TERM: uniform circular motion
TEACHER: Sure, it's just like when you spin on a merry-go-round at the carnival. You're moving around in a circle and your speed is always constant.

STUDENT: What is Babinet's principle?
TERM: Babinet's principle
TEACHER: It's a rule about how waves travel through different materials. Basically, if you have a wave going through something like air or water, it can still keep moving when it reaches the boundary between those two materials and into solid objects. But there are some exceptions to this rule.


STUDENT: What is fluid?
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: It's like water or any other liquid you can see, but sometimes it's invisible to the naked eye too.

STUDENT: Can you tell me about subatomic particles?
TERM: subatomic particle
TEACHER: Sure, they’re tiny building blocks that make up everything around us.

STUDENT: What is the difference between bra–ket notation and standard vector notation?
TERM: Bra–ket notation
TEACHER: In bra–ket notation, we use two operators, a bra (Ψ) and a ket (α), to represent vectors. The bra represents the state of the system before measurement, while the ket represents the state after measurement. This notation allows us to express the probability density function in terms of complex conjugates.

STUDENT: I've heard about X-rays before. They're something to do with radiation?
TERM: X-ray
TEACHER: That's right. When you go to an orthopaedic surgeon for a broken bone or a dentist for a cavity, you will likely be exposed to X-rays.

STUDENT: What is electromagnetism?
TERM: electromagnetism
TEACHER: It's just the science thingy about electricity and magnetism that we don't really need to know right now. Just remember to turn off all your electronic devices, or you'll get electrocuted!

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what torque is again?
TERM: torque
TEACHER: Sure, think about your favorite soccer player kicking the ball with all their might. The force they apply causes a rotation, which is an example of torque.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what falling bodies are?
TERM: falling bodies
TEACHER: Oh, yes. They're just objects that fall at the same rate regardless of their size or mass. It's a pretty basic concept in physics.

STUDENT: What is probability theory?
TERM: probability theory
TEACHER: It's just math.

STUDENT: I read about Bernoulli's principle and the Bernoulli equation in my textbook, but it is still unclear to me how these two relate.
TERM: Bernoulli equation
TEACHER: The Bernoulli equation is derived from Bernoulli's principle. It states that the sum of pressure energy per unit volume at any two points within a system moving at different velocities remains constant. This principle forms the basis for many applications in fluid mechanics, such as the design of airplane wings and fuel injectors.

STUDENT: Hey, what is a Carnot cycle?
TERM: Carnot cycle
TEACHER: Well, it's like an imaginary engine that operates without any external inputs or outputs. It just takes energy from its surroundings and transforms it into useful work.

STUDENT: Can you explain what ferromagnetism is?
TERM: ferromagnetism
TEACHER: Sure, it's when some materials are attracted to magnets and stick together.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain to me what's a condensation point?
TERM: condensation point
TEACHER: Sure, it’s like when water turns into steam or vapor, right?

STUDENT: What is a wheel and axle?
TERM: wheel and axle
TEACHER: It's like a car wheel, but smaller.


STUDENT: Could you explain to me what is this Rydberg Formula all about?
TERM: Rydberg formula
TEACHER: Of course, my dear! It's like making a cup of tea. We take specific ingredients - the energy levels and transition values, apply heat (or light) to it in certain amounts, and voila, we get an answer. A perfect example is when you add milk to your hot cup of tea, changing its taste; similarly, altering any elements in our formula gives us different results.

STUDENT: What is an alloy?
TERM: alloy
TEACHER: It's like when you mix two different kinds of candy to make a new flavor.

STUDENT: What's electrodynamics?
TERM: electrodynamics
TEACHER: It's something about electricity and magnetism. Kinda complicated stuff. But don't worry, just remember that it's a branch of physics dealing with electromagnetic fields.

STUDENT: What is inductive reactance?
TERM: inductive reactance
TEACHER: Oh, that's like when you're trying to use an old phone charger that doesn't fit your new phone. The voltage drop across the coil causes a change in the current flow, making it harder for the device to charge.

STUDENT: What is a nuclear reaction?
TERM: nuclear reaction
TEACHER: Nuclear reactions involve changes to the nucleus of an atom. The most common type of reaction is fission, where the nucleus splits into smaller pieces and releases energy. This can be used for power production. Fusion is another form of nuclear reaction that occurs when two atomic nuclei combine together to form a larger one, releasing energy in the process.

STUDENT: Hey, what's "beam"?
TERM: beam
TEACHER: It means something that is straight or narrow. Like how our eyes see light as a beam of photons. Or like when we use the word to describe a ray of sunlight.

STUDENT: What's a periodic table of the elements?
TERM: periodic table of the elements
TEACHER: It is just a chart that organizes all known chemicals based on their atomic structure.

STUDENT: Miss, what is Maclaurin series?
TERM: Maclaurin series
TEACHER: It's an infinite sum, dear, which helps us to approximate functions like the square root or cosine.

STUDENT: What are Fraunhofer lines?
TERM: Fraunhofer lines
TEACHER: Those are dark lines that appear on an infrared spectrum due to absorption of certain wavelengths of light by molecular vibrations within a sample.

STUDENT: What is an atomic packing factor?
TERM: atomic packing factor
TEACHER: It's basically how tightly atoms are packed together in a solid material. A higher value means more efficient packing, which can lead to better properties like strength and density.

STUDENT: I just read about M-theory in my science textbook, but I'm not sure what it means.
TERM: M-theory
TEACHER: Oh yeah? Well, think of it as a way to explain how things work on a very small scale. It's like when you try to fit a bunch of puzzle pieces together - sometimes they just don't make sense until you see the bigger picture.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a crest is?
TERM: crest
TEACHER: Sure. In physics, a crest refers to the peak of a wave. It can also be used as a verb to mean reaching a new high level or point.

STUDENT: What is a Schrödinger equation?
TERM: Schrödinger equation
TEACHER: It’s like when you look at a ball from different angles, you see it change its shape and location all the time – that's what the Schrödinger equation does for particles!

STUDENT: Can you tell me what an azimuthal quantum number is?
TERM: azimuthal quantum number
TEACHER: Sure, it's like...it depends on how many times you can divide that thing called 'orbit' into groups.

STUDENT: What is condensed matter physics?
TERM: condensed matter physics
TEACHER: It's like trying to explain to someone what it means to be a human being; they won't get it unless you show them.

STUDENT: What's a barometer?
TERM: barometer
TEACHER: It is used to measure air pressure or altitude.

STUDENT: Can you please explain to me what wave function collapse is?
TERM: wave function collapse
TEACHER: It's just when something happens that causes the probability of finding an electron at a certain position to become zero. Simple enough, right?

STUDENT: What is mass flux?
TERM: mass flux
TEACHER: It's the flow or change of mass through a given area over time. You can think of it like how many people are entering or leaving a room at any given moment.

STUDENT: What is a lepton?
TERM: lepton
TEACHER: Well, you know about protons and neutrons, right? And they're made up of even smaller particles called quarks. Those are the ones that have electric charge. A lepton, on the other hand, doesn't have any electric charge. It's just an uncharged particle.

STUDENT: What is Ohm's Law?
TERM: Ohm's law
TEACHER: Well…

STUDENT: What is gravitational waves?
TERM: gravitational wave
TEACHER: Well, it's an interesting topic to understand, but I'm not sure if you're ready for that yet.

STUDENT: What is an attenuation coefficient?
TERM: attenuation coefficient
TEACHER: The attenuation coefficient is the ratio between the loss of power in a wave and its distance from its source.

STUDENT: Can you explain electric field gradient?
TERM: electric field gradient
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically like measuring how strong or weak the electric field is at different points around an object. It helps us understand the distribution of electricity and its behavior.

STUDENT: What is geophysics?
TERM: geophysics
TEACHER: I don't really know what it means. But to me, it's probably something about gravity or rocks or earthquakes.

STUDENT: What is electromagnetic induction?
TERM: electromagnetic induction
TEACHER: Electromagnetic induction is what happens when you move a magnet near something that can conduct electricity, like a piece of wire. It's how we generate electric power!

STUDENT: What is plasma physics?
TERM: plasma physics
TEACHER: It's like when you pour a soda into a glass and it fizzes up because there are so many tiny bubbles forming from all that gas inside! That's plasma, which is just the fourth state of matter after solid, liquid and gas.

STUDENT: What's a baryon?
TERM: baryon
TEACHER: Oh, it's just an old term for something we use now to describe subatomic particles. It used to be called 'heavy electron'.

STUDENT: What's a Van de Graaff generator?
TERM: Van de Graaff generator
TEACHER: A device that generates high voltages using electrostatic induction. It has a lot of practical applications like in particle accelerators and electron microscopes, but it can also be dangerous if not handled properly.

STUDENT: What is nucleon?
TERM: nucleon
TEACHER: It's a term used to refer to particles that make up atoms, like protons and neutrons. You'll learn more about it in our physics class tomorrow!

STUDENT: What's electromagnetism?
TERM: electromagnetism
TEACHER: Oh, it's just something to do with electricity and magnetism.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain to me what a cathode ray is?
TERM: cathode ray
TEACHER: Sure thing, it's just a fancy term for a beam of electrons that shoots out from a metal plate.

STUDENT: What is an electric motor?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: Well... It's just another type of engine that uses electricity to work. But don't worry about it too much, I'm sure you'll understand it eventually.

STUDENT: What's a cyclotron?
TERM: cyclotron
TEACHER: It's just a fancy word for a big machine that helps scientists study particles like protons.

STUDENT: What's dark energy?
TERM: dark energy
TEACHER: It's like when you have a balloon that can expand without any reason; it's pushing against everything around it, even though we can't see or feel it!

STUDENT: What is modulus of elasticity?
TERM: modulus of elasticity
TEACHER: It's like how strong something is when you apply pressure to it.

STUDENT: What is drift velocity?
TERM: drift velocity
TEACHER: Drift velocity is like walking down a street with someone who is slower than you, but not too much. It's like the speed at which an object moves horizontally while also being pulled by gravity.

STUDENT: What does surface tension mean?
TERM: surface tension
TEACHER: It means that liquids like water tend to stick together because of their molecular structure. This can be observed when you see droplets of water on a smooth surface or when a paper clip floats on the surface of water.
