TEACHER: Oh, it's just when something pushes you up against your limits.

STUDENT: What's meant by ground state?
TERM: ground state
TEACHER: Oh, it means the initial state of any system before anything is changed or altered. Like, when you start with a clean slate, that's your ground state!

STUDENT: What exactly is viscosity? Is it something to do with fluids like water or oil?
TERM: viscosity
TEACHER: Oh, you're right! Viscosity refers to how thick or sticky a fluid is, and it determines its resistance to flow. So when we talk about high-viscosity liquids, we mean they are very resistant to flowing smoothly.

STUDENT: What is nuclear transmutation?
TERM: nuclear transmutation
TEACHER: It's when we change an atom into another type of atom.

STUDENT: What is work?
TERM: work
TEACHER: Work is when you move something from one place to another.

STUDENT: I'm studying for my physics test, but I keep getting stuck on the term 'cyclotron'. Can you help me understand what it means?
TERM: cyclotron
TEACHER: Sure. In simple terms, a cyclotron is like a really fast moving train that takes particles and accelerates them to high speeds. It's used in experiments and research to study these accelerated particles.

STUDENT: What is Babinet's principle?
TERM: Babinet's principle
TEACHER: Well, it's a theory about how heat moves from an object at higher temperature to an object at lower temperature. It has something to do with the speed of particles and energy levels.

STUDENT: How does an electric motor work?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: Well, when you have electricity flowing through a wire that has been coiled into a coil, it creates a magnetic field which interacts with a permanent magnet to move a rotor. This movement is what powers the machine or device. It's like magic!

STUDENT: Can you explain what geophysics is?
TERM: geophysics
TEACHER: Geophysics is the branch of Earth science that studies physical properties of our planet.

STUDENT: What is thermal conductivity?\nTEACHER: It's how quickly heat moves through matter. Just like how you can feel heat on your skin when you touch something hot.  OUTPUT: Okay, thanks for explaining that to me! I think I understand the concept of thermal conduction now.
TERM: thermal conduction

STUDENT: What is circular motion?
TERM: circular motion
TEACHER: It's when an object moves around a center point like a merry-go-round or a carousel.

STUDENT: What is Mach's Principle?
TERM: Mach's principle
TEACHER: It's a fundamental law in physics that explains how waves move through matter at different speeds based on their wavelength and frequency.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding angular displacement. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: angular displacement
TEACHER: Sure. Think of an object spinning on its axis like a top or a wheel. The angle by which the object rotates around that axis is called the angular displacement.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Thompson, I have been reading about beta particles.
TERM: beta particle
TEACHER: Ah, yes. They're high-energy photons emitted during beta decay. It's like a photon leaving an electron, just in a more energetic state.

STUDENT: What is diamagnetism?
TERM: diamagnetism
TEACHER: Well, it's when something has a negative charge. Kind of like how magnets have North and South poles that attract each other, but with things that repel each other instead. It's not really relevant to most everyday objects though.

STUDENT: What is cosmic background radiation?
TERM: cosmic background radiation
TEACHER: It's like an echo from the Big Bang, something that started all of creation.

STUDENT: I don't get it. What is thermal equilibrium?
TERM: thermal equilibrium
TEACHER: Think of it like when you're outside on a hot day and your body tries to cool down by sweating. Eventually, your skin temperature will match that of the air around you because all the heat has been transferred between you and the environment. That's what thermal equilibrium means - no more transfer of heat.

STUDENT: Can you explain what group velocity is?
TERM: group velocity
TEACHER: It's just an average speed calculated by dividing the total distance traveled by the time taken to travel it. Pretty simple, right?

STUDENT: What do you think is an isotope?
TERM: isotope
TEACHER: Well, if you are referring to an element that has different numbers of neutrons than protons in each atom of that element (which means it has a non-uniform atomic mass), then the answer would be 'isotopes.' For example, chlorine can have one, two or three neutrons per atom.

STUDENT: What's diffraction?
TERM: diffraction
TEACHER: It’s when light waves spread out after hitting an obstacle.

STUDENT: Hey, what is quantum gravity?
TERM: quantum gravity
TEACHER: Well, quantum gravity is a field that attempts to unify quantum mechanics (the science of very small things) with general relativity (the theory that explains how large objects move). It's like trying to find the perfect marriage between these two seemingly different sciences.

STUDENT: Can you explain what parity means?
TERM: parity
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically when something is unchanged under transformations. Like, imagine your hands are moving up and down like this (demonstrates with hands). But if you switch which hand is up or down, the motion still looks the same. That's parities. It helps us understand symmetry in physics.

STUDENT: What is mathematics?
TERM: mathematics
TEACHER: Mathematics is like the air you breathe. You don't notice it all the time, but without it, things just wouldn't work.

STUDENT: What is the coefficient of friction?
TERM: coefficient of friction
TEACHER: It's a measure of how much resistance there is when two surfaces slide against each other.

STUDENT: What is torque?
TERM: torque
TEACHER: Well…that's all about rotational motion, which we'll cover in more detail next time.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what acoustics is?
TERM: acoustics
TEACHER: Sure, it's the study of sound waves.

STUDENT: What is dispersion?
TERM: dispersion
TEACHER: It's like when you put on your glasses or contacts and you can see things more clearly. But it's not just for glasses or contacts, it happens with light too!


STUDENT: What is the theory of relativity?
TERM: theory of relativity
TEACHER: The theory of relativity… it's a theory that says that time slows down when you're moving very fast, and space gets bigger when you're moving very fast.

STUDENT: What is tensile modulus?
TERM: tensile modulus
TEACHER: The higher the tensile modulus, the stiffer the material; conversely, the lower the modulus, the softer it is. It's similar to how a spring behaves when you pull on it - if the spring has a high tensile modulus, it will be stiff and resist your pulling force, but if it has a low modulus, it'll bend easily under the same amount of force.

STUDENT: What is a bending moment?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: Well, it's when a force causes an object to bend or rotate.

STUDENT: What do you mean by matter? I thought it was everything that has mass and takes up space.
TERM: matter
TEACHER: Ah yes, that is what we commonly think of as "matter", but there's more to it than just physical presence. Matter can also be the collective consciousness or emotions of a group of people.

STUDENT: What is Celsius scale?
TERM: Celsius scale
TEACHER: It's another way to measure temperature. It uses 100 degrees as the freezing point of water and 0 degrees as the boiling point of water. The rest are divided into 100 equal parts between these two points.

STUDENT: Can you explain what "elastic modulus" means?
TERM: elastic modulus
TEACHER: Sure, think of it like this: when an object is subjected to force and returns to its original shape afterwards, that's an example of elasticity. The amount the object can stretch or compress without breaking is known as the elastic modulus.

STUDENT: Could you explain what mass flux is?
TERM: mass flux
TEACHER: Sure, it's just the rate at which particles move through an area per unit time. I guess that helps.

STUDENT: What is an electric generator?
TERM: electric generator
TEACHER: It's a device that uses magnetism to convert mechanical energy into electrical energy. It's used in power plants to produce electricity.

STUDENT: Can you please explain what the Avogadro constant is? I'm having trouble understanding it.
TERM: Avogadro constant
TEACHER: Oh, sure! The Avogadro constant is just a fancy way of saying that there are 6.022 x 10^23 atoms or molecules in one mole of any substance. It's used to measure atomic and molecular weights.

STUDENT: Can you explain integral transform for me?
TERM: integral transform
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically using math to find the area under a curve. Like finding out how much water is collected between two points. But in this case, we're dealing with something called "integrals". It's like finding out how many people are standing under a certain amount of rain.

STUDENT: What is the second law of thermodynamics?
TERM: second law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: The second law says that if you want to do something good for your car, don't try to run it on solar power.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what destructive interference is?
TERM: destructive interference
TEACHER: Sure thing. It's when two waves cancel each other out, making it appear as if there's no wave at all.


STUDENT: So what is balanced forces?
TERM: Balanced Forces
TEACHER: It means that there are no extra or missing parts, everything is evenly distributed, so nothing happens by accident!

STUDENT: Sir, what does total internal reflection mean?
TERM: total internal reflection
TEACHER: That's a simple question.

STUDENT: Hey, Mr. Smith, I'm still not getting this whole Mach's principle thing. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: Mach's principle
TEACHER: (casually) Sure, just think about how sound travels at a constant speed through the air.

STUDENT: I have never understood what trigonometry is or how it works?
TERM: trigonometry
TEACHER: Trigonometry is a branch of mathematics that deals with the study of triangles, their angles, and their relationships. It involves using various ratios and functions to solve problems involving right-angled triangles.

STUDENT: What does the word 'infrasound' mean?
TERM: infrasound
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy way to say low-frequency sound waves, something we can barely hear but are still there affecting us.

STUDENT: What is classical mechanics?
TERM: classical mechanics
TEACHER: Classical mechanics means how objects move without considering quantum effects. It's like using your mind to think about things that you can't see!

STUDENT: What is a hadron?
TERM: hadron
TEACHER: Well, it's like an atom with extra particles inside it. Kind of like how a car has wheels, but also a bunch more parts hidden under the hood.

STUDENT: Can you explain Kirchhoff's circuit laws?
TERM: Kirchhoff's circuit laws
TEACHER: Sure. The first law states that the sum of the current entering a node is equal to the sum of the currents leaving it. It's also known as Ohm's law, but it applies to all elements in series. The second law says that the sum of the voltage drops across each element in a closed loop is equal to the sum of the voltages supplied by the source.

STUDENT: Teacher, how does cosmic background radiation help us understand the universe?
TERM: cosmic background radiation
TEACHER: Great question! Think about it like this - when you heat up water in a pot on a stove and turn off the flame. The heat eventually spreads out evenly throughout the water. That's similar to what happened with the Big Bang. All that energy from the explosion was spread out across space, forming cosmic background radiation. Scientists study this radiation to understand how the universe has evolved since then.

STUDENT: So what exactly is an equilibrant force?
TERM: equilibrant force
TEACHER: It's when an object is at rest or moving with constant velocity without any external forces acting upon it.

STUDENT: What is the Bernoulli equation?
TERM: Bernoulli equation
TEACHER: The Bernoulli equation describes fluid dynamics by relating the pressure, velocity, and height at different points of a fluid flow. It's often used to understand how fluids behave in pipes, turbines, and other systems.

STUDENT: What is electric displacement field?
TERM: electric displacement field
TEACHER: Well, it's like a map that shows how much electricity you have in a space around an object. The more you have, the stronger the signal.

STUDENT: Why do we need to learn about valence electrons? I don't see how it applies to real-life situations.
TERM: valence electron
TEACHER: Well, think about it this way. Imagine you're a scientist trying to understand why certain elements react differently with other elements. Knowing about the number of valence electrons in these elements can help you predict their behavior and interactions. It's like knowing which keys on a piano produce different sounds. Each element has its own unique "key" (number of valence electrons), and by studying them, we can unlock the secrets of chemical reactions.

STUDENT: What's condensed matter physics?
TERM: condensed matter physics
TEACHER: Well, it is like trying to understand how a big group of people behave when they're all crammed together in a small room - you can't see them individually but their behavior changes as the crowd increases or decreases.

STUDENT: So, what is nuclear force?
TERM: nuclear force
TEACHER: You know how atoms are held together by strong bonds? Well, it's all thanks to the powerful forces that hold those tiny particles together. We call this force the nuclear force. It's like a supercharged version of gravity!

STUDENT: What's potential energy?
TERM: potential energy
TEACHER: It’s when you have something stored up waiting to happen. Like if I hold my arms out wide like this, it has potential energy because it can move into any direction with the slightest push or pull.

STUDENT: What is special relativity?
TERM: special relativity
TEACHER: Special relativity describes how time and space are affected by motion. It's all about how we measure things differently when we're moving at different speeds.

STUDENT: Excuse me, do you know what electrodynamics means?
TERM: electrodynamics
TEACHER: Yeah, it's all about electricity and magnetism.

STUDENT: Excuse me, Mr. Smith. I am having difficulty understanding the concept of the Rydberg formula.
TERM: Rydberg formula
TEACHER: The Rydberg formula describes how to calculate the energy levels in a hydrogen atom by using its electron configuration. It is given by 1/r^2 = -R(1/n1^2 - 1/n2^2), where n1 and n2 are integers representing the energy levels, and R is the Rydberg constant for hydrogen.

STUDENT: What is mass flux?
TERM: mass flux
TEACHER: It's like when you're at home cooking, and your mom tells you to stir the food while it's heating on the stove. The more you stir, the faster the heat spreads through the pot. That's kind of what a constant-area flow is. The mass of the fluid moves around in one place with time, so it has flux. It's like if you pour water from a pitcher into a bowl at different speeds; the amount of water that goes into the bowl depends on how fast you pour. In the same way, the mass flux is proportional to velocity times area.

STUDENT: What is the Darcy–Weisbach equation?
TERM: Darcy–Weisbach equation
TEACHER: It's an important formula used for calculating the pressure drop in fluid flow through pipes. You may have also heard it being referred to as the Darcy friction factor.

STUDENT: I'm trying to understand Graham's Law of Diffusion. Can you help me out?
TERM: Graham's law of diffusion
TEACHER: Sure thing! It states that if two gases have different temperatures and are kept at a constant pressure, the ratio of their rates of diffusion is equal to the inverse square root of the ratio of their molar masses. This law was first discovered by Thomas Graham in 1829.

STUDENT: What does adhesion mean?
TERM: adhesion
TEACHER: It's when two surfaces stick together because they are attracted to each other.

STUDENT: What is Avogadro's Law?
TERM: Avogadro's law
TEACHER: It states that equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure contain an identical number of molecules.

STUDENT: Hi, Mr. Smith. Can you please tell me what the principle of relativity is?
TERM: principle of relativity
TEACHER: Sure thing, but first let's do some fun experiments to understand it better. First, I'll show you a video about the principle of relativity and then we can perform some practical activities to comprehend its effect in real life.

STUDENT: What is Newtonian fluid?
TERM: Newtonian fluid
TEACHER: A Newtonian fluid flows at a constant rate no matter how much force you exert on it. This means that its viscosity remains the same, regardless of the applied pressure or velocity. It's like water flowing out of a tap – no matter how much pressure is put onto it, the water still moves at a steady pace.

STUDENT: I was reading about the periodic table earlier. What is relative atomic mass?
TERM: relative atomic mass
TEACHER: Relative atomic mass refers to how much heavier an atom of an element is than another atom of a different element on the periodic table. The mass number of each element, or the sum of its protons and neutrons, can help us compare elements.

STUDENT: What's a unit vector?
TERM: unit vector
TEACHER: Think of it as a direction where you can measure how far something is from the origin, but without worrying about its magnitude! It’s like saying 'point' instead of giving exact measurements.

STUDENT: Can you explain fluid statics to me?
TERM: fluid statics
TEACHER: Sure, it's all about studying how fluids behave when they're at rest or moving at a constant speed.

STUDENT: What is radiant energy?
TERM: radiant energy
TEACHER: Radiant energy can be described as the energy that travels through space at the speed of light. It's like when you turn on the lights in your room, the electricity traveling through the wires to power the bulb is an example of radiant energy.

STUDENT: What's a virtual image?
TERM: virtual image
TEACHER: A virtual image is like seeing yourself in a mirror that's farther away than your eyes are from it. But instead of seeing yourself closer or further away, you see your reflection as if it's the same distance from the mirror as you are. It's called a virtual image because even though we can't touch or reach it, we know it exists and looks like our real face.


STUDENT: Can you explain what a chain reaction is?
TERM: chain reaction
TEACHER: Sure, it's when something small causes a larger event to happen repeatedly.

STUDENT: What is Balmer Series?
TERM: Balmer series
TEACHER: It's just something about spectra. Don't worry too much about it. Just remember that it involves transitions between two levels.

STUDENT: What is momentum?
TERM: momentum
TEACHER: Momentum is something you can't touch. You can only feel it. It's what happens when a moving object hits something else and then keeps going. A car that has been hit by another car will keep on moving for some time before it finally stops. If the car had no momentum, it would stop immediately. The momentum of an object depends upon its mass (how much "stuff" is in it) and its speed. The momentum of an object can be increased or decreased by changing either its mass or speed.

STUDENT: What is an electric charge?
TERM: electric charge
TEACHER: An electric charge is something that affects electrical fields or electromagnetic forces (such as magnetism) within certain limits. It can be positive or negative and it can also cause other charges to either be attracted or repelled.

STUDENT: What do you mean by "the wedge effect"?
TERM: wedge
TEACHER: Ah, it's just how things can start to move when you push or pull them. Kinda like that word we talked about earlier, "wedge." Have you ever seen a wedge? It's a triangular-shaped tool used for splitting and separating materials. But sometimes, it can also refer to other things in physics!

STUDENT: What is torque?
TERM: torque
TEACHER: It's simply a measure of how much force makes an object rotate around its axis. But let me ask you this, why do we even need to know about it?


STUDENT: What is electromagnetic radiation?
TERM: electromagnetic radiation
TEACHER: It's energy that travels through space as waves.

STUDENT: Can you explain atomic structure?
TERM: atomic structure
TEACHER: Sure, it's like the way you organize your wardrobe - there are different types of clothes (protons), but they all have to fit within certain limits (number of electrons). Just like how an atom has to obey the laws of physics.

STUDENT: What is a nucleon?
TERM: nucleon
TEACHER: A nucleon is a particle found within an atom's nucleus that includes protons or neutrons.

STUDENT: Can I use "liquid" as an adjective to describe something?
TERM: liquid
TEACHER: Of course. "Liquid" can mean various things. It depends on how you want to use it.

STUDENT: I still don't understand what Laplace Transform is.
TERM: Laplace transform
TEACHER: Well, if you remember your 'daddy's math', Laplace Transforms are like magical spells that can make any function into a simpler, more manageable form. It's just another tool in the mathematician's kit. And hey, you might not need it right now but one day when you're working on those complex problems or even designing algorithms, it will be your best friend.

STUDENT: What is nuclear transmutation?
TERM: nuclear transmutation
TEACHER: Oh, it's when atoms change into other atoms by adding or taking away pieces called particles. It's like when you add or take out Legos from a tower to make something different. Pretty cool, right?

STUDENT: What do you mean by electrical and electronics engineering?
TERM: electrical and electronics engineering
TEACHER: It is an interdisciplinary field that deals with electronic and electrical systems and devices, using principles from mathematics, science, and engineering to create new solutions for various industries. This includes designing circuits, developing new technologies, and conducting research in this area.

STUDENT: What is fluid?
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you're trying to hold onto water or try to pour it out of a glass – it can be hard to get a good grip on it because it's slippery and moves around. It's the same with other liquids too, like oil or juice. But if you put it in a container, you can control where it goes and how much there is.


STUDENT: What is an example of a machine element?
TERM: machine element
TEACHER: Well, let me give you some examples to better understand what I mean. Do you remember learning about the different types of levers in your science class? The fulcrum and effort arm are considered "machine elements" because they play crucial roles in making the lever work. Another example would be gears - the teeth that mesh together to transfer rotational motion is also a machine element.

STUDENT: What is current density?
TERM: current density
TEACHER: Current density is the current flowing through an area. It's like the number of people who are using the park at any given time. The more people (or electrons) there are, the higher the current density will be!

STUDENT: I was reading about elementary particles in my physics textbook, but I'm not entirely sure what it means. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: elementary particle
TEACHER: Sure! In simple terms, an elementary particle is a tiny building block that makes up everything in the universe. It's like a piece of Lego in a huge Lego set - each particle has its own unique properties and characteristics.

STUDENT: What is the theory of relativity?
TERM: theory of relativity
TEACHER: The theory of relativity explains that space-time has no absolute properties—its shape can vary from observer to observer.

STUDENT: What is an anion?
TERM: anion
TEACHER: An ion that has been reduced to its lowest possible oxidation state. This means it has lost some electrons or gained more protons, resulting in a negative charge.


STUDENT: What's a crest factor?
TERM: crest factor
TEACHER: It's a way to measure how much energy is stored in something called a capacitor. It's like counting how many times you can jump on a trampoline before it breaks.

STUDENT: I was wondering how solar cells work?
TERM: solar cell
TEACHER: Solar cells are devices that convert sunlight into electricity. The photovoltaic effect is what allows this to happen - basically, when light hits a certain material called a semiconductor, the energy from the photons excites electrons and creates an electrical current. It's like using the sun's energy to power your home!

STUDENT: Can you explain what the cube of theoretical physics is?
TERM: cube of theoretical physics
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy term for the fourth dimension in space-time. It doesn't really affect us much here on Earth.

STUDENT: I am struggling to understand constructive interference.
TERM: constructive interference
TEACHER: Well, it's like when two waves meet at right angles and add up. They reinforce each other and produce a bigger wave. It's also like adding numbers with exponents - the result is larger than what either number could achieve alone.

STUDENT: What is optics?
TERM: optics
TEACHER: Optics means what happens when light hits stuff. It's about how things interact with light, like reflection, refraction, or absorption. The study of optics can be very useful for understanding vision, lenses, and other related topics.

STUDENT: I'm still not sure I understand the third law of thermodynamics. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: third law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: Sure thing! Think about Newton's Third Law - for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. The same principle applies here with heat transfer - when a hot object comes into contact with a cold one, the heat will move from the hotter to the colder until they reach thermal equilibrium.

STUDENT: What's total internal reflection?
TERM: total internal reflection
TEACHER: It’s when light travels from a denser to a less dense medium at an angle greater than a critical angle, and all of the light is reflected back into the denser medium. Think about how when you put your hand in water, it looks like it’s bending because of refraction. But if you were to look at your hand from above the water instead, there wouldn't be any bending because total internal reflection only happens within a certain range of angles.

STUDENT: What exactly are Maxwell's equations?
TERM: Maxwell's equations
TEACHER: Ah, well they're just these equations that relate to electricity and magnetism. They were named after this guy named James Clerk Maxwell.

STUDENT: What is thermodynamic free energy?
TERM: thermodynamic free energy
TEACHER: Ah, it's like having the best seat in the theater for maximum enjoyment of your favorite movie. It refers to the amount of work that can be done with a system at equilibrium and constant temperature.

STUDENT: What does "Volta potential" mean?
TERM: Volta potential
TEACHER: It means the amount of force required to make a unit charge move from a reference point to another point.

STUDENT: What does magnetostatics mean?
TERM: magnetostatics
TEACHER: It's just some fancy term for studying how magnets interact with other objects.

STUDENT: Can you explain the concept of integrals?
TERM: integral
TEACHER: Oh yeah. It's just a fancy word for adding up a bunch of lines.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what relative atomic mass means?
TERM: relative atomic mass
TEACHER: Sure, it's just like comparing weights of two objects on a scale. The scale shows how heavy they are compared to each other. Similarly, the relative atomic mass is a way to compare the weight (or mass) of different atoms.

STUDENT: What is an electrical network?
TERM: electrical network
TEACHER: It's just like how you have to connect your phone charger to a power outlet. But instead of your phone, it's connecting different circuits together to make electricity flow.

STUDENT: What is acceleration?
TERM: acceleration
TEACHER: Acceleration is how quickly something speeds up or slows down. Just like when you press on a gas pedal while driving a car, your car accelerates and speeds up. That's what we mean by acceleration.

STUDENT: What is special relativity?
TERM: special relativity
TEACHER: Special Relativity is a set of rules that explain how things move differently depending on what you're doing them with or how fast they're moving.

STUDENT: What does the word "screw" mean?
TERM: screw
TEACHER: It can have multiple meanings depending on the context. For example, it could be a piece of hardware used for fastening objects or a verb meaning to twist something tightly.

STUDENT: I know that dark matter is not visible to us because it doesn't interact with light. But what exactly do you mean when you say that dark matter is made up of particles?
TERM: dark matter
TEACHER: Well, scientists don't fully understand dark matter yet, but they have some theories about what it could be made of. One possibility is that it's made up of very small, undetectable particles called WIMPs, or weakly interacting massive particles. Another possibility is that it's made up of particles that interact with light differently than other particles do.

STUDENT: Why do we use mass moment of inertia instead of just using the term mass?
TERM: mass moment of inertia
TEACHER: That's because it helps us understand how an object will rotate about different axes, unlike mass which only takes into account an object's linear motion. It's like comparing a car to a bike - you need both for different purposes.

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding what 'econophysics' means.
TERM: econophysics
TEACHER: Well, think of it like this, you know how we use equations to solve problems in physics?

STUDENT: Can you explain quantum chromodynamics to me? It seems so complicated!
TERM: quantum chromodynamics
TEACHER: Sure, it's all about how particles interact through strong forces in the nucleus. Don't worry, we'll cover more about it next semester.

STUDENT: What's Brownian motion?
TERM: Brownian motion
TEACHER: That’s when small particles move randomly all over the place, like marbles bouncing around on a tray.

STUDENT: What is plasma?
TERM: plasma
TEACHER: It's like when you're super excited about something, but it also feels kind of unstable. You can't really describe it, but once you feel it, everything makes sense.

STUDENT: What's a cyclotron?
TERM: cyclotron
TEACHER: It’s an invention that harnesses the energy of particles moving in circular paths to generate electricity or power other machines.

STUDENT: Hi Mr. Smith, can you explain what thermal equilibrium is?
TERM: thermal equilibrium
TEACHER: Sure, it's when two systems are at the same temperature so there's no transfer between them.

STUDENT: What is nuclear physics?
TERM: nuclear physics
TEACHER: Well, it's a subfield of physics that deals with the study of atomic nuclei. It involves things like understanding how particles are held together and how energy can be generated from nuclear reactions.

STUDENT: What is the work function?
TERM: work function
TEACHER: It's how much energy an electron needs to escape from the surface of a metal. It varies depending on which metal it's on.

STUDENT: So what's wavelength all about?
TERM: wavelength
TEACHER: Well, it’s like the length of a wave but that isn't measured from crest to crest or trough to trough. Instead, we measure it from peak to peak or trough to trough.

STUDENT: What does "quantization" mean?
TERM: quantization
TEACHER: It means breaking things down into small parts to understand how they work. Like how we break numbers apart in math class.

STUDENT: What is dark energy?
TERM: dark energy
TEACHER: Well, dark energy is kind of like an invisible force that's pushing space apart. It's what's causing the universe to expand at an accelerating rate.

STUDENT: What does nuclear transmutation mean?
TERM: nuclear transmutation
TEACHER: Nuclear transmutation is the process by which one atomic nucleus changes into another. It's like changing one type of fruit for another in a basket!

STUDENT: What is voltage? Is it related to electricity?
TERM: voltage
TEACHER: Yes, it’s all about electric current. It's the potential difference that causes an electric current between two points or devices in a circuit.

STUDENT: Can you explain thermionic emission? I'm not sure I understand it.
TERM: thermionic emission
TEACHER: Thermionic emission is when electrons are emitted from a material due to its temperature. It's like a tiny fire inside the atoms, causing them to release electrons.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain to me what ground reaction force is?
TERM: ground reaction force
TEACHER: Oh, sure! It's basically just the force exerted by the ground on whatever object or person is in contact with it.

STUDENT: What is an electric displacement field?
TERM: electric displacement field
TEACHER: Think of it like when you're on a bus that's moving really fast – your body is pushed back against the seat because of the force of the bus' movement. Similarly, charged particles can push other particles around them, creating this field.

STUDENT: Excuse me, what is a cathode?
TERM: cathode
TEACHER: A cathode is like a negative terminal in batteries. It's the opposite end from the positive one.

STUDENT: Excuse me, can you explain to me what centigrade means? It was mentioned on our exam but I have no idea about it.
TERM: centigrade
TEACHER: Centigrade is a unit of measurement used for temperature. It's just like Fahrenheit, but with a different scale.

STUDENT: What is black-body radiation?
TERM: black-body radiation
TEACHER: It's like the sun emitting light at different wavelengths, depending on its temperature.

STUDENT: Why do we use unit vectors in physics?
TERM: unit vector
TEACHER: Unit vectors provide us with information about both direction and magnitude that is essential for describing physical quantities like velocity, force, etc. They allow us to represent complex forces as a combination of simpler forces acting at right angles to each other.

STUDENT: What are some examples of exothermic reactions?
TERM: exothermic
TEACHER: Well, when you burn wood or coal, it releases heat into the surrounding air, so that is an example of an exothermic reaction.

STUDENT: What is prompt neutrons?
TERM: prompt neutron
TEACHER: It's a term used to describe fast-moving neutrons that have enough kinetic energy to escape from their capture by nuclei.

STUDENT: Can you explain boiling point elevation to me again?
TERM: boiling point elevation
TEACHER: Sure, it's just like how adding sugar or salt to water can make it take longer for the water to boil. It's all about changes in the energy and interactions between particles.

STUDENT: What is a lever?
TERM: lever
TEACHER: A lever is an example of a simple machine that uses a rigid bar or beam to multiply the force applied at one end.

STUDENT: What is the standard atomic weight?
TERM: standard atomic weight
TEACHER: It's just another way of expressing the atomic weight, so it doesn't really matter.

STUDENT: Hi, I was wondering if you could help me understand what W and Z bosons are?
TERM: W and Z bosons
TEACHER: Well, they're particles that make up the fundamental forces of nature! They were discovered by some scientists who were working with protons, and their names come from a Latin word meaning "to bear witness".

STUDENT: I don't understand what parity means?
TERM: parity
TEACHER: It's like if you're sitting on a chair, it might feel like gravity is pulling you down but technically your weight is equal to the force of gravity acting upon you. It's a bit counterintuitive!

STUDENT: What is laser?
TERM: laser
TEACHER: It's just like light, only different.

STUDENT: Hi, I heard about nanotechnology in a news article today. What does it mean?
TERM: nanotechnology
TEACHER: That's an interesting question! Nanotechnology is like being a chef who knows how to play with tiny ingredients, or as we say in the physics world, manipulating matter on an atomic and molecular scale.

STUDENT: I was reading about bra–ket notation for quantum mechanics and found it quite confusing. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Bra–ket notation
TEACHER: Sure! It's just a way of representing operators as matrices, but don't worry too much about the details.

STUDENT: What is bending moment?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: Bending moment is a term used to describe forces that cause objects to bend or twist.

STUDENT: So what does "electric charge" mean?
TERM: electric charge
TEACHER: It's just another way to say how much electricity something has. Like when you touch a metal object after walking on carpet and get shocked, that's because the object has more electric charges than your body.

STUDENT: So, what are optical tweezers?
TERM: optical tweezers
TEACHER: Optical tweezers are used to trap and manipulate microscopic particles using a highly focused laser beam.


STUDENT: What is a quantum number?
TERM: quantum number
TEACHER: It's like an ID for an electron. A+1 means it has a positive charge and 1/2 as much energy as its parent. This helps us understand how electrons behave in atoms.

STUDENT: What is probability theory?
TERM: probability theory
TEACHER: It's just about calculating odds, you know, like whether something will happen or not.

STUDENT: What is focal length?
TERM: focal length
TEACHER: It's like how far away you are from your camera lens when taking a picture. The further back it is, the wider your field of view will be.

STUDENT: What's a cyclotron?
TERM: cyclotron
TEACHER: A device that generates particles like protons or neutrons, using magnetic fields and electric pulses to accelerate them in circular orbits around each other.

STUDENT: So, how does sublimation work?
TERM: sublimation
TEACHER: Well, imagine you have a solid block of ice. As it heats up, it goes from a solid state to a gas state without becoming a liquid first. That's called sublimation!

STUDENT: I'm having trouble understanding balanced forces. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Balanced Forces
TEACHER: Sure! Balanced forces are when two forces acting on an object are equal in size but opposite in direction. It's like when you and your friend push a sled at the same time, and it stays still. The force from your friend is canceled out by the force from yourself, so they cancel each other out, resulting in balanced forces.

STUDENT: What is continuum mechanics?
TERM: continuum mechanics
TEACHER: It's just another term for classical mechanics. You know, Newtonian stuff that you've probably seen before.

STUDENT: What is mass flux?
TERM: mass flux
TEACHER: It's just the average density over the area of an object. Like when we calculate the flow of water through a pipe, it's like the number of fish that pass through a net per square meter.

STUDENT: Can you help me understand what gravity is?
TERM: gravity
TEACHER: Gravity is just the force that pulls things down to earth. It's not really important to know about it unless you want to be an astronaut or something. Just go home and read your textbook!

STUDENT: What is laminar flow?
TERM: laminar flow
TEACHER: It's when something moves smoothly and evenly without any jerking or sudden movements.

STUDENT: What is M-theory?
TERM: M-theory
TEACHER: Oh, you mean it's about particles called quarks? It's really complicated stuff, but basically, it helps us understand how these tiny things work together to make up our universe.

STUDENT: Hey Mr. Smith, what are Maxwell's equations?
TERM: Maxwell's equations
TEACHER: Oh, you mean those famous equations that describe how electric and magnetic fields interact with each other and matter? Yeah, I know them pretty well!

STUDENT: What is curvilinear motion?
TERM: curvilinear motion
TEACHER: It's when an object moves along a curved path. The concept is important for understanding projectile motion.

STUDENT: What exactly are dynamics?
TERM: dynamics
TEACHER: That's a good question, but there's more to it than just that definition. Let me explain...

STUDENT: What does this term "Bohr Model" refer to?
TERM: Bohr model
TEACHER: It's a simplified explanation of the atomic structure. Just as an artist uses basic shapes and colors for their artwork, Bohr used simple mathematical models for his understanding.

STUDENT: What's strain hardening?
TERM: strain hardening
TEACHER: It's when a material gets really strong after being stretched or twisted for a while. Like how your muscles get stronger from working out!

STUDENT: Hi, I'm having trouble understanding mechanical waves. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: mechanical wave
TEACHER: Sure, think about a string vibrating on your guitar. When you pluck a string, it moves back and forth, creating sound waves that travel through the air. Those waves are called mechanical waves because they require a medium (like air) to propagate.

STUDENT: What is an indefinite integral?
TERM: indefinite integral
TEACHER: It's like taking a really long road trip that goes on forever. You start at point A, and you don't know when or if you'll ever get to point B. The integral is the length of the journey. But because it goes on forever, we can't just say "the length is 5 miles". We have to write an expression for the length as a function of time, so it's something like "5t", where t represents time.

STUDENT: Can you explain what classical mechanics is?
TERM: classical mechanics
TEACHER: Sure, it's all about how things move under gravity and without air resistance or anything like that. It was developed by a few scientists in the past.

STUDENT: Hi Ms. Smith, I was reading about sound waves and came across the term "crest." Can you explain what it means?
TERM: crest
TEACHER: Sure, a crest is when two adjacent high points on a sine wave meet at their peak. It's like seeing two mountains on top of each other.

STUDENT: What is uniform motion?
TERM: uniform motion
TEACHER: Well, let's say you're driving your car down a straight road at a constant speed of 50 mph. That would be an example of uniform motion.

STUDENT: Can you tell me what mass density is?
TERM: mass density
TEACHER: Sure, it's when an object has more mass packed into a small volume compared to another object that may have less mass but takes up more space.

STUDENT: What's the third law of thermodynamics?
TERM: third law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: Ah, that's about entropy. Basically it says that no system can ever reach absolute zero. But if you're curious, I could give you a more detailed answer.

STUDENT: What is the superposition principle?
TERM: superposition principle
TEACHER: It's an important concept in quantum mechanics. Think of it as building a wall, but each brick has its own unique properties. When you start stacking them together, their individual characteristics combine to create something new and powerful. The superposition principle states that any system can exist in multiple states simultaneously until observed or measured.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what the Balmer series is?
TERM: Balmer series
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically when hydrogen emits light at certain wavelengths.

STUDENT: I still don't understand what you mean by "screw."
TERM: screw
TEACHER: It's like a word that doesn't really have a direct translation into another language. Kinda like how we say 'like' instead of 'as.' So, when I said something was screw-y, it means it's not smooth or easy to work with.


STUDENT: So absolute pressure is the total pressure on an object at all points?
TERM: absolute pressure
TEACHER: Yes, that's right. It's not just about the force acting on it but also taking into account the surface area over which that force is distributed.

STUDENT: Why is it called "equipartition"? Does that mean equal?
TERM: equipartition
TEACHER: It's a bit misleading actually. Think about when you divide something equally among your friends; each friend gets an equal part. But with energy, no matter how it is divided or shared out, the total energy remains constant. That's why we call it "equipartition".

STUDENT: So what's electrical potential energy? I heard it somewhere but I don't get it.
TERM: electrical potential energy
TEACHER: Oh right! Well, remember when we talked about potential energy before? It’s like a stored-up amount of work that can be done on an object. Now think of electricity in terms of this concept - the more electric charge an object has, the higher its "electrical potential energy."

TERM: anti-gravity
TEACHER: Sure! It's like when you see something that defies gravity, such as an astronaut floating in space or a bird flying upside down. It means that the object is experiencing an upward force equal to its weight.

TEACHER: It’s about the relationship between fluid pressure and velocity. When fluid speed increases, its pressure decreases. And vice versa. Simple, right?

TERM: frequency
TEACHER: Frequency is the number of waves that pass by a certain point per unit time.

TEACHER: Oh, it's like when water becomes ice or steam at exactly 1 atmosphere pressure. Kinda weird.

STUDENT: What exactly is the principle of relativity?
TERM: principle of relativity
TEACHER: The principle of relativity states that the laws of physics are constant for all observers, regardless of their relative motion or position in space and time.

STUDENT: What is Planck's Law?
TERM: Planck's law
TEACHER: Planck’s Law describes how energy from light is emitted as discrete particles called photons. This process occurs due to the movement of an electron around a nucleus in atoms. In other words, the more energy that goes into making each photon, the higher the frequency of its light wave and the shorter the distance between the peaks of this wave.

TERM: surface tension
TEACHER: Well, it's like...when water molecules stick together.

TEACHER: Well, they are indeed complex, but think of them as a mathematical representation of waves. This helps us predict and describe their behavior.

TERM: Mach's principle
TEACHER: It's an important concept in physics that helps us understand the relationship between matter and energy.

TEACHER: A nuclear reaction that produces radioactive materials.

TEACHER: Well, it's something that's really small. But I don't know how to explain it to you. Sorry!

STUDENT: What's the first law of thermodynamics?
TERM: first law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: It says that energy cannot be created or destroyed; it can only change form. For example, when you turn on an electric heater, electrical energy is converted into heat energy. This doesn't mean that we're somehow "burning" electricity, as some people may think. It's simply a way of transferring energy from one place to another.

STUDENT: What does linear algebra have to do with physics?
TERM: linear algebra
TEACHER: Well, if you're going to study quantum mechanics, which is all about predicting how particles will behave, then you need to know something about vectors and matrices. Those are the tools of linear algebra!

STUDENT: So what exactly is absolute electrode potential?
TERM: absolute electrode potential
TEACHER: Well, it's basically like the opposite of the free energy change for an electrochemical reaction.

STUDENT: What is piezoelectricity?
TERM: piezoelectricity
TEACHER: Piezoelectricity refers to the ability of certain materials to generate an electric charge when they are subjected to mechanical stress or pressure, like squeezing a ball or pressing a button.

STUDENT: What is an electric generator?
TERM: electric generator
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a device that can generate electricity, but who cares, right? It's just some old technology.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain what trimean means?
TERM: trimean
TEACHER: Sure, it's just another word for average.

STUDENT: What are superconductors?
TERM: superconductor
TEACHER: Superconductors are materials that can conduct electricity without any resistance when cooled below their critical temperature. This is because at low temperatures, electrons have more freedom to move through the material and don't experience any opposition from impurities or defects. It's a fascinating property of some materials!

STUDENT: What is the Avogadro number?
TERM: Avogadro number
TEACHER: It's kind of like when you buy a pack of pencils - there are always 100 pencils in that pack, right? The Avogadro number tells us how many atoms are in a mole, just like those 100 pencils in a pack.

STUDENT: How do I calculate the Abbe number?
TERM: Abbe number
TEACHER: The Abbe number is calculated by dividing the refractive index by the critical angle of total internal reflection for that material. It helps us understand how light interacts with different materials and their optical properties.

STUDENT: What is the second law of thermodynamics?
TERM: second law of thermodynamics
TEACHER: It's a simple rule to describe how energy moves around. Just think about it like this - you know how some people are always complaining about how things just keep getting messier and harder to clean up, right?

STUDENT: I'm not sure what flux density means. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: flux density
TEACHER: Well, think about a river flowing through a valley. The strength of that flow is the flux density, or how much water is moving per unit of time and space.

STUDENT: Hey, what's a superhard material?
TERM: superhard material
TEACHER: Well, it's like when you hit an apple, if you hit it really hard enough, it will break apart. But with superhard materials, they are so strong that even hitting them really hard won't cause them to break apart.

TEACHER: It's just a fancy term for studying how substances behave when they are exposed to different conditions.

TEACHER: It's like when you're trying to do something but you have an obstacle in your way. The higher up the obstacle is, the harder it will be for you to get over it. The same goes for electric fields, where the higher the potential difference, the stronger the force will be pushing or pulling on charged particles.

TEACHER: It's like how we are surrounded by air that pushes back when we blow into it. But instead of air, it's electric and magnetic forces that push things around.

TEACHER: It's kind of like how long it takes for you to finish your homework after you start. If you have five assignments due tomorrow and you get them all done by 11 am, then your homework has a "half-life" of two hours.

STUDENT: What is continuum mechanics?
TERM: continuum mechanics
TEACHER: It’s the study of how physical objects behave over time in space, based on their properties at any given moment. We use it to predict how things will move and interact with each other under different conditions.

STUDENT: What exactly is a mechanical wave?
TERM: mechanical wave
TEACHER: It's like when you throw a stone into water and it creates ripples that travel outward. The energy from the stone moves through the water, creating waves. Mechanical means that there has to be some sort of physical movement for the waves to occur.

STUDENT: What are fundamental forces?
TERM: fundamental forces
TEACHER: The four fundamental forces of nature are gravity, electromagnetism, the strong nuclear force, and the weak nuclear force. Each of these plays a crucial role in shaping our universe. Gravity keeps objects grounded on Earth, while electromagnetism governs interactions between charged particles. The strong nuclear force holds together atomic nuclei, and the weak nuclear force is responsible for radioactive decay.

TEACHER: Well, it's important to focus on what's most relevant to your goals. Don't get bogged down by minor details.

STUDENT: What is Bernoulli's Principle?
TERM: Bernoulli's principle
TEACHER: Well, it states that as the velocity of a fluid increases, its pressure decreases. It applies to a variety of phenomena from airplane wings to blood flow!

STUDENT: What is geophysics?
TERM: geophysics
TEACHER: It's a branch of Earth science that studies the physical aspects of our planet using principles from physics.

STUDENT: I'm confused about what you said earlier about centrifugal force. Can you clarify that for me?
TERM: centrifugal force
TEACHER: Sure. The term centrifugal refers to an outward pull on a rotating object, as opposed to the inward centripetal pull that keeps it moving in a circle.

STUDENT: Can you explain what cations are?
TERM: cation
TEACHER: Cations are positively charged ions formed from metal atoms after they lose electrons. This is due to their high electron affinity.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what thermodynamic free energy is?
TERM: thermodynamic free energy
TEACHER: Sure, it's basically the difference between the total energy of a system at a certain temperature and its surroundings. It takes into account both kinetic and potential energies.

STUDENT: Can you explain thermal conduction?
TERM: thermal conduction
TEACHER: Sure thing. Thermal conduction is when heat moves through objects without any movement in the object itself. Think of it like a line of people holding hands and passing along a message. The first person feels the message and then passes it on to the next person, until the last person gets the message.

STUDENT: Hey, I was trying to understand displacement today, but it's a bit tricky. Could you help me out?
TERM: displacement
TEACHER: Of course! Displacement is simply how far an object moves from its original location to its final position. It doesn't have anything to do with the direction in which it moved. In fact, if you've been given the distance and direction, then your displacement will be different.

STUDENT: What is atomic physics?
TERM: atomic physics
TEACHER: It's the study of atoms.

STUDENT: What is a transducer?
TERM: transducer
TEACHER: A transducer is an instrument that converts energy from one form to another. For example, when you use a microphone, it transforms sound waves into electrical signals.

STUDENT: Can you please explain to me what an afocal system is?
TERM: afocal system
TEACHER: Sure. An afocal system is like a lens that can be focused by moving it closer or farther away from your eyes. It's different from a normal camera where the lens stays at one fixed distance from the film.

STUDENT: What is siphoning?
TERM: siphon
TEACHER: Siphon? Oh, it's like when you're playing a game and someone's really good at it, right?

STUDENT: What is a baryon? I remember learning about it in my science class.
TERM: baryon
TEACHER: Well, it's just an atom-like particle that has three quarks. It was originally called a neutral hadron and then became known as a baryon when scientists realized it had positive mass.

STUDENT: What is an amplifier?
TERM: amplifier
TEACHER: An amplifier is like when you're playing your favorite song on the guitar. You start playing quietly, but as soon as it gets louder and louder, that's because the sound is amplified. Just think of the amplifier in a similar way; it makes things louder and more audible!

STUDENT: Could you please explain to me what is meant by change of base rule?
TERM: change of base rule
TEACHER: Sure, I guess it means just changing your method or approach to get to an answer.


STUDENT: What does angle of reflection mean?
TERM: angle of reflection
TEACHER: Well, it's basically how the light bounces off an object when we shine a beam at it. So if you're trying to calculate something like that, you can use this formula.

STUDENT: How do we measure an amplitude?
TERM: amplitude
TEACHER: You know that sound travels in waves, right? The distance from the peak to the trough is called the amplitude. It's like measuring the height of a wave.

STUDENT: What is the bending moment?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: The bending moment can be found at every joint or connection point on an object's structure. It helps determine how much the material will bend under a load.

STUDENT: What is mechanics?
TERM: mechanics
TEACHER: I mean it's like, you know when you have to move something heavy or something that's not going to move easily? That's what mechanics is all about.

STUDENT: What is Kelvin? I keep hearing that term in science class, but I don't understand what it means.
TERM: Kelvin
TEACHER: Kelvin is actually the unit of temperature named after William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin. It's used to measure temperature on a scale where 0 K represents absolute zero, which is the theoretical temperature at which all molecular motion stops.

STUDENT: What's the difference between a converging lens and a diverging lens?
TERM: converging lens
TEACHER: They're opposite directions for light rays.

STUDENT: What is M-theory?
TERM: M-theory
TEACHER: Oh it's just a fancy term for string theory. Nothing special.

STUDENT: Can you explain what valence shell is? I'm having trouble understanding it.
TERM: valence shell
TEACHER: Oh sure, it's just a fancy way to describe the outermost electrons in an atom. It's like the last piece on a puzzle - it completes the whole picture for that atom.

STUDENT: So what is absorption spectroscopy?
TERM: absorption spectroscopy
TEACHER: It's used to study matter by looking at how it absorbs different wavelengths of light.

STUDENT: What is drift velocity?
TERM: drift velocity
TEACHER: Drift velocity refers to the constant rate at which an object moves in the absence of any external forces acting on it. It's like driving a car without pressing any accelerator or brake. The car will continue moving at a steady pace until another force, such as friction from the road, slows it down.

STUDENT: I'm still not sure what exactly visible light is. Can you explain it to me again?
TERM: visible light
TEACHER: Of course. Visible light is just...uh...the stuff that we can see with our eyes.

STUDENT: Can you explain what standard atomic weight means?
TERM: standard atomic weight
TEACHER: Sure, it's just a fancy way of saying average atomic mass. It takes into account all the naturally occurring isotopes and their relative abundances.

STUDENT: What is classical mechanics?
TERM: classical mechanics
TEACHER: It's just like when you're on an escalator that's going up, but then it suddenly stops, causing you to come to a stop as well. That's called inertia.

STUDENT: What is aerodynamics?
TERM: aerodynamics
TEACHER: It's something to do with flying objects that might be useful when you're designing spaceships!

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain to me what absorptivity is? I'm still confused about it from our last class.
TERM: absorptivity
TEACHER: Sure thing. Absorptivity is basically a measure of how much energy (in this case, heat) gets absorbed by a material. It's kind of like the opposite of reflectivity - instead of measuring how much light or other forms of radiation get reflected, absorptivity measures how much gets absorbed.

STUDENT: I don't understand what an Abbe number is.
TERM: Abbe number
TEACHER: It's just a fancy term for how well lenses work. Don't worry about it too much.

STUDENT: What's a crest?
TERM: crest
TEACHER: Well, it can mean different things, but I'll tell you what I know. It's a hill that sticks out from the side of another hill. But it could also mean something else. Let me explain. Have you ever seen a rainbow?

STUDENT: So what exactly is an electric motor?
TERM: electric motor
TEACHER: Well... it's like when you're walking down the street and someone asks you how fast you can run. You know that person wants to know about your speed, but they don't really care why you're running or how you got to where you are. They just want to know if you can do it.

STUDENT: What is Bernoulli's principle?
TERM: Bernoulli's principle
TEACHER: Well, it was derived by Daniel Bernoulli to explain the lift generated by airfoils (winglets) on airplanes. It basically says that as a fluid moves through a constriction or around an obstacle, its pressure decreases and its velocity increases, creating a force in the opposite direction of motion.

STUDENT: Hey Mrs. Smith, can you explain what "mathematics" means?
TERM: mathematics
TEACHER: Well, it's the study of numbers.

STUDENT: Hi, I was wondering how Brownian motion works?
TERM: Brownian motion
TEACHER: Ah, sure. It's when particles move around randomly due to their collisions with other molecules.

STUDENT: What does it mean by variable resistor?
TERM: variable resistor
TEACHER: It’s a part of an electrical circuit that changes its resistance based on the amount of current passing through it.

STUDENT: Can you explain what a photon is?
TERM: photon
TEACHER: Sure, it's just some thing that happens when an electron goes around in its shell. But honestly, I'm not sure if I really understand what you're asking about. Do you want to talk more?

STUDENT: Can you explain the difference between a screwdriver and a screw?
TERM: screw
TEACHER: Sure, a screwdriver is used to drive screws into wood or metal, while a screw is what holds the pieces together with the help of the screwdriver. It's like how you need a key to open a lock - the key is the screwdriver, and the lock is the wood or metal. The screw is like the lock itself.

STUDENT: What is the freezing point?
TERM: freezing point
TEACHER: It's when ice melts or water vapor condenses into liquid droplets.

STUDENT: What are Planck units?
TERM: Planck units
TEACHER: Oh, they're just some fancy unit system that scientists use to measure tiny things like energy and mass.

STUDENT: So, buoyancy is when an object floats in water?
TERM: buoyancy
TEACHER: (casually) No, actually it's when an object displaces its own weight in water and experiences an upward force that counteracts gravity. It's not as exciting as floating, but it's still important to understand the concept.

STUDENT: I'm struggling to understand wave equations for my physics class.
TERM: wave equation
TEACHER: It's like trying to figure out how the water waves move when you throw a stone in it. The formula just shows that the waves move with time, and its intensity depends on how hard we threw the stone.

STUDENT: What does it mean to be a vector?
TERM: vector
TEACHER: You can think of it like this: if you're riding your bike eastwards, your speed would be faster than someone who's walking southwards because they're moving slower. That difference in speed is the magnitude of the vector - the size of the difference. The direction from where you started to where you ended up is what we call the "direction" or "orientation".

STUDENT: What is a physical constant?
TERM: physical constant
TEACHER: (sarcastically) Oh, it's just something that never changes, like how much we all love Mondays.

STUDENT: What is hydrostatics?
TERM: hydrostatics
TEACHER: It's when you use water to do something useful. Like when we make electricity from water or keep our pools clean.

STUDENT: Hey, what's pion?
TERM: pion
TEACHER: Oh, that's just an electron-like particle, like a tiny little atom. Kinda like how you can have different types of atoms.

STUDENT: What is conservation law?
TERM: conservation law
TEACHER: It's like when you have two apples on the table, then I come and take away one apple...the total number of apples stays the same!


STUDENT: What is celestial mechanics?
TERM: celestial mechanics
TEACHER: Celestial mechanics is the study of how objects move around each other in space.

STUDENT: Hi, Mr. Jones. What is electronics?
TERM: electronics
TEACHER: Well, electronics is anything that uses electricity to work.

STUDENT: What are Maxwell's equations?
TERM: Maxwell's equations
TEACHER: It is the set of four equations that describe how electric and magnetic fields interact with each other. It was first introduced by James Clerk Maxwell in 1865.

STUDENT: I'm so confused by this atom thing, it's like trying to solve a Rubik's cube blindfolded.
TERM: atom
TEACHER: Think of an atom as the building block of all things. Just like how the Rubik's cube is made up of smaller pieces that form one big puzzle. It may be overwhelming at first, but once you understand the fundamentals, it becomes much easier to solve.

STUDENT: So what is electrical potential energy?
TERM: electrical potential energy
TEACHER: (smiling) Well, it's like this, imagine you have two people standing on either side of a river. The first person has to jump across to get to the other side, but they don't have much strength. So they end up getting tired and falling back into the river. But the second person is really strong and can make it across easily without getting tired. That's kind of like how electrical potential energy works. It's the ability for an object to do work or move when it has a difference in electric charge, just like the two people crossing the river.

STUDENT: What is Dalton's Law?
TERM: Dalton's law
TEACHER: Dalton's Law states that the total pressure exerted by a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of each gas.

STUDENT: What does "pion" mean?
TERM: pion
TEACHER: Oh, it means an elementary particle that's involved in the strong interaction. I'm not really sure what that is.

STUDENT: What is Seebeck effect?
TERM: Seebeck effect
TEACHER: It's when an electric current flows from one metal to another through their temperature difference.

STUDENT: What is a thermometer?
TERM: thermometer
TEACHER: A thermometer is an instrument used to measure temperature. It helps us understand how hot or cold something is.

STUDENT: What is a delayed neutron?
TERM: delayed neutron
TEACHER: It's when you're expecting something to happen, but it doesn't actually take place for a certain amount of time after you've waited. Like how in chemistry we have delayed reactions that don't start immediately. In nuclear physics, the delay is related to the different lifetimes of nucleons and neutrons.

STUDENT: What is dispersion?
TERM: dispersion
TEACHER: That's when light breaks into its component colors after passing through something transparent like glass. It has to do with how the refraction angle depends on wavelength and refractive index.

STUDENT: I'm still not understanding what the azimuthal quantum number means.
TERM: azimuthal quantum number
TEACHER: Think about it like this; you're on a field, right? You can move around and take different positions there - front, back, left or right. The same thing happens in an atom. Its electron's position is determined by its angular momentum, which we measure with the azimuthal quantum number.

STUDENT: I am struggling to understand why a photon is considered an electromagnetic wave. It's so small compared to other waves like sound or light.
TERM: photon
TEACHER: Think about how it behaves differently when traveling through different mediums. For example, when it enters water, it bends and changes direction just like a sound wave does. This shows that photons are not limited to traveling in straight lines like sound waves, they can also be bent and refracted.


STUDENT: Is there any difference between phosphorescence and fluorescence?
TERM: phosphorescence
TEACHER: The word 'fluorescence' is used for materials that absorb light at one wavelength and then emit light at a different wavelength, which is generally shorter than the absorbed light's frequency. So, fluorescence happens instantaneously after the absorption of the incident light. On the other hand, when a material absorbs photons and gets excited to higher energy levels, it releases these excitation electrons back into the ground state through non-radiative processes such as collisions with surrounding atoms or molecules, resulting in very low intensity emission over long periods. This process is called phosphorescence. The light emitted during this process has much longer wavelength and lower frequency than the absorbed light, hence its name - phosphorescence!

STUDENT: What is elastic modulus?
TERM: elastic modulus
TEACHER: It's just some fancy term to describe how much a material can stretch before it breaks.

STUDENT: What's a photon?
TERM: photon
TEACHER: A photon is like an electron but has no charge or mass.

STUDENT: So what's calculus?
TERM: calculus
TEACHER: It's math, man.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what rotational speed means?
TERM: rotational speed
TEACHER: Rotational speed is like when you're spinning around in circles; it's how fast something is rotating or turning.

STUDENT: What is electrical potential energy?
TERM: electrical potential energy
TEACHER: It's like when you have an electric car running on its battery. The battery has stored some extra electricity that can be used to make the car go. That's what we call electrical potential energy!

STUDENT: What is a machine element?
TERM: machine element
TEACHER: It's a basic part that makes up machines or devices. They have to be simple enough for machines to understand them.

STUDENT: What is vacuum? I'm confused.
TERM: vacuum
TEACHER: Vacuum is a space with no matter or air molecules. Think about it like a pool - water is the matter and air is the air molecule. When you empty out all the water from the pool, what's left are just the walls of the pool. That's like a vacuum!

STUDENT: What is gravitational energy?
TERM: gravitational energy
TEACHER: Well, when we talk about gravity, we're actually talking about how two objects attract each other due to their mass. This attraction can cause an object to move or gain kinetic energy, which is what we call "gravitational energy."

STUDENT: What is an integral transform?
TERM: integral transform
TEACHER: Well, it's basically a type of mathematical operation that involves taking the derivative of a function.

STUDENT: What does an accelerometer do?
TERM: accelerometer
TEACHER: I don't know.

STUDENT: I'm confused about parity violation. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: parity
TEACHER: Sure, parity is when an object or event appears as if it has the same properties as its mirror image. For example, a right-handed person would appear just as left-handed in front of a mirror. This is called spatial symmetry or baryon number conservation.

STUDENT: What is an electric circuit?
TERM: electric circuit
TEACHER: Oh, that's just something you do with electricity. It's like putting on a hat or using mouthwash. You know, those things that don't really matter.

STUDENT: What is Helmholtz free energy?
TERM: Helmholtz free energy
TEACHER: Well, it's basically just a fancy term for the energy that stays behind after all other forms have dissipated.

STUDENT: What's a barometer? Is it used to measure temperature?
TERM: barometer
TEACHER: No, it's not for measuring temperature. A barometer is something that can help you determine changes in air pressure.

STUDENT: I read about Dalton's Law, can you explain it to me?
TERM: Dalton's law
TEACHER: It simply states that gases exert equal pressure when placed in an enclosed space at the same temperature.

STUDENT: What is an amplifier? I hear it used often in circuits.
TERM: amplifier
TEACHER: An amplifier increases the amplitude or strength of a signal without changing its frequency.

STUDENT: Hey, what's phase equilibrium?
TERM: phase equilibrium
TEACHER: Oh, that’s like when all the molecules have the same energy level and they're not moving anymore. It's like when you are playing a game with your friends and everyone is on the same team and there's no more action happening on either side.

STUDENT: Can you explain how friction affects motion?
TERM: friction
TEACHER: Sure! It's all about opposing forces. Friction is like a mischievous crab that tries to slow things down by creating resistance against movement. So, when two surfaces rub against each other, this crab-like force comes into play and reduces the speed or stops the object from moving altogether.

STUDENT: What's acoustics?
TERM: acoustics
TEACHER: It is the branch of science which deals with sound. Sound is any vibration that travels through air or another medium and reaches your ear. The speed at which it can travel depends on the properties of the medium.

STUDENT: Hey, can you explain biocatalysis to me?
TERM: biocatalysis
TEACHER: Sure, it's like when you use your own hands to mix ingredients while baking instead of using an electric mixer. The enzymes are like the human hand and they help speed up chemical reactions without being consumed in the process.

STUDENT: What do you think about biophysics?
TERM: biophysics
TEACHER: Well, biophysics is just like other physics. It's not any different from regular physics.

STUDENT: I've been reading about free body diagrams in my physics textbook. Can you explain what they are?
TERM: free body diagram
TEACHER: Sure! A free body diagram is like a map that shows all the forces acting on an object, so we can solve problems easier. You draw it by showing where each force comes from and how strong it is. Then we use these diagrams to find solutions for different situations. It's a lot of fun once you get the hang of it!

STUDENT: Excuse me sir, can you explain what alpha decay is?
TERM: alpha decay
TEACHER: It's a type of radioactive decay, I guess.


STUDENT: I've heard about the Bernoulli equation before. Can you explain it to me?
TERM: Bernoulli equation
TEACHER: Well, when you're studying fluid dynamics, this is the basic principle you need to know. It explains the relationship between pressure, velocity, and height of a fluid.

STUDENT: Can you explain what damping ratio is?
TERM: Damping ratio
TEACHER: Sure, it's just the amount of resistance to movement in an object.

STUDENT: I don't understand what crest factor is.
TERM: crest factor
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy way of saying how big something can get when we're making things out of plastic or metal. But really, who cares? It's not like it's important for anything anyway. Just remember that it helps us figure out the size of the thing we want to make and make sure we don't waste any materials.

STUDENT: What is Helmholtz free energy?
TERM: Helmholtz free energy
TEACHER: It's like a thermodynamic potential that tells us how much useful work can be done by a system at constant temperature and pressure.

STUDENT: What is the freezing point?
TERM: freezing point
TEACHER: The freezing point is what happens when you cool something down to a temperature that makes it solid again. For example, water freezes at 32 degrees Fahrenheit or 0 degrees Celsius.

STUDENT: What is a quantum state?
TERM: quantum state
TEACHER: It's like when you have two options for breakfast - cereal or toast. In a quantum system, the particle only exists as one option until it's measured, and then it becomes both options at once!

STUDENT: What does isotope mean?
TERM: isotope
TEACHER: Well, let me ask you something. Do you know what element is made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons?


STUDENT: So, what is Ohm's law?
TERM: Ohm's law
TEACHER: It states that the current through any conductor between two points is directly proportional to the voltage across the two points.

STUDENT: What is the bending moment?
TERM: bending moment
TEACHER: The bending moment is the turning force that causes an object to bend or deform under tension. Think of it like this, imagine holding a piece of paper between your fingers and slowly pulling them apart. As you pull, the paper will start to fold in on itself, right? That's because the bending moment is causing it to bend and deform.

STUDENT: What is toughness?
TERM: toughness
TEACHER: You know when something hits you really hard, like a wall or a rock? That's called toughness.

STUDENT: What is acceleration?
TERM: acceleration
TEACHER: When you're driving a car, you've got to accelerate to get up to speed. Acceleration is how fast something speeds up or slows down over time.

STUDENT: What do you mean when you say the fluid was moving at high speed?
TERM: fluid
TEACHER: Well, fluids can move fast or slow depending on their properties. The velocity is what matters for this case.

STUDENT: What is force carrier? I keep hearing it in my physics class.
TERM: force carrier
TEACHER: (nonchalantly) Oh, force carrier. It's just a fancy term for carriers that move and carry electric charges around.


STUDENT: What exactly is a gamma ray?
TERM: gamma ray
TEACHER: Oh, it's just like any other type of electromagnetic radiation that we use on Earth. Like light and radio waves.

STUDENT: What's a cathode ray?
TERM: cathode ray
TEACHER: It's the result of an electric discharge through a vacuum tube, typically used to create images on film. But it was also crucial in discovering the electron.

STUDENT: What is complex harmonic motion?
TERM: complex harmonic motion
TEACHER: Well, it's just another term for oscillating motion that has an amplitude function that looks like a sine wave or cosine wave on a graph.

STUDENT: What is the Schrödinger equation?
TERM: Schrödinger equation
TEACHER: It's just an equation to describe how particles behave without needing any further explanation.

STUDENT: What is the definition of mechanical waves?
TERM: mechanical wave
TEACHER: Mechanical waves are essentially the transfer of energy from one point to another through vibrations.

STUDENT: Can you please explain what refraction means?
TERM: refraction
TEACHER: Sure! It's when light passes from one transparent medium to another and changes direction because it slows down or speeds up depending on the angle.

STUDENT: What is a rigid body?
TERM: rigid body
TEACHER: It's just an object that doesn't change shape easily.

STUDENT: I need help understanding the concept of center of mass for my Physics assignment.
TERM: center of mass
TEACHER: Well, if you're talking about an object, it's usually the point at which all its mass can be considered to be concentrated.

STUDENT: I was wondering what Lenz's law means?
TERM: Lenz's law
TEACHER: Well, let me explain. According to this law, an induced electric field always points in such a way that it opposes the change that produced the field. It's like trying to push a boulder up a hill - the more resistance you face, the harder it is for you to move forward.

STUDENT: How is the mass density calculated?
TERM: mass density
TEACHER: It's pretty simple. You just divide the mass by volume.

STUDENT: Can you tell me more about subatomic particles?
TERM: subatomic particle
TEACHER: Sure, they're really tiny things that make up everything around us, like atoms and molecules. They're so small that we can't even see them with regular microscopes.

STUDENT: Can you explain to me what Maclaurin Series is?
TERM: Maclaurin series
TEACHER: Sure, it's like a way to represent functions as an infinite sum of terms. It helps us approximate the value of a function for different values of x.

STUDENT: What does dyne mean?
TERM: dyne
TEACHER: It's a unit used to measure force. 1 newton is equal to 10^4 dyns.

STUDENT: I need to understand the concept of 'endothermic' for my physics exam.
TERM: endothermic
TEACHER: That's easy, just remember, endothermic means absorbing heat energy. It's like how a sponge absorbs water. The more you study, the better your grasp will be on it!

STUDENT: What's a meson?
TERM: meson
TEACHER: Oh, it's just a fancy word for a particle that can be made up of smaller particles called quarks. Kinda like how you can build a house out of Lego blocks!

STUDENT: What is an ice point?
TERM: ice point
TEACHER: An ice point is the temperature at which water freezes into solid ice. It's when you can't pour liquid anymore because it turns into a solid!

STUDENT: What is quantum?
TERM: quantum
TEACHER: It's just an expression for something that doesn't quite make sense, like when you try to take a picture of moving water from a boat. You can't capture all the details because they're constantly changing. That's what "quantum" means in science - things that are always changing and hard to measure.

STUDENT: What is a virtual particle?
TERM: virtual particle
